The units of speed are either surface feet or meters per minute. It is particularly useful to use a Surface Speed value in boring operations where a single tip does the work.
Feed per Tooth
Specifies the amount of material that each tooth removes. The tooth movement is based on the spindle rotation rate and the feed rate of the tool. The units of measurement can be inches or millimeters.
Tip:
Enter the Surface Speed or Spindle Speed value before you change the Feed per Tooth value.
More
Reset from Table
Supports the legacy method for recommending appropriate Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values using part material, tool material, cut method, and cut depth parameters that it extracts from predefined tables. Depending on the operation type, the Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values are used to calculate the spindle speed and some cutting feed rates.
Note:
The predefined tables contain parameters only after you specify them.
The currently preferred method is to use machining data libraries and the Set Machining Data option.

Automatic Settings
Reset from Table
Recommends appropriate Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values using part material, tool material, cut method, and cut depth parameters that it extracts from predefined tables. Depending on the operation type, the Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values are used to calculate the spindle speed and some cutting feed rates.
Note:
The predefined tables contain parameters only after you specify them.

Document Title: Spindle Speed group for milling and drilling
Document Body:
Spindle Speed
Spindle Speed (RPM)
Sets a mom variable for the spindle status. Some users require this variable to generate custom output.
The variable that is set is not used by the example post processors, and it does not affect tool path output.
Spindle Speed (RPM)
Specifies the rotation speed of the tool.
If you change the value, Calculate Speeds and Feeds based on this value in the same row becomes active. The software uses the Spindle Speed value to calculate the Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values.
Retract Speed (%)
Available for drilling operations. Lets you increase or decrease the spindle speed on the retract move.
More
Output Mode
RPM = revolutions per minute.
SFM = surface feet per minute.
SMM = surface meters per minute.
Direction
CLW = output the code for clockwise rotation.
CCLW = output to code for couinterclockwise rotation.
None = do not output a rotation direction code, if the post supports no direction code output.
Outputs the NC code for clockwise or counterclockwise rotation, or suppresses the output of a direction code if the post allows this.
Range Status
Controls whether the Range Status box is available. This governs the output of the RANGE,n command to set a spindle speed range. You can enter any value or keyword that you have defined in your post.
The classic NX Post output is either a numeric value, LOW, MEDIUM or HIGH, where the text is interpreted as follows:
LOW = 1
MEDIUM = 2
HIGH = 2 if there are only 2 ranges
HIGH = 3 if there are more than 2 ranges
Text Status
Specifies text to add to the LOAD or TURRET command during CLS output.
During postprocessing the software stores this text in a MOM variable.

Spindle Speed
Output Mode
Specifies the postprocessed output mode.
RPM = revolutions per minute.
SFM = surface feet per minute.
SMM = surface meters per minute.
Spindle Speed
Available when RPM is selected in the Output Mode list.
When selected, the Spindle Speed box is available to specify the spindle rotation in RPM.
The following options are available when SFM or SMM is selected in the Output Mode list.
Surface Speed (sfm)
Specifies the surface feed per minute in the specified units, meters or feet.
Maximum RPM
When selected, the Maximum RPM box is available to specify the output of the maximum RPM of which the machine is capable.
When you are performing a facing operation with constant surface speed, the calculated spindle speed increases as the tool moves closer to the centerline. The Maximum RPM value limits the speed that is output to the specified maximum value. The value is also used for calculations of feed rates with constant surface speed in the local return by time calculations.
Preset RPM
When selected, the Preset RPM box is available to specify the exact spindle speed to be output. This is used as an alternate means to manage local return by time calculations when the cutting tool is close to the centerline.
Direction
In NX2206 and later versions, the direction of rotation is determined by the view from the part to the tool.
In Post Configurator postprocessors, the Spindle configuration object Lathe Spindle Direction Definition default setting of Normal corresponds to the CLW direction or the CCLW direction set in the operation dialog box. The Reverse option reverses the rotation specified in the operation. The Lathe Spindle Direction Definition is output in the new MOM variable mom_sys_turning_spindle_direction_mode and complements the existing MOM variable mom_spindle_direction.
Note:
If you use a Post Configurator postprocessor created prior to NX 2206, you do not need to change to your spindle direction setting in the postprocessor. Leave the Lathe Spindle Direction Definition option as Reverse. This includes a postprocessor that is updated with a library from NX 2206 or later.
Automatic
Sets the correct spindle rotation direction based on the side of the centerline where the tool insert is located. The calculated direction appears beside Automatic, as shown:
Automatic (CLW)
Automatic
Sets the spindle rotation direction manually.
None
No direction specified.
CLW
Clockwise spindle rotation.
CCLW
Counter clockwise spindle rotation.
More
Range Status
Controls whether the Range Status box is available. This governs the output of the RANGE,n command to set a spindle speed range. You can enter any value or keyword that you have defined in your post.
The classic NX Post output is either a numeric value, LOW, MEDIUM or HIGH, where the text is interpreted as follows:
LOW = 1
MEDIUM = 2
HIGH = 2 if there are only 2 ranges
HIGH = 3 if there are more than 2 ranges
Text Status
Specifies text to add to the LOAD or TURRET command during CLS output.
During postprocessing the software stores this text in a MOM variable.

Feed Rates
Cut
Sets the feed rate for tool movement while the cutter is in contact with part geometry.
Rapid
When you view the tool path listing or CLSF output, note that RAPID commands apply only to the next GOTO point in the tool path and CLSF. Subsequent moves use the last specified feed rate.
Output
G0 — Rapid Mode
Sets rapid motions to use the machine’s non-interpolated motion.
Writes the RAPID command into the tool path and CLSF.
G1 — Feed Mode
Sets rapid motions to use the machine’s interpolated motion at the specified rapid feed rate. Use this for machines that would otherwise make dog-leg rapid moves. You specify the rapid feed rate value and units using the Rapid Feed option.
More
For all motion types in this group, you can specify no units, units per revolution, units per minute, and percent of the specified cut feed.
For all motions except First Cut and Step Over, you can also specify a rapid feed.
Approach
Sets the feed rate for tool movement from the start point to the engage position.
Approach motion at rapid feed
Approach motion between cut levels
Approach motion at a feed rate
Engage
Sets the feed rate for tool movement from the engage position to the initial cutting position. This feed rate also applies to the return move when the tool returns to the workpiece after lifts.
First Cut
Sets the feed rate when a first-cut motion is generated. This motion occurs when the cutter diameter is embedded in the material to be cut. Examples include:
The first cut in a volume of material that is not approached in several smaller cutting stages, such as the first cut in a pocket, or the first cut within a boundary.
The first cut when the cutter moves through a narrow passage or slot, or into an acute-angled concave corner.
Passes where the cutter is not embedded use the cut feed rate.
Operations that contain only profiling passes, and the Standard Drive cut pattern, do not generate First Cut motions.
The Follow Part and the Follow Periphery Outward cut patterns apply different rules to First Cut feed rates.
When you first specify a First Cut feed rate value that is different from the Cut feed rate, NX recalculates the tool path and marks the appropriate sections as First Cut motions. Subsequent changes to the First Cut feed rate do not require recalculation of the tool path.
You can specify a different tool path color to verify which moves are calculated to be first cut moves.
Stepover
Sets the feed rate for the cutter as it moves from one pass to the next.
Traversal
Sets the feed rate for fast horizontal non-cutting tool motion when the Transfer Method option on the Engage/Retract menu is set to Previous Level.
This feed rate is used only when the tool is at a vertical clearance distance above the uncut surface and the horizontal clearance distance away from any islands or walls. This position and feed rate combination protects the part during tool transits where the tool can be moved without having to be lifted to the clearance plane.
Retract
Sets the feed rate for tool movement to the retract position from the final tool path cutting position.
Departure
Sets the feed rate for tool movement for the retract move, traversal moves, or the return move. The first return move above the retract point can also be a departure move.
Units
These options change the units setting for all cutting and noncutting motion types.
Set Non-Cut Units and Set Cut Units
none
No units are output.
ipr or mmpr
Units per revolution are output.
ipm or mmpm
Units per minute are output.
Rapid
The RAPID command is output.
%Cut
A percentage of the cut feed is calculated and output.
  Optimize Feed Rate when Generating
Optimizes the feed rates immediately after you generate the tool path. This option automates the result you achieve when you use the Operation Navigator to optimize feed rates.
This option also updates feed rates when the amount of material being removed changes. NX uses a 3D IPW model or blank geometry to calculate new feed rates.
Use this option to obtain more accurate feed rates and save on the time taken to remove material.

The Operation Navigator has four hierarchical views that you use to create and manage an NC program. Each view organizes the same set of operations based on the theme of the view: the order of operations within the program, the tools used, the geometry machined, or the machining methods used.
Use the Operation Navigator to:
Cut or copy and paste operations, programs, methods, or geometry within the setup for a part or between setups for different parts.
Note:
If you select a geometry or program group to copy, the operations are also copied.
If you select a method or tool group to copy, operations are not copied.
Drag and drop groups and operations within the setup for a part.
Specify common parameters in one group location, such as the Workpiece geometry group. The parameters are passed down (inherited) by operations within the group.
Turn Inheritance on for specific parameters.
Display the tool path and geometry of an operation in the graphics window to quickly see what is defined and which areas are machined.
Display the In Process Workpiece (IPW) of a milling or turning operation.
Within the Operation Navigator:
A tree structure controls the relationships between groups and operations. The position of a group or operation determines how parameters are passed down (inherited).
Individual columns display different types of information. You can change the display of columns using the configurations available in the sub menu of Column Configuration.
You have the ability to view multiple parts at the same time, each in its own graphics window, within the same NX session.
If you expand or collapse the tree structure in the navigator, that structure continues to display the same way if you change to another part, and then return to the first part. The vertical position of the cursor in the tree structure is also saved.
For more information on using multiple windows in NX, see Using multiple windows.
Note:
Operation Navigator display options can be turned on or off in Manufacturing Preferences.
Operation Navigator view examples
For more information on the Resource bar, see Resource bar overview.
For information on how to copy and paste an object, see Copying, pasting, and deleting objects in the Fundamentals help.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Resource bar
Operation Navigator

Configure View Columns
Candidate Columns
Lists the columns that you can add to the selected column configuration. To add a candidate column to the Column Configuration list, double-click the title or right-click and choose Add .
Column Configuration
Lists the columns used in the selected column configuration. Select the check box next to the column name to display the column, or clear the check box to hide the column. You can also right-click the column name and choose Hide or Show.
Saved Configurations
Lists the available column configurations. The standard configurations that are delivered with NX are labeled System. The configurations that you define are labeled User, Site, or Group depending on the location of that configuration.
New
Opens the New Column Configuration dialog box, where you specify the name and level of the new configuration.
Save
Available for User, Site, and Group configurations.
Saves the selected configuration if it is not loaded.
Delete
Available for User and Site configurations only.
Deletes the selected configuration if it is not loaded.
Column header commands
Filter
Opens the Filter dialog box, where you can select a filtering criterion and specify a string to filter by. NX shows the filtered objects in the navigator.
For example, you can select the Begins With rule and enter B to display only columns that begin with the letter B.
Find
Opens the Find dialog box where you can select a filtering criterion and specify the string that you want to search for. NX searches the values in the columns that match the specified string and highlights those objects in the navigator.
For example, you can set the Contains rule to roughness to display only columns that include the string roughness.
Note:
You can combine the Filter and Find commands to search for specific columns that contain the specified strings to limit the objects that you want to show in the navigator.
Example:
In the Candidate Columns list, set the Begins With rule to B in the Filter dialog box, then set the Contains rule to roughness in the Find dialog box.
The Candidate Columns list displays all columns that begin with B. The Find dialog box displays the number of column titles that begin with B and contain roughness.

Document Title: Freeze a column in the Operation Navigator
Document Body:
This example shows how to Freeze or Unfreeze a column from scrolling horizontally in the Operation Navigator.
Video
Procedure
Right-click the column heading and choose Freeze or Unfreeze.
The Freeze and Unfreeze column display options effect all columns before, and including, the selected column. When frozen, the columns do not move when you move the horizontal scroll bar.

In the Operation Navigator, in the appropriate view, select an operation (or group).
Home tab→Actions group→Copy Object , or Cut Object . You can also right-click the operation and choose Copy or Cut.
Right-click the target location and choose Paste or Paste Inside.
Paste places the operation below the selected group or operation, and the copied operation does not inherit parameters from the selected location.
Paste Inside places the operation inside the selected Tool, Method, Geometry, or Program location, and the copied operation inherits parameters from the selected location (group).

Document Title: Move an operation to the top of a group
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, in the appropriate view, select the operation to move to the top of the group.
Right-click the operation and choose Cut.
Right-click the first operation in the group and choose Paste.
This places the operation you pasted below the selected operation.
Right-click the first operation and choose Cut.
Right-click the operation that is now first and choose Paste.
The Operation Navigator is ordered properly.
You can also drag the operations to their new locations.

Document Title: Copy an operation from one setup to another
Document Body:
Loading requirement for Part Families
When the work part in a CAM setup assembly contains a part family relationship, NX attempts to map the geometry when you copy and paste an operation. If the assembly is not fully loaded, NX then fully loads the necessary components. If any of these components were modified, the status of the operations associated to the geometry of these components will be Regenerate .
To ensure that the setup assembly is fully loaded before you copy and paste operations, do the following:
Choose File tab→Options→Assembly Load Options.
The Assembly Load Options dialog box is displayed.
In the Scope group, set the parameters as shown.
Load = All Components
Option = Fully Load
Click OK to save the settings.
Copy the operation
In the source file, in the Operation Navigator, select one or more operations to copy.
Choose Actions tab→Copy Object , or Cut Object . You can also right-click the operation and choose Copy or Cut.
Choose File tab→Open, and select the target setup or setup assembly file.
If necessary, switch to the Geometry view.
Select a valid Geometry location.
Example:
If the operation was in Workpiece in the source file, select Workpiece in the target file.
Right-click and choose Paste Inside.
The Tool, Program, and Method groups are determined as follows:
If there is a valid matching group in the target, the operation is placed there. The target group must have the same name as the source group.
If a matching group does not exist, the software uses the group in the source file as a template to create a new group.
If a parent group cannot be found or created, then the operation is placed in the Unused Items group.

Document Title: Lock or unlock a tool path
Document Body:
Lock a tool path if you do not want to overwrite the tool path accidentally when upgrading from a prior version, after editing the tool path, or after using a function like flowcut manual cut order.
In the Operation Navigator, select the operation.
Right-click and choose Tool Path→Lock.
This either adds a Lock status for the tool path or removes an existing Lock status.

Document Title: Orient the view in an operation
Document Body:
You can orient the view of an operation to the Tool Axis or to the Machine Coordinate System (MCS).
Select an operation and right-click in the graphics window. You can choose one of the following:
Set View to Tool Axis
Set View to MCS
Set View to Tool Axis inactive.
Set View to Tool Axis active.
You can use these commands to orient the view in the following operation types:
Fixed axis milling operations:
Variable axis milling operations:
Planar milling
Cavity milling
Floor wall milling
Plunge milling
Fixed axis Zlevel
Fixed axis surface contour
Variable axis Zlevel
Variable axis surface contour
Note:
When you use the set view commands while creating variable axis operations, you must first set the Display→Select Tool Path option. The view is oriented to the tool axis associated with the selected tool path position.

Document Title: Approve a tool path to override a Regenerate or Repost status
Document Body:
Some changes, such as geometry or tool parameters, will set operations to the Regenerate status. Other changes, such as feed rates or post commands, do not require regenerating the tool path, but set the operation status to Repost. If you know that the tool path is still up-to-date, you can override the Regenerate or Repost status by changing it to Approved. This will help you avoid regenerating or reposting operations unnecessarily.
In the Operation Navigator, select the operation.
Right-click and choose Object→Approve.

Document Title: Remove the approval on a tool path
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, select the operation.
Right-click and choose Object→Unapprove.

Document Title: Operation Navigator columns and status indicators
Document Body:
The Operation Navigator displays icons along with, or instead of, text in some of the columns. For example, the Name column uses icons as well as text to communicate the name and status of the operation. When you point to an icon, a tool tip is displayed with a description of the icon and related information. For example, the Toolchange column tool tip includes the name of the new tool.
Font color
NX displays operations with the following conditions in the noted default font colors:
Tool change (Medium Purple)
The active operation for functions such as Simulate Machine (Strong Red)
Suppressed tool path (Silver Gray)
Located in the Unused Items folder (Medium Sea)
Parent dependencies for a selected operation (Deep Magenta)
Child dependencies for a selected operation (Medium Teal)
To modify the Operation Navigator appearance, including font colors, choose File→Utilities→Customer Defaults→Manufacturing→User Interface→Operation Navigator.
Status changes
In most cases, changing an operation changes its status to Regenerate and you must regenerate to make sure the tool path is up-to-date. Examples of changes that require regenerating are tool, geometry, or cutting parameter changes.
Other changes only require reposting or generating the CLSF to update the output files. Examples of changes that do not require regenerating the tool path are: feed rates, post commands, or the MCS parent group.
Operation Navigator, Program Order view example

Title
Displays the name and status of the object.
Complete
The tool path has been generated and the postprocessed machine code is up-to-date.
Note:
Postprocessing occurs when you output or simulate machine code. NX saves the generated NC code in the CAM setup, so that you can avoid an additional postprocessing run each time you postprocess or simulate a tool path.
Regenerate
The tool path for the operation has never been generated, or the generated tool path is out-of-date due to a change in the operation or CAM setup.
Repost
The tool path has never been postprocessed, or the tool path has changed and the saved machine code is out-of-date.
Approved
The user has overridden the system status to indicate the operation is complete, regardless of the software indicators.
If the status of all operations in a program is either Complete or Approved, then the status of the program is Approved.
Pending
This indicates that the operation is in queue for a scheduled Parallel Generate process. The indicator appears when the maximum number of concurrent processes is exceeded.
Parallel Generating
This indicates that the operation is processing in the background.
Toolchange
Program Order view only
Displays an icon showing the type of tool used by the operation when there is a tool change. The tool tip displays the name of the tool.
Drilling tool
Milling tool
Turning tool
Path
Displays the status of the tool path.
Note:
A warning message is displayed if you attempt to generate an operation with a status of Imported, Edited, or Locked.
Generated
The tool path has been generated. It may or may not contain tool motions.
None
The tool path has either not yet been generated, or has been deleted.
Imported
The tool path was imported using the Tools→CLSF→Import command.
The tool path can be replayed, postprocessed or edited with the graphical tool path editor.
Edited
The tool path has been changed with the graphical tool path editor.
Suspect
Questionable geometry was encountered when this path was generated. The path may or may not be valid, and must be inspected carefully:
For a visual inspection: Right-click the operation and choose Object→Display.
For diagnostics with a description of the condition that was encountered: Right-click the operation and choose Information.
Transformed or Mirrored
The path is from a transformed or mirrored operation.
Suppressed
The path is not output, and does not affect the IPW. The operation is displayed in the assigned Suppressed Path color.
Empty Tool Path
The tool path has been generated, but does not contain valid motion.
Some examples are a Flowcut operation that finds no valleys, or a Cavity Mill operation without an IPW to cut. Operations like Machine Control that are not designed to contain motion, do not display this status.
Locked
The tool path is protected from overriding.
Lock a tool path if you do not want to override the tool path accidentally:
When upgrading from a prior version.
After editing the tool path.
After using a function like flowcut manual cut order.
Pasted with Reference
Channel
Multi-channel machines only.
Displays the channel number and synchronization status. Lets you remove synchronization data without opening the Synchronization Manager.
Tool
Displays the tool name.
Tool Description
Displays the tool description.
Holder
Displays the description entered in the Holder tab of the tool dialog box.
Tool Number
Displays the tool number.
Tools may have a tool parent, such as a pocket, that is identified in the Name column.
When you sort tools by their tool number, NX sorts the tools within each tool parent separately. You will only see the tools reordered if a tool parent contains multiple tools with different tool numbers.
Time
Available for Milling, Turning, and Drilling operations.
Displays the total estimated time for the tool path in hours:minutes:seconds.
The software calculates this estimate based on the following:
Feed
Distance
Estimated rapid feed
Estimated tool change time
The software does not consider feed adjustment on arcs, feed slowdown in corners, or machine kinematics.
The Time value updates immediately when feed rates are changed. The Time value displayed is:
Zero (blank) if no tool path is present.
The previously calculated value if the status of the operation is Regenerate. This value is out-of-date.
The sum of all the operations for a group.
The tool tip displays the Cutting and Non Cutting values as well as the total value. The Non Cutting value includes estimates for tool changes and rapid feeds.
By default, Time is only displayed in the Program Order view.
Note:
To specify the time estimates, see Specify time estimates for tool changes and rapid feeds.
The Time column is blank for operations that were last generated in a release when this column was not available. You must generate the operations for the time to be displayed.
Length
Available for Milling, Turning, and Drilling operations.
Displays the estimated length of the tool path. The software adds the lengths of all cutting moves and non cutting moves, but excludes machine kinematics or mechanical functions, such as tool changes. The Length value displayed is:
Zero (blank) if no tool path is present.
The previously calculated value if the status of the operation is Regenerate. This value is out-of-date.
The sum of all the operations for a group.
The tool tip displays the Cutting and Non Cutting values as well as the total value. The Non Cutting value includes rapid moves.
By default, the Length column is not displayed.
Geometry
Displays the Geometry parent group for the operation.
MCS
Displays the Machine Coordinate System (MCS) parent group for the operation.
Method
Displays the Method parent group for the operation.
Stock
Displays the Part Stock or Part Side Stock setting for the operation.
Floor Stock
Displays the Part Floor Stock or Final Floor Stock setting for the operation.
For fixed or variable contouring operations, displays the Part Stock setting for the operation.
Wall Stock
Displays the Wall Stock setting for the operation.
Note:
Wall Stock is not displayed by default. You must add it through column configuration.
Depth of Cut
Displays the Common Depth per Cut setting for the operation.
Stepover
Displays the Stepover setting for the operation.
Shortest Tool Length
Available for Cavity Mill, Adaptive Milling, Plunge Milling, and Rest Milling operations. Displays the length of the shortest tool that can machine the operation without tool holder collisions.
[Operation] dialog box→Report Shortest Tool.
Operation Navigator→right-click the operation→Tool Path→Report Shortest Tool
Feed
Displays the Cut feed rate setting for the operation.
Speed
Displays the Spindle Speed setting for the operation.
Surface Speed
Displays the Surface Speed setting for the operation.
Optimize Feed
Indicates whether the feed rate has been optimized for more efficient material removal.
Feed Rate Optimized
The operation was generated with the Optimize Feed Rate When Generating option selected in the Feeds and Speeds dialog box, or the tool path was optimized after generation.
Program Group
Displays the program parent group for the operation.
Edit Status
Displays the status of the object.
Complete
The tool path has been generated and the postprocessed machine code is up-to-date.
Regenerate
The tool path for the operation has never been generated, or the generated tool path is out-of-date.
Repost
The tool path has never been output, or the tool path has changed and the postprocessed machine code is out-of-date.
IPW
Displays the status of the In Process Workpiece.
Generated
The IPW has been generated and is up-to-date.
None
There is no IPW for this operation.
Out-of-Date
The IPW for this operation is out-of-date. The IPW is updated if it is used by a subsequent operation, or if it is generated from the Tool Path Visualization dialog box.
This icon also appears for all the operations below the operation that is out-of-date.
Unable to update
The IPW flow has geometry that is not loaded. When the geometry is not loaded, NX can't update the IPW because it has no access to the geometry.
Description
Tool
User-defined tool
Displays the tool description entered in the tool dialog.
Otherwise, displays the standard tool description, such as Milling Tool 5 Parameter.
Library tool
Displays the template subtype with a template subtype that can be queried.
Otherwise, displays the standard tool description, such as Milling Tool 5 Parameter.
Machine tool root node
For machines with the Manufacturer and Description strings defined, displays a combination of these two strings.
Otherwise, displays Generic Machine.
Turret
Displays Tool Carrier: <ID>.
<ID> = Carrier Name
Pocket
Displays Pocket: <ID>.
<ID> = Pocket ID
Head
Displays Head
Operations and parent groups, such as Geometry or Method
Displays the template subtype.
Notes
Lets you add informative text to any operation.
Indicates that there are notes stored with the operation. To display the note, pause your cursor on the icon.
Gouge Check
Displays the status for gouge checks.
Not checked
The operation has not been gouge checked yet, or the operation has been edited since the last check.
No Gouges
The operation has been checked and no gouging motions were found.
Gouges
The operation has been checked and gouging motions were found. A tool tip displays the number of gouges.
Warning
The operation has been checked but the result may not be reliable. For example, nonuniform stock may affect the results.
Error
An error caused by missing part geometry or check geometry occurred while checking the operation.
Start Events, End Events
Displays an icon to let you find the operations with user defined events without editing each operation.
The operation has a user defined machine control event, such as Coolant On. A tool tip displays the user defined events included in the operation.
Dependencies
Identifies a parent operation used by a Paste Inside with Reference or Mirror command.
Identifies a child operation resulting from a Paste Inside with Reference or Mirror command.
Identifies a child operation resulting from a Mirror command that has modified parameters. When you hover over the icon, NX lists the modified parameters that are no longer associative. All of the other parameters remain associative.
NX appends the name of the mirrored or pasted operation with an enumerated suffix.
Work Instructions
Indicates an operation with work instruction sheets.
Material Removal Color
Displays the color of the material that remains after the operation has been played.
Total Time
Displays the total of the cutting and secondary times for your programs.
Note:
The machining times are generated by the Calculate Machining Times command. In order to use the command, you must have a machine tool and blank geometry defined in the CAM setup because the times are calculated using the NX MTS function. If the times have not been calculated, or have become invalid, the times are not displayed in the columns.
Cutting Time
Displays the total of the material and air cutting times for your programs. The material time is when the cutter is engaged in the IPW. The air time is when the tool is not removing material. (See the note for Total Time.)
You can display the material and air cutting times using:
Material Cutting Time
Air Cutting Time
Note:
You can set the default Detect Air Cutting Time in the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box→Operation tab to calculate the material and air portions of the Cutting Time.
Secondary Time
Displays the total of the positioning, dragging, delay, wait, and tool change times for your programs. (See the note for Total Time.)
Positioning Time
Displays the time of all positioning motions, such as rapid moves. (See the note for Total Time.)
You can display the portion of time for linear, rotary, or mixed positioning motion types using:
Positioning Linear Time
Positioning Rotary Time
Positioning Mixed Time
Note:
The mixed motion is when both the linear and rotary axis are moving simultaneously.
Dragging Time
Displays the phase of a rapid move when the interpolator of a joint has reached the target value, but the real joint value has not yet reached the target, although it is closing the gap. (See the note for Total Time.)
Delay Time
Displays all times introduced through a delay() statement in AnyController code. (See the note for Total Time.)
Wait Time
Displays time spent while stopping on WAIT commands for channel synchronization, and all times that do not fit in other categories. (See the note for Total Time.)
Tool Change Time
Optional. Displays the time it takes to change the tool. (See the note for Total Time.)
Note:
The AnyController commands StartClock("ToolChange") and StopClock("ToolChange") must be defined in the CSE tool change subprogram of the machine. The tool change time is the time spent executing the NC code lines defined between the commands.
Transition Path
Displays the status of a Transition Path.
Generated
The Transition Path has been generated and is up-to-date.
None
There is no Transition Path for this operation.
Out-of-Date
The Transition Path for this operation is out-of-date and needs to be regenerated.
Carrier
Displays the tool carrier name.
Pocket
Displays the tool pocket number.
Inherited From
Displays the name of the parent operation.
Value *
Deviation *
Feature
Displays the name of a geometry feature related to the operation such as sweep tool geometry used to see the extent of a gouge in the part.
Machine Code
Displays the status of the postprocessed Machine Code for an operation.
Note:
Postprocessing occurs when you output or simulate machine code. NX saves the generated NC code in the CAM setup, so that you can avoid an additional postprocessing run each time you postprocess or simulate a tool path.
Generated
The Machine Code saved for this operation is up-to-date.
None
There is no Machine Code saved for this operation.
Broken Link
The Machine Code saved for this operation is out-of-date.
Measured Status *
Operation Type
Displays the description of the operation subtype.
Override *
PCS *
Note:
* Column definition is not currently available.

You can add a description to any program, operation, geometry group, or method. The description can be viewed in all four views of the operation navigator.
This is useful to add a meaningful description to an operation.
The Description box is displayed on the tool dialog box by default. To display the Description box in an operation dialog box, you must customize the dialog box.
The following mom variables output descriptions for post and shop documentation:
mom_operation_description
mom_method_description
mom_geometry_description
mom_program_description
mom_carrier_description
mom_head_description
mom_pocket_description
mom_operation_notes

You can add multiple lines of informative text to any operation.
The Notes dialog box is available in the following ways:
All operation dialog boxes, in the Description group.
From the operation shortcut menu in the Operation Navigator.
You can add the Notes column in the Operation Navigator by right-clicking in the navigator background and the selecting Column→Notes.
The icon indicates that there are notes stored with the operation. To display the note, pause your cursor on the icon.
In the Notes dialog box, you can cut, paste, copy, insert text from a file, and save your notes as a text file.
The mom variable mom_operation_notes outputs operation notes for post and shop documents.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Notes
Operation Navigator
Right-click an operation→Notes

The following rules apply when you rename manufacturing objects:
Operations cannot have the same name as any other existing CAM object. This means that an operation cannot have the same name as another operation. The operation also cannot have the same name as an existing tool, geometry, method, or program group.
Group objects cannot have the same name as an existing operation, or the same name as a group object of the same type. For example, a geometry group cannot have the same name as an existing operation or an existing geometry group. However, a geometry group can have the same name as a tool, program, or method group.

NX now offers the choice to see objects in the navigator named with System and User, System Only, or User Replaces System.
System and User displays both the system name and the user-defined name.
System Only displays only the system name for the object. This is the NX default.
User Replaces System displays only the user-defined name for the object.
Note:
You can change the default in the Customer Defaults.
Note:
The following characters cannot be used !, @, *, ?, ". :, <, >, ', |, \.
System and User
MCS_MAIN "Main Spindle"
WORKPIECE1 "Initial Stock"
MCS_1 "Local Coordinate System"
CAVITY_MILL "Rough Cavity"
PLANAR_MILL "Plane top of part"
PLANAR_PROFILE "Profile Machine"
FACE_MILLING_AREA "Face mill top of part"
HOLE_MILLING "Machine Hole #1"
System Only
MCS_MAIN
WORKPIECE1
MCS_1
CAVITY_MILL
PLANAR_MILL
PLANAR_PROFILE
FACE_MILLING_AREA
HOLE_MILLING
User Replaces System
"Main Spindle"
"Initial Stock"
"Local Coordinate System"
"Rough Cavity"
"Plane top of part"
"Profile Machine"
"Face mill top of part"
"Machine Hole #1"
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Navigator
Right-click in navigator→Name Display
Choose System and User, System Only, or User Replaces System
Customer Defaults
Name Display
Choose System and User, System Only, or User Replaces System

Document Title: Specify time estimates for tool changes and rapid feeds
Document Body:
If a machine tool is not specified, the Generic Machine dialog box controls the values for tool change time and rapid feed. The default values for rapid feed are 400 ipm or 10000 mmpm.
You can change these values to match your machine parameters.
In the Operation Navigator, in the Machine Tool View, double-click Generic Machine.
In the Generic Machine dialog box, in the Time Estimates group, specify values for Tool Change and Rapid Feed.
Click Update Operation Navigator .
Note:
If a machine tool is specified for the Manufacturing setup, the Tool Change and Rapid Feed options are not available in the dialog box when you edit the machine. The following MOM variables in the postprocessor for the machine tool control the values for tool change time and rapid feed:
mom_kin_tool_change_time
mom_kin_rapid_feed_rate
If a machine tool has multiple postprocessors defined, the first postprocessor controls the values.

The Operation Navigator has four views which display the same set of operations differently.
View
Description
Program Order View
Organizes operations by the order in which they are executed on the machine tool. Each program group represents a separate program file that is output to the postprocessor or CLSF.
Sorting of columns is disabled in this view.
For more information, see Program Groups.
Machine Tool View
Organizes operations by the cutting tools used and displays all the tools retrieved from the tool library or created in the current setup. You can also organize cutting tools by turrets on a lathe or by tool type on a mill.
Geometry View
Organizes operations by machining geometry and MCS orientation.
Each geometry group displays operations by the order in which they are executed on the machine tool.
Sorting of columns is disabled in this view.
For more information, see Geometry Groups.
Machining Method View
Organizes operations by common machining applications which share the same parameter values, such as roughing, semi-finishing, and finishing.
For more information, see Method Groups.
Add program view
Allows you to add up to two program order view. This is very helpful in multiple spindle machines
Remove program view
Removes your additional program order view.
Each view:
Organizes the operations into groups that control relevant parameters. The contents of a group are inherited by the groups and operations below it in the Navigator tree. The groups display whether they are actually used in the NC program or not.
For example: If a tool is used, it has one or more operations below it in the Machine Tool View. Unused tools do not have an operation below the tool.
Contains an Unused Items folder to store items that you might need later. Generating operations in the Unused Items folder does not update the In Process Workpiece.
When you select an operation in a view, then change views, the groups are expanded to show the selected operation in each view. You can also look at the Dependencies panel to see where an operation is located in all four views.
You can switch from one view of the Operation Navigator to another by clicking the appropriate button on the Top Border bar.
Note:
When you change the order of the operations in a geometry group in the Geometry view, remember to check how your changes have affected the sequence of operations in the Program Order view before outputting your program. For more information see Operation Order.
The groups that initially appear in the Operation Navigator are defined by the setup template specified the first time you start the Manufacturing application for a model. For more information, see Available CAM session setups.

Document Title: Using the Program Order View to Create Your NC Program
Document Body:
When you have viewed the Program Order View and seen the order in which the operations are going to be machined, you can analyze the situation and decide if it is arranged in the most efficient way. If you decide that some operations need to be rearranged to make the program more efficient, it is easy to rearrange the operations in the Program Order View. For example, if are trying to reduce tool changes you can either choose to change the order of the operations, or change the tool that the operation uses. Changing the order of the operations is most easily done in the Program Order View. Changing the tool the operation uses is most easily done in the Tool View. This is because the Program Order View groups the operations together in chronological order and the Tool View groups the operations by the tool.
Note:
The Program Order view will always be synchronized when moving operations in the other views of the Operation Navigator.

Document Title: Using Geometry View to Enhance Your NC Programs
Document Body:
If you want to plan your NC program based on geometry, use the Geometry View instead of the Program Order View. You can then organize the setup by geometric feature.
For example, you can create a geometry group for Pocket A that includes a rough mill operation and a finish mill operation. You do the same for Pocket B. In the Program Order View, you change the order of the operation so that you rough both pockets first then finish both pockets. In the Geometry View your operations are organized by the geometry they machine, but in the Program Order View, those same operations are organized in the order they are output.
If you create your NC program in the Program Order View, you can still use the Geometry View to help you edit the NC program. Use the Geometry View to evaluate the operations used in each geometry group and decide if the arrangement is the most efficient. Since the Geometry View groups the operations together according to their geometry group, the Geometry View can be used to easily move or copy an operation from one geometry group to another.
Always check how the changes you have made in any view affect the Program Order View, as this is the view that contains the sequence of the operations for output.
Operation Order
The order of the operations within the geometry groups is linked from the Geometry View to the Program Order View. If you change the order of operations within a geometry group in the Geometry View, those changes are also reflected in the Program Order View.  
For example, if a hole_geom group contains center drill, drill, and tap, those three operations must occur in that order at each hole. Other operations in other geometry groups can occur in between, but for any hole in the group, center drill must precede drill which must precede the tap.
For reordering to occur in the program group and be maintained in the Program Order View, the operations:
Must be in the same geometry group
Must be in the same program group
Must appear in sequential order
If there are operations from different programs between your ordered operations, then the order will not be maintained in the Program Order View. For example, if there are three operations in one geometry group, but the third operation is in a different program, and operation 1 is moved to a position after operation 2, the order will be updated in the program view. However, if operation 1 is moved to after operation 3, the order in the Program Order View will not be updated, because operation 3 is in a different program.
The relative order of consecutive operations within a geometry group is maintained in the Program Order View, the order of the geometry groups in the Geometry View is not.  In other words, the order of operations in different geometry groups is not automatically maintained in the Program Order View.
The Tool and Method Views have no effect on the Program Order View.
Operations in the Unused Items group are not considered when determining the order between the Geometry and the Program Order Views.

Document Title: Using the Tool View to Enhance Your NC Program
Document Body:
When you have viewed the Tool View and seen all the operations in which the tools are used, you can analyze the situation and decide if it is arranged in the most efficient way. Use this view to change the tool the operation uses, by moving the operation to a different tool parent. Since the Tool View groups the operations together by tool name, it allows you to quickly locate the tool you are searching for. Therefore, making changes in your operation relating to the tool are most easily performed in the Tool View. For example if you modified a tool, you would use the Tool View to see all of the operations that used that tool, and regenerate them to update their tool paths.
The graphic below is an example of the Tool View. In the furthest left hand column, under Name, you can see all the tools that are in the part. You can also see that only two of these tools are actually used by operations. You can tell this by the plus or minus sign that is to the left of the tool name.
In this example Tool UGTI0203_013 has been expanded to show the operation in which it is used. If you decide you want tool UGT0203_008 to perform this operation (FLOWCUT_SINGLE) you can drag and drop the operation into the correct place. Select the operation and drag it to the tool you want to use in that operation. Let go of the mouse, and that tool is now used in that operation.
After moving an operation, status is set to regenerate, so you need to regenerate the operation to update the tool path.
Tool UGTI0203_017 is collapsed. Expand it and see the operation(s) listed below it. These are the operations in which it is used.
In the Tool View

Document Title: Using the Method View to Enhance Your NC Programs
Document Body:
You can use the Method View to analyze the situation and decide if it is arranged in the most efficient way. In the Method View the system displays the operations grouped together according to their machining method (rough, finish, semi-finish). This organization makes it easy to manipulate the method choice within the operations. Be sure to always check how the changes you have made in any view affect the Program Order View as this is the view that contains the sequence of operations.
Use this view to change the method information for several operations at once. For example, to change the cut color for all Mill-Rough operations, edit the Mill_Rough Method, and change the display options. Now all the operations in that method inherit the new colors. This is easier than changing the display options in each operation.

The Details panel displays an overview of the parameters for the selected object (operation, geometry group, etc.). You can edit parameter selection, but you cannot edit the parameter values. Values are only displayed here for reference whether the parameter is currently inherited or not inherited.
The parameter is inherited, and the inheritance status cannot be changed in this list. You must edit the parameter in the operation to break the inheritance.
The parameter is not currently inherited.
The parameter is selected for inheritance.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
File→Utilities→Customer Defaults→Manufacturing→User Interface→Operation Navigator→ Show Details view
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operation→expand Details panels

Document Title: Set Inheritance on for a parameter
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, select the operation.
In the Details panel, select the check box in front of the parameter.
Click Apply changes .
Applying changes also updates the list and the tree display in the Operation Navigator. Changing the selection in the Operation Navigator tree without first applying changes in the inheritance display discards the changes.

Note:
The Details panel can be displayed if you chooose the Show Details view option in the Customer Defaults.
Details menu options
Right-click in the background of the Details panel for the following options:
Export to Browser
Saves the information in the Details panel to an html file, and exports it to your web browser. If none of your browsers are running, this option starts your default browser.
Export to Spreadsheet
Exports the information in the Details panel to a spreadsheet. You can use the spreadsheet tools to help you analyze or publish the data. For example, you can use the tools to sort the data in number cells or to color the text in cells that you want to emphasize.
See the Gateway Help for more information about the spreadsheets used in NX.
Freeze and Unfreeze
See more on Freeze a column in the Operation Navigator.
Columns
The Columns sub menu allows you to quickly activate or deactivate the display of columns in the Details panel. The sub menu contains all columns that are available for the current view. Columns that are visible show a check mark in front of the menu entry. To change the display status of a column, select it in the menu.
Send to Window
Opens the currently selected view of the Details panel in a new window.
Details Panel Option
Details Panel Option
Apply
To apply any changes you have made in the Details panel select the apply button.

You can select and right-click any object in any view of the Operation Navigator to perform a variety of functions on operations and groups. Many of these options are also available in the menu and on the ribbon bar.
In most cases, if you are currently editing an operation the menu options are unavailable. The options are context sensitive. This means that if an option is not applicable to what you have right clicked on, the option will not appear in the menu.
To access options that are not specific to an object, right-click in the background.

Document Title: Operation Navigator column and background commands
Document Body:
The following options are available in any view of the Operation Navigator. Some options are available when you right-click a column heading. Some options are available when you right-click in the background of the Operation Navigator.
Find
For common options, see more on Find dialog box. For options that are available only when you find values in the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator, see Find: Program Order dialog box.
Filter
For common options, see more on Filter dialog box. For options that are available only when you filter values in the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator, see Filter: Program Order dialog box.
Program Order View
This option changes the view on the Operation Navigator to the Program Order view.
The Program Order view shows which Program group each operation belongs to, and the order in which operations will be executed on the machine tool. This is the only view in which the order of the listed operations is relevant or important. Selecting this option displays the Program Order view in the Operation Navigator.
Machine Tool View
This option changes the view on the Operation Navigator to the Machine Tool view.
The Machine Tool view organizes operations by cutting tools. It can also organize cutting tools by turrets on a lathe or by tool type on a mill, for example. Selecting this option displays the Machine Tool view in the Operation Navigator.
Geometry View
This option changes the view on the Operation Navigator to the Geometry view.
The Geometry view shows the machining geometry and Machine Coordinate System (MCS) each operation will use. Selecting this option displays the Geometry view in the Operation Navigator.
Machining Method View
This option changes the view on the Operation Navigator to the Machining Method view.
The Machining Method view allows you to organize the operations under common machining applications which share the same parameter values (rough, finish, semi-finish). Selecting this option displays the Machining Method view in the Operation Navigator.
Name Display
System and User
The navigator items display both the system name and the user-defined name.
System Only
The navigator items display the system name only.
User Replaces System
The navigator items display the user-defined name. If no user-defined name is given, the system name is displayed.
Expand All
Expands all collapsed parent groups in the Operation Navigator so that every operation is visible.
Collapse All
Choosing Collapse All collapses all the parent groups in the Operation Navigator.
Column Configuration
Lets you modify an existing column configuration to show or hide columns. Also lets you create custom column configurations.
See more on Configure columns dialog box.
Freeze and Unfreeze
See more on Freeze a column in the Operation Navigator.
Export to Browser
Saves the information in the Operation Navigator to an HTML file, and exports it to your web browser. If none of your browsers are running, this option starts your default browser.
Export to Spreadsheet
Exports the information in the Operation Navigator to a spreadsheet. You can use the spreadsheet tools to help you analyze or publish the data. For example, you can use the tools to sort the data in number cells or to color the text in cells that you want to emphasize.
See the Gateway Help for more information about the spreadsheets used in NX.
Send to Window
Opens the currently selected view of the Operation Navigator in a new window.

Multiple program order views can be displayed and filtered individually.
Add program view
This option adds an additional program order view.
This is very useful in machines with multiple spindles.
Remove program view
This option removes the additional program order view.

The following options are available only when you find values in the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator. For details about Equals, Does Not Equal, Begins With, Ends With, Contains and Contains options, see Find dialog box.
Find: Program Order
Find: Title criterion list
Specifies the type of search criterion.
Edit Status : All
Finds all objects.
Edit Status : Needs to Regenerate
Finds objects for which the tool path has never been generated, or the generated tool path is out-of-date.
Edit Status : Generated
Finds objects for which the tool path has been generated, and the generated tool path is up-to-date.
Edit Status : Needs to Repost
Finds objects for which the tool path has never been output, or the tool path has changed and the postprocessed machine code is out-of-date.
Edit Status : Approved
Finds objects for which the user has overridden the system status to indicate the operation is complete, regardless of the software indicators.
Edit Status : Complete
Finds objects for which the tool path has been generated and the postprocessed machine code is up-to-date.
Find value box
Sets the text string, integer, or real number for which you want to search.

The following options are available only when you filter values in the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator. For details about Equals, Does Not Equal, Begins With, Ends With, Contains and Contains options, see Filter dialog box.
Filter: Program Order
Filter: Title criterion list
Specifies the type of filtering criterion.
Edit Status : All
Filters the list to all objects.
Edit Status : Needs to Regenerate
Filters the list to objects for which the tool path has never been generated, or the generated tool path is out-of-date.
Edit Status : Generated
Filters the list to objects for which the tool path has been generated, and the generated tool path is up-to-date.
Edit Status : Needs to Repost
Filters the list to objects for which the tool path has never been output, or the tool path has changed and the postprocessed machine code is out-of-date.
Edit Status : Approved
Filters the list to objects for which the user has overridden the system status to indicate the operation is complete, regardless of the software indicators.
Edit Status : Complete
Filters the list to objects for which the tool path has been generated and the postprocessed machine code is up-to-date.
Filter value box
Sets the text string, integer, or real value against which the filtering criterion is evaluated.

Select and right-click any object in any view of the Operation Navigator to display the available commands for that object.
Edit
This option allows you to change parameters within the highlighted object by displaying the group or operation dialog box. If multiple objects are highlighted, each dialog box will appear in succession in the order listed in the Operation Navigator as the previous dialog is dismissed.
Cut and Copy
These options allow you to temporarily remove or duplicate a chosen object from the Operation Navigator for the purpose of pasting it in a different position. You may choose multiple objects to either Cut or Copy. All groups and/or operations contained within a Cut or Copied group are also Cut or Copied. And as an alternative option to cutting or copying, it is possible to drag and drop multiple operations into new Parent Groups.
Paste
This option allows you to place previously Cut or Copied objects back into the Operation Navigator in a specific positional relationship to the currently selected object. This option is especially useful in reordering the operations in the Program Order view. Paste>Inside positions the object below and one level lower than the currently highlighted object. i.e. the currently highlighted object becomes the parent of the pasted object.
Delete
This option allows you to permanently remove objects. All groups and/or operations contained within a deleted group are also deleted.
Rename
This options allows you to rename the operation you have highlighted and right clicked. To rename an operation you can also do a slow double click on the operation. Also if the operation is highlighted and you hit F2 you enter into rename mode. All of these options will highlight the operation name and place the cursor at the end of the name.
Generate
Generate allows you to create tool path(s) for the currently selected operation(s).
The following dialog box is displayed if Pause After Each Path (in the CAM General Preferences dialog box) is turned on when generating tool paths for one or more selected operations.
Note:
A warning appears whenever you Generate an operation containing suppressed geometry. Select Yes to remove only the suppressed geometry from the operation and then continue to edit or generate the operation. Select NO to retain the suppressed geometry in the operation. Unsuppressing redisplays the geometry, but does not add it back into the operation. You must respecify the unsuppressed geometry as Part, Blank, Check, Drive, or Avoidance Geometry for the operation to again recognize it.
Yes removes suppressed geometry from the operation.
For more information, see Path Generation options.
Post Process
In the Operation Navigator, choose the operations you want to postprocess or choose the root in the Program Order View to postprocess all operations. The operations must contain tool paths (indicated by a ! symbol).
Right-click and choose Post Process.
Choose the desired machine, using the browse button if the desired machine is not listed.
Specify an output file, and click OK.
The system creates an NC program for the specified controller:
List
List causes the system to display a text description of the tool path for the operation that just completed generating. The tool path listing is displayed in an Information Window.
List Affected Operations
This option will bring up a listing window displaying the names of the operations since the last pause (i.e. all the operations generated after turning Pause After Each Path "Off").
Replay
Replay causes the system to display a graphical representation of the tool path.
Information
This option displays an Information window on the currently selected operation or group. For more information go to the Base Info On setting in the General section.
Properties
This option brings up a dialog with two tabs, General and Attributes.
The General tab contains an edit field. In the edit field you can rename the current node. Changing the name and hitting either OK or APPLY will change the name of the current node. Before the new name is applied, a check will be performed to see if it is valid. If it is not valid a message box informs you that the name is not valid.
Note:
Note that the edit field is insensitive if the object properties dialog is invoked on a system object which cannot be renamed (for example Unused Items) .
The information icon is also available on the General tab. This icon displays an information window on the currently selected operation or group.
The Attributes tab allows you to view the attributes associated with the node. It also allows you to edit, add, or delete attributes.
Suppressed Status
When you choose Object → Suppressed Status, the Operation Navigator will show the current suppression status (suppressed or non) of all operations within the selected groups. This information updates when the Suppressed Status changes.

These options appear when you right-click an object in the Operation Navigator and choose Insert.
Operation
Opens the Create Operation dialog box to let you insert an Operation group in the selected object. Depending on what you have selected, in the Operation Navigator the operation will either be inserted immediately behind the selected object, if the selected object is an operation, or at the end of the group, if the selected object is a group.
Note:
When inserting an object using the menu or the Ribbon bar, it is not clear whether the currently selected object is intended to serve as an insert position or if it is just a randomly selected object. It might also be possible that no object is selected. Therefore, the selected object in the Operation Navigator is not taken into account when inserting a new object via the menu or ribbon bar.
If you want the selection in the Operation Navigator to determine the exact location of the inserted operation, use this MB3 method of inserting the operation.
Program
Opens the Create Program dialog box to let you insert a Program group in the selected object.
Tool
Opens the Create Tool dialog box to let you insert a Tool group in the selected object.
Geometry
Opens the Create Geometry dialog box to let you insert a Geometry group in the selected object.
Method
Opens the Create Method dialog box to let you insert a Method group in the selected object.

To change the colors in which the IPW is shown, choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing→Geometry→Colors.
Note:
If you select the manufacturing preference to save the IPW in a separate part file, then the software puts the IPW in a part file and adds this part to your assembly.
To view the IPW, do the following:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation for which you want to see the IPW.
Choose Workpiece.
Choose one of the following options to view the IPW:
Show 2D
In turning operations, this shows you the material removal status immediately before the selected operation (in pink) and immediately after the selected operation.
In planar milling operations, this option displays the uncut material boundaries if you choose Save 2D Workpiece in the operation.
Show filled 2D (for turning operations)
This shows you uncut material (blue below) after the selected operation has been carried out. The finished part geometry shape is also shown (pink below).
Show 3D (for mill-turn and milling operations)
This shows the 3D IPW.
For program groups containing both milling and turning operations, this shows the 3D shape of the workpiece after the selected operation has been carried out.
In milling operations, if you saved an IPW generated by Visualize or the operation has set the Use 3D IPW option, it is displayed. Otherwise the software displays the static IPW.
Show 3D Workpiece after a z-level milling operation
Show spinning 3D (for turning and mill-turn operations)
For turning operations, this shows the spinning 3D IPW of an operation. A quarter section is omitted for easier viewing into the inside of the IPW.
For program groups including both milling and turning operations, this shows the spun shape of the workpiece computed from the state of the 3D IPW after the selected operation.
Workpiece→Save As
In Turning, this option allows you to save the 2D and 3D In Process Workpiece associated with the highlighted operation as a separate 3D model.
In Milling, if the operation has a generated IPW, this option allows you to save the 3D In Process Workpiece in a separate file as a faceted body.
Note:
When you save the workpiece in Turning, NX saves the spinning IPW. However, in certain situations when material is removed in previous Milling operations, the material removal might not be saved.

These options appear when you right-click an object in the Operation Navigator and choose Object.
Transform
Display
This option highlights the geometry (part, check, cut area, trim) used in the currently selected operation or geometry group. If a tool in the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator is highlighted, the tool is displayed on the part. If suspect geometry was found during the generation of the toolpath, the bounding box of the suspect geometry will displayed. This will aid you in finding the geometry that was not processed as expected.
Note:
If the suspect geometry is updated in Modeling, it will no longer be displayed.
Adopt
This adopts the operation into Knowledge Fusion to access the operation parameters. Once an operation is adopted into KF, you can control the most important operation parameters through KF functions.
Note:
This option is only available for operations used by feature-based milling and holemaking.
Find Related Features
The Find Related Features command highlights the machining features in the Machining Feature Navigator that belong to the program, tool, geometry, or operation that is selected in the Operation Navigator.
Operation Navigator, Machine Tool View
Machining Feature Navigator, Group View
Customize
Select this option and the system displays the Customize dialog. Here you specify the parameters (text fields, buttons, and option menus) that appear in the highlighted operation creation dialog box. Refer to Customizing a Dialog for details.
Customize From
Select this option and the system displays the Update Customization dialog. Use the Update Customization dialog to customize your current dialog in one of the following ways: from another object dialog in your work part, from a object dialog in another part, or from the latest template for this object type. For more information go to Overview For Customizing From Another Source.
Using Template Settings to make an operation a template
A CAM template part file may contain many operations. The Template Settings command determines which operations are used as templates, and which objects are created with their geometry parents.
Note:
To use the part as a Type template, select it from the CAM Setup area in the Machining Environment dialog.
For more information, see Create a template.
Switch Layer/Layout
This option allows you to retrieve the view layouts saved using Save Layout/Layer in the group creation dialog boxes.
Set Machining Data
Update List
Feed Rates
Update Tool from Library

Update List displays the status of the selected operation or group of operations.
The information shown for each operation includes the following:
A status of Complete, Need to Generate, or Need to Post.
Lists of the parameters that have changed since the operation was last generated or posted.
Parameters Affecting Tool Path (Regenerate Status) lists the changed parameters that may affect the tool path when NX generates the operation. These parameters cause the status to be Regenerate.
Parameters Affecting Output (Repost Status) lists the changed parameters that may affect the postprocessor output file or the CLS output file. These parameters cause the status to be Repost.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Right-click the selected node→Object→ Update List

You can access the Feeds and Speeds dialog box in the following ways:
In the operation dialog box, in the Path Settings group, select the Feeds and Speeds node.
In the Operation Navigator, right click an operation and choose Object→Feed Rates
Note:
The feeds and speeds values entered here are applied to all operations selected in the Operation Navigator. You cannot edit Wire EDM feed rates from the Operation Navigator.
The available options depend on the operation type and subtype.
Automatic Settings
Set Machining Data
Sets parameters to match the Machining Data Library values.
Calculates feeds and speeds for the first operation selected, and then applies those values to all the operations. Does not change depth of cut or stepover values.
For more information see Set Machining Data overview.
Surface Speed
Specifies the cutting speed of the tool measured at the cutting edge of each tooth in surface feet or meters per minute.
The software uses Surface Speed to calculate Spindle Speed and Feed per Tooth. Changing this value recalculates the other parameters.
Tip:
Surface Speed and Spindle Speed are different methods for specifying the tool's cutting speed.
Feed per Tooth
Measures the amount of material removed per tooth in inches or millimeters. The software uses this value to calculate the Cut feed rate.
Changing this value recalculates the Cut feed rate.
Tip:
Enter the Surface Speed or Spindle Speed value before changing the Feed per Tooth value.
Output
Wire EDM only
Feed Rates
Specifies the type of moves to output:
None
(Default) Does not output any feed rate control command to the tool path. Use None for machines that control feed rates by means of the machine power setting.
Rapid Only
Does not output a FEDRAT/ post command. Use Rapid only for machines that need a faster speed for non-cutting moves.
All Moves
Outputs a FEDRAT/ statement for non-zero, positive feed rate values. Use for machines with full feed rate control capability.
Spindle Speed
The software uses Spindle Speed to calculate Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth. Changing this value recalculates the other parameters.
Spindle Speed (rpm)
Sets a mom variable for the spindle status. Some users require this variable to generate custom output.
The variable that is set is not used by the example post processors, and it does not affect tool path output.
Spindle Speed
Specifies the cutting speed of the tool measured in revolutions per minute.
If you change the value, Calculate Speeds and Feeds based on this value in the same row becomes active. The software uses the Spindle Speed value to calculate the Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values.
Tip:
Surface Speed and Spindle Speed are different methods of specifying the tool's cutting speed.
Output Mode
RPM
Defines the spindle speed in revolutions per minute.
SFM
Defines the spindle speed in surface feet per minute.
SMM
Defines the spindle speed in surface meters per minute.
Direction
CLW = output the code for clockwise rotation.
CCLW = output to code for couinterclockwise rotation.
None = do not output a rotation direction code, if the post supports no direction code output.
Outputs the NC code for clockwise or counterclockwise rotation, or suppresses the output of a direction code if the post allows this.
Range Status
Activates the Range box.
The Range box allows you to enter the spindle speed range. Spindle range is normally programmed as a numeric value; however, LOW, MEDIUM and HIGH can be used as follows:
LOW = 1
MEDIUM = 2
HIGH = 2 if there are only 2 ranges
HIGH = 3 if there are more than 2 ranges
Text Status
Specifies text to add to the LOAD or TURRET command during CLSF output.
During postprocessing the software stores this text in a mom variable.
Feed Rates
Specifies the feed rates and units for different types of cutting and non-cutting moves.
See also:
Feeds in the Milling online Help.
Feed rates in the Turning online Help.
Feed Rates in the Wire EDM online Help.
The Feeds and Speeds Library.

Set Machining Data calculates all values, including depth of cut and stepover, separately for each operation selected in the Operation Navigator. The values are determined by the part material, tool material, and cut method assigned to each operation.
Note:
When you click Set Machining Data , the stepover type changes to Constant. If your operations use the Scallop or Multiple stepover types, and you want to keep those settings, deactivate the Always change stepover type to Constant customer default. When you change this setting, NX does not change multiple stepover values defined as %Tool. It also reduces multiple values greater than the calculated stepover to the system calculated stepover.
For more information see Set Machining Data overview.

Use the Mass Edit command to edit multiple operations at the same time. The command opens a dialog box for the selected operations. The dialog box displays the parameters that are available to edit simultaneously.
Note:
Parameters that allow you to specify a range of values using a list cannot be updated in all operations in a mass edit. For example, multiple stepover distance parameters and range definition parameters.
When you click OK, NX applies all of the changes to all of the selected operations.
Operations to edit
Editable parameters
Note:
If some of the operation dialog boxes are in the Explorer-style format, and some are in the previous format, NX displays the editable parameters in the format used by the first operation in the hierarchy.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisites
The operations must be the same type. For example, all drilling or all cavity mill.
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operations→Mass Edit

You can mirror operations through a plane for more efficient opposite-hand machining. The mirrored operations are associative copies that optionally let you reverse the tool path while maintaining the cut direction and thread hand or cut angle.
NX applies the Maintain Cut Direction or Maintain Cut Angle option when the mirrored operation is generated. If you select the Generate Tool Path check box, NX generates the mirrored operation for you. Otherwise, you must manually generate it.
If you change an operation parameter in the source operation, NX automatically changes the parameter in the mirrored copy.
If you change an operation parameter in the mirrored copy, it becomes an independent parameter. All of the other parameters remain associative, and the source operation is not affected.
1 Original tool path (climb cut)   2 Mirrored tool path (climb cut - reversed path)
  You can place the mirrored operations in a separate program group to post them independently from the original operations. The mirrored operations can also have their own blank geometry and MCS parent groups.
Part geometry is not required on the mirrored side because NX only uses it for visualization.
If you define a blank geometry parent for mirrored operations:
NX does not use the blank to calculate the tool path, or to verify using the 3D Dynamic options. When you generate the tool path of a mirrored operation, NX always uses the part and blank of the source operation. For IPW-aware operations, NX keeps the blank and IPW of the source and mirrored operations separate to guarantee undisturbed tool path computation for the mirrored set of operations.
NX subtracts the mirrored tool path from the blank geometry parent to show the resulting IPW only when you show the 3D workpiece.
Tip:
To show the 3D workpiece, select one or more mirrored operations, right-click and choose Workpiece→Show 3D.
Note:
The dialog box for a mirrored operation displays the parameter settings of the original operation before applying the mirror settings. Check the information in the Dependencies column to determine if NX is maintaining the cut direction and cut angle.
Operation Navigator indicators
In the Operation Navigator, in the Path column, NX clearly indicates that the new tool path is a mirrored copy of the original tool path. In the Dependencies column, NX indicates which operations are the original source operations and which operations are the mirrored copies . NX also indicates if a mirrored operation has modified parameters .
When you hover over the icon, NX lists the Mirror dialog box options applied to the operation.
When you hover over the icon, NX also lists the modified parameters that are no longer associative. All of the other parameters remain associative.
Operation Navigator — Program
Name
Path
Dependencies
PROGRAM_LEFT
  FLOOR_WALL_IPW
HOLE_MILLING_CLIMB
THREAD_MILLING
