PROGRAM_RIGHT
FLOOR_WALL_IPW_1
HOLE_MILLING_CLIMB_1
THREAD_MILLING_1
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Exclusions
You cannot mirror the following existing operations:
Turning operations
Operations created by using these commands: Transform, Mirror, Paste With Reference, Copy CAM from Component
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operation→Object→Mirror

Suppose you want to mirror the toolpaths created for the part on the left to machine the part on the right, and you want the mirrored operations to use the same cut direction as the original operations.
In this example, the following apply:
The mirror plane is already defined.
There is a separate program, PROGRAM_RIGHT, to contain the mirrored operations so that you can post the mirrored operations separately.
The manufacturing setup part file includes the right-side part geometry to help you visualize the tool paths.
The right side geometry is not necessary because NX uses the geometry defined for the original operations to create the tool paths for the mirrored operations.
Original tool paths
Operation Navigator — Program
PROGRAM_LEFT
FLOOR_WALL_IPW
HOLE_MILLING_CLIMB
THREAD_MILLING
PROGRAM_RIGHT

Operation Navigator — Geometry
MCS_MILL
WORKPIECE_LEFT
FG_STEP1POCKET_THREAD_2
HOLE_MILLING
THREAD_MILLING
FLOOR_WALL_IPW
In the Operation Navigator, Program Order view, select the operations to mirror, right-click and choose Object→Mirror.
FLOOR_WALL_IPW
HOLE_MILLING_CLIMB
THREAD_MILLING
Select the mirror plane.
In the Mirror dialog box, set the following and click OK.
Location group
Program = PROGRAM_RIGHT
Geometry = WORKPIECE_LEFT (default)
Path Settings group
Maintain Cut Direction =
Maintain Cut Angle =
Actions group
Generate Tool Path =

Path
Dependencies
PROGRAM_LEFT
FLOOR_WALL_IPW
HOLE_MILLING_CLIMB

Mirror Plane
  Specify Plane
Let you specify the plane about which to mirror the operations.
Use the Plane dialog box options to define a mirror plane.
Use one of the standard plane definition methods to specify the mirror plane.
Location
Program
Lets you specify which program folder to place the mirrored operation in.
The Same as Source option places the mirrored operation in the same location as the parent operation.
Geometry
Lets you specify which geometry group to place the mirrored operation in.
The Same as Source option places the mirrored operation in the same location as the parent operation.
Path Settings
Maintain Cut Direction
(Default) Creates a mirrored operation with the cut direction reversed from the original operation.
Original operation - Climb Cut
Mirrored operation - Conventional Cut
Maintains the climb or conventional cut direction of the tool by reversing the path.
Original operation - Climb Cut
Mirrored operation Climb Cut
Maintain Cut Angle
Applicable only for Zig cut patterns, or a single straight pass.
To maintain both the cut direction and the cut angle in zig patterns, select the Maintain Cut Angle and Maintain Cut Direction check boxes.
(Default) Reverses the direction of the tool movement by 180 degrees regardless of the Maintain Cut Direction setting.
Original operation

Maintains the direction of the tool movement regardless of the Maintain Cut Direction setting.

Maintain Cut Direction
Actions
Generate Tool Path
(Default) Does not generate the mirrored operation. You must manually generate the operation.
Generates the tool path in the background, independently from the parent operation.
Note:
You must generate the mirrored operation to apply the Maintain Cut Direction or Maintain Cut Angle settings.
If the source operation changes, generating the mirrored operation updates the tool path to reflect the current condition of the source operation.
If you change an operation parameter in the mirrored copy, it becomes an independent parameter. All of the other parameters remain associative.

What is it?
You can edit Path Settings for a mirror operation after the operation is mirrored.
  If you select multiple operations, NX shows the path settings of the first operation. Once modified, all selected operations have the new path settings.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Right-click the mirror operation→Object→Edit Mirror

Use the Transform command to copy a tool path to other areas of the part or to adjust the original tool path.
When you transform an operation:
You can move the operation. This changes the location or orientation of the operation.
You can copy the operation. This creates a new operation with its own set of parameters and tool paths.
You can make an instance of the original operation. This also creates a new operation, but it is linked to the original operation, which can save you time creating and editing the corresponding tool paths.
The new operation, copy, or instance remembers its relationship to the original operation.
Non-associative objects are mapped using the reference coordinate system (RCS) and translated with the operation. Non-associative objects include geometric parameters, such as tool axis vectors and clearance planes that are not modeled.
Associative objects created using Point, Vector, or Plane Constructor are not mapped or translated with the operation because they retain their associativity.
From and GoHome Points are not translated with the operation because they are associated with the machine tool and not the operation.
You can remove the transformation and restore an operation, its instance, or its copy to the position and orientation of the original operation.
Note:
If the Generate Tool Paths check box is selected in the Operation page of the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box, and the tool paths of the original are edited, are transformed, or are missing, the software:
Does not generate the tool paths.
Displays a warning message indicating that the tool paths are missing or are edited.
Makes the Redisplay Tool Path option unavailable.
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Requires an operation with generated tool path.
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operation→Object→Transform

Type
Type
Provides linear and angular reposition methods for the selected objects. Available methods are:
Translate
Moves the selected operations or tool paths from a reference point to a destination point, or along an incremental (Delta) distance.
Scale
Changes the size of the selected operations or tool paths relative to a reference point.
For example, if the scale factor is 2, the XC, YC, ZC coordinates are multiplied by 2.
If you enter multiple copies, the scale factor is applied to each copy. The original is scaled to create the first copy and then the scale factor is applied to the scaled copy to create the next copy and so on.
Rotate About a Point
Rotates the selected operations or tool paths around a reference line that is parallel to the ZC-axis and passes through a specified reference point. A positive rotation is in the counterclockwise direction from the positive X (or XC) axis to the positive Y (or YC) axis.
Rotate About a Line
Rotates the selected operations or tool paths around any reference line. A positive rotation is in the counterclockwise direction from the positive X (or XC) axis to the positive Y (or YC) axis.
Mirror Through a Line
Creates a mirror image of the selected operations or tool paths on the opposite side of a reference line. The distance from each Goto point to the reference line is maintained in the mirrored path.
Multiple copies are not available for this option.
For more information, see Mirror Through a Line.
Mirror Through a Plane
Creates a mirror image of the selected operations or tool paths relative to a specified plane. The distance from each Goto point to the plane is maintained in the mirrored path.
Multiple copies are not available for this option.
Circular Array
Copies the selected operations or tool paths to create a circular pattern.
You specify a reference point and the array origin point. The software places the reference point of the first element of the array at the array origin point. Each element of the array maintains the same relationship to the destination point as it had to the reference point.
Multiple copies of the array are not available.
Rectangular Array
Copies the selected operations or tool paths to create rows and columns parallel to the XC and YC axes.
You specify a reference point and the array origin point. The software places the reference point of the first element of the array at the array origin point. Each element of the array maintains the same relationship to the destination point as it had to the reference point.
Multiple copies of the array are not available.
CSYS To CSYS
Moves the selected operations or tool paths from the current coordinate system to a destination coordinate system. The transformed operations or tool paths maintain the same positions relative to the destination coordinate system as they had to the original coordinate system.
Transformation Parameters
The available Transformation Parameters options depend on the Type option selected. For information on options for specifying points, vectors, planes, and coordinate systems (CSYS), see:
Point dialog box
Vector dialog
Datum Plane options
CSYS options
To a Point
Lets you specify a reference point to move from, and a destination point to move to. The operations or tool paths maintain the same relationship to the destination point as they had to the reference point.
Delta
Lets you enter the incremental distance, in XC, YC, and/or ZC coordinates, to translate the operation or tool path from its current position.
Specify
Lets you enter the value directly.
Select
Lets you select an existing line to define the axis of rotation.
Two Points
Lets you specify the reference line by defining the line start and end points.
Point and Vector
Lets you specify the reference line by defining a start point and a vector.
Radius
(Circular Array)
Specifies the radius of the array circle, measured from the array origin point to the reference point of the first element of the array.
Starting Angle
(Circular Array)
Specifies the position on the array circle to place the reference point of the first element of the array.
Increment Angle
(Circular Array)
Specifies the angular distance between successive array elements.
Number
(Circular Array)
Specifies the number of array elements to create.
Note:
If the number of elements and the specified increment angle add up to more than a 360 degree angle, the array elements will overlap.
XC Offset
(Rectangular Array)
Specifies the distance between reference points in columns.
YC Offset
(Rectangular Array)
Specifies the distance between reference points in rows
Array Angle
(Rectangular Array)
Specifies the angle of the array, measured counter- clockwise from the positive XC axis, at the array origin.
Number Along XC
(Rectangular Array)
Specifies how many duplicates of the selected entities to place in the positive XC direction.
Number Along YC
(Rectangular Array)
Specifies how many duplicates of the selected entities to place in the positive YC direction.
Result
Specifies how to carry out the desired transformation.
Move
Moves the selected tool paths or operations from their original location to a new location.
The tool path name remains the same, and the tool path retains its position in the CLSF file.
Copy
Creates a new operation, with its own set of parameters and tool paths, and retains the original location of the selected tool paths.
The new tool paths are appended to the CLSF file and are not associative to the original tool path. The new path or operation is assigned the current name appended with _COPY.
Number of Unassociative Copies lets you specify how many copies to create.
Instance
Creates linked instances of an operation that are directly related to the original operation.
The new path or operation is assigned the current name appended with _instance.
Number of Instances lets you specify how many linked instances to create.
Note:
Editing a linked instance of an operation modifies all the instances. To update all linked instances when you regenerate, the Update All Instances check box in the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box must be selected.
To edit an individual instance, the Unlink Instances check box in the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box must be selected.
There is only one set of data for instanced operations, and only the tool path is copied for each instance. This means that some functionality, such as the in-process workpiece, is not available for instances because the data is not copied for each instance.
Distance/Angle Divisions
Specifies how many equal parts you want the transformation angle or distance divided into.
If you select Move, the transformation is to the first subdivision of the total distance (or angle).
If you select Copy, or Instance, each copy or instance is spaced according to the subdivided distance or angle.
Remove Transformation
Appears only when there is an existing transformation to remove.
Removes a transformed tool path and moves the operation back to its original position. If several transformations were applied to the operation, all transformed tool paths are removed.
Note:
When you click Remove Transformation, NX immediately removes the transformed tool path and sets the operation status to Regenerate . If you click Cancel, the dialog box closes, but the transformed tool path is still removed. You must generate the operation and then reapply the desired transformation.
Preview
Show Results
Lets you verify the transformation settings.
Undo Result
Lets you remove the transformation.

Program and tool path before Transform command
PROGRAM
PLANAR_MILL

Original tool path showing reference point.

This example uses the following Transformations dialog box parameters:
Type group
Type = Rectangular Array
Transformation Parameters group
Number Along XC = 3
Number Along YC = 2
XC-offset = 10
YC-offset = 10
Array Angle = 0
Result group
Result = Instance
Program and tool paths after Transform command
PROGRAM
PLANAR_MILL
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_1
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_2
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_3
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_4
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_5
NX retains the original tool path, PLANAR_MILL, and creates six instances of the tool path for the 3x2 array. There are now two tool paths at the first location: the original operation and the first instance, PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE. Delete the first instance so that the program does not have an extra operation.
Final result
PROGRAM
PLANAR_MILL
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_1
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_2
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_3
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_4
PLANAR_MILL_INSTANCE_5

Use the Delete Transformation command to return the selected operation to its original position and orientation.
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Requires an operation with a transformed tool path.
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operation→Object→Delete Transformation

Use the Update Tool from Library command to modify a library tool in the work part to match the current version of the tool in the library. You can:
Restore a library tool that you retrieved into your work part and then modified. The Library Reference is also restored.
Update a library tool in your work part when that tool is updated in the library.
Tip:
You can use the customer default Check Library Tools for Update to ensure that all library tools in your CAM setup match the tools in the current library. NX automatically checks your CAM setup for tools that have changed since the last time the tools were retrieved from the library. If a tool is found to be out-of-date, NX then:
Displays the tool icon as out-of-date (tool with clock overlaid) in the operation navigator and in the tool tip.
Displays the Out of Date Tools warning message with a list of out-of-date tools, and a prompt to let you automatically update those tools.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
A tool in your CAM setup that was retrieved from the tool library.
Command
Update Tool from Library
Customer default
Check Library Tools for Update

Edit
Allows you to make corrections or modifications to a generated tool path. See Tool Path Editor.
Trim
Opens the Trim Tool Path dialog box. This command lets you trim away unwanted portions of a generated tool path. This is useful as a temporary fix to keep the cutter out of unwanted areas.
Lock
Protects the tool path from being accidentally overwritten. Use this command if you do not want to overwrite the tool path accidentally when upgrading from a prior version of NX, after editing the tool path, or when using a function like flowcut manual cut order.
Divide
Opens the Tool Path Divide dialog box. Use this command to divide an existing into multiple operations that are each limited to a maximum cutting time or path travel length.
Tilt Tool Axis
Opens the Tilt Tool Axis dialog box. Use this command to avoid tool holder collisions in surface contouring, cavity milling, and Zlevel operations.
Divide by Holder
Opens the Divide by Holder dialog box. Use this command to split a single tool path into multiple tool paths using tools of different lengths to avoid collisions and machine the entire cut area.
Delete
This option allows you to delete the tool path for the currently highlighted operation.
List
List displays an Information window containing GOTO's, machine control information, feed rates, etc. The GOTO values are a "snapshot" of the current tool path. The values listed are referenced from the MCS stored in the operation.
Optimize Feed Rate
Opens the Optimize Feed Rate dialog box. This option monitors tool load and adusts the feedrate to maintain a uniform tool load.
Verify
This option allows you to inspect material removal with enhanced visualization of the part and cutter motion.
Simulate
If your part contains a kinematic model of a machine, you can use this option to simulate your entire machine tool in the cutting process.
For more information on simulating your machine tool, see NX Machine Tool Simulation Help.
Gouge Check
This option allows you to gouge check an operation highlighted in the Operation Navigator for which you have saved the tool path. In addition, you can optionally check for collisions with the tool holder. When gouges are found, the software displays them in a color of your choice. If you activate the Pause option, NX displays a motion range dialog indicating the gouge detections. The software stops at any subsequent gouge detection to indicate the range. If turned off, the system continues to process and display all gouges until the End-of-Path is reached. A report is written to the standard NX Information window listing the number of gouges detected.
Tip:
To see a report containing information about individual gouges, use the Gouge Check option.
The gouge check is faster when the tool axis is aligned, in either the positive or negative direction, along the main X, Y, or Z axis. Rotating the tool axis or the MCS increases the calculation time.
Note:
If you want the software to automatically gouge check an operation before postprocessing, you can activate the Gouge check before Postprocessing option in the Manufacturing → Output → Postprocessing section of the customer defaults.
The following table explains how certain parameters affect gouge checking. There is no user interface for these values, since they are taken from the operation being gouge checked.
Safe Clearance
When checking for holder collisions, the software takes this value from the operation. It defines the minimum distance the tool holder should stay away from the material.
Intol/Outtol
Changing the Intol or Outtol values of an operation alters the tolerance for gouging motions. NX uses the following formula to calculate a threshold value from the specified Intol/Outtol:
2*(Intol+(Intol+Outtol)/2)
NX compares the depth of each gouge against the threshold value, then reports all gouges that are greater than the threshold value.
Part Offset and/or Part Stock
The cutters diameter is virtually enlarged by the sum of this value. If the real tool comes closer to the part than this value, the internal virtual tool intersects the part and a gouge is reported.
Transforming
Transforming or editing the path does not change the stock or tolerance values. If you transform a correct tool path to go right through the part geometry, gouges are found.
The Gouge Check column of the Operation Navigator quickly shows you the gouge check status of each operation.
List Gouges
This command is available after you run the Gouge Check command on the selected operations. This command opens the Tool Path Report dialog box. In that dialog box, you can view a list of gouges for each selected tool path, and open the Information window for further review and output.
If you have not yet checked the operation for gouges, this option is unavailable.
Report Shortest Tool
This command calculates the shortest tool necessary for a collision-free tool path.
Load
This option adds the selected tool paths to run time memory when the tool path is listed, replayed, or generated. Once loaded, the tool path remains loaded for the remainder of the work session. This results in faster response time each time the tool path is subsequently listed, replayed, or generated.
Unload
This option removes the selected internal tool paths from run time memory, thereby freeing up space. This action is most useful when very long paths are generated or pulled in from a file. Only paths that have been saved or that are unchanged can be unloaded. Before performing the action, the paths are checked. If any of the paths cannot be unloaded, a warning message is displayed with the path names that cannot be unloaded. The action then proceeds with all the paths that can be unloaded.

Use the Tilt Tool Axis command to avoid tool holder collisions in surface contouring, cavity milling, and Zlevel operations. NX either trims the tool path and retracts the tool, or replaces the 3-axis, 4-axis, or 5-axis motions with 5-axis tilting motions.
You can:
Reach greater depths using the shortest tools possible for added rigidity.
Adjust the tool path for fixed-axis, 4-axis, and 5-axis operations.
Use tools without a defined shank or holder.
Use ball or non-ball tools.
Modify the tool tilt multiple times in direct succession.
In these examples, the tool axis tilts when a tool holder collision is detected, so that the tool can continue cutting down the wall towards the bottom of the part.
Note:
If you regenerate the operation in which NX tilts the tool path, the tool path reverts to the original tool path.
Support for tools other than ball mills
NX checks for gouges, collisions, and motion outside of the swinging axis limits of the machine tool. If NX finds one of these conditions, it trims the tool path and retracts the tool.
Support for ball-end tools
For ball-end tools, you can do the following:
Manually tilt the entire tool path to any 3+2 axis orientation by specifying spherical angles.
Manually tilt the entire tool path towards or away from a point or 3D curve before NX performs the collision check and creates avoidance moves.
Specify what NX should do when the initial tool position could cause a tool gouge, or a collision with the shank or holder. You can automatically do the following:
Tilt the tool to a safe orientation.
Retract the tool and trim the paths.
Limit motion to match the machine tool swinging axis limit.
Avoid pole transition by defining a minimum angle for the swing/tilt axis.
Turn collision checking off in the operation and generate an initial tool path that positions the tool in the entire machining area without considering tool neck, shank, or holder collisions. You can then use the Tilt Tool Axis command to create a collision-free tool path that considers the machine tool limits and swing/tilt characteristics.
For example, you can create a tool path that positions the ball portion of the tool in undercut areas, and then use the Tilt Tool Axis command to produce an optimized tool path without collisions.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisites
A fixed-axis or variable-axis surface contouring operation, or a Zlevel 3-axis operation.
To tilt the tool manually and/or to avoid collision by tilting:
The tool must have a ball shape where the lower radius of the tool = ½ of the diameter of the tool.
To position the tool manually, you should turn collision checking off in the operation. To position the tool in undercuts, you must turn collision checking off in the operation.
A defined shank and holder are recommended, but not mandatory.
Operation Navigator
Right-click an operation→Tool Path→Tilt Tool Axis

Document Title: Tilt Tool Axis dialog box Tilting tab
Document Body:
Manual Tilting group
Specifies parameters that control the tool axis tilt.
Manual Tilting list
Specifies how to apply the tool axis tilt.
Keep Original
Does not apply the Manual Tilting settings. NX maintains the original tool axis orientation unless there is a potential collision.
The tool begins cutting in the original tool axis orientation.
As NX encounters a potential collision, it tilts the tool minimally to avoid the collision and then returns the tool to the original tool axis orientation. NX repeats these tool motions when it encounters the next collision.
User Defined
Applies the Manual Tilting settings. Lets you specify a fixed tilt angle or define geometry to control the tilt direction.
Reference
Specifies the reference axis used to calculate the tilt angle. +ZM is the default axis.
Tool Tilt Method list
Specifies the manual tilt method used.

Toward Curve
Away from Curve
Let you use a curve to control whether the top of the tool holder tilts towards the guiding curve or away from the guiding curve. These settings define the orientation of the tilt plane around the +ZM axis.
Toward Curve
Away from Curve
NX calculates the rotation around the +ZM axis by projecting the shortest distance vector from the tool position to a reference point on the guiding curve.
Shortest Distance
Creates a reference point on the selected guiding curve to generate the tilt plane. The reference point is the shortest distance from the tool position on the tool path.
2D
Measures the shortest distance vector by projecting along the +ZM axis onto a plane. The reference point on the guiding curve has the same X and Y coordinates as the projected point. This option is best for planar curves.
3D
Measures the shortest distance vector in 3D space. This option is best for complex curves that do not have a single clear orientation.
Shortest Distance = 2D
Shortest Distance = 3D

1 Reference point, 2 Guiding curve, 3 Tool path, 4 Shortest distance, 5 Tilt plane
Tilt Angle
Sets the tilt angle inside the tilt plane. How NX measures the value depends on the Tilt Rule and Shortest Distance settings.
Note:
NX limits the applied tilt angle to a range that is within the values you enter for Min Angle and Max Angle in the Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group.
Tilt Rule
Controls how NX measures the tilt angle inside the tilt plane. The tilt plane is defined by the +ZM axis and a line through the tool position that intersects the reference point on the selected guiding curve.
Toward Constant with Shortest Distance = 2D and 3D
Allows you to set a constant amount of tilt unless the tool axis must change either to avoid collisions or when moving to another cut area on the part.
Note:
When you use the toward constant tilt rule, the tool will not tilt until it is within the fan distance.
Toward Snap with Shortest Distance = 2D
Measures the tilt angle from the +ZM axis towards the line that intersects the reference point on the selected guiding curve. The tool axis snaps to the guiding curve when the tilt angle through the reference point on the curve is smaller than the specified Tilt Angle value. NX generates a 4+1 axis motion as long as the tool axis does not touch the guiding curve before the subsequent collision check.
Note:
The Tilt Angle value for this rule should be larger than zero, or NX will not tilt the tool axis prior to collision avoidance.
Tilt Angle = 30
1 Guiding curve
2 Line intersecting reference point on guiding curve
Note:
When you use the toward snap tilt rule, the tool will snap toward or away from the curve anywhere within the fan distance.
Away with Shortest Distance = 2D
Measures the tilt angle away from the line that intersects the reference point on the selected guiding curve towards the +ZM axis.
When Tilt Angle = 0, the tool axis intersects the reference point on the selected guiding curve.
Tilt Angle = 0
1 Guiding curve
2 Line intersecting reference point on guiding curve
When Tilt Angle is greater than 0, NX reduces the amount of tilt.
Tilt Angle = 30
1 Guiding curve
2 Line intersecting reference point on guiding curve
Through with Shortest Distance = 2D and 3D
The through tilt rule is the same as setting the tilt rule to Away, and the Tilt Angle to 0.0000. You cannot set a tilt angle when using this tilt rule.
Toward Point
Away from Point
Let you use a point to control whether the top of the tool holder tilts towards the point or away from the point. These settings define the orientation of the tilt plane around the +ZM axis.
Toward Point
Away from Point
Tilt Angle
Sets the tilt angle inside the tilt plane. How NX measures the value depends on the Tilt Rule setting.
Note:
NX limits the applied tilt angle to a range that is within the values you enter for Min Angle and Max Angle in the Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group.
Tilt Rule
Controls how NX measures the tilt angle inside the tilt plane. The tilt plane is defined by the +ZM axis and a line through the tool position that intersects the selected guiding point.
Toward Constant
Allows you to set a constant amount of tilt unless the tool axis must change either to avoid a collision or to move to another cut area on the part.
Note:
When you use the toward constant tilt rule, the tool will not tilt until it is within the fan distance.
Toward Snap
Measures the tilt angle from the +ZM axis towards the line intersecting the guiding point. The tool axis snaps to the guiding point when the tilt angle through the point is smaller than the specified Tilt Angle value. NX generates a 4+1 axis motion as long as the tool axis does not touch the guiding point before the subsequent collision check.
Note:
The Tilt Angle value for this rule should be larger than zero, or NX will not tilt the tool axis prior to collision avoidance.
Tool Tilt Method = Toward Snap, Tilt Angle = 30
1 Guiding point
2 Line intersecting the guiding point
Note:
When you use the toward snap tilt rule, the tool will snap toward or away from the point anywhere within the fan distance.
Away
Measures the tilt angle away from the line intersecting the guiding point towards the +ZM axis. When Tilt Angle = 0, the tool axis intersects the guiding point. This tool axis behavior is similar to that in variable-axis contouring operations, except for the following:
Collision avoidance
Limiting tilt to the minimum and maximum angle limits of the swinging/tilting machine axis
Smoothing
Tool Tilt Method = Away from Point, Tilt Angle = 0
1 Guiding point
2 Line intersecting guiding point
When Tilt Angle is greater than 0, NX reduces the amount of tilt.
Tool Tilt Method = Away from Point, Tilt Angle = 30
1 Guiding point
2 Line intersecting guiding point
Through
The through tilt rule is the same as setting the tilt rule to Away, and the Tilt Angle to 0.0000. You cannot set a tilt angle when using this tilt rule.
Fixed
Defines a fixed orientation using spherical angles, such as those used on a B-C dual axis fork head.
Tilt Angle defines the amount of tilting from the +ZM axis.
Angle from +XM defines the rotation of the tilt plane about the +ZM axis, and is measured from the +XM axis.
NX first rotates the tool axis around the +YM axis by the Tilt Angle value, then rotates the tool axis around the +ZM axis by the Angle from +XM value. NX rotates positive angles in the counterclockwise direction.
1 Positive Tilt Angle value
2 Positive Angle from +XM value
Tilt Smoothing group
Available for:
Fixed axis tool paths before you tilt the tool path to avoid collisions, when you set the Manual Tilting option to Keep Original.
Fixed or variable axis tool paths when you set the Manual Tilting option to User Defined, and the Tool Tilt Method option to Fixed.
Note:
When you tilt a 3-axis tool path, NX converts it to a 5-axis tool path.
Fan Distance
Sets the maximum distance along which the required tool axis orientation change will blend before and after a potential collision occurs.
Enter a larger value (1) for smoother motion of all axes. Enter a smaller value (2) to maintain the initial tool orientation longer.

Document Title: Tilt Tool Axis dialog box Collision Check/Avoidance tab
Document Body:
Collision Check/Avoidance group
Avoidance Method list
Specifies how to avoid collisions.
Tilt
Tilts the tool minimally to avoid collisions and returns the tool to the original tool axis orientation.
Note:
This option is available only for ball mills and spherical cutters.
Retract
Trims the tool path and retracts the tool.
Note:
When you use the Keep Original option to convert a 3-axis tool path to a 5-axis tool path, the following additional Collision Check/Avoidance options are available:
Inputs group
Avoidance Direction list
Specifies the direction that the tool uses to avoid collisions.
The option you select determines the available options that follow.
Rotate/Tilt
Tilts and rotates the tool simultaneously, relative to the Reference setting on the Tilting tab.
Lead/Tilt
Tilts the tool relative to the tool path, without rotating it.
Preferred Axis list
Specifies the axis that the tool uses to avoid collisions.
The option you select determines the available options that follow.
Equal
Tilts and rotates the tool in equal amounts.
Prefer Rotation
Rotates the tool, rather than tilts.
Prefer Tilt
Tilts the tool, rather than rotates.
Rotation group
Available when Avoidance Direction is set to Rotate/Tilt.
Rotary Axis
Lets you select one of the following options:
From Tilting
Rotates around the tool tilt axis.
+Zm
Rotates around the machine tool Z axis.
Specify Vector
Rotates around a vector that you specify from the list.
Dynamic
Rotates around a vector that you dynamically specify.
Max Increase/Decrease in Rotation
Lets you set a value for the maximum amount that the tool axis rotation amount can increase or decrease.
Lead group
Available when Avoidance Direction is set to Lead/Tilt.
Max Increase/Decrease in Lead
Lets you set a value for the maximum amount that the tool axis lead amount can increase or decrease.
Tilt group
Available when Avoidance Direction is set to Rotate/Tilt or Lead/Tilt.
Max Increase/Decrease in Tilt
Lets you set a value for the maximum amount that the tool axis tilt amount can increase or decrease.
Clearance group
Tool Holder
Tool Shank
Tool Neck
Set separate clearance zone values around the holder, shank, and neck of the tool.
1 Tool Holder
2 Tool Shank
3 Tool Neck
Note:
The default clearance values are taken from the original operation. When you set the clearance values, always set the minimum clearance distance required. Large clearance values may result in partial or unsmooth tool paths.
Tilt Clearance Angle
Specifies the angle used to clear the tool. NX adds the clearance angle to the Tool Holder, Tool Shank, and Tool Neck clearances.
Tilt Clearance Angle = 0
Tilt Clearance Angle > 0
The Tilt Clearance Angle value gives controllers with internal smoothing routines the ability to smooth the tool path. A higher value increases the freedom the controller has to smooth the tool path, but it decreases the amount of tilt available for NX to avoid collisions.
Note:
The time required for NX to find a collision-free tilting solution increases as the Tilt Clearance Angle value increases, and a large value can make it impossible for NX to find a collision free solution for the tool path. The Tilt Clearance Angle value should be as small as possible, but large enough to give the controller some freedom for the smoothing routine. When necessary, NX retracts the tool to avoid violating this value.

Document Title: Tilt Tool Axis dialog box Machine Tool Characteristics tab
Document Body:
Rotary Axis group
Main MCS Axis
Specifies the axis used to orient the tool. The default is the +ZM axis. If the rotary axis is not aligned with the +ZM axis of the machine tool coordinate system, select the appropriate axis.
Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group
Min Angle
Max Angle
Set the minimum and maximum angle to which the tool axis can tilt if contact occurs with the part. The angle is measured from the main MCS axis of the operation. The default values are 0 and 45 degrees. If the maximum angle is not enough to avoid a collision, NX trims the tool path and retracts the tool.
1 Maximum tool axis change angle
2 ZM-axis (default)
Maximum Tool Axis Change group
Degrees per Step
Sets the values used to control the maximum amount of swinging or tilting axis angle change between two tool positions on the output path. The default value is 2 degrees.
Max Step
Controls the linear distance, measured along the direction of the cut, between two tool positions on the output path. These are the points where NX calculates the tilt angle. The default value is 30 percent of the tool diameter.
A smaller step size creates more data points, and NX adjusts the tool axis tilt more frequently to avoid collisions.
A larger step size improves performance. However, when the step size is too large, NX may not have enough data points to avoid collisions.
The value you enter for Max Step applies as long as the resulting tool path does not violate the specified Intol and Outtol values for the operation.

Document Title: Avoid collisions after positioning a tool in an undercut
Document Body:
This example shows a method for positioning the ball portion of the tool in an undercut area and then tilting the tool axis to produce an optimized tool path without collisions. This example works for variable-axis drive methods. It also works for fixed-axis drive methods that use a projection vector other than the tool axis.
In a fixed-axis or variable-axis surface contouring operation dialog box, enter Check Tool in the Find box.
Clear the Check Tool above Ball check box.
To use the Tilt Tool Axis command to position a ball-end mill in an undercut area, you must deactivate collision checking in the operation.
Generate the operation and click OK to save it.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Tilt Tool Axis.
The Tilt Tool Axis dialog box is displayed.
(Optional) On the Tilting tab, in the Manual Tilting group, define a manual tilting method.
Define the required parameters.
On the Collision Check/Avoidance tab, specify the clearances around the tool.
On the Machine Tool Characteristics tab:
Specify the main MCS axis.
Specify the minimum and maximum Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits angles to control how far the tool axis can tilt if contact occurs with the part.
Specify the Maximum Tool Axis Change values to limit the amount of swinging or tilting axis angle change between two tool positions on the output path.
On the Tilting tab, in the Collision Check/Avoidance group, from the Avoidance Method list, select Tilt.
Click OK to start the collision check.
NX tilts the tool to avoid collisions while machining the undercut.

Currently, the postprocessor code decides whether the post is 3-axis, 4-axis, or 5-axis based on the operation type. When the tool axis is tilted in a 3-axis operation, the operation type does not change, but the tool path becomes a 5-axis tool path.
For the Post to convert from a fixed-axis operation to a tilting tool axis operation correctly, you must use the mom_tool_path_type MOM variable. This variable indicates the state of the tool path and has two states: 3-axis and 5-axis. The default is 3-axis, but the setting is modified based on the tool path.
The Post uses this setting to determine the kinematics.

Document Title: Tilt Tool Axis rotary and swinging axis control
Document Body:
When you use the Tilt Tool Axis command, NX must first identify the machine coordinate system (MCS) to define the rotary axis. For each operation, the machine coordinate system used depends on the following criteria:
If there is a valid kinematics model, NX uses the coordinate system of the Machine Zero junction.
If there is no kinematics model, and an MCS geometry group is defined, NX uses the coordinate system of the parent MCS. If more than one MCS geometry group is defined, NX uses the coordinate system of the highest level parent MCS. For this example, operations 1 and 2 use the coordinate system defined for MCS_MILL1. Operations 3 and 4 use the coordinate system defined for MCS_MILL2.
Operation Navigator — Geometry
MCS_MILL1
WORKPIECE1
OPERATION_1
MCS_MILL1_TILTED
OPERATION_2
MCS_MILL2
WORKPIECE2
OPERATION_3
MCS_MILL2_LOCAL
OPERATION_4
If MCS geometry groups are not defined, NX uses the absolute coordinate system.
If the rotary axis is not aligned with the +ZM axis of the machine tool coordinate system, use the Main MCS Axis option to select the appropriate axis.
Rotary and swinging axis limit control
After defining the rotary axis, you can use the options for rotary axis and swinging axis limits to:
Prevent tool paths that cannot be milled by your machine. To do this, use the Max Angle option. Usually this option controls your machine tool A or B limit.
For example, if your machine limits are between +30 and –115 degrees, set Max Angle to 115. Your post handles the minus sign.
For special machine configurations, such as a rotary table with a 45 degree incline, consult with Customer Support.
Guide NX to by-pass singularities. To do this, use the Min Angle option.
When the tool is almost aligned with the rotary axis, a small angular change in tool orientation may require a nearly 180 degree motion of the table. This condition is called a singularity.
(1) Motion is allowed within the Min Angle and Max Angle limits.
(2) Motion is not allowed beyond the Max Angle limit.
(3) Motion near the pole area is high-risk. The machine can do this motion, but the machining results are not optimal. This limit is set by the Min Angle option.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in dialog box
Tilt Tool Axis dialog box→Rotary Axis group and Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group

Document Title: Tool Tilt Method examples for Away from Curve and Away from Point
Document Body:
When Tool Tilt Method is set to Away from Curve or Away from Point, the top of the tool holder points away from the selected geometry.
The following examples show the tool tilting away from a curve or point, and use these common settings:
Tilt Rule = Away
Within the tilt plane, NX tilts the tool holder away from the defined curve.
Min Angle = 0
Max Angle = 90
Shortest Distance = 2D for the Away from Curve examples
NX defines the tilt plane by intersecting the guiding point, or a reference point on the guiding curve, with the tool axis.
The original operation is a Variable Contour operation using the Streamline drive method.
Away from Point example with different points selected
For the same Tilt Angle setting, the tool inclination changes depending on the location of your guiding point. This example shows the tool inclination for the same Tilt Angle value when the guiding point is at points 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Tilt Angle = 0
Away from Point example with different Tilt Angle values
For the same guiding point, the tool orientation changes depending on your Tilt Angle value. This example shows the tool orientation for the same guiding point when the Tilt Angle value is set to 0, 10, 20, and 30.
Away from Point examples with different tool positions
These examples show how, for the same guiding point and Tilt Angle value, the tool inclination changes as the tool moves down the part.
Tilt Angle = 0, Max Angle = 90
Tilt Angle = 60, Max Angle = 90
Away from Curve example with different curves selected
When you set Tool Tilt Method to Away from Curve, the top of the tool holder points away from the selected curve. For the same Tilt Angle setting, the tool inclination changes depending on the Z level of your guiding curve. This example shows the tool inclination for the same Tilt Angle value when the guiding curve is at levels 1, 2, 3, and 4.
Away from Curve example with different Tilt Angle values
For the same guiding curve, the tool orientation changes depending on your Tilt Angle value. These examples show the tool orientation for the same guiding curve when the Tilt Angle value is set to 0 and 15.
Tilt Angle = 0
Tilt Angle = 15

Document Title: Tool Tilt Method examples for Toward Curve
Document Body:
Tilt Tool Axis settings:
Tool Tilt Method = Toward Curve
The tool holder points towards the defined curve.
Shortest Distance = 2D
Toward Curve example with different Tilt Angle values
Tilt Rule = Away
NX tilts the tool away from the defined curve, and reduces the maximum tilt by the specified Tilt Angle value.
Original tool path
1 Defined curve
Max Angle = 45
Tilt Angle = 0
NX tilts the tool within the tilt plane to 45°, which is the maximum amount allowed.
Max Angle = 45
Tilt Angle = 15
NX reduces the amount of tool tilt by 15°, measured from the defined curve towards +ZM.
Tool axis transitions are smooth as the tool cuts the part.
Tilt Angle = 0
Tilt Angle = 15
Toward Curve example with different Tilt Angle values
Tilt Rule = Toward Snap
NX tilts the tool toward the defined curve, at the specified Tilt Angle value.
Original tool path
1 Defined curve
Tilt Angle = 10
NX tilts the tool within the tilt plane to 10°, measured from +ZM.
Tilt Angle = 25
NX tilts the tool within the tilt plane to 25°, measured from +ZM.
The tool inclination becomes smaller than the defined Tilt Angle value as the tool axis snaps to the curve or point.

Document Title: Tilt the tool axis manually before the collision check
Document Body:
You can manually tilt the entire tool path before NX performs the collision check and creates avoidance moves.
Deactivate collision checking in the operation.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Tilt Tool Axis.
In the Tilt Tool Axis dialog box, from the Manual Tilting list, select User Defined.
Set the other Manual Tilting options.
Click OK to process the new tool path.

Document Title: Collision Check/Avoidance parameters for tool tilt axis
Document Body:
You can use the options in the Tilt Tool Axis dialog box to control the tilt method when avoiding collisions.
The following examples show how you use the Preferred Tilt from Fixed Axis and Max Distance Between values and the Maintain Current Tilt between Collisions check box to control the tilt of the tool axis to avoid collisions, and the tool tilt between collisions.
Preferred Tilt from Fixed Axis = 0.0000°
Maintain Current Tilt between Collisions
1. The tool path begins with the tool axis fixed in its original orientation.
2. The tool tilts the minimal amount possible to avoid the first collision.
Note:
The end view is sectioned in this image for clarity.
3. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the first collision avoidance.
4. The tool tilts the minimal amount possible to avoid the second collision.
5. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the second collision avoidance.
Preferred Tilt from Fixed Axis = 20.0000°
Maintain Current Tilt between Collisions
1. The tool path begins with the tool axis fixed in its original orientation.
2. The tool tilts the preferred 20° to avoid the first collision.
3. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the first collision avoidance.
4. The tool tilts the preferred 20° to avoid the second collision.
5. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the second collision avoidance.
Preferred Tilt from Fixed Axis = 20.0000°
Maintain Current Tilt between Collisions
Max Distance Between = 10.0000 in
1. The tool path begins with the tool axis fixed in its original orientation.
2. The tool tilts the preferred 20° to avoid the first collision.
3. The tool maintains the current tilt between collisions because the Max Distance Between value of 10.000 is equal to or greater than the actual distance between collisions.
4. The tool maintains the preferred 20° to avoid the second collision.
5. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the second collision avoidance.
Preferred Tilt from Fixed Axis = 20.0000°
Maintain Current Tilt between Collisions
Max Distance Between = 5.0000 in
1. The tool path begins with the tool axis fixed in its original orientation.
2. The tool tilts the preferred 20° to avoid the first collision.
3. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the first collision avoidance because the Max Distance Between value of 5.000 is less than the actual distance between collisions.
4. The tool uses the preferred 20° degree tilt to avoid the second collision.
5. The tool returns to the original tool axis after the second collision avoidance.

Document Title: Tilt the tool axis using a guiding point
Document Body:
This example shows how to use a guiding point to control the tool axis tilt. The sample operation is a variable-axis surface contouring operation with the following settings:
Drive Method = Streamline
Tool Axis = Relative to Vector
Tilt Angle = –25
Notice that the tool collides in the confined space between the walls. You will use the Tilt Tool Axis command to correct this problem.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Tilt Tool Axis.
The Tilt Tool Axis dialog box is displayed.
Set the options as shown.
Manual Tilting group:
Manual Tilting = User Defined
Tool Tilt Method = Away from Point
Tilt Rule = Away
Tilt Angle = 0
Collision check/Avoidance group:
Avoidance Method = Tilt
Clearance group:
Tilt Clearance Angle = 0.5
Enter a value only if your controller has internal smoothing routines. A higher value increases the freedom the controller has to smooth the tool path, but it decreases the amount of tilt available for NX to avoid collisions. Enter a value that is as small as possible, but large enough to give the controller some freedom for the smoothing routine.
Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group:
Min Angle = 0
Max Angle = 90
Note:
Enter values within the effective limits of your machine tool. Enter positive values. Your post handles the minus sign.
In the Manual Tilting group, click Specify Point and select the point shown.
Click OK to process the new tool path.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Verify.
The Tool Path Visualization dialog box is displayed.
Notice that the tool axis intersects the selected guiding point.
Move the Animation slider to 2 or 3 and click Play .
Notice that initially the tool axis continues to intersect the selected guiding point unless it must tilt more or less to avoid collisions. As the tool moves down the part, the angle between +ZM and the tool axis increases until it equals 90 degrees, which is the Max Angle value.

Document Title: Tilt the tool axis from its original orientation
Document Body:
This example shows how to tilt the tool axis only when it is necessary to avoid collisions. The sample operation is a variable-axis surface contouring operation with the following settings:
Drive Method = Streamline
Tool Axis = Relative to Vector
Tilt Angle = –25
In the following tool path, notice that the tool collides in the confined space between the walls. You will use the Tilt Tool Axis command to correct this problem.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Tilt Tool Axis.
The Tilt Tool Axis dialog box is displayed.
Set the options as shown.
Manual Tilting group:
Manual Tilting = Keep Original
Collision check/Avoidance group:
Avoidance Method = Tilt
Clearance group:
Tilt Clearance Angle = 0.5
Enter a value only if your controller has internal smoothing routines. A higher value increases the freedom the controller has to smooth the tool path, but it decreases the amount of tilt available for NX to avoid collisions. Enter a value that is as small as possible, but large enough to give the controller some freedom for the smoothing routine.
Swinging/Tilting Axis Limits group:
Min Angle = 0
Max Angle = 45
Note:
Enter values within the effective limits of your machine tool. Enter positive values. Your post handles the minus sign.
Click OK to process the new tool path.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Verify.
The Tool Path Visualization dialog box is displayed.
Move the Animation slider to 2 or 3 and click Play .
Notice that the tool axis maintains its original orientation unless it must tilt more or less to avoid collisions.

The Tool Path Divide function divides an existing operation into two or more operations, each limited to a maximum cutting time or distance, or to one or more selected motions.
Note:
Tool Path Divide is not available for Sequential Milling operations.
When non-cutting moves (NCM) are in the set of tool path motions to divide, they are not split. Instead, NX either trims back to the previous cut motion if the cut plane is before the NCM midpoint, or advances to the next cut motion if the cut plane is after the NCM midpoint.
Parameters
Divide Method
Lets you specify the method for dividing the operation.
Cutting Time
Lets you specify a maximum cutting time for each sub-operation in the Minutes box.
Cutting Distance
Lets you specify a maximum distance to be traveled for each sub-operation in the Distance box.
Selected Motions
Lets you select certain tool path motions for each sub-operation using the Select Path Segment command.
Tolerance Percent
Lets you specify a tolerance percentage for either the Cutting Time or Cutting Distance, to provide the software flexibility for selecting an appropriate dividing point.
Non Cutting Moves
Engage/Retract
Linear
Lift and Plunge
Smooth
None
Length
Lets you specify an engage/retract length.
Height
Lets you specify an engage/retract height.
Transfer at
Direct
Clearance
Lowest Safe Z
Smooth
Plane
Output Between Paths
Lets you specify or edit User Defined Events for the start or end of the path.
Edit an operation created by Divide
After dividing the tool path, you can edit the new operation to change the following for tool changes:
Tool length
Note:
The other tool parameters must remain the same. The Tool list within the operation's dialog box only displays appropriate tools. Also, you can only drag the operation to an appropriate tool in the Operation Navigator, Machine Tool view.
Tool output
Tool change settings
Start and end of path events
The program
Caution:
If you change anything that affects the tool path shape or output in the original operation, you must Generate, and the Divide operations will be deleted.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Right-click an operation→Tool Path→Divide

Use the Divide By Holder command in a semi-finishing or finishing operation to split the tool path to avoid collisions and machine the entire cut area. You can split the tool path between tools of different lengths with different tool holders, but the cutter must have the same shape and diameter. Dividing data can then be modified and reapplied without having to regenerate the entire operation.
Initial Surface Contouring operation
Tool path divided into 3 using Divide by Holder
Divide by Holder paths
Shortest tool
Medium length tool
Longest tool
The Divide by Holder command lets you predefine a sequence of tools and their specific parameters. NX stores the data in the base operation. You can copy and paste the base operation into the current part or you can import the tools and parameters as a template from one part file into another part file. The operation brings all the divided holder data with it.
When using a Zig cut pattern, you can define overlaps, minimum cut length, and other controls, by using the Divide at Collision option. This operation recognizes part geometry and check geometry but ignores Blank geometry and the IPW.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
mill_contour operations Zlevel and Fixed Axis that contain a tool path. Operation tool with a holder and or a shank, with Check Tool and Holder turned off.
Zig and Zigzag cut patterns.
Command
Divide by Holder
Operation Navigator — Program Order View
Right click the cutting operation→Tool Path→Divide by Holder

Gouge and Collision Checking
Gouge Check
Checks for tool gouges using the parameters set in the Gouge Settings group.
Collision Check against Part
Checks for collisions between the tool and the part.
Collision Checks against IPW
Reports holder IPW and tool rapid motion IPW collisions
Tool shape for Checking
Tools Shape
Tool Parameters
Uses the parameters for the tool, shank, and holder in gouge checking and collision calculations.
Solid Assembly
If an assembly model of the solid tool and holder are available, NX uses the solid bodies in gouge checking and collision calculations. Otherwise, you get a warning message and the tool parameters are used.
Gouge Settings
Automatic
Uses the minimum value for part stock, wall stock, and floor stock that is defined in the cutting parameters for each operation that you check. If you have non-uniform stock, NX displays a warning.
Note:
NX does not display this warning in Area Mill, Zlevel, and Cavity Mill operations. Non-uniform gouge check is supported for these operations.
User Defined
Makes the Gouge Check Stock box available for input. You can input a value for one time use.
The value reverts to the automatic value that NX selects from the operation parameters when you next open the dialog box.
Gouge Check Stock
Displays the read-only stock value when Automatic is selected, or lets you specify a stock value when User Defined is selected.
List Non-Uniform Stock
Opens the Information window which lists the minimum value for part stock for all the selected operations.

For Area Mill, Zlevel, and Cavity Mill operations, the window also lists the following:
The Final Stock that is defined in the Custom Data for the part geometry and for the cut area.
The custom stock that is defined by different Part Side Stock and Part Floor Stock values.
The check stock that is defined by a value that is different from the Part Stock.
Stop when Limit Reached
Stops the tool path from processing when a gouge or collision is detected.
Maximum Limit
Available when the Stop When Limit Reached check box is selected.
Limits the maximum number of gouges and collisions allowed before the tool path stops processing.
NX considers the tool neck in gouge checks for the following.
5-axis operations.
3-axis operations with undercuts.
Operations where the tool neck diameter is greater than the cutting diameter.
Note:
NX displays message boxes to inform you about the following:
Negative part offsets that are greater than the tool radius.
Tools other than milling and drilling tools.
You can choose whether to cancel the check, or to continue to run with some limitations.

In addition to gouges, you can also use the Tool Path Report command to display findings in robotics operations such as limit violations, unwinds, and reach failures.
Note:
The new Path Colors Configurator dialog box allows you to change the color for each type of finding by clicking the swatch in the Findings list.
A Finding is the answer to a yes or no question that can be asked of a tool path event. For example: Is this tool path gouging?
You can use the Tool Path Report command to create an interactive report for a tool path. When you select a motion in the report, the tool positions itself to the location in the graphic window, or you can select a location in the graphic window, and the corresponding motion is selected in the report.
  ZLEVEL_PROFILE
     Level-1
     Level-2
     CIRCLE/CX0.000,CY0.000,CZ-25.095,EX-151.440,EY28.533,EZ-25.095
     Level-3
     Level-4
     Level-5
     Level-6
The Tool Path Report dialog box displays the tool path motion in each operation in a program group. You can expand or collapse the hierarchy to display or hide the individual tool motions.

The columns in the report can be turned on or off, reordered, or resized.
These columns are available for machining operations:
CL
Level/Page
Feed Rate
Motion Type
Findings
Machine Code
These columns are available for multi-axis deposition operations:
Width
Height

Tip:
You can select a pair or group of consecutive levels in an operation, and then shift to the previous or next set using the Selection Shift arrows.
By default, NX shows all motions, and highlights gouging motions in red.
This shows the same tool path, with the non-cutting motions hidden. It is easier to see the gouging motions.
Select an individual gouging motion to highlight it in orange.
Select multiple gouging motions to highlight them.
Using Tool Sweep to examine gouge areas
You can use the tool sweep commands to display gouges as physical features in the part geometry.
When a gouging motion occurs in a tool path, it appears in the list of gouges in the dialog box, and is displayed as a gouge in the graphics window as shown below:
Use the Tool Sweep command to create a group of solid bodies, which represents the entire area that the tool occupies as it moves through the tool path.
Use the Intersect with Part command to subtract the tool sweep features from the part geometry, to see the extent of a gouge.
Note:
You can use the Sweep Tool and Holder option to include the holder geometry along with the tool.
Tip:
The sweep tool geometry features are saved as groups in the Part Navigator. They can be deleted when they are no longer needed.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Ribbon Bar
Display group→Tool Path Report

Tool Path Report
Show Findings
The Show Findings button groups consecutive motions that share a finding, such as a gouge, into a folder in the report.
Reset Report
The Reset Report button returns the Tool Path Records list back to the chronological state.
Tool Path Records
Name/Index list
A tree structure shows the name of one or more selected tool paths.
  ROUGH
  Level-1
GOTO/X212.460,Y30.162,Z-1.600
CIRCLE/CX73.247,CY151.395,CZ-1.600,EX223.439,EY206.410,EZ-1.600
CIRCLE/CX155.469,CY57.729,CZ-1.600,EX230.300,EY203.078,EZ-1.600
GOTO/X245.300,Y195.356,Z-1.600
  ZLEVEL_PROFILE
  Level-1
CIRCLE/CX0.000,CY0.000,CZ-24.895,EX-19.707,EY153.126,EZ-24.895
  Level-2
CIRCLE/CX0.000,CY0.000,CZ-25.095,EX-19.626,EY152.849,EZ-25.095
Selection Shift
Selection Shift
Navigate up or down through the selected levels by clicking the appropriate arrow.
Tool Sweep
Create Tool Sweep 
Lets you create a tool sweep, which represents the entire area that the tool occupies as it moves through the tool path.
The tool sweeps are saved as features in groups in the Part Navigator.
Note:
A tool sweep will not be computed if the path contains tool motion that creates a self-shadowing shape.
Intersect with Part 
Lets you intersect the tool sweep area with the part geometry to see the extent of a gouge.
The gouges are saved as features in groups in the Part Navigator.
Sweep Tool and Holder 
Lets you include the holder geometry and tool geometry in the tool sweep.
Settings
Non-motion Events
Displays non-motion events such as limit violations. It also displays events that occur before level one, such as the start of a path event.
The events are maintained within a single session. That means you see the same information, even if you open and close the tool path report multiple times within a single session or open another part within that session.
Display
Controls the way NX displays selected gouges.
All
Displays the entire tool path, and the all motions.
Selected Only
Displays only the selected motions.
Levels or Pages
Displays the findings motions only.

The Path Colors Configurator dialog box allows you to define the colors of findings and motions in tool paths.
The Finding Colors node lets you select a color for each type of finding in the tool path.
  Finding Colors node
Gouges
A gouge occurs when the cutting portion of the tool removes material from the design part in excess of the tolerance settings.
Singularities
When the tool is almost aligned with the rotary axis, a small angular change in tool orientation may require a nearly 180-degree motion or larger motion of the tool or table. This condition is called a singularity.
Soft Limit Violations
Safety factor limitations defined by the user.
Hard Limit Violations
Physical limitations of the machine.
Unwinds
When the machine cannot rotate past its limits, it must rotate in the opposite direction to get back within limits. That rotation is an unwind.
Collisions
A collision occurs in a program when two machine components, defined in the collision pairs, collide.
Reach Failures
When the machine cannot physically reach a target location, that is a reach failure.
Variable Limit Violations
A violation of a definable limit.
Tool Holder Collisions
When NX checks ToolHolder, Tool Shank, and Tool Neck distances to the tool holder shape to ensure a safe clearance from the geometry, it is checking for tool holder collisions.
Tool Rapid Collisions
The cutting part of a tool contacts the IPW in rapid ( G0) motion.
  The Motion Output Colors node lets you select a color for each motion output type.
  Motion Output Colors node
Line
Assign the color of a line motion.
Arc
Assign the color of an arc motion.
Other
Assign the color of a heliz, spline, or other motion.

Use the Report Shortest Tool option to calculate the minimum tool length that avoids tool holder or shank collisions. When you use the shortest tool possible, your cutting tool setup is generally more rigid, which can extend tool life.
When NX calculates the shortest tool length:
NX uses part geometry, blank geometry, and check geometry.
NX supports the shank as well as the holder.
NX considers the holder and shank clearance.
If both the holder and shank are defined for a tool, NX reports the shortest tool that satisfies both the holder and shank clearance values.
Changing the Tool Insertion offset value does not affect the shortest tool value.
The operation parameters and tool path do not change. You determine which tool to use based on the reported value.
The recommended value displays in the Report Shortest Tool group in the operation's dialog box, and in the Shortest Tool Length column in the Operation Navigator. The recommended value is an approximation. In all cases, NX rounds up the reported value to 1 decimal point for metric parts and 2 decimal points for inch parts. For example:
120.206 mm = 120.3 mm
30.206 in = 30.21 in
NX does not display or update values in the following conditions:
The current holder and shank parameters do not cause a collision at any tool length.
The generated tool path has missing regions.
The length displayed is either Unknown or the previously calculated shortest tool value.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Cavity Mill, Adaptive Milling, Plunge Milling, or Rest Milling operation
The tool used in the operation must have a shank or holder defined.
The operation must have a generated tool path.
Operation Navigator
Right-click the operation→Tool Path→Report Shortest Tool
Location in dialog box
Find→Report Shortest Tool

Use the Calculate Volume Removed option to calculate and view the material removal measurements in the Removed Volume and Material Removal Rate columns in the Operation Navigator for any milling operation.
You can select one or more milling operations, or select associated geometry, tool, method, or program groups to calculate and view the material removal measurements.
You can use this option to get an estimate of both the life of the tool and its cutting productivity.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
The Removed Volume and Material Removal Rate columns must be selected in the Column Configuration list in the Configure Columns dialog box.
The blank must be defined for the in-process workpiece (IPW).
The tool path must be generated for the milling operation.
Operation Navigator
Right-click the milling operation or associated geometry, tool, method, or program group and choose Tool Path→Calculate Removed Volume

The Tool Path Editor allows you to make corrections or modifications to a generated tool path. You can:
Select multiple motions from the graphics region or from the motion list.
Delete selected motions.
Edit a single motion different ways: double-click, right-click and choose Edit, or click
Gouge check the entire path, a range of motions, or multiple motions that are not connected. Gouge checking supports:
All motions, including the edited motions.
All milling and drilling tool types and tool holders.
Reverse the entire path or a range of motions.
Copy and paste sections of the tool path from one area of the part to another.
Move motions.
Edit multiple feed rates at the same time.
Extend or trim motions.
Animate the tool path.
The Tool Path Editor displays graphical feedback as you insert, modify and delete tool path commands.
Warning:
An edited tool path loses its associativity.
The Tool Path Editor is not available for operations containing Nurbs.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Right-click an operation→Tool Path→Edit
Location in dialog box
Tool Path Editor dialog box→Edit Actions group

In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Tool Path→Edit.
In the Tool Path Editor dialog box, or from the graphics region, select the part of the tool path you want to edit.
Choose the type of edit to perform.
Define the parameters needed for the edit.

Sub-Operations
Add New Path Event
Lets you create a new sub-operation. you can then select the subop from the graphics region or from the list.
Edit lets you modify the Move Definition, Motion, and Settings options for the selected sub-operation.
Delete, Cut, Copy, and Paste let you delete, copy, or re-order a single subop or a range of subops.
Cut and paste behavior here is similar to the Operation Navigator. New events are added below the event you select.
Note:
Cut is only available if you can delete the selected segment without affecting the next segment. For example:
If you select the segment before a circle move, Cut is not available because the selected segment defines the start of the circle move.
If you select the segment before a circle move and also select the circle move, Cut is available.
When you select the operation name to add an event, the new event is added at the bottom of the list. If you need to move the operation to the top of the list, see Move an operation to the top of a group.
Sub-Operation/path event list
Displays the Name and Feedrate of tool path events for the operation you are editing. The motions of selected events are highlighted in the graphics window. The tool displays at the last cutter location.
The list also includes level markers so that you can see when the tool path moves from one cutting level to another.
Selection Filter
Lets you select similar tool path segments. All segments that are not within the specified type become non-selectable.
All
Lets you select all tool path segments either individually, or within a defined range.
First Cut/Last Cut
Lets you select only the tool path segments available for the Extend tool path action.
A First Cut motion is the first cut motions after an engage or stepover for a zig or zig-zag cut type. A Last Cut motion is the last cut motion before a retract or stepover motion.
Edited
Lets you select only the tool path segments that have been edited since last entering the Tool Path Editor.
Spikes/Plunge Motions
Lets you select only tool path segments that form spikes or plunges.
Graphics Selection
Controls how you select motions from the graphics window.
Single
Lets you select individual events.
Range
Lets you select two events to define a single range.
Between Rapids
Lets you select the motion between two rapids. You can continue to select additional events.
Cut Level
Lets you select a complete cut level. You can continue to select additional cut levels.
Edit Actions
Move
Requires selecting a motion.
Lets you move an existing motion to another position.
Note:
You can dynamically move tool path motions in the graphics window.
Extend
Available for first_cut/last_cut motion types of Zig and Zig-Zag Surface Contouring operations only
Extends out the cutting pass of a Zig or Zig-Zag type of cut for a surface contouring operation.
Note:
Extend is not available if the operation is marked as edited.
Extend is not available for Flow Cut operations.
Trim
Surface contouring operations only
Lets you trim away unwanted portions of a tool path.
Reverse
Lets you reverse the direction of certain tool paths. This option is designed primarily for milling operations. It does not apply to helical motions, or to the following operations:
Point to Point
Face Milling
Lathe
Wire EDM.
When a tool path is reversed, the motion types of the new path are switched as follows.
Engage <> Retract
Approach <> Return
FROM point <> GOHOME
If the tool path has multiple cut layers that cut from the top to the bottom, then the reversed tool path will cut from the bottom to the top. The reversed tool path will also only contain one set of first cut motions, no matter how many first cut motions the tool path had before it was reversed.
Analyze Tool Path
Gouge and Collision Check
Lets you check the tool path for gouges.
Not available if the software cannot perform a check. This is usually due to missing part or blank geometry.
Checks the entire tool path, if no motions are selected.
If motions are selected, these motions are checked.
Tip:
To abort the gouge check, click OK in the Work in Progress message box.
Options
Tool Display
Lets you choose how to display the tool in the graphics window:
On displays a wire frame outline of the tool.
Point displays a point for the tool at its current position.
Axis displays a line for the tool axis at its current position.
Solid displays a solid body representation of the tool at its current position.
Assembly displays an NX part that represents the tool assembly.
Note:
 If a part file for the tool assembly does not exist, a solid body is displayed instead.
None does not display the tool.
Animation lets you check the tool path motion as you edit the tool path.
Animation controls
Lets you view the tool movement from GOTO point to GOTO point along the edited tool path. There is no interpolation between points.
Tip:
To undo a single editing mistake, press Ctrl+Z without exiting the Tool Path Editor dialog box.

Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
For information on options for specifying points and vectors see:
Point dialog box
Vector dialog
Move Parameters
Motion
Specifies how to define the motion.
To a Point
Moves the tool to a specified point.
For information on options for specifying points, see: Point dialog box.
Delta
Moves the tool an incremental (delta) distance along the WCS axes.
Enter a positive distance to move the tool along the positive direction of the axes. Enter a negative distance to move the tool in the negative direction. The default values are 0.000 for all axis.
Dynamic
Displays a CSYS manipulator in the graphics window that is used to move the tool path motions.
Settings
Move Start Point
Automatically moves the entire motion.
Clear the check box to only move the end position of the current motion. The end position of the previous move still defines the starting position of the current move.
Transform adjacent Circles
Automatically modifies tangent circular motions to match your change.
Note:
If a circle is moved out of plane, and Transform adjacent circles is on, the adjacent circle will become non-planar.

Document Title: Tool Path Editor — Create Subop options
Document Body:
Type lets you select the subop to create.
For each motion subop:
The move defines an end position for the tool.
The end position of the previous subop defines the starting position of the current subop.
Points or vectors defined by selecting geometry are associative to the selected geometry and will update as the geometry changes.
Points or vectors that do not reference geometry are not associative.
Positive, negative, and zero values are valid for input boxes.
The end position of the first motion subop serves as the first known position for the rest of the tool path.
Linear Move To Point
Moves the tool to a specified point.
Linear Move Along Vector
Moves the tool along a direction vector for a specified distance.
Linear Delta Move
Moves the tool an incremental (delta) distance along either the WCS axes or the active MCS axes.
Select either WCS or MCS and enter a positive distance to move the tool along the positive direction of the axes. Enter a negative distance to move the tool in the negative direction. The default values are 0.000 for all axis.
Circular Move
Moves the tool in a circle around an axis defined by a vector and a center point. The circle lies in a plane that is normal to the axis vector. The software controls the radius.
Machine Control
Adds non-motion information to the tool path, such as a machine control event (UDE).
Include Machine Control with the motion subops to control the machine tool and to carry operator instructions.
Move Definition
Lets you define the move. The options available vary depending on the subop Type selected.
Motion
Motion Type
Lets you specify the tool motion. For example, Rapid, or Cut.
New motion subops have a default Motion Type assigned. Multiple subops created sequentially using the Apply button are assigned the same Motion Type and feed rate until you change the options or click OK.
Feed Rate Type
Lets you choose the default feed rate for the motion type or enter a Custom feed rate value for this subop. The units of the custom feed rate are the same as for the specified Motion Type.

Document Title: Tool Path Editor — Range Selection options
Document Body:
Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Range Selection
Selection Method
Range
Lets you select two events to define a single range.
Between Rapids
Lets you select the motion between two or rapids. You can continue to select additional events.
Cut Level
Lets you select a complete cut level. You can continue to select additional cut levels.
Preview
Preview
Highlights the selected motions as you select them.
Display
Highlights all selected motions.

Document Title: Tool Path Editor — Extend Cuts options
Document Body:
Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Extend Direction
Reverse Direction
Reverses the direction of the extension.
Extend Parameters
The options available depend on the Method selected.
Method
Specifies how to extend the motion.
Linear
Arc
Linear, Arc
Arc, Linear
Linear, Arc, Linear

Document Title: Gouge Check dialog box (Tool Path Editor)
Document Body:
Gouge Check
Check for Tool Holder Collisions
Activates additional collision checking that includes the tool holder.
Gouge Check
Starts the gouge check on the selected segments of the tool path.
Each gouge reported is a set of continuous tool path segments.
Clearance
Specify Plane
Lets you specify a clearance plane to remove gouges. You must specify a clearance plane to make the gouge removal options available.
Gouge Removal
Lets you select and remove gouges.
Select all Gouges
Selects all gouges in the tool path.
Select Gouge
The previous and next arrows let you select individual gouges.
Move to Clearance Plane
Moves the selected gouge or gouges to the clearance plane specified in the Clearance group.
NX considers the tool neck in gouge checks for the following.
5-axis operations.
3-axis operations with undercuts.
