Operations where the tool neck diameter is greater than the cutting diameter.
Note:
Gouge checking displays message boxes to inform you about the following:
Negative part offsets that are greater than the tool radius.
Tools other than milling and drilling tools.
You can choose whether to cancel, or to continue to run with some limitations.

Spikes
A spike is two consecutive cut motions. A valid spike must meet the following conditions, as illustrated below:
The angle (Alpha) defined by the two consecutive cut motions should be less than 40 degrees.
The shorter of the two minimum distance measurements (a and b) between the non-common endpoint and the opposite motion segment must be less than 50 X (intol+outtol).
Illustration of a spike
Plunges
A plunge is a pair of steep motions with one or more cut motions in between. A valid plunge must meet the following conditions, as illustrated below:
Motions m2 and m5 must be valid steep motions, which requires:
The angle between the motion segment and the tool axis (a, b) is less than 2.5 degrees.
The total drop or rise distance (d1, d2 ) is greater than (INTOL +OUTTOL) / 2.
The straight line distance (x) between the lowest points in the steep motions must be less than the maximum radius of the tool.
The length of motions m2 and m5 must be greater than the part tolerance.
Illustration of a plunge

When you select from the Tool Path Editor dialog box, you can:
Click to select a single event line. If the line corresponds to a tool motion, the tool displays at this location. For other types of events, the tool moves to the tool motion preceding the selected line.
Control-click to select events in any random order from the listing. You can deselect an event simply by clicking at the selected line.
Shift-click to select a range of contiguous events on the tool path.
When you select from the graphics region, you can use selection preferences and the Top Border bar for some help.
Generally, multiple selection works best with the Selection Rule option set to Inside/Crossing.
To set multiple selection preferences, choose Menu→Preferences→Selection→Selection Preferences dialog box→Multi-Select group.
The default Mouse Gesture option is Rectangle. If needed, you can change this option to Lasso.
Use Deselect All on the Top Border bar to clear the tool path selection.

Trim Tool Paths lets you trim away unwanted portions of a generated tool path. This is useful as a temporary fix to keep the cutter out of unwanted areas that are identified by shop personnel after the tool path is released for production.
Original tool path
Trimming plane selected
Trimmed tool path

Document Title: Tool Path Editor — Trim Tool Paths options
Document Body:
Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Trim Geometry
Geometry
Lets you define the area to trim.
Plane
Lets you define a trimming plane.
The arrow points to the side to be trimmed.
Tip:
To make the trim plane and direction arrow clearer in complex tool paths, refresh the screen.
Line in View
Lets you specify a line to define a trimming plane normal to the current view plane.
Tip:
To get the trimming plane that you want, orient your work view before you trim.
Boundary
Lets you define a boundary by selecting faces, curves, or points.
When Boundary is selected, Specify Trim Boundary is available to open theTrim Boundaries dialog box.
Permanent Boundary
Lets you select a previously defined permanent boundary.
Caution:
This option trims the entire tool path to the permanent boundary. Use another option to trim selected movements.
For more information, see Permanent Boundaries.
Selection in View
Lets you trim a tool path by selecting an area in the current graphics view plane. The selection is projected to the tool path along the view normal vector.
The selection tools include:
Rectangle
Lasso
Polygon
Tip:
To add the polygon Select by Polygon method, use the search box in the top right corner of NX to search for Select by Polygon . Right-click and choose Add to Top Border Bar. You can further customize the Top Border bar by dragging the icon into the Selection list.
Non Cutting Moves
Engage/Retract
Linear
Begins engage and retract moves the specified length distance from the start of cutting moves. You can specify additional parameters for Swing Angle and Ramp Angle.
Lift and Plunge
Produces engages and retracts with vertical moves.
Enter a Height value.
Smooth
Creates transfers with arc motions. If their is not enough clearance at the specified length and height, NX calculates a safe move.
Length
Specifies the target length of the transition.
Height
Specifies the target height of the transition.
Transfer at
Lets you specify the type of transfer motions.
Direct
Connects trimmed motions directly to the next cutting motion.
Clearance
Uses the clearance plane from the operation.
Lowest Safe Z
Transfers at the specified Distance value.
Smooth
Creates a default smooth transfer with no selectable options.
Plane
Lets you specify a plane for transfer motions.

Document Title: Tool Path Editor — Trim Boundaries dialog box
Document Body:
Main tab
Filter Type
Face Boundary
Lets you select a single planar face of a sheet or solid body. The interior edges are determined by the Ignore Holes and Ignore Islands options.
Curve Boundary
Open the Create Boundary dialog box where you can specify existing curves or edges.
Point Boundary
Lets you create a closed boundary from a sequence of defined points.
Point Method
Available when Point Boundary is selected.
Lets you filter your selection by types of points.
Chaining
Available when Curve Boundary is selected.
Lets you use the legacy curve chaining method to choose a boundary.
The following are available when Face Boundary is selected.
Class Selection
Lets you use filtering methods such as object type, color, and layer to choose a face.
Non-planar faces are selectable, but you will get an error message.
Ignore Holes
Ignores holes in the selected face.
Ignore Islands
Ignores islands in the selected face.
Ignore Chamfers
Creates boundaries that extend to include chamfers, fillets, and rounds adjacent to the selected faces.
Plane
Available when Curve Boundary or Point Boundary is selected.
Manual
Lets you define a boundary plane using the Plane Subfunction.
Automatic
Creates the boundary plane from the first two curves/edges or the first three points selected. Creates the boundary plane on the XC-YC plane if it is not possible to define a plane using the selected curves, edges, or points.
Trim Side
Inside
Outside
The following are available after one boundary is defined.
Remove Last
Removes the previously completed boundary.
Create Next Boundary
Begins a new boundary definition, the same as Add New in newer dialog boxes.
Custom Data tab
Offset
Lets you specify an offset value for the boundary, for example, to account for a casting thickness.

Document Title: Using a boundary with the Area Milling drive method
Document Body:
Use the Specify Trim Boundaries command to control cut areas in contouring operations that use the Area Milling drive method. You can isolate and remove areas of the tool path to avoid clamps and fixtures, or to remove all but an isolated area of tool path that requires further machining.
Contain the cut area by one or more loops of bounding objects. Boundaries can be edges, any type of curves including sketch curves, or points. Boundaries are projected onto the part surfaces along the normal vector of the boundary plane.
Edge as boundary
Cut Region
Boundary edge, trim inside
Tool Path
Sketch as boundary
Boundary sketch, trim outside
Tool Path
Closing gaps
You can leave gaps between curves or edges. The gaps are automatically closed by straight lines.
The arrows indicate closed gaps, boundary trim outside
Tool Path
Nested boundaries, no overlap
You can define nested containment boundaries provided they indicate a clear trimming area and do not overlap.
Outer boundary trim outside
Inner boundary, trim inside
Tool Path
Linear open boundary
You can define open boundaries provided that the open ends project off the part.
Mouse clicks at (1) and (2) define two points, off part, as an open boundary
Tool Path
Trim boundary options
The trim boundary options are always available in the Contour Area operation subtype. They appear in the following operation subtypes after you select the Area Milling drive method :
Fixed Contour
Contour Surface Area
Contact tool position
When you specify the Contact tool position, NX moves the tool to contact the projected boundary in such a way that the entire area is cut.
Area milling geometry with boundaries
In the Geometry view of the Operation Navigator, you can create a MILL_AREA geometry group and include trim boundaries in the definition. You can then reuse the geometry area in multiple operations.
NX displays this type of geometry group in the initial Geometry list only when you choose the Contour Area operation subtype. If you create Fixed Contour or Contour Surface Area operation subtypes, you must edit the drive method to Area Milling before the area mill geometry appears in the Geometry list.

Document Title: Selecting trim areas in the view plane
Document Body:
You can trim a tool path by selecting an area in the current graphics view plane. The selection tools include:
Rectangle
Lasso
Polygon
Tip:
To add the polygon Select by Polygon method, use the search box in the top right corner to search for Select by Polygon . Right-click and choose Add to Top Border Bar. You can further customize the Top Border bar by dragging the icon into the Selection list.
To select by polygon one time, while Specify View Boundary is active, choose Menu→Edit→Selection→Polygon.
You can specify smooth connections between the truncated cutting motions.
In the tool path shown, the walls marked (1) and (2) are colliding with the tool holder. You can trim those areas from the tool path.
You can remove one area by trimming inside a rectangle, as shown.
To complete the edit, repeat the trim using a second inside rectangle trim.
The figure shows the trimmed path, with the smooth connections option.
You can achieve the same result in a single trim operation by trimming outside a selected area using the Lasso method (shown) or the Polygon selection method.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
You must edit a generated tool path.
Command
Edit Tool Path
Operation Navigator
[Select operation]→right-click→Tool Path→Edit
Location in dialog box
Edit Actions→Trim →Trim Tool Paths dialog box→Trim Geometry group→Geometry = Selection in View
Choose the trim method on the Top Border bar.

Document Title: Connecting tool path segments after edits
Document Body:
Use options in the Transfer/Rapid group of the Trim Tool Path dialog box to connect disjoint segments of tool paths that you have trimmed or divided with options in the Tool Path Editor dialog box.
Transfer at
Direct
Makes a direct connection between the end of the retract of a cutting motion to the start of the engage of the next cutting motion.
Clearance
Sets the clearance height for the transfer.
Lowest Safe Z
Applies a direct move first. If the move is not gouge free, NX uses a previous safe Z-level plane.
Smooth
Creates a default transfer with no selectable options.
Smooth connections
Plane
Lets you define a plane for transfer moves for each trim that you perform.
Transfer using
None
Does not use any specific transfer motions.
Ramp on Shape
Creates a ramping engage move that follows the shape of the first cutting motions.
Lift and Plunge
Produces engages and retracts with vertical moves.
Enter a Lift and Plunge Height.
Height
Sets the height at which the transfer takes place.
Where do I find it?
Initial release
NX 9.0.1
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Edit tool path
Operation Navigator
Right-click operation→Tool Path→Edit
Location in dialog box
[Tool Path Editor] dialog box→Edit Actions group→Trim →[Trim Tool Paths] dialog box→Transfer/Rapid group

As you define or edit a boundary with the Tool Position option set to Contact, the outer boundary of the contact position is dynamically calculated and shown on all surfaces through the part.
The following images show arbitrary curves used to define a boundary that contains the cutter within a small area of the part.
The boundary curves contain the toolpath in the area shown.
When the Trim Boundaries dialog box is open, and the Tool Position option is set to contact, NX displays the tool contact boundary on all part surfaces. The boundary that is displayed on the surface that is being cut shows you the actual cut area.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisites
Operations must use the Area Milling drive method.
In geometry groups, the Geometry Subtype option must be set to MILL_AREA.
In the Trim Boundaries dialog box, in the Boundaries group, the Tool Position option must be set to Contact.

Use the Author command to add work instruction sheets to a machining operation. You can also edit the work instruction sheets for a selected Documentation or machining operation.
Use the Publish command to output PDF or html files of the work instruction sheets for the selected object. When you select a program, NX outputs all work instruction sheets in their respective program order.

The options that are available depend on the operation that is generated.
Display options
Pause After Each Path
Pauses the tool path generation after each operation when you select multiple operations.
Refresh Before Each Path
Refreshes the graphics window before generating the tool path for each operation when you select multiple operations.
Accept Path
Saves the tool path.
Continue
Generates the tool path for the next operation. The software does not generate tool paths for subsequent operations if the check box for this option is not selected.
Display Cut Regions
Available in Planar and Cavity Milling.
Displays the curve defining the machinable region(s) for each cut level before processing the tool path.
Pause After Display
Available in Planar Milling, Cavity Milling, and Fixed and Variable Contour operations.
Pauses the processor after displaying the machinable region and/or the cutter path at each cut level.
Refresh Before Display
Available in Planar Milling, Cavity Milling, and Fixed and Variable Contour operations.
Removes all existing temporary screen displays before displaying the generated tool path.
Uncut Regions
Overlap Distance
Available in some planar milling operations.
Display uncut Regions
Available in Planar and Cavity Milling.
Displays uncut regions for each level. This is a temporary screen display for visual reference only.
Actions
Replay
Displays the tool path.
List
Displays a description, in an information window, of the tool path that just completed generating.

Use the Divide By Holder command in a semi-finishing or finishing operation to split the tool path to avoid collisions and machine the entire cut area. You can split the tool path between tools of different lengths with different tool holders, but the cutter must have the same shape and diameter. Dividing data can then be modified and reapplied without having to regenerate the entire operation.
Initial Surface Contouring operation
Tool path divided into 3 using Divide by Holder

Divide by Holder paths
Shortest tool
Medium length tool
Longest tool
The Divide by Holder command lets you predefine a sequence of tools and their specific parameters. NX stores the data in the base operation. You can copy and paste the base operation into the current part or you can import the tools and parameters as a template from one part file into another part file. The operation brings all the divided holder data with it.
When using a Zig cut pattern, you can define overlaps, minimum cut length, and other controls, by using the Divide at Collision option. This operation recognizes part geometry and check geometry but ignores Blank geometry and the IPW.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
mill_contour operations Zlevel and Fixed Axis that contain a tool path. Operation tool with a holder and or a shank, with Check Tool and Holder turned off.
Zig and Zigzag cut patterns.
Command
Divide by Holder
Operation Navigator — Program Order View
Right click the cutting operation→Tool Path→Divide by Holder

Tool
Tool
Tool List
Lists defined tools that are available for additional operations.
Create Tool
Opens the New Tool dialog box where you can create and organize tools and their parameters.
Edit/Display
Opens the dialog box for the current tool where you can edit the tool’s features and parameters.
Operation Parameters
Opens the Edit Operation dialog box, where you can set parameters for the currently selected operation.
Add New Tool
Adds the currently selected tool from the Tool List, to the list of tools to be used for the current operation.
Default Dividing Rules
Divide at
Transfer
Moves the tool backwards along the tool path to the closest transfer when NX detects a collision, and then divides the tool path into two operations at the transfer.
Collision
Separates the non-colliding portions from the colliding portions of the tool path.
Minimum Cut Length
Sets the minimum length for divided tool paths. Paths that are less than the specified length will be grouped in a separate cutter path.
Overlap Distance
Sets the distance to which NX extends the path when divided sections must overlap.
Note:
You must populate the tool list with tools that are long enough to divide the path properly. If the tools are not long enough, Divide by Holder does not do a divide with the last tool in the list. Instead, NX puts all of the motions from the previous divide there.
Non Cutting Moves
Engage/Retract
Linear
Begins engage and retract moves the specified length distance from the start of cutting moves. You can specify additional parameters for Swing Angle and Ramp Angle.
Lift and Plunge
Produces engages and retracts with vertical moves at the specified height.
Smooth
Creates transfers with arc motions. If there is not enough clearance at the specified length and height, NX calculates a safe move.
Length
Specifies the target length of the transition.
Height
Specifies the target height of the transition.
None

Height
Lets you specify an engage/retract height.
Transfer at
Direct
Makes a direct linear connection between the end of the retract for the last cutting motion to the start of the engage for the next cutting motion.
Clearance
Sets the engage and retract height at the clearance plane specified in the operation dialog box.
Lowest Safe Z
Applies a direct move first. If the move is not gouge free, NX uses a previous safe Z-level plane.
Smooth
Creates direct transfers using arc motions.
Plane
Lets you specify the transfer plane.
Use Global Clearance For Initial and Final
Sets the height for the initial engage and final retract at the clearance plane specified in the operation dialog box. All other transfers use the specified Transfer at method.
Default Clearance
You can define the following clearance objects:
Tool Holder
Tool Shank
Tool Neck
Enter a value in the box and then select either the default units, or tool diameter percentage from the drop down list.

Document Title: Geometry, tool, method, and program parent groups
Document Body:
Before you create an operation, you can define the parameters for programs, tools, geometry and methods. The parameters and selections within the Program, Tool, Geometry and Method groups may then be inherited by other groups or by operations. Because groups have parent-child relationships, groups that contain operations or child groups are called parents or parent groups.
Program group
Use the Create Program command to create a Program group. NX provides one for you but you create additional Program parent groups. View program groups in the Program Order View in the Operation Navigator.
A Program parent group can contain:
Other program groups
Operations
The Program parent group controls the order of operations for postprocessing.
Tool group
Use the Create Tool command to create tools, and to organize tools and their related parameters. View tool groups in the Machine Tool View in the Operation Navigator.
A Tool parent group can contain:
Other tool groups such as milling tools, carriers, pockets, and heads
Operations
Geometry group
Use the Create Geometry command to create geometry parents. In the geometry parents, you specify geometry for machining, clearance and for machine tool orientation. View geometry groups in the Geometry View in the Operation Navigator.
A Geometry parent group can contain:
Other geometry groups such as MCS, WORKPIECE, MILL_AREA, MILL_BND, MILL_TEXT, MILL_GEOM, _MILL_BLADE_GEOM, DRILL_GEOM, and HOLE_BOSS_GEOM
Operations
Method group
Use the Create Method command to create method parents and to specify some common operation parameters and display settings. View method groups in the Machining Method view of the Operation Navigator.
A Method parent group can contain:
Other method groups such as MILL_ROUGH, MILL_SEMI_FINISH, MILL_FINISH, and NONE
Operations
Note:
Parent group object names have a limit of 128 characters.

Document Title: Select parent groups and create an operation
Document Body:
This example describes how to create a cavity milling manufacturing operation using Program, Tool, Geometry and Method groups that were previously defined.
This example assumes that the following parent objects were previously defined:
Parent
Name
PROGRAM
MY_PROGRAM
TOOL
EM-12
GEOMETRY
WORKPIECE
METHOD
MILL_ROUGH
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Operation .
In the Create Operation dialog box, from the Type list, select mill_contour.
Cavity milling is a subtype of the mill_contour type.
In the Operation Subtype group, click CAVITY_MILL .
In the Location group, specify the following parents:
Program=MY_PROGRAM
Tool=EM-12
Geometry=WORKPIECE
Method=MILL_ROUGH
Click OK to create the operation.
The selected parent groups are specified in the operation parameters.
In the Cavity Mill dialog box, in the Actions group, click Generate to create the tool path.
Click OK to save the operation.
In the Operation Navigator, select the new operation.

Document Title: Copy operations and parent groups using Copy CAM from Component
Document Body:
Use the Copy CAM from Component command to copy all operations and parent groups from one part, so you can machine another part.
Create a new assembly and insert the base part.
In this example we use the head part.
Click Add Component on the Ribbon bar to add the part needed to machine the base part.
In this example we use the insert part.
Pattern the insert component.
In the Assembly Navigator right-click insert and choose Replace Reference Set→F_BODY.
This allows you to hide the patterned parts later.
Select Menu→Insert→Associative Copy→ WAVE Geometry Linker.
Note:
Linking the body is not required to copy CAM from the component. You can do this as soon as the part is brought into the assembly.
From the Type list, select Body.
Select all bodies and click OK.
Hide the head and insert.
Only the linked body is displayed.
From the Feature group, subtract the inserts from the head.
Start Manufacturing.
Select Menu→Tools→Copy CAM from Component.
Select the Geometry view of the Operation Navigator.
Right-click in the Operation Navigator and choose Expand All.
You can see the instances of the MCS, workpiece, and the operations within.
By defining the CAM information once, and reusing it multiple times, you save programming time.

Use the Create Geometry command to define:
The machine coordinate system (MCS) parent group. You can specify location, orientation, fixture offset, clearance plane and tool axis information.
Areas to be machined on the part.
Areas not to machine such as clamps and fixtures.
Boundaries for tool containment.
Part material, which is used to calculate machining data such as feeds and speeds.
When you specify geometry in a Geometry parent, it is inherited by all operations in the hierarchy. You do not have to repeat the geometry selections. In the Geometry parent group, you can also:
Add stock to position the tool away from the part, blank, check, or trim geometry.
Save Layout/Layer settings.
Use one or more selection intent rules to keep your selections up to date.
Geometry groups may contain other geometry groups and cutting operations. For example, a MILL_GEOM group may contain a  MILL_AREA group, and the MILL_AREA group may contain several operations. The operations will inherit part geometry from both the MILL_AREA and the MILL_GEOM groups. Not all operations can be placed in all geometry groups, because different operations can inherit different geometry types. For example, a milling operation cannot inherit a turning Geometry parent group.
In the Geometry View of the Operation Navigator, all operations with the same geometry parent appear below the geometry group.
Note:
You can display the geometry inherited from a geometry parent inside an operation, but you cannot override the geometry selections. When geometry is inherited from a parent group, the specify button for that geometry type is inactive.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Geometry
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Geometry group

Geometry selections in a Manufacturing Setup represent either the part model that requires machining; portions of the part model; or additional geometry added by the programmer.
Blank geometry represents the raw material and can be cut through or engaged into directly.
In Process Workpiece (IPW) geometry represents the machined workpiece at the end of each stage of machining.
Part geometry represents the finished part.
Check geometry represents areas you do not wish to violate such as clamps that hold the part.
Trim geometry constrains the cut regions.
Cut area or face geometry define specific areas to machine.
Wall geometry
Floor geometry
Geometry added by the programmer helps to control the tool path during the manufacturing process.
Depending on the operation Type and Subtype, the geometry you use may be a solid body, face, or boundary. NX CAM also supports the use of convergent geometry when creating operations.

The Machine Coordinate System (MCS) determines the orientation and origin of tool paths for all operations in the orient group. The Work Coordinate System (WCS) determines most input parameters, such as From points, clearance planes, and the tool axis.
The MCS has an initial position that is matched to the Absolute Coordinate System. The position of the MCS is saved in the part file. Each orient group (for example, MCS, MCS_MILL) defines the MCS that is necessary to machine a specific side of the part. If you move the MCS, you re-establish the base location for the subsequent tool path output points. The MCS has the following characteristics:
It stores the Reference Coordinate System (RCS).
It can store the Clearance plane, Lower Limit plane, and Avoidance points.
Operations stored under the MCS parent inherit the parameters specified in the MCS parent.
Operations moved from one MCS to another do not need to be generated to reflect the new orientation or origin.
Common uses for the MCS
The MCS is useful when you do the following:
Output the tool path in relation to the machine home position or any other frequently used setup location.
Reorient the machine tool axes to the workpiece.
Shift large parts for successive tool paths.
Set up parts which no longer have a reference point; for example, a tooling hole which has been machined away.
Reestablish setup position and orientation after rotary table movement and after compound axis movement.
Maintain critical dimensions that would be otherwise lost to warping or tolerance buildup.
Establish basic and true positions.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Geometry
Location in dialog box
[Valid geometry type]→Geometry Subtype→MCS

Document Title: Create an MCS geometry parent group
Document Body:
The MCS references the NC/CNC program origin which is the zero reference point for all tool path output. If the MCS moves, the zero point of all the tool paths that use it move with it.
It is helpful to create and save a clearance plane when you specify the orientation and origin of the machine coordinate system in an MCS parent group. The clearance plane defines a safe clearance distance for tool motion before and after an operation.
This example shows how to create an MCS geometry parent group with a specified clearance plane.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Geometry .
In the Create Geometry dialog box, do the following:
In the Geometry Subtype group, click MCS .
In the Location group, select the appropriate Geometry group to assign your new MCS to.
In the Name group, enter a name for the new MCS, and click OK.
You must specify the orientation and origin of the MCS, or it is assigned the current orientation and origin of the WCS.
In the MCS dialog box, in the Machine Coordinate System group, click CSYS Dialog .
In the CSYS dialog box, click Dynamic .
In the graphics window, use the handles on the MCS to rotate it or move it to the correct location.
Click OK when you are done.
You return to the MCS dialog box.
In the Clearance group, do the following:
Select Plane as the clearance option.
Click Specify Clearance Plane.
In the Plane Constructor dialog box, define a safe location for the clearance plane, and enter an Offset distance if necessary.
The following graphic shows a specified clearance plane created at an offset distance of 0.500 above the top face of the blank stock.
Click OK to save and close the dialog box.
In the MCS dialog box, click OK.

The programmer sets the purpose of the coordinate system to either Main or Local in the MCS geometry group.
The main MCS defines the center of rotation when machining about a rotary axis.
In the following example, the main MCS is set to machine zero.
The local MCS defines either fixture offsets or machine tool zero data.
In the following example, the main MCS is set to machine zero, and a local MCS is placed at each of the four pockets.
The tool paths for all four pockets have the same X, Y and Z values because they are based on the local MCS.
The posted output of the four tool paths have different X, Y, and Z values because they are based on the main MCS. This is equivalent to controlling the output with an ORIGIN statement.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Geometry
Location in dialog box
[Valid geometry type]→Geometry Subtype→MCS →MCS dialog box→Machine Coordinate System group→Details subgroup→Purpose list

Document Title: Create a Main MCS and a Local MCS
Document Body:
This example will use a Main and Local machine coordinate system (MCS). The Main MCS is set where machine zero would be. The tool paths are based on the Local MCS. When you post the program, the output of the tool paths, with their respective X,Y, and Z values, are based upon the Main MCS.
Create a fixture assembly.
This should include components like rotary table, fixture plates, and clamping devices.
Note:
The assembly can be put together in the Modeling or Manufacturing application.
Position your part on the fixture assembly in the normal position.
If necessary, choose Application tab→Manufacturing .
In the Geometry view position the MCS to the center of the rotary axis.
The rotary table center is now the zero point.
Note:
It is a good idea to rename the MCS. For example, MCS_Main.
In the Geometry view, double click on the Main MCS.
The MCS dialog box is displayed.
On the MCS dialog box, in the Machine Coordinate System group, click Details.
Set Purpose to Main.
Click OK to accept and close MCS dialog box.
Create, locate, and orient all Local coordinate systems to the appropriate locations on the part.
This example shows two cut paths, each contains its own independent Local MCS.
MCS_000
A Local coordinate system specified for the narrow pocket cut path.
MCS_090
A Local coordinate system specified for the wide pocket cut path.
The Local coordinate systems should be a sub-set of the Main MCS geometry group and displayed in the Geometry view.
MCS_MAIN
MCS_000
MCS_090
Note:
It is a good idea to rename the Local coordinate systems individual names. For example, MCS_000 and MCS_090.
Edit each Local coordinate system one at a time , by double clicking on the coordinate system in the Geometry view.
The MCS dialog box is displayed.
On the MCS dialog box, in the Machine Coordinate System group. click Details.
Set Purpose to Local.
Set Special output to Use Main MCS.
Assign a work piece geometry group and operation to each Local coordinate system.
MCS_MAIN
MCS_000
WORKPIECE_1
FM_001
MCS_090
WORKPIECE_2
FM_002
Generate the operations.
This example shows:
A cut path using one Local MCS to machine the narrow pocket.
The turn table rotating 180 degrees about the Main MCS.
A cut path using a second Local MCS to machine the wide pocket.
Post process the tool paths.

A Reference Coordinate System (RCS) is the coordinate system that maps parameters when you create, copy, move or transform an operation. By default, it is in the same location as the Absolute Coordinate System, whose coordinates are X = 0, Y = 0, and Z = 0. You can specify the RCS either when you create or edit the MCS. Every orient group (for example, MCS, MCS_Mill) has an RCS.
You can use the RCS to relocate tool axis vectors, clearance planes, and avoidance points after transforming an operation.
Note:
When you create an operation, the operation is copied from a template without the defining geometry.

Specify an RCS to help you relocate tool axis vectors, clearance planes, and avoidance points after transforming an operation.
In the Operation Navigator, in the Geometry View, double-click the MCS.
In the Mill Orient dialog box, in the Reference Coordinate System group, specify the RCS location in one of these ways:
To place the RCS in the same location as the MCS, select the Link RCS to MCS check box.
Note:
If you always want the RCS linked to the MCS in a new MCS group, you can set a manufacturing preference to do this.
To place the RCS in a different location from the MCS, clear the Link RCS to MCS check box, and then specify the RCS in one of these ways:
To
Do this
Orient the RCS directly in the graphics window
Click CSYS Dialog .
In the CSYS dialog box, click Dynamic
In the graphics window, use the handles on the RCS to rotate it or move it to the correct location.
Click OK when you are done.
Select one of the other options to define a coordinate system
Select an option from the RCS list.

Document Title: Link the RCS to the MCS
Document Body:
You can set a preference to always link the RCS to the MCS when you create a new MCS.
In the Manufacturing application, choose Menu→Preferences→ Manufacturing.
In the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box, click the Operation tab.
In the Operation property page, under Edit, select the Link MCS/RCS check box. Click OK.
Note:
When you create an MCS, the link is turned on. Set the MCS, and see that the RCS follows it, always matching the MCS.

Document Title: Turn the MCS display on or off
Document Body:
Choose Menu→Format→MCS Display.
The RCS display is also turned on or off.
Tip:
To turn the WCS display on or off, choose Menu→Format→WCS→Display.

To display a hidden MCS until the graphics window is refreshed:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the MCS and choose Object→Display.
Note:
A hidden MCS also displays when you edit it.
Automatically display a hidden MCS when it is selected in the Operation Navigator
Choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing Preferences .
In the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box, click the General tab.
Select the Display Selected Objects check box and click OK.

You can define tool axis vectors, clearance planes, and avoidance points using associative or non-associative geometry. The software handles associative and non-associative objects differently, depending on whether you create an operation or transform an existing operation.
Object→Transform
Create Operation
Associative objects defined relative to geometry present in the part.
Associative objects:
Are not mapped to the RCS.
Are not translated with the operation.
Remain associative to the defining geometry.
Associative objects:
Are made non-associative before they are mapped to the RCS for the new operation.
Have the same spatial relationship to the RCS for the new operation as they did to the RCS in the template operation.
Non associative objects defined relative to the ACS.
Non-associative objects:
Are mapped to the RCS.
Are translated with the operation.
Non-associative objects:
Are mapped to the RCS for the new operation.
Have the same spatial relationship to the RCS for the new operation as they did to the RCS in the template operation.
From Point and Go Home Point
From and Go Home Points are not mapped to the RCS. From and Go Home points are never translated with the operation because they are associated with the machine tool and not the operation.
From and Go Home Points are not mapped to the RCS and maintain the spatial relationship to the ACS that existed in the template operation.

Machine Coordinate System
Origin Location
Specify lets you position the MCS using one of the options in the CSYS list, or in the CSYS dialog box.
On Blank positions the MCS on the blank geometry selected in the MCS dialog box.
On Part Box positions the MCS on the part bounding box geometry selected in the MCS dialog box.
For more information on the On Blank and On Part Box options, see Origin Location options to position the workpiece.
Specify MCS
Lets you specify an MCS using either the MCS list or CSYS Dialog .
Note:
The dynamic MCS does not display when the dialog box is first opened. Click CSYS Dialog to see the dynamic MCS.
Details
Purpose
Specifies the coordinate system as Main or Local. By default, all coordinate systems are local. In some types of programming, such as fixture offsets, you need to define a main coordinate system at the center of rotation of the machine tool. Then you create local coordinate systems under the main coordinate system in the Geometry View to represent the offset location for each fixture.
Special Output
Available when Purpose is set to Local.
Special Output only affects the postprocessor output.
None
(Default) Bases the output on the local MCS coordinates.
Use Main MCS
Ignores the local MCS coordinates and bases the output on the main MCS. The main MCS is found in the geometry tree above the local MCS in the Geometry View.
Fixture Offset
Bases the output on the local MCS coordinates. The postprocessor can use these coordinates along with the main coordinates to output fixture offsets, such as G54.
CSYS Rotation
Bases the output on the local MCS coordinates. The postprocessor can use these coordinates along with the main coordinates to output programming in a local coordinate system, such as CYCLE 19.
CSYS Rotation only supports coordinate system functions such as G68.1, cycle 19, and G125 for orthogonal head and table positioning on common mill/turn B/C machine tools. For all other machine tools, use the Fixture Offset output.
Use Inherited MCS
Ignores the local MCS coordinates and bases the output on the parent MCS. The parent MCS is found in the geometry tree immediately above the local MCS in the Geometry View.
Fixture Offset
Specifies the fixture offset number for machines that use a fixture offset. Each part orientation on the machine corresponds to a specific MCS, and thus a specific fixture offset value. The software loads the fixture offset value into MOM_post during output to create the appropriate G code.
Save MCS
Creates a coordinate system entity based on the current MCS. This is useful if you need to select this as your WCS.
Reference Coordinate System
Link RCS to MCS
Lets you specify a different location for the RCS.
Link RCS to MCS
Places the RCS at the same location and orientation as the MCS.
Specify RCS
Lets you specify an RCS using either the RCS list or CSYS Dialog .
The software uses the RCS to relocate tool axis vectors, clearance planes, and avoidance points when you move an operation from one section of a part to another.
Clearance
The clearance plane defines a safe clearance distance for tool motion before and after an operation and during any programmed obstacle avoidance.
These options are inherited by the Non Cutting moves of operations in this Mill Orient group.
Clearance Option
Specifies the clearance.
Use Inherited
Uses the clearance definition from a higher level MCS.
None
Does not use a clearance plane.
Automatic Plane
Clears geometry by the Safe Clearance Distance value.
Plane
Specifies the clearance plane for this operation Use the Plane Constructor to define a clearance plane.
Point
Specifies the safe point to transfer to. You can either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Bounding Cylinder
Specifies a cylinder shape as clearance geometry. The cylinder size is determined by the shape of the part and a specified Safe Clearance distance. The software always assumes that the volume outside the cylinder is safe clearance.
Select Bounding Cylinder and enter a clearance value to determine the cylinder size.
Cylinder
Specifies a cylinder shape as clearance geometry. This cylinder is of infinite length. The software always assumes that the volume outside the cylinder is safe clearance.
To create the cylinder, you must:
Enter a Radius value and specify a center point.
To specify the point, either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Specify a tool axis direction.
To specify the tool axis, either selecting geometry or use the Vector Constructor to specify the tool axis.
Sphere
Specifies a sphere shape as clearance geometry. The sphere size is determined a radius value. The software always assumes that the volume outside the sphere is safe clearance.
To create the sphere, you must:
Enter a Radius value and specify a center point.
To specify the point, either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Bounding Box
Specifies a box shape as clearance geometry. The box size is determined by the shape of the part and a specified Clearance distance. The software always assumes that the volume outside the box is safe clearance.
Select Bounding Box and enter a clearance value to determine the box size.
Note:
If there is no previous clearance plane definition, the inherited option is the same as None.
Lower Limit Plane
These options are inherited by the Non Cutting moves of operations in this Mill Orient group.
Lower Limit Option
Lets you specify the lower limit plane. The lower limit plane defines the lower limit of cutting and non cutting tool motions in some operations.
Avoidance
These options are inherited by the Non Cutting moves of operations in this Mill Orient group.
For descriptions of Avoidance options, see Avoidance tab options.
Tool Axis
Tool Axis
Lets you specify a tool axis for this geometry group.
The tool axis specified here is inherited by fixed axis operations when you select Specify Vector from the Axis list in the main operation dialog box.
Note:
The All Axes option is used only to determine feature based machining accessibility vectors.
Use Axis Limits
Available when Tool Axis is set to All Axes
Specifies limits for the machining access direction vector.
None
NX accepts all features when creating feature groups, and all tool axis directions when creating operations.
Rotate: Y, Tilt: Z, Rotate: X, Tilt: Z, Rotate: Z, Tilt: X
Lets you specify a range of acceptable rotation and tilt angles for the Group Features and Create Feature Process commands. Valid inputs for rotation are between -180 and 180. Valid inputs for tilt are between -90 and 90.
The commands add a machining feature to a feature group only when the feature's access direction is within the specified ranges for rotation and tilt angle.
Example:
Use Axis Limits = Rotate: Z, Tilt: X
Minimal Tilt Angle = 0
Maximal Tilt Angle = 20
Minimal Rotation Angle = 0
Maximal Rotation Angle = 180
The Group Features and Create Feature Process commands add a machining feature to the feature group only if its access direction is between the rotation angles of 0° and +180° about the Z-axis, and also between the tilt angles of 0° and +20° about the X-axis.
Part to machine
Features selected for feature group
Note:
To access Use Axis Limits, you must customize the MCS dialog box to add the Tool Axis Filter customizable object to the Tool Axis group.
For more information, see Add an item to a dialog box.
Layout and Layer
Save Layer Settings
Saves only the view information for the current layout.
Save Layer Settings
Saves the layer settings with the view information for the current layout.
Save Layout/Layer
Saves the layout and layer settings of the current orientation. You can view the part from this orientation during NC programing.

You may find the RCS useful when:
Repositioning a part on a machine tool (setup change).
Repositioning from one work face to another.
Machining multiple parts (such as "chimney" setups).
In the following illustration, the RCS is shown at its original location. The Start Point is specified and its location is stored relative to the RCS when you Accept the operation. Later you can move the RCS to the next face and retrieve the previous operation. The Start Point is then positioned relative to the new RCS location.
The Reference Coordinate System

When you select faces and bodies, you can set Selection Intent rules on the Top Border bar to narrow the selection to just the objects that you want. You can then create a set of geometry for each rule that you define. You can also apply different custom data to each set of geometry, for example, stock and tolerance data.
This example demonstrates how to select and apply different stock data to two face regions in a cavity milling operation. The sidewalls of the cavity, the flat face of the tooling, and the part contours each have different stock requirements.
In the Cavity Mill dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Cut Area .
You can click any option that lets you select faces or bodies.
In the Part Geometry dialog box, expand Custom Data and List.
On the Top Border bar, do the following:
From the Type Filter list, select Face.
From the Face Rule list, select Single Face.
Select the flat parting face of the tooling.
You would machine your parting faces in a separate operation. This example demonstrates the single face rule and adding custom stock.
Under Custom Data, select the Stock check box.
Selecting a custom data check box adds one or more relevant input boxes to the dialog box. In the example, this face is going to have extra stock left on it because the face can be cut to the finished level with a sturdy cutting tool.
In the Final Stock box, enter the amount of stock to leave on the current selection. For example, type 2.0 mm.
Under List, in the Custom Data column, the word Yes indicates that set number 1 has custom data.
Click Add New Set .
The next selection demonstrates the use of a different selection intent rule, but no custom stock is specified at this time.
On the Top Border bar, from the Face Rule list, select Tangent Faces.
The current selection rule is included in the face information that appears beside the cursor as you move it over faces.
Select any one side wall face for the current set.
The face you selected and all tangent faces are included in the set.
Under List, note that the number of faces in the set is listed under Number of Items, and that the word No appears under Custom Data.
When there is no custom data, the faces in the set are machined according to the operation defaults.
Pause your cursor over one of the highlighted faces.
The selection rule that was used for the face is included in the face information that appears beside the cursor.
Hold down the Shift key, and with the cursor still over a highlighted face, wait until the three dots for the QuickPick tool appear, and then click.
You have the option to deselect all faces of the intent, or just a single face.
Close the QuickPick dialog box to cancel the deselection.
Click Add New Set .
Select any single face of the part.
In this example, all part faces are blended and thus all faces are tangent. You can apply other rules, such as a color or an attribute, or make multiple selections for the same set.
All part faces are included in the set.
Under List, under Set, click 2.
Set 2 is highlighted. You can highlight each set, modify the selections, and add or modify custom data.
Under Custom Data, select the Stock check box.
In the Final Stock box, enter the amount of stock to leave on the current selection. For example, type 1.0 mm.
Under List, in the Custom Data column, the word Yes indicates that set number 2 has custom data.
The custom data values are shown in the graphics window when you select a set.
Click OK.
When the tool path is generated, the faces in set 1 have 2 mm stock, the faces in set 2 have 1 mm stock, and the faces in set 3 have the default stock for the operation.

You can use the multiselect gestures to select multiple facet bodies for part, blank, or check geometry. In an assembly, NX adds facets from all components within the multiselect gesture to the geometry definition. NX creates a separate geometry set for each facet body and displays an alert message to tell you that multiple geometry sets were created.
Geometry to select
16 separate facet bodies

19 separate solid bodies

Types Filter = Facet Body
Types Filter = Solid Body
NX creates 16 geometry sets. Each set contains one facet body.
NX creates one geometry set that contains 19 solid bodies.

Types Filter = Facet Body and Solid Body
NX creates 17 geometry sets. One geometry set that contains 19 solid bodies, and 16 geometry sets that each contain one facet body.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in dialog box
Workpiece dialog box→Geometry group
Ribbon bar
Selection tab→Filters group→turn on Selection Filters
Resource bar
Selection Filters →Types tab

The material attribute assigned to part geometry is one of several parameters used to determine cutting feeds and speeds. Once this part material as well as tool material, cut method and cut depth have been specified, the Reset from Table button in the Feeds and Speeds dialog uses these parameters to recommend appropriate Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values.
To
Do this
Assign a part material to all operations in a part
Choose Menu→Tools→Part Material.
In the Search Result dialog box, select a part material and click OK.
The specified Part Material applies to all operations in the part unless you specify another material in a geometry group dialog box.
Assign a part material to a specific geometry group
In the Geometry View of the Operation Navigator, double-click the geometry group that requires a part material.
In the [geometry] dialog box, in the Description group, click Material
In the Search Result dialog box, select a part material and click OK.
The contents of the part material listing is determined by the Configuration File.
