The Mill Geometry and Workpiece icons in the Create Geometry dialog box perform identical functions. They both allow you to define Part, Blank, and Check geometry from selected bodies, faces, curves, or surface regions. In addition, they allow you to define Part offset, Part Material, and save the currently displayed layout and layer.
Material
This option assigns a material attribute to the geometry as one of several parameters used to determine cutting feeds and speeds. Once this part material as well as tool material, cut method and cut depth have been specified, the Reset from Table button in the Feeds and Speeds dialog uses these parameters to recommend appropriate Surface Speed and Feed per Tooth values extracted from predefined tables.
The material specified using this option determines the Feeds and Speeds only for operations using this geometry group. The material specified here supercedes the material specified using Tools>Part Material for these operations.
The Material button displays a listing of available part materials to choose from. The contents of this listing is determined by the Configuration File.
Refer to Object>Feed Rates described in the Operation Navigator section for details on how the Feeds and Speeds dialog uses this and other parameters.

Geometry

Specify Part
Specifies geometry that represents the finished part. Valid selections include:
(Preferred) Sheet bodies or solid bodies
Facet bodies
Surface regions
Faces

Specify Blank
Specifies geometry that represents the material to cut from, such as forgings or castings. Blank geometry does not represent the final part and can be cut through or engaged with directly. Valid selections include:
(Preferred) Sheet bodies or solid bodies
Facet bodies
Surface regions
Faces
Curves

Specify Check
Specifies geometry that represents clamps or other areas, to avoid machining the areas. Valid selections include:
(Preferred) Sheet bodies or solid bodies
Facet bodies
Faces
Curves
Physical Workpiece
Allows you to assign the part geometry of multiple workpiece setups for machine simulation from the ONT without using the Setup Configurator in the Machine Tool Navigator. For example, this simplifies the workflow for machine simulation when you select multiple parts on a tombstone.
Setup Components
Displays a list of machine components classified as _SETUP_ELEMENT or _SETUP, _SETUP_ELEMENT in the kinematic model.
The color of the workpiece icon in the Geometry View changes to if a Physical Workpiece is defined in the Workpiece dialog box.
Note:
Physical Workpiece is available only if NX detects more than one component classified as _PART, _SETUP_ELEMENT in the kinematic model of the machine. The workpiece geometry is automatically assigned when the machine is loaded with one component classified as _PART, _SETUP_ELEMENT.
To use the Physical Workpiece method in existing parts, you must deselect all the part and workpiece geometry assigned to the corresponding components in the Machine Tool Navigator - Setup Configurator.
Selecting the machine components is not supported by simulation in the Synchronization Manager and an error message appears about missing K components. For proper material removal during simulation, you must use the Machine Tool Navigator - Setup Configurator to assign the part to the _PART, _SETUP_ELEMENT component, and its blank to the _WORKPIECE, _SETUP_ELEMENT component in the kinematic model of the machine.
Offsets
Part Offset
Specifies how far to offset the part from the selected part geometry.
Description

Material
Opens the Part Material Search Result list. Select a part material from the list to assign to your geometry.
Layout and Layer
Save Layer Settings
Saves the layer settings with the view information for the current layer.
Layout Name
The name of the layout.
Save Layout/Layer
Saves the layout and layer of the current view settings. This is helpful when you machine the part from a specific orientation.

Geometry
Trim Boundaries apply to the Area Milling and Flow Cut drive methods of Fixed Axis Surface Contouring. Trim Boundaries further constrain the cut regions. You may define the area of the cut region to be excluded from the operation by specifying Material as Inside or Outside. Trim boundaries are always Closed, always use an On condition, and are projected to the Part geometry along the tool axis vector. More than one Trim Boundary may be defined. You may specify a Trim Stock to define the distance the tool is positioned from the Trim Boundary, and Boundary Intol/Outol.
Part Offset
Part Offset adds to or subtracts from the modeled part geometry by a specified offset (thickness) value. A positive value offsets the thickness outside the part. A negative value offsets the thickness inside the part. The cutter recognizes the Part Offset as the workpiece and machines to it accordingly. Part Stock and Custom Stock are measured from the Part Offset. This is useful when the model geometry is offset from the part you are machining, such as an EDM electrode or a sheet metal die.

The following options are available for the Part Geometry, Blank Geometry, Check Geometry, and Cut Area Geometry dialog boxes.
Geometry
Reverse Material Side
Available for Cavity Milling operations after you click Unify All in the Topology dialog box.
Reverses the material side for all of the selected geometry.
Custom Data
Lets you assign custom parameters that apply to the selected geometry. The default values for each option are the same as the cutting parameter defaults in the operation dialog box.
The Stock and Tolerance values override the Stock and Tolerance values specified in the operation dialog box.
The default values for each option are the same as the defaults in the operation dialog box.
For fixed and variable contouring operations, the Cut Feed Rate values override the Cut Feed Rate values specified in Feeds and Speeds.
For geometry specified in a parent geometry group, the Offset value adds an offset to the entire part geometry.
Topology
Topology
Available after you select or edit geometry.
Provides surface analysis options to check for the following:
Material side inconsistency.
Gaps and missing surfaces.
Duplicate surfaces.

Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Some models contain geometry errors that can create multiple shells and an incorrect tool path. Use the Topology options to inspect the model for missing, duplicated, and non-tangent faces. NX uses the settings to connects each object in a shell to every adjacent object.
Tolerances
Lets you adjust the distance and angle tolerances so that all the geometry is connected into one or more shells. You can then generate an acceptable tool path.
Distance
Specifies the maximum value that two objects can be apart and still considered connected. If surfaces are adjacent, one or more shells are created when you rebuild the topology.
Enter a larger value to join two objects that are not connected with the default value.
Angle
Specifies the maximum angle, in degrees, that the normals of two adjacent faces (or curves) can vary at an edge.
For example, if you enter a value of 5 degrees and the angle along an edge between two faces is less than 5 degrees, NX classifies the edge tangent.
Rebuild Topology
Creates the shell if the surfaces are adjacent. NX considers surfaces adjacent if the gaps are less than the specified tolerance.
NX does not modify the model geometry.
Material Side
NX represents the material side by a vector arrow that points away from the material.
Display Material Side
Displays the material side indicator when you select one of the Faces options.
Refresh Before Display
Refreshes the screen when you select one of the Faces or Edges options.
Shell
Note:
NX only shows the options that apply to your model.
Faces
Lets you review the material side defined for each face.
Undefined highlights faces without a defined material side.
Same highlights faces with the same material side as that of the majority of the faces.
Opposite highlights the faces with a different material side than that of the majority of the faces.
Edges
Lets you review how NX classifies the edges.
Undefined highlights the edges that are not classified by NX.
Nonmanifold highlights the unresolved portion of an edge where more than two faces meet.
Note:
The Modeling application does not allow you to create nonmanifold edges.
Exterior highlights all of the outside edges that define the cutting region.
Interior highlights all of the inside edges that define the cutting region.
Inconsistent highlights the edges where adjacent faces have opposite material sides.
Complex highlights the edges that are neither completely tangent, concave, or convex. For example, part of the edge is tangent, and the rest of it is convex.
Tangent, Concave, Convex highlight the specified edges.
Unify All
Places the material side for all of the selected geometry on the same side.
Reverse All
Available after you click Unify All.
Reverses the material side for all of the selected geometry.

Geometry
Specify Part Boundaries
Specifies geometry that represents the finished part.
The preferred geometry selection is faces. Other valid geometry selections are: curves, edges, permanent boundaries and points.
For collision and gouge avoidance, select the entire part, including the faces you are not cutting, as part geometry. Then use Specify Trim Boundaries to limit what is cut.
Specify Blank Boundaries
Specifies geometry that represents the material to cut from, such as forgings or castings. Blank geometry does not represent the final part and can be cut through or engaged into directly.
The preferred geometry selection is faces. Other valid geometry selections are: curves, edges, permanent boundaries and points.
Specify Check Boundaries
Specifies boundaries that represent clamps or other areas to avoid machining.
Specify Trim Boundaries
Specifies boundaries to define areas of the cut region to exclude from the operation.
Note:
Use trim boundaries with caution. Trim Boundaries can sometimes hide part geometry and lead to unexpected results. This is particularly important where it is important the tool is not overly embedded.
Specify Floor
Uses the Plane Constructor to specify the floor plane. The part, blank, check and trim boundaries are swept along the tool axis to the floor plane to define the part and blank volumes, and the volumes to avoid machining.
Floor defines the lowest (last) cut level for Planar Mill operations.
If you do not specify a floor, the system uses the X-Y plane of the Machine Coordinate System (MCS).
Offsets
Part Offset, Blank Offset, Check Offset, and Trim Offset offset the boundary from the geometry selected to define the boundary.
Layout and Layer
Save Layer Settings
Save Layout/Layer
Saves the layout and layer of the current view settings. This is helpful when machining the part from a specific orientation.

Document Title: Display the saved view orientation for an operation
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Object→ Switch Layer/Layout.
The software changes the working layer and retrieves the display layout that was active when Save Layout/Layer was selected.

Use boundaries in Manufacturing to define the regions to machine. Part, blank, and check boundaries are mainly used for Planar Milling. Trim boundaries are used in Planar Milling and are also used for containment in the solids based processors such as Cavity Milling and Surface Contouring.
They define a path or area.
A single boundary, for example, a pocket or closed area, contains the tool. Combined boundaries, for example, a pocket with an island, can both contain and exclude the tool.
They have a material side or tool side.
They consist of members.
Each member is a segment which may contain custom data, such as Intol/Outtol, Stock, and Tool Position. A segment can be the edge of a face or a curve.
Individual members are easily identified by their tool position indicators.
They are always planar.
In Milling and Wire EDM operations, boundaries define a volume, path or direction.
NX projects the selected geometry to the boundary plane. The projection is along a vector that is normal to the boundary plane.
In Turning operations, boundaries define a planar cross section of material to be removed.
They are displayed as temporary entities and disappear whenever the screen is refreshed.
They have a start point, forward direction, and end point.
When you create a boundary from a face, NX automatically establishes the boundary direction.
When you create a boundary from curves, edges, or points, you establish the boundary direction. The direction is from the first item you select to the second item you select.
After the boundary direction is established, you cannot edit it or reverse it.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Geometry
Location in dialog box
Geometry parent
Create Geometry dialog box→[Valid geometry type]→[Valid geometry subtype]→[Geometry] dialog box→Geometry group

Operation specific geometry
[Operation] dialog box→Geometry group

Document Title: Moving boundary start and end points - legacy boundary dialog box
Document Body:
Boundary Start Point
Action
Open boundary
Closed boundary
Move the start point
Trim moves the start point back along the boundary member so that the member is shortened.
Extend lengthens the boundary member along a straight line tangent to the boundary member.
Note:
Select the boundary member nearest the end you want to trim or extend.
Moving the start point to a different boundary member removes all members between the new location and the original location.
All post commands associated with the original start point are moved to the new start point.
The boundary member is split.
If you move the start point back to the previous location, the software tries to join the two members to form the original member. If the members have different parameters (for example, feed rate or stock), they cannot be joined.
All post commands associated with the original boundary member are removed.
Distances and percentages must be non-negative values.
All tolerance, feed rate, and stock values are copied from the original boundary member to the newly created boundary members.
Move the end point
Trim and Extend function the same as for start point.
Not applicable. The end point follows the start point
Specify the first member
Not applicable.
Use arrows to highlight the desired first member, then click First Member.
Note:
Planar Milling only uses the boundary start point to determine the cut start point if you go to Non Cutting Moves in the main operation dialog box and change the Region Start Points option to Corner.

Document Title: Moving boundary start and end points
Document Body:
Open boundaries
Closed boundaries
Symbol
Description
Start point of the selected boundary curve
End point of the selected boundary curve
Start point of any additional boundary curve
End point of any additional boundary curve
Selected member of the selected boundary curve
Additional member of the selected boundary
Member of any additional boundary curve
Direction arrow and tool side indicator attached to start point
Action
Open boundary
Closed boundary
Move the start point along the same boundary member
Boundaries dialog box→Members group→ Trim / Extend Member
Distances and percentages must be non-negative values. However, you can drag the start point in the graphics window to increase the boundary member length.
Decreasing the length moves the start or end point back along the boundary member.
Increasing the length moves the start or end point along a straight line tangent to the boundary member.
Boundaries dialog box→Members group→ Trim / Extend Member
Distances and percentages must be non-negative values.
The boundary member is split.
The curve segment in front of the start point becomes the new Member 1 item in the member list.
This boundary member retains the start point. It does not retain any custom member data.
The curve segment behind the start point becomes the last item in the member list.
This boundary member retains all custom member data, including post commands, assigned to the previous Member 1.
Specify the first member
Boundaries dialog box→Boundaries group→ Select Curve
In the graphics window, shift-select each member that is before the required Member 1 curve segment to remove it from the boundary.

The start point moves to the new Member 1 curve segment.
The new start point does not retain any custom member data.
Boundaries dialog box→Members group→ Start on this Member

NX copies all tolerance, feed rate, and stock values associated with the original boundary member to the new Member 1.
However, if the new Member 1 has existing custom member data, it retains the data.
NX does not copy any post commands associated with the original boundary member to the new Member 1.
Move the end point
Boundaries dialog box→Members group→ Trim / Extend Member
Not applicable. The end point always follows the start point.
Note:
Planar Milling uses the boundary start point to determine the cut start point only if you go to Non Cutting Moves in the main operation dialog box and change the Region Start Points option to Corner.
Tip:
It is not necessary to change the boundary start point to change the starting point of the tool path.
In the operation dialog box: Non Cutting Moves→Start/Drill Points node→Region Start Points group→Select Points

Note:
This dialog box is available for drive boundary geometry.
The Part Boundaries, Blank Boundaries, Check Boundaries, and Trim Boundaries dialog boxes have the same options as the Boundary Geometry and Create Boundary dialog boxes, but with a slightly different layout.
Option
Description
Mode
Chooses the method for defining a boundary:
Curves/Edges
Accesses the Create Boundary dialog box to specify existing curves or edges.
Boundary
Lets you select an existing permanent boundary
The software copies the permanent boundary to a manufacturing boundary. The new boundary can be edited. It is associative to the curves and edges from which the permanent boundary was created, and not to the permanent boundary itself. If the permanent boundary is deleted, the manufacturing boundary remains.
Face
Lets you select a single planar face of a sheet or solid body This is usually the easiest method. The interior edges are determined by the Ignore Holes and Ignore Islands options.
Face mode is not available for Turning.
Points
Lets you create a closed boundary from a sequence of defined points.
Accesses the Create Boundary dialog box to specify associative or non-associative points (not available for Turning)
List Boundaries
Lists of the names of previously created boundaries
Material Side
Specifies which side of the boundary the part or stock material is on.
Side Trimmed
Specifies the side on which the tool path is not generated.
Geometry Type
Displays the type of boundary (part, blank, check, trim) you are creating.
Custom Boundary Data
Sets Tolerance, Side Stock, Blank Distance and Cut Feed Rate values associated with the selected boundary
Remove Last
Removes the previously defined boundary.
Face Selection options
Ignore Holes
Create boundaries around each hole on the selected face.
Ignore Holes
Ignores holes in the selected face.
Ignore Islands
Creates boundaries around each island on the selected face.
Ignore Islands
Ignores islands in the selected face.
Ignore Chamfers
Creates boundaries on the edges of the selected faces.
Ignore Chamfers
Creates boundaries that extend to include chamfers, fillets, and rounds adjacent to the selected faces.
Convex Edges, Concave Edges
Controls the tool position for boundary members that occur along convex and concave edges of the selected face.Tanto is the default for concave edges. On is the default for convex edges.

Note:
The Create Boundary dialog box displays when Mode in the Boundary Geometry dialog box is set to Curves/Edges or Points.
This dialog box is available for drive boundary geometry and for boundary geometry defined within planar milling operations, such as Planar Mill and Finish Walls.
Type
(Curves/Edges mode only)
Specifies the boundary as either Open or Closed.
Point Method
Point mode only
Selects the method for defining points (such as Point on Face) to create a boundary from a sequence of defined points. The boundary direction and start point are defined in the same way when defining a sequence of points as when selecting a sequence of curves.
Point Method always creates a closed boundary which cannot be edited to become an open boundary.
Plane
Specifies how to define the boundary plane. The boundary plane is the plane onto which the selected geometry will be projected and the boundary created.
Automatic
Creates the boundary plane from the first two curves/edges or the first three points selected. Creates the boundary plane on the XC-YC plane if it is not possible to define a plane using the selected curves, edges, or points.
Automatic is useful for establishing the ZC level when selecting planar curves that are parallel to the XC-YC plane.
Caution:
Using Automatic with 3d curves can lead to unexpected results and is not recommended.
Boundary Plane Defined by Selected Edges
User–Defined
User-Defined allows you to define a Boundary Plane using the Plane Subfunction.
Use this option to define a boundary plane from contoured 3d curves or edges.
Non planar edges projected to boundary plane
Material Side
Specifies the side of the boundary which you do not want to cut.
Tool Position
Determines how the tool will position (On, Tanto, Contact) when it approaches the boundary member
Custom Member Data
Sets Tolerance, Side Stock, and Cut Feed Rate values for individual boundary members. Also lets you define post commands to insert at the beginning or end of the tool path segment for the selected boundary member:
Retrieve
Lets you select a MILL_CONTROL (Post Command) template and removes any User Defined Events (post commands) previously defined.
Edit
Lets you add User Defined Events, such as Coolant On.
Chaining
Automatically selects a contiguous sequence of curves and edges
Select a starting member and when necessary, an ending member. All contiguous members become selected for boundary geometry.
If you want to chain all of the edges that form a contiguous loop, select the first edge and choose OK.
Note:
The post commands at the start and at the end are not applied to objects selected by the chaining method.
The direction of the chaining sequence and the boundary indicators is determined by where you select the entity relative to its middle control point.
Select to the left of the middle control point.
Select to the right of the middle control point.
Remove Last Member
Deletes the last boundary member created
Create Next Boundary
Completes the creation of the current boundary and immediately starts creating the next temporary boundary

Note:
This dialog box is available for drive boundary geometry and for boundary geometry defined within planar milling operations, such as Planar Mill and Finish Walls.
Type
Curves/Edges mode only
Lets you change a boundary from Open toClosed or vice versa, and displays the status.
Plane
Specifies how to define the boundary plane. The boundary plane is the plane onto which the selected geometry will be projected and the boundary created.
Automatic
Creates the boundary plane from the first two curves/edges or the first three points selected. Creates the boundary plane on the XC-YC plane if it is not possible to define a plane using the selected curves, edges, or points.
Automatic is useful for establishing the ZC level when selecting planar curves that are parallel to the XC-YC plane.
Caution:
Using Automatic with 3d curves can lead to unexpected results and is not recommended.
Boundary Plane Defined by Selected Edges
User–Defined
User-Defined allows you to define a Boundary Plane using the Plane Subfunction.
Use this option to define a boundary plane from contoured 3d curves or edges.
Boundary Created on the Boundary Plane
Material Side
Specifies the side of the boundary on which material will be removed or retained
Geometry Type
Displays the type of boundary (part, blank, check, trim) you are creating.
Propagate Boundary Plane
Lets you move a boundary to a different boundary plane.
Custom Boundary Data
Sets Tolerance, Side Stock, Blank Distance and Cut Feed Rate values associated with the selected boundary.
Create Permanent Boundary
Creates a permanent boundary from the selected boundary.
Edit
Lets you modify the individual members of the selected boundary.
Use Edit Member to change the parameters of individual boundary members. This option allows you to editf an individual boundary member for:
tool position
tolerances
stock value
feed rate
post commands
Note that you can also select permanent boundary members to edit.
Remove
Deletes the last boundary member created.
Append
Completes the creation of the current boundary and immediately starts creating the next temporary boundary.
Reselect All
Deletes all boundaries.

Document Title: Boundary options on the Top Border bar
Document Body:
Boundary options appear in the Selection Group of the Top Border bar, next to the Curve Rule list.
Boundary selection method
Top Border bar appearance
Face
Curves
Points

Option
Description
Tool Position Tanto
Aligns the side of the tool with the boundary.
Tool Position On
Aligns the center point of the tool with the boundary along the tool axis.
Ignore Holes
On: Ignores holes in the selected face.
Off: Creates boundaries around each hole in the selected face.
Ignore Islands
On: Ignores islands in the selected face.
Off: Creates boundaries around each island in the selected face.
Ignore Chamfers
On: Creates boundaries that extend to include chamfers, fillets, and rounds adjacent to the selected faces.
Off: Creates boundaries on the edges of the selected faces.
Snap Point
Controls point selection. For example, you can choose to snap to the nearest end point on a curve.
More
Lets you use curve or face chaining.
You select the beginning curve, then select the ending curve. NX joins all curves between the two curves.

Click here to download the part.
In this hands-on procedure, you create open and closed boundaries to profile the part shown.
Note:
A blank boundary is not required for these operations.
The program includes a roughing operation.
Create the open boundary
Unzip and open 06-0001M.prt.
The part contains a cavity milling operation to rough the part. You define the required boundaries for the profiling operations.
In the Operation Navigator, Program Order view, double-click the PROFILE_OPEN_BOUNDARY operation.
In the Planar Profile dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Part Boundaries .
A blank boundary is not required for this operation.
In the Part Boundaries dialog box, in the Boundaries group, set the following:
Selection Method = Curves
Boundary Type = Open
Tool Side = default setting
Plane = Automatic
You will check the tool side later.
Click Select Curve .
On the Top Border bar, from the Curve Rule list, select Tangent Curves.
Setting Curve Rule to Tangent Curves helps you to select the boundary with fewer picks. The Tangent Curves curve rule selects all of the curve segments that are tangent and continuous to each pick.
You can change the Curve Rule setting when needed as you select the curve segments.
On the Top Border bar, from the Initial Tool Position list, select Tool Position Tanto .
Zoom in to the part area shown.
In the graphics window, select the first curve.
Select the curve close to the starting point, so that the boundary direction is correct.
The tool side indicator should be outside of the part geometry, as shown.
Correct tool side

If the tool side indicator is inside the part geometry, select the opposite Tool Side option.


Notice that only one curve is selected, because none of the connected curve segments are tangent. The boundary plane is not established yet.
Select the second curve segment.
The boundary plane is now defined.
Zoom out to see the tangent curves selected with your second pick.
Zoom in to the part as shown, to select the last curve segment.
Select the last curve segment.
The boundary definition is complete.
This operation machines only the open boundary. You can have multiple curve sets for each boundary definition, but they must be the same boundary type: all open or all closed.
Click OK to save the part boundary definition and to return to the Planar Profile dialog box.
In the Actions group, click Generate .
In the Actions group, click Verify .
In the Tool Path Visualization dialog box, on the 3D Dynamic tab, set the Animation Speed slider, and click Play .
The appropriate slider setting depends on your computer's processing speed, and the amount of material to remove. To see the material removal for this operation, try a setting of 1 or 2.
3D in-process workpiece (IPW) before the profiling operation
3D IPW after the profiling operation
Click OK as required to close the Tool Path Visualization dialog box and to save the operation.
  Create the closed boundaries
In the Operation Navigator, Program Order view, double-click the PROFILE_CLOSED_BOUNDARY operation.
In the Planar Profile dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Part Boundaries .
In the Part Boundaries dialog box, in the Boundaries group, set the following:
Selection Method = Curves
Boundary Type = Closed
Tool Side = Outside
Plane = Automatic
Click Select Curve .
Select the outer circle.
Note:
The location of the start point and the orientation of the direction arrow depend on where you select the circle. Your boundary start point and direction arrow may be different.
Click Add New Set
In the Boundaries group, from the Tool Side list, select Inside.
Select the inner circle.
Click OK to save the part boundary definition and to return to the Planar Profile dialog box.
In the Actions group, click Generate .
Click Verify .
In the Tool Path Visualization dialog box, on the 3D Dynamic tab, set the Animation Speed slider, and click Play .
3D IPW before the profiling operation
3D IPW after the profiling operation
Click OK as required to close the Tool Path Visualization dialog box and to save the operation.
Add custom member data
In the Operation Navigator, Program Order view, double-click the PROFILE_OPEN_BOUNDARY operation.
In the Planar Profile dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Part Boundaries .
In the Part Boundaries dialog box, expand the Members group.
In the Members group, from the members list, select Member 1 and Control-select the last member.
The dialog box displays settings that apply to individual members. You can select one or more of the boundary members.
Note:
You can set the tool position (On or Tanto) and add custom member data to any of the boundary members. You can trim or extend only the first and last members.
In the Members group, expand the Custom Member Data group.
Set the following, and click OK to save the part boundary definition.
Stock =
Stock value = 0.05
Generate and verify the operation.
The first and last segments of the boundary retain stock.
Delete boundary members
In this example, you no longer need the beginning and ending segments of the previously defined open boundary.
In the Planar Profile dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Part Boundaries .
With nothing selected in the Part Boundaries dialog box, zoom in to the part as shown.
Note:
When more than one boundary is defined, you select the boundary to modify from the list in the Boundaries group. If you must select a boundary, do not select any of the individual members from the list in the Members group.
Shift-select the last curve segment.
Move to the boundary beginning, and shift-select the first curve segment.
Notice that the boundary start point, direction arrow, and tool side indicator move to the new Member 1 curve segment.
Click OK to save the part boundary definition and return to the Planar Profile dialog box.
In the Actions group, click Generate .
Close the planar profile operation.
Save and close the part file.

There are currently different ways to define boundaries. The boundary user interface introduced in NX 9 is used to specify all boundaries except the drive geometry for the Boundary drive method. The Boundary drive method is available in fixed axis and variable axis surface contouring operations, such as surface contour, guiding curves, and streamline.
NX automatically updates legacy operations to the correct Tool Side value. The Tool Side option replaces the Material Side option that was available in versions prior to NX 9.0.
Boundaries interface
The way to define Milling boundaries is consistent with the way you define other types of geometry and includes the following.
The graphics display clearly shows the boundary plane and the projection vector.
1 Boundary label
2 Boundary plane
3 Boundary projection vector
You can see each boundary segment projected to the boundary plane as you select it.
You can identify the start point, end point, boundary direction, and tool side for each boundary.
Boundary selected:
1 Start point
2 Tool side indicator (left)
3 Direction arrow
4 Tool position indicator (Tanto)
5 End point
The graphics display includes custom offsets for the boundary and for individual members.
Boundary member selected:
1 Boundary label
2 Custom boundary Offset input box connected to the start point
3 Custom boundary Member Offset input box connected to the position indicator of the member
4 Selected boundary member
The Tool Side option replaces the Material Side option. NX automatically updates legacy operations to the correct Tool Side value.
Pre-NX 9 boundaries interface
Using the pre-NX 9 boundaries interface, you can see each boundary segment projected to the boundary plane as you select it. NX automatically closes gaps in the boundary as you select the boundary segments.
In pre-NX 9 boundaries:
You use the Material Side option to specify which side of the boundary you do not want to cut.
The graphics display when you create or edit the boundary includes the start point and tool position indicators. The material side, end point, and boundary plane are not shown.
1 Start point
2 Tool position indicator (Tanto)

This boundaries dialog box is available in all operations, except the surface contouring drive methods.
Note:
The Part Boundaries, Blank Boundaries, and Check Boundaries dialog boxes have the same options. In the Trim Boundaries dialog box, the Side Trimmed option replaces the Tool Side option
Boundaries
Selection Method list
Selection Method
Specifies the geometry used to define the boundary.
Note:
The available options depend on what you select from the Selection Method list.
Face
Lets you select a single planar face of a sheet or solid body.
If the defining face for a boundary is non-planar, use the Curves option to select the face edges.
Curves, Points
Let you select multiple curves or points to define an open or closed boundary. You define the boundary direction when you select the second curve or point. You must select the remaining boundary members in order after defining the boundary direction.
Tip:
To delete a curve from the boundary definition, hold Shift and select the curve.
Boundary Type
Specifies whether the boundary is open or closed.
Tool Side
Available for part, blank, and check boundaries.
Specifies the side of the boundary on which to place the tool.
Side Trimmed
Available for trim boundaries.
Specifies which side of the boundary to exclude from the tool path.
Plane
Specifies how to define the boundary plane. The boundary plane is the plane onto which NX projects the selected geometry to create the boundary.
Automatic
Creates the boundary plane from the first two curves or edges, or from the first three points selected. Creates the boundary plane on the XC-YC plane if it is not possible to define a plane using the selected curves, edges, or points.
The Automatic option is useful for establishing the ZC level when selecting planar curves that are parallel to the XC-YC plane.
Caution:
Using the Automatic option with 3D curves can lead to unexpected results and is not recommended.
Specify
Lets you manually define a boundary plane. You can specify how far from the selected geometry to place the boundary plane. Use this option to define a boundary plane from contoured 3D curves or edges.
Custom Boundary Data
The available custom boundary options depend on the following:
Whether you specify the boundary within a parent geometry group or within an operation.
The type of boundary.
Offset
Available for boundaries specified in a parent geometry group.
Lets you specify an offset value for the entire boundary. For example, if you select part geometry to define the blank boundary, you can add an offset value to represent the casting thickness.
Stock
Available for some operation-specific boundaries.
Lets you specify a stock value for the boundary.
Cut Feed Rate
Available for some operation-specific boundaries.
Members
The Members options are available after you select one or more boundary members from the list. These options specify the settings to apply to the selected boundary members only.
Custom Member Data
Connect to Next Member
Specifies how to close gaps between boundary members.
Extend
(Default) Closes gaps between the selected member and the next member by extending the segments in a straight line until they intersect. If the members do not intersect, NX joins their end points.
Member 1
Member 2
Note:
The Extend option does not apply to boundaries that use the Contact tool position.
Direct
Closes gaps between the selected member and the next member by connecting the end points of the curves.
Note:
NX always uses the Direct option for boundaries that use the Contact tool position.
Offset
Available for boundaries specified in a parent geometry group.
Lets you specify an offset value for the selected boundary members.
Stock
Available for some operation-specific boundaries.
Cut Feed Rate
Available for some operation-specific boundaries.
Start of Path Events, End of Path Events
Available for some operation-specific boundaries.
Control the motion output. You can specify machine events such as tool changes, start and end events, or special Post commands.
Copy From
Lets you copy post commands from another operation or from an operation template.
Edit
Lets you select from a list of user-defined events.
Start on this Member
Available when you select a member of a closed boundary. Sets the selected member as the first member (Member1) of the boundary.
Trim / Extend Member
Available when you select the first or last member of an open boundary, or when you select the first member of a closed boundary.

Document Title: Create Geometry — mold and die sequences
Document Body:
The Create Geometry dialog allows you to create geometry parent groups used in various operation types. The Types that are available are determined from the Machining Environment selected. The Type determines the Subtype or types of geometry that are available for selection as shown below.
Type
Parent Group/Subtype
machining_knowledge
MCS, WORKPIECE, MILL_AREA, SIMPLE_HOLE, CB_HOLE, CS_HOLE, THD_CB_HOLE, THD_SIMPLE_HOLE, THD_CS_HOLE, ALL_FEATURES, FEATURE_PROCESS.
hole_making
MCS, WORKPIECE, MILL_AREA, SIMPLE_HOLE, CB_HOLE, CS_HOLE, THD_CB_HOLE, THD_SIMPLE_HOLE, THD_CS_HOLE, ALL_FEATURES, FEATURE_PROCESS.
die_sequences
SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG, SEQUENCE ZLEVEL, SEQUENCE IPW, SEQUENCE_PROFILE_2D and SEQUENCE_PROFILE_3D
mold_sequences
SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG, SEQUENCE ZLEVEL, SEQUENCE IPW, SEQUENCE_TOOL, SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG_HSM and SEQUENCE_ZLEVEL_HSM
Note:
WORKPIECE is a MILL_GEOM Group.
Mold and Die Sequences
There are special geometry groups for machining processes, that contain a specific sequence of operations. For example, the die_sequence type contains geometry groups that create complete processes for Zlevel cutting, zigzag cutting, and 3D profiling.
The process assistants are provided for these. To read more about it go to Mold and Die Setups.
Parent Group/Subtype
Description
SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG
Use this option to cut mold cores and cavities that are mostly shallow, without steep walls or deep areas. After the initial roughing, it uses a series of operations that finish the areas with zig-zag cutting in a criss-cross fashion, and flowcut to cut the valleys. The operations use progressively smaller tools, stock, and tolerance. Common tools and methods are included in the setup, so you can modify the predefined operations, or create more of your own.
SEQUENCE ZLEVEL
Use this option to cut mold cores and cavities containing steep walls or deep areas. After the initial roughing, it uses a series of operations that finish the areas with zig-zag cutting in the non-steep areas, zlevel cutting in the steep areas, and flowcut to cut the valleys. The operations use progressively smaller tools, stock, and tolerance. Common tools and methods are included in the setup, so you can modify the predefined operations, or create more of your own.
SEQUENCE IPW
Use this option to rough a mold core or cavity with rest milling. It uses a series of cavity milling operations with progressively smaller tools. Using the in process workpiece (IPW), each operation cuts only the material remaining from the previous operations. This is commonly used to reduce the steps left by roughing, and to clean out material in corners left by a larger tool.
SEQUENCE_PROFILE_2D
Use this option to cut a 2d profile with a series of five operations, using progressively smaller tools and less stock. A common boundary is machined, and the depth is controlled with the floor plane. The operations use the 2D in process workpiece (IPW) to clean out the material in the corners that are left by the previous tool. This is commonly used for the edges of trim dies.
SEQUENCE_PROFILE_3D
Use this option to cut a 3d profile with a series of five operations, using progressively smaller tools and less stock. A common boundary is machined, and the depth is controlled by offsetting from the height of the edges or curves used to create the boundary. The operations use the 2D in process workpiece (IPW) to clean out the material in the corners that are left by the previous tool. This is commonly used for the edges of trim dies.
SEQUENCE_TOOL
This demonstrates the use of holder collision checking and minimum material removal in a series of cavity milling operations. The sequence starts with a short tool, and each following operation uses a longer tool. If any of the operations will remove less than 35% of the remaining material, they are suppressed.
SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG_HSM
This is similar to SEQUENCE_ZIGZAG, but the depths of cut, stepovers, stock, tolerance, corner smoothing, and engages have been modified for high speed machining of mold steel.
SEQUENCE_ZLEVEL_HSM
This is similar to SEQUENCE_ZlEVEL, but the depths of cut, stepovers, stock, tolerance, corner smoothing, and engages have been modified for high speed machining of mold steel.

Geometry parents are used to define geometry for manufacturing. You must first create the geometry parent, and then add geometry to the new geometry parent. The geometry can then be inherited by manufacturing operations or other geometry parents.
This example shows how to create a WORKPIECE geometry parent in the hierarchy of an existing higher level MCS geometry parent.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Geometry .
In the Create Geometry dialog box, select a Milling option from the Type list.
The Type option determines the Geometry Subtypes that are available.
In the Geometry Subtype group, click WORKPIECE .
You can define Part Geometry in the WORKPIECE, MILL_AREA, and MILL_GEOM Geometry Subtypes.
In the Location group, select MCS_MILL from the Geometry list.
Your new geometry parent inherits geometry from the location you select. For example, when you select MCS_MILL, the WORKPIECE geometry parent inherits orientation and clearance geometry from the higher level MCS geometry parent.
Click OK.
The Workpiece dialog box opens. The dialog box name matches the Geometry Subtype you select.
In the Workpiece dialog box, in the Geometry group, click Specify Part .
The Part Geometry dialog box opens.
In the graphics window, select the desired Part Geometry.
The default selection option is Geometry. If you want to select facet bodies or features (surface regions), select the appropriate option under Selected Options.
Click OK to close the Part Geometry dialog box.
(Optional) In the Workpiece dialog box, specify Blank or Check Geometry using the preceding steps.
Click OK to save the geometry parent.
The new geometry parent appears in the Geometry View of the Operation Navigator. It is located in the hierarchy of the higher level geometry parent you selected in step 4.
MCS_MILL
WORKPIECE

Use the Create Tool command to create a new tool and tool group. You can populate a tool group by creating tools or by retrieving tools from the tool library.
In the Create Tool dialog box, you must first select a tool type from the Type list. The type you select determines the tool subtypes and parameters that are available. For example, the mill_planar and hole_making tool types include the cutting insert, carrier, head, and pockets. You create the objects and place them within the Operation Navigator in a specific order to control the parent-child relationships. In the following example, the carrier is the parent group of the head, and the head is the parent group of the pocket.
CARRIER
HEAD
POCKET1
MILL1
You can save parameters associated with the tool to use as default values for the corresponding postprocessor commands. For milling, drilling, and turning tools, the parameters that you can reuse include:
ADJUST and CUTCOM register numbers
TOOL/POCKET number
Spindle directions
Offsets
User-defined attributes
Each operation needs an appropriate tool to machine the part area. Tool parameters define:
The cutting insert shape and dimensions.
The tool holder.
The tool material, which is used to calculate machining data.
Tool parameters can be retrieved from a library with hundreds of standard tools, or created as needed. Each cutting tool is placed in a holder, within a carrier and turret, and loaded on a machine tool.
All operations that use the tool inherit the tool parameters from the Tool parent group. In the Machine Tool View of the Operation Navigator, all operations using the tool are shown below the tool.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Tool
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Tool group

Use the Create Tool dialog box to define cutting tools for use in operations.
To define a tool, you can:
Enter the parameters for the tool.
Retrieve a tool from the provided library.
Copy a tool in the Operation Navigator, and modify it.
If you access the Create Tool dialog box from a node in the Operation Navigator, the location of the new tool depends on the node that you select. If the node is a valid parent, the tool is created under that parent. Otherwise, it is created under the default parent.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Tool

You define milling tool holders in the tool parameters dialog box, by using the options on the Holder tab to define a stack of one or more cylinders or cones. You can also retrieve tool holders from the holder library.
When you define a holder for a tool and export the tool to a tool library, the holder definition is exported with the tool and linked to the tool, so that the holder is always retrieved with the tool.
In some operations, you can select the Check Tool and Holder check box to use a tool holder definition during collision checking. For example, the Area Milling and Flow Cut drive methods of the surface contouring operation subtypes, and the Zlevel Profile operation subtype.
The tool holder is displayed any time that you display the tool. You can display the tool in the following ways:
When you select a tool node in the Operation Navigator.
From the tool dialog box when you click Display .
When you click Edit Display in an operation parameters dialog box, and you select 3D from the Tool Display list in the Tool group of the Display Options dialog box.
From the Tool Path Visualization dialog box , when Tool Display is set to Solid, On, or Assembly on the 3D Dynamic tab or the Replay tab. NX can display the holder during replay and dynamic material removal.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in dialog box
[Milling tool] dialog box→Holder tab

Document Title: Hands-on: Extract a tool holder using an existing reference point
Document Body:
Click here to download the step file.
This hands-on procedure shows how to use an existing reference point to extract a tool holder to the reference point while creating a tool. The region above the reference point is inside the machine tool and hence the tool holder is extracted only to the reference point.
Procedure
Create a 01-0006M folder and unzip 01-0006M.zip in that folder.
In NX, choose File tab→Open .
In the filter that is available after the File name box, select STEP Files (*.stp;*.step;*.stpx;*.stpz;*.stpxz) to display step files in the current directory.
Select 01-0006M.stp file from the 01-0006M directory and click OK.
Choose Application tab→Manufacturing .
In the Machining Environment dialog box, select the following and click OK.
CAM Session Configuration = cam_general
CAM Setup to Create = mill_planar
Choose Home tab→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, select MILL as the Tool Subtype and click OK.
Move the tool as shown in the following graphic.
Select the Holder tab.
In the Holder Definition group, from the Holder Source list, select Solid Body.
In the graphic window, select the body as shown in the following graphic.
In the Holder Definition group, click Extract Step parameters .
Select the Tool tab and in the Diameter group, set the (D) Diameter to 10.
Click OK.
Close the step file without saving it.

Document Title: Hands-on: Extract a tool holder by defining a reference point
Document Body:
Click here to download the step file.
This hands-on procedure shows how to define a reference point and use that reference point to extract a tool holder while creating a tool. You can define an additional reference when an existing reference point cannot be used for extracting the required tool holder.
Procedure
Create a 01-0007M folder and unzip 01-0007M.zip in that folder.
In NX, choose File tab→Open .
In the filter that is available after the File name box, select STEP Files (*.stp;*.step;*.stpx;*.stpz;*.stpxz) to display step files in the current directory.
Select 01-0007M.stp file from the 01-0007M directory and click OK.
Choose Application tab→Manufacturing .
In the Machining Environment dialog box, select the following and click OK.
CAM Session Configuration = cam_general
CAM Setup to Create = mill_planar
Choose Home tab→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, select MILL as the Tool Subtype and click OK.
Move the tool as shown in the following graphic.
Select the Holder tab.
In the Holder Definition group, from the Holder Source list, select Solid Body.
In the graphic window, select body as shown in the following graphic
In the Holder Definition group→Specify Mounting, click CSYS Dialog.
Select the edge of the body as shown in the following graphic and click OK in the CSYS dialog box.
In the Holder Definition group, click Extract Step parameters .
Select the Tool tab and in the Diameter group, set the (D) Diameter to 12.
Click OK.
Close the step file without saving it.

Type
List
Lets you select the operation type in which the tool will be used. This selection determines the available tool subtypes.
Library
Retrieve Tools from Library
Opens the Library Class Selection dialog box. You can retrieve a tool after you specify the class and subclass.
Retrieve Tools from Cloud Connect Tool Manager
Opens the Cloud Connect Tool Manager tabbed window. You can retrieve or create a tool in this window
Retrieve Devices from Library
Opens the Library Class Selection dialog box.
Tool Subtype
Displays tool options depending on the operation type that you specify in the Type list.
Location
Tool
Specifies the parent object or parent group for the tool.
Name
System Name
Text box
Sets the tool name. Enter a name by which you can recognize the tool.
Tool names may contain letters, numbers, periods, underscores, and dashes.
User Defined Name
Text box
Sets the tool name. Enter a name by which you can recognize the tool.
Tool names may contain letters, numbers, periods, underscores, dashes, and spaces.
Note:
Cannot contain the following characters !, @, *, ?, ". :, <, >, ', |, \.

This example shows how to create a milling tool in a manufacturing part in which a setup has been created.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, from the Type list, select mill_planar.
In the Tool Subtype group, click MILL .
In the Location group, from the Machine Tool View list, select POCKET_01.
The new tool will inherit the tool number from the location. In this example, the number for the tool will be 1.
(Optional) In the Name box, enter a descriptive name by which you can identify the tool.
Click OK.
A default tool of the selected type is displayed in the graphics window. In the Milling Tool-5 Parameters dialog box, in the Numbers group, the selected pocket number is assigned in the Tool Number, Adjust Register, and Cutcom Register boxes.
In the Dimensions group, enter the desired tool parameters.
As you enter parameters, the display of the tool is updated.
The holder definition is optional. You can click OK to create the tool without a holder.
Click the Holder tab.
Enter the desired holder parameters.
As you enter parameters, the display of the holder is updated.
Click OK to create the new tool.
At this point, the tool exists only in the current part file. To make the tool available in the future, you must save the part. To make the tool available in other parts, you must add the tool to a library.
The new tool is created and added to the Machine Tool View of the Operation Navigator. If you designed a holder, the holder parameters are also saved with the tool.
To check your new tool, in the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, expand the CARRIER→POCKET_01 node and double-click the new tool node. The saved tool and holder parameters are available for editing.

This example shows how to create a tool holder that works like the one shown. The holder shown accepts a 12 mm end mill.
The tool holder associated with a tool is displayed whenever you select the tool.
Do one of the following steps:
If you have a tool for which you require a holder definition, double-click the tool in the Operation Navigator to edit it.
If you do not have a tool, choose Home tab→Insert group→ Create Tool , and define a suitable tool.
12 mm diameter ball mill, 75 mm long, with 40 mm flute length
In the Preview group, make sure that the Preview check box is selected.
In the milling tool dialog box, click the Holder tab.
In the Holder Steps group, enter parameters for the first step, as shown:
Lower Diameter
26.0
Length
13.9
Upper Diameter
42.0
When you add a value to the Lower Diameter box and press Tab or Enter, the list shows New in the step column, and you might see an Alerts message that tells you that the length must be greater than zero. When you add the length value, the message is removed.
After you enter a value in the Length box, the Step column in the list shows 1, and the values appear in the appropriate columns.
The taper angle is calculated to produce an upper diameter of zero, and the holder is displayed as a flat disk.
When you enter the value in the Upper Diameter box, NX shows the first step in a preview above the tool.
In the Tool Insertion group, in the Offset box, type the distance to which the tool is inserted into the holder.
Offset
30.0
The holder moves to the position in which cutting occurs.
In the Holder Steps group, click Add New Set .
By default, a new step is shaped like a cylinder. It has the same lower diameter as the upper diameter of the previous step, and the same length.
Change the value in the Length box to 16.
NX updates the preview.
Click Add New Set .
Because the next step is by default a cylinder with the same length and diameter of the previous step, the second step appears to increase in length. You will change this appearance by editing the parameters.
Enter parameters as shown:
Lower Diameter
80.3
Length
19.0
Upper Diameter
80.3
This step represents the portion of the tool holder that, in a solid tool assembly model, has a V-groove and that is notched for drive dogs on the spindle. You need not model the groove because it is not used in the kinematic model. If the drive dogs are a concern for collision checking, model a larger diameter.
For practical purposes, you can stop here. The rest of the tool holder is inserted into the spindle, and does not play a role in collision checking.
Although it plays no part in collision checking, you can add a taper.
(Optional) Click Add New Set .
Enter parameters as shown:
Lower Diameter
57.2
Length
82.7
Taper Angle
-8.3
The taper angle is the half-angle of a conical step. A negative angle results in the upper diameter being smaller than the lower diameter.
The Taper Angle and the Upper Diameter values are linked. If you change one value, NX updates the other.
Click OK to save the tool and holder.
If you export the tool to a library, the holder is exported with it, and both are retrieved when you retrieve the tool.

This example shows how to edit a tool holder.
In the Operation Navigator, select the node for the tool that is held by the tool holder.
The tool and the holder that you defined for it are displayed when you select the tool.
Edit the tool.
You can double-click the node in the Operation Navigator or right-click the node and choose Edit.
You are going to edit the step shown in the figure and add more steps.
In the tool parameters dialog box, on the Holder tab, in the Holder Steps group, select step 3 in the list.
Because the display does not represent permanent geometry, you cannot select steps in the graphics window. You must select steps in the list.
The parameters for the selected step are displayed in the boxes in the Holder Steps group, and are available for editing.
In the Length box, change the value to 6.0.
With step 3 still selected, click Add New Set .
The new step has the same lower diameter as the upper diameter of the previous step, and the same length.
In the Taper Angle box, edit the value to –60 and press Enter.
The Taper Angle and the Upper Diameter values are linked. If you change one value, NX updates the other.
Click Add New Set .
The new step has the same lower diameter as the upper diameter of the previous step, and the same length.
Change the value in the Taper Angle box to 60.
Click Add New Set .
The new step has the same lower diameter as the upper diameter of the previous step, and the same length.
Select step 7, the tapered segment that is inserted into the spindle, and click Delete .
Because this portion of the tool holder does not take part in collisions on the machine, it is not important to represent it.
In the list, select step 1, and edit the value in the Corner Radius box to 5.0.
A corner radius is valid only at the bottom of a step and only for a convex radius. If you add a radius that violates these conditions, the value is ignored.
Click OK to save your changes.

This explains how to define a tool holder for a turning insert.
Define a new turning insert, or edit an insert.
In the tool dialog box, on the Holder tab, in the Holder (Shank) group, select the Use Turn Holder check box.
The check box is not available for threading or form tools.
From the Style list, select an available style.
You can select User Defined if you require a non-standard shape.The Legend group shows a two-view drawing of the selected style.
From the Hand list, select Right or Left.
The Hand list can be replaced by shortcuts, as shown.
From the Shank Type list, select Square Shank or Round Shank.
The Shank type list can be replaced by shortcuts, as shown.
In the Dimensions group, enter parameters that are available for the style of holder that you specified.
You can use the dimensions shown in the Legend group as a guide.
Click OK to save the tool and holder.
The holder is displayed whenever the tool is displayed.

A carrier and pocket represent the tool change belt and the pockets on a machine tool.
Define a carrier and pockets to:
Manage the capacity, or number of tools that the device holds. NX will allow users to add tools only until the specified capacity Is reached.
Substitute tools between pockets without redefining tool numbers by assigning tool numbers to the pockets.
Preload company default tools in templates.
Note:
When you create a carrier for turning tools, specify the lathe work plane relative to the WCS.
Pockets
For each pocket you can:
Specify an adjust register and cutcom register that is different than the tool number. Both registers match the tool number by default.
Tools inherit the pocket number and register values.
Turning tools do not use register values inherited from the pocket. Turning tools support multiple tracking points, and each tracking point can have different register values.
Modify the list of holding systems on the pocket.
Use the holding systems when you want to restrict tool loading. For example, you may have some positions on a turret that accept one holding system, and other positions that accept a different holding system.
Specify the capacity. The default value is 1.
Pockets inherit adjust register and cutcom register from the machine model.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Tool
Location in dialog box
Tool Subtype→MCT_POCKET , CARRIER

The head object can be found in the Create Tool dialog. The head object can have only carriers as parents. Only pockets or tools may be placed under a head.
You can specify an angled head by selecting the head axis with a vector. This vector will be used to output rotary and linear coordinates for your machine tool. The head object will not change the tool axis or the goto points in the operation.
Note:
The Head object replaces the previous HOLDER functionality.
For the Postprocessor, the head's kinematics are passed as mom variables to the Machine Tool Drivers (MTD) used for NX Machine Tool Simulation (NX MTS). The MTD then makes a new junction to correctly orient the tool. In the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, place an operation under the appropriate head object to process the goto points in the generated tool paths with the correct kinematics information. Head doesn't send output to the CLSF. The tool path contains the correct rotated coordinates. A head used in this manner has the same affect on the tool path as a HOLDER command on the LOAD UDE had in previous versions.
The usage of the new head depends on the new kinematics. The mom_kin_iks_usage flag must be set to 1, for the software to use the head object in the tool view. In NX 4 and later; only the head object and the new mom variables will be used, the HOLDER word will be ignored.
There is no vocabulary output to the CLSF for the head object. The tool path itself will contain the correct rotated coordinates.

From the Create Tool dialog, select the head icon, then choose OK or Apply. This will open the Head dialog.
Enter coordinates for the gauge point to define the difference between the where the tool is loaded on the machine tool and the new location on the head where the tool will be loaded.
Enter coordinates for the spindle axis to define the axis direction of the tool when it is loaded into the head.
See theOptions tab for further definitions.

You can use the Head dialog box to define:
Gauge Point: the difference between the spindle gauge point where the tool is loaded on the machine and the new location on the head where the tool will be loaded.
Spindle Axis: the axis direction of the tool when it is loaded into the head with respect to the Z axis of the machine tool. A right angle head along the +X axis would have a spindle axis of (1,0,0).

You can validate that the tool flute length is long enough to cut to the specified depth per cut. By using the Check Flute Length and Depth per Cut option found in the Manufacturing Customer Defaults. If this customer default is selected, and the flute length of the tool is less than the nominal programmed cut depth, a warning is issued with an option to continue.

Note:
The parameters describing the insert shape depend on the selected insert type.
Tool tab
Insert
Insert Shape
Specifies an insert shape as used by the majority of tool vendors.
Standard
The standard grooving insert represents a cutter with two identical corner radii.
Full Nose Radius
This insert type describes a grooving tool having no bottom edge with the insert width being equivalent to the tool's nose diameter.
Ring Type Joint
The ring type joint grooving tool represents a special tool type with no corner radii and side edges not providing clearance for plunge cuts.
User Defined
This insert shape allows for maximum variability of the grooving insert, as it represents a cutter with two independent corner radii and two independent side clearance angles.
Insert Position
This determines the spindle direction for machining.
Topside
This will cause the spindle to turn clockwise when cutting above centerline.
Underside
This will cause the spindle to turn counterclockwise when cutting above centerline.
Legend
Displays a sketch representing the currently selected tool insert shape.
Dimensions
(OA) Orient Angle
Measured CCLW from the positive X-axis to the first cutting edge met from exterior.
Warning:
The operation's level angle (or the level angle +/- 180) should not equal the tool's orient angle. If these are equal, the system cannot determine which side to move into the material in linear roughing. You can try making your tool orient angle incrementally larger or smaller (eg. 359.9999) or try using a plunge zig cutting strategy with an appropriate step angle and cleanup inactive.
(IL) Insert Length
This parameter represents the total length of the insert.
(IW) Insert Width
The insert width describes the width of a groove that would result from a straight cut (radial cut for OD groove tool) into material. This parameter appears with the Standard, Ring Type Joint and User Defined Tools.
(R) Radius
This is the radius of the circle at the corner of the cutter. The Standard tool Radius assumes the tool's left and right nose radii are equal. You may define a left and right Radius in User Defined tool types.
(SA) Side Angle
The side angle defines the clearance angles of the tool on the left and on the right side as equal. An insert shape as shown in the Standard sketch represents a positive value of the side angle. This parameter appears only in the Standard and Full Nose Radius tool types.
(LA) Left Angle , (RA) Right Angle
These angles define the clearance angles of the tool with the possibility to insert unequal values if the tool that you are defining is asymmetrical
The left angle is the angle on the left side of the tool at an orientation angle of 90 degrees as seen from the top.
(TA) Tip Angle
This parameter represents the angle at the bottom of the cutter to the rotation axis. The TA shown in the sketch represents a positive value of the tip angle. This parameter appears only in the dialogs for Standard and User Defined tools.
More
Thickness
The thickness of the insert.
Description
Description
Contains your description of the tool.
Material
Lets you specify a material for the tool.
Numbers
Tool Number
This is the T-code number that brings the tool into cutting position on the turret. 
Information
Catalog Number
This is a user-defined character string that can be used to identify the tool.
Library
Library Reference
Specifies a unique identifier within the library.
Export Tool Part File
This tells NX you are defining a solid turning tool, and makes the tool mount and tool tip junction options available.
.
Export Tool to Library
Exports the tool to the library.
More tab
Machine Control
Manual Tool Change
Adds a stop to allow changing the tool manually.
Text
Specifies text for the tool change.
Limits
Maximum Tool Reach
This is the maximum distance which a tool and its holder can travel into a part. This is dependant upon the geometry of a part and the tool holder. The purpose of this parameter is to prevent collision of the tool holder with the part.
Maximum Depth
This parameter describes the maximum depth per cut that the tool can plunge into a groove. This is dependant upon the geometry of the insert. Notice the relationship between Max Depth and Level Depth in the grooving operation.
Minimum Facing Diameter
This is the minimum diameter that the tool can cut when grooving on the face of the part (trepanning) that will not cause interference on the outside of the tool.
This option must be customized into the dialog box.
Maximum Facing Diameter
This is the maximum diameter that the tool can cut when grooving on the face of the part (trepanning) that will not cause interference on the inside of the tool.
This option must be customized into the dialog box.
Simulation
X Mount, Y Mount
Position the tool relative to the turret/head for machine simulation.  These values are the signed distances from the tool tracking point to the turret/head reference point.
