When you set Type to Drilling Tool, select the Subtype of the tool you want to create. These tools are intended for use with the Point to Point module. The Point to Point module only recognizes a drilling tool. Therefore, the spotdrill, boring bar, reamer, counterbore, countersink, and tap are all seen by the system as the standard drill. These subtypes are available to help you separate and organize your tools.
For example, when you select Tap as your subtype and select OK, the system displays the drilling tool dialog. Enter the parameters for a tap and select OK. The system displays this tap in the Machine Tool View of the Operation Navigator as a Tap. To you it is a tap, to the system it is a drilling tool.
You can also use Holemaking tools for point to point operations. However, the processor does not recognize all the Holemaking tool parameters.
Drilling Tool Dialog Parameters
Choose or define the following when creating a drill:
(D) Diameter
Diameter is the diameter of the drill.
(CR) Corner Radius
Corner Radius is the lower corner radius at the corner of the profile of the drill.
(L) Length
Length is the length of the drill.
(PA) Point Angle
Point Angle is the angle of the point of the drill.
(PL) Point Length
The length from the tool shoulder to the tool tip.
(FL) Flute Length
Flute Length is the height of the cutting area along the profile of the cutter. See previous diagram.
Number Flutes
Number Flutes is the number of flutes in the drill.
Direction
Direction is the spindle direction of the tool. Choose either CLW or CCLW.
XOFF
XOFF is a value used by the controller to position the tool with respect to a reference point. XOFF represents the distance from turret reference point to tool tip, parallel to the centerline.
Y/ZOFF
YOFF or ZOFF is a value used by the controller to position the tool with respect to a reference point. ZOFF and YOFF are measured along the turning axis of either the spindle or the lathe. ZOFF is used for drilling machines and YOFF is used for lathes which have no Z axis.
ADJUST Register
ADJUST Register allows you to correct the positioning of the tool due to variations in the milling machine. This option is similar for all tool types.
CUTCOM Register
CUTCOM Register allows you to correct the positioning of the tool due to the variations in tool diameter caused by wear. This option is similar for all tool types.
Tool/Face Number
Tool/Face Number provides a way to reference the tool or the turret location for the LOAD/TOOl command in the CLSF. This option is similar to the Tool Number option for milling tools and the Turret Face Number option for lathe tools.
Catalog Number
Catalog Number provides a method to track the tool. This option is similar for all tool types.
Display Tool
Display Tool allows you to display a profile of the tool in the graphics window. This option is similar for all tool types.
Coolant Through
Generates the mom variable mom_tool_coolant_through with a value of yes or no. The postprocessor uses this value to determine whether the tool has a coolant passage through the tool body, and outputs the corresponding coolant code.
This option does not create a Coolant On or Coolant Off user defined event. (UDE).

Define solid tools for cases which do not match the existing milling, drilling, or turning parametric tool classes. For example, you can define probes, laser heads, and painting heads as solid tools.
All solid tools are library tools. You create the tool directly from the NX solid model with the following settings:
Type = probing
Tool Subtype = GENERIC or PROBE
Probe tools include additional parameters to define sensors and stems.
Solid modeled tools can be one solid model or an assembly, and support:
All display, verify, and simulation commands
Mounting junction and multiple tracking points
Special parameters for each tracking point
Sensor tip diameter, length and vector (direction)
Sensor tip shape
Storage in the ASCII library and in Teamcenter.
The tool parameters, such as stored tracking points, are available when needed. It is not necessary to parametrically define the shape of the tool because the solid model defines the shape, and tracking points determine what point on the solid follows the programmed path.
Note:
For an existing milling, drilling, or turning tool class, you completely define the tool parameters and export a solid model part file with the tool definition to use for simulation and verification.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Tool
Location in dialog box
Type→probing

Activate global translucency.
Choose Menu→Preferences→Visualization.
Select the Rendering→Graphics node.
In the Graphics group, select the Translucency check box.
Set the translucency value.
Choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing.
On the Visualization tab, in the Tool Display group, move the Tool Translucency slider to increase or decrease the tool translucency.

When a parametric tool references a tool assembly part file, you can display the parametric representation and the tool assembly at the same time, while you edit the tool parameters. The dual tool display helps you to match tool parameters to the exact shape of the tool assembly's cutting portions. In the following example, the Tool and Assembly display shows that the parametric tool does not exactly match the tool assembly.
Tool
Tool Assembly
Tool and Assembly
Note:
Tool and Assembly is only available when the dialog box for the tool is open.
Library tools
When you manually overwrite the parameters for a library tool within your CAM setup file, NX removes the library reference. NX breaks the link to the library tool assembly when you click OK in the tool dialog box to save your manual changes.
To use the library tool parameter values, and restore the tool assembly display, you do one of the following:
Retrieve another copy of the tool from the library.
If the name of the first copy of the tool is ugt0202_020, the name for the second copy of the tool is typically ugt0202_020_1.
This method maintains the manual values you entered for the first copy of the tool.
Update the tool from the library.
Right-click the modified tool and choose Object→Update Tool From Library.
This method discards your manual changes to the tool.
See Match tool parameters to the tool assembly dimensions
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Milling, drilling, or turning tool that references a tool assembly part file.
Tool dialog box must be open for edits.
Menu
Tools→Tool Path Display
Command
Display Tool
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Display group→Tool , Tool Assembly , Tool and Assembly

When you select or edit a tool, the tool is displayed at the default position.
The scenario determines the tool's default position:
If the tool is associated with one operation, the tool is displayed at the start of the tool path.
If the tool is associated with more than one operation, the tool is displayed at the start of the tool path in the first operation.
If the tool is not associated with an operation, the tool is displayed at a distance from the part blank that is calculated by NX.
If the MCS is defined and available, the tool is displayed at the MCS.
If no MCS is available, the tool is displayed at the WCS.
If no part is displayed in the graphics window, the tool is displayed at the center of the graphics window.
If an operation is selected, the tool is displayed at the start of the operation.
If more than one operation is selected, the tool associated with the first operation as determined by the program order view is displayed at the start of that operation.
Note:
When you select the tool to view it, it is displayed in the orientation in which it is used in the operation. When you edit the tool, it is displayed in the orientation in which it was created.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
A tool and operation must exist
Graphics window
Shows the tool location relative to the part, blank, MCS, or WCS

Document Title: Match tool parameters to the tool assembly dimensions
Document Body:
In this example, the parameters of a library tool do not match the dimensions of the associated tool assembly.
Note:
You must have write permissions for your tool library to modify the tool.
Add the library tool to your CAM setup.
In the tool view of the Operation Navigator, double-click the tool node to open the dialog box for the tool, and edit the parameters.
Machine name
Unused Items
SPINDLE
POCKET_1
Library tool with tool assembly
With the tool dialog box open, choose Home tab→Display group→Tool and Assembly .
The dual display helps you to see which parameters you need to change.
Modify the parameters to match the tool assembly.
When the tool parameters are correct, click OK to save the tool definition.
The Edit Tool message box displays to warn that you are modifying a library tool.
In the Edit Tool message box, click Yes to save the tool definition.
When you click Yes to save the changes, you manually overwrite the library tool parameters in your CAM session. NX removes the library reference, and the tool assembly display disappears. Notice that the Tool and Assembly option is no longer available in the tool display list.
Select the tool node again to display the parametric tool.
If required, update the library tool.
To update the library tool, open the tool dialog box again.
In the tool dialog box, in the Library group, enter the library reference, exactly as it appears in the library.
For example, ugt0201_020
Clear the Export Tool Part File check box.
You only use this option when you create or modify the tool assembly part file.
Click Export Tool to Library .
The Export to Library message box displays to warn you that ugt0201_020 already exists.
Click Replace to update the library tool definition.
The Export Tool to Library message box displays the update status.
Click OK as required to complete the tool export, and close the tool dialog box.

Document Title: Retrieve a tool from a library
Document Body:
This example describes how to retrieve a twist drill from a native ASCII library. The procedure for other tools follows the same pattern of steps. The procedure to retrieve a device is very similar.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Library group, click Retrieve Tools from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, expand a node, and select the tool subtype that you want to find.
For example, expand the Drilling node, and select Twist Drill.
Click OK.
(Optional) In the Search Criteria dialog box, in the Search Parameters group, enter data to filter the search.
For example, if the Library Units list is set to Millimeter, in the Diameter box, type 8. If the Library Units list is set to Inch, in the Diameter box, type 0.75.
You can enter exact values or a simple range of values using <, >, <=, or >=. If you enter >=6 in the Diameter box, the search is narrowed to tools with a diameter that is greater than or equal to 6.
In the Actions group, click Count Matches .
The number of matches is shown in parentheses after the Count Matches label.
You can click List Results to preview the tools that will be displayed in the Search Results dialog box.
If there are too many results or no results, refine the search criteria and count matching tools again until you are ready to proceed.
Click OK.
In the Search Result dialog box, from the Matching Items list, select the tool that you require.
You can click Display to see a preview of a selected tool. The display does not change until you click Display again, or leave the dialog box. You can select the Preview check box to automatically see the display of each tool that you select.
The tool holder for the selected tool is also shown, if one is defined.
Part, blank, and fixture geometry are hidden to clarify the example drill previews.
With a tool selected, click OK.
The tool is added to your part, and is displayed in the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator.
The Create Tool dialog box remains open. You can continue to add or retrieve tools, or click Cancel to close the dialog box without creating another tool.

Document Title: Enable priorities in a tool search result
Document Body:
This example uses custom priority assignments to help you select tools from a search result. You search for 8 mm twist drills and view the priority assigned to each drill.
The following files delivered with NX define sample tool priority functions that you can modify:
The dbc_tool_ascii.tcl file in the mach\custom\library\tool\ascii folder defines tool priorities for native NX.
The dbc_mrl_tooling_library_tlas.tcl file in the mach\custom\library\tool\inclass folder defines tool priorities for the material resource library (MRL).
Exit NX.
Define the environment variable so that NX can find the custom .tcl file that defines tool priorities, using one of the following commands.
Native NX:
set UGII_CAM_CUSTOM_TOOL_LIBRARY_DIR=${UGII_CAM_CUSTOM_DIR}/library/tool/ascii/
MRL:
set UGII_CAM_CUSTOM_TOOL_LIBRARY_DIR=${UGII_CAM_CUSTOM_DIR}/library/tool/inclass/
Restart NX.
Open a manufacturing setup file.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Library group, click Retrieve Tools from Library .
The Information window displays a Ready to extend message.
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, select Drilling→Twist Drill, and click OK.
In the Search Criteria dialog box, in the Search Parameters group, in the Diameter box, type 8 and press Enter.
The Information window displays the tools that match your query.
In the Search Result dialog box, scroll to the right until you see the Priority column.
Close the Information window, and all open dialog boxes.

When you create or edit an operation, you select a tool from the list in the Tool group. If you select the Browse option, you can use the Tool Selection dialog to more easily sort the list and determine the correct tool for the operation.
The Tool Selection dialog box displays all the tools that are part of the manufacturing setup. You can sort tools by category or specific type. If you sort the tools by type, their parameters are displayed in sortable columns, and an image of the tool you select is displayed in the graphic screen.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
The Browse option is available only in native NX.
Location in dialog box
Tool group→Tool list→Browse.

Tool Type
Displays the hierarchy of tools included in your manufacturing according to their type. You can expand or collapse the hierarchy.
A sample hierarchy is shown below:
Tool   Displays all tools in the setup.
Milling   Displays all tools of a single category.
End Mill (nonindexable)   Separates tools by specific type.
Matching Tools
Lists the available tools that match the selected category or type.
If you select a type, the list includes sortable columns that display the tool parameters.
Details
Displays additional parameters for the selected tool.

Document Title: Retrieve a tool or device into a specific pocket or holder
Document Body:
When you retrieve a tool or device from the library, by default, it is inserted into the first available pocket or holder in your setup. You can select the target pocket or holder into which to retrieve the tool or device.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
You can also right-click a pocket or carrier node in the Operation Navigator, and choose Insert→Tool.
In the Location group, select the target pocket or holder from the Machine Tool View list.
Only pockets and holders that are not at full capacity are available in the list.
If there is available capacity in the tool pocket or holder that you right-click in the Operation Navigator, it becomes the target location by default.
Complete the specification for a new tool, or choose one or more library tools.
Tools that you specify are inserted into the specified pocket, depending on its capacity. Tools in excess of the capacity of the specified pocket or carrier are inserted into available pockets that appear in the list below the specified pocket.
Note:
When you specify a carrier as the location:
If the HLD field in the tool_database.dat file is empty, or the Holding System Name box in the Pocket dialog box is empty, NX places the tool under the pocket.
If the HLD field and the Holding System Name box both have values, but they do not match, NX places the tool under the carrier.

The system outputs the tool number located in the operation and displayed in the Operation Navigator to the postprocessor or CLSF file. The tool number (or T code) can come from three places: the pocket, the tool, and the operation. The tool number is inherited from the pocket level to the tool level to the operation level. Based on what the T code means on your NC machine, you need to decide which is the best way for you to assign tool numbers in your programs.

There are three common scenarios for assigning tool numbers. These are described below.
Note:
If no tool number was assigned to the tool, you can assign the tool number in the setup and the link to the tool library will not be broken.
If no tool number was assigned to the tool, the tool number is automatically inherited pocket that you inserted the tool and the library link is not broken.
If the tool has a number greater than zero specified, and exported to the library. The tool number cannot be changed manually without breaking the library link to the tool.
Assign Tool Number at the Pocket Level
The most common scenario is to assign the T code to the tool position number on the machine. When the program asks for T1, the tool in pocket 1 is loaded. If this is how your machines work, create pockets in the Tool View, and assign them numbers to match your machine. This can be part of your setup template or library machine, so you do not need to do this for every program. Whenever you put a tool in a pocket, it inherits the tool number from the pocket. When you assign an operation to a tool, it inherits the tool number from the tool.
Assigning The Tool Number To The Pocket
Assign Tool Number at the Tool Level
The second most common scenario is to assign numbers to tools as tool codes, regardless of what pocket they are placed in on the machine. For example, a tool has a code of 1234, possibly programmed on a baluf chip or some other device. In this case, you should not use the pockets in the Tool View. You should assign the correct tool number to each tool, either in the tool dialog or in the tool library. Any operation assigned to the tool inherits the number from the tool.
Assigning The Tool Number in The Tool Dialog
If the tools in your library always have the same preassigned number, you can modify the tool library to assign the tool number, adjust register, and cutcom register for each tool.
Assign Tool Number at the Operation Level
In the third most common scenario, you may have a tool defined in the system that represents several identical tools on the machine. You might also have a tool defined in the system that has one tool number in one program in the setup, and a different number in another program in the same setup. In these cases, because the tool needs several different tool numbers to be output, enter a tool number in each operation that is assigned to the tool.
Assigning the Tool Number to the Operation
Library tool number
When a tool is created and saved to the library, or when a tool is retrieved from the library, and the tool is placed in a pocket in the manufacturing setup.
If the tool number is greater than zero, the number cannot be changed manually without breaking the library link to that tool.

The Tool Number column in the Operation Navigator displays the tool number at the operation level in the Tool and Program Order Views.
To add the Tool Number column in the Operation Navigator:
In the Operation Navigator, click MB3 on the background and select columns. The system displays all the possible columns in the Operation Navigator. (If a check is already displayed next to Tool Number, then the Tool Number column is already active.)
Select Tool Number from the list.
The system displays a check to the left of the option and displays the new Tool Number column in the Operation Navigator.
You can use the same process to add other types of columns to the Operation Navigator.

Document Title: Assign the Tool Number to the Pocket
Document Body:
The tool number can be stored in three places; the pocket, the tool, and the operation. The tool number is inherited from the pocket to the tool to the operation. A carrier must be defined to contain pockets.
Creating a Carrier
In your program select the Machine Tool View icon.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, select any type from the Type list. Note that some types, such as wire_edm, do not offer a Carrier.
Select the Carrier icon .
Select the Parent Group and Name you want and click OK.
The Tool Carrier dialog box is displayed . Click OK to close the dialog box.
The system displays the new carrier in the Carrier column of the Tool View in the Operation Navigator.
Creating a Pocket
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, select any type from the Type list. Note that some types, such as wire_edm, do not offer a Pocket.
Select the Pocket icon .
Select the carrier you just made for the Parent group and enter a name in the Name field. Click OK.
The Pocket dialog box is displayed. Enter the tool number you want associated with this pocket in the Pocket ID field. Click OK.
The system displays the new pocket in the Pocket column of the Tool View in the Operation Navigator.

Document Title: Assign The Tool Number In The Tool Dialog
Document Body:
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog select a Type, Subtype, Parent Group, and enter a name in the Name field. Click OK and the system displays the respective tool dialog.
Towards the bottom of the dialog enter a number in the Tool Number field and click OK.
In the Tool View of the Operation Navigator the system displays the tool in the Name column and the tool number in the Tool Number column. If your system doesn't display a Tool Number column go to Customizing The Tool Number Column.

Document Title: Assign The Tool Number To The Operation
Document Body:
Entering a tool number in the operation deactivates the inheritance of the number from the tool.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Operation .
Select the Type, Subtype, Program, Use Geometry, Use Tool, Use Method, and Name that you want and Click OK.
In the Operation dialog select the Machine button and the system displays the Machine Control dialog.
In the Machine Control dialog, under Tool Change, select the Tool Number checkbox and enter a number in the Tool Number Field.
OK the Machine Control dialog, and OK the Operation dialog.
In the Operation Navigator the system displays the new operation in the Name column and the tool number in the Tool Number column. If your system doesn't display a Tool Number column go to Customizing The Tool Number Column.

Document Title: Adjust register and Cutcom register inheritance
Document Body:
Milling tools without tracking points
You can specify Cutcom and Adjust registers in the following locations:
Pocket
Tool
You can specify local Cutcom and Adjust register numbers for the tool, or allow the tool to inherit the register numbers from the pocket.
Operation
You can specify local Cutcom and Adjust register numbers for the operation, or allow the operation to inherit the register numbers. Operations can inherit register numbers directly from the tool, or indirectly from the pocket.
Note:
The icon tells you how the value is defined:
= inherited from the tool or pocket
The tool tip tells you where a value is inherited from.
= defined locally in the operation
To define a register value in the operation, click the Inherited icon and choose Local .

Milling tools with tracking points
If a milling tool has tracking points, but the Tracking Data option is not available in the milling operation:
The tracking point is set to None.
The inheritance is the same as it is for a milling tool without tracking points.
If a milling tool has tracking points, and the Tracking Data option is available in the milling operation:
When the operation outputs cutter compensation data, the operation inherits the Cutcom and Adjust registers specified in the tool for the selected tracking point.
When the operation does not output cutter compensation data, the Cutcom and Adjust register inheritance is the same as for a tool without tracking points.

You can specify common machining parameters in a machining method parent group so that they are inherited by all operations in the hierarchy. Parameters in a method parent group include:
Stock
Tolerances
Feed rates
Display colors
Cut method
The cut method is used to calculate machining data.
For information on inheritance, see Parent groups and inheritance.
In the Machining Method View of the Operation Navigator, all operations with the same method parent appear below the method group.
In the operation you can:
Select the method parent.
Create a new method parent for this operation.
Edit the selections in a previously defined parent group.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Method
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Path Settings group

Use the Create Method command to specify common machining parameters so that they can be inherited by all operations in the hierarchy. Parameters in a method parent group include:
Stock
Tolerances
Feed rates
Display colors
Tool display
Cut method
The cut method is used to calculate machining data.
In the Machining Method View of the Operation Navigator, all operations with the same method parent appear below the method group.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Method
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Path Settings group

The Create Method dialog box lets you create machining method parent groups used in various operation types. The Type option lets you select a template part that determines the available Method Subtype options.
Note:
Many of the CAM setups include predefined methods. You can use these as they are, or you can customize. For example, the mill_contour template has MILL_ROUGH, MILL_SEMI_FINISH, and MILL_FINISH methods. You can create new operations in these groups to inherit different stock values.
Type
Type list
Lets you select a template part that determines the available Method Subtype options.
Method Subtype
The subtype is the type of method group used to specify common machining parameters so that they can be inherited by all operations in the hierarchy. Some template parts include multiple versions of a method subtype. For example, the COUNTERSINK_METHOD and DEEP_HOLE_METHOD subtypes let you specify variations of the DRILL_METHOD parameters.
DRILL_METHOD
Drill methods let you specify the cut method and feeds parameters.
MILL_METHOD
Mill methods let you specify common part stock, tolerance, cut method, and feeds machining parameters.
The MILL_ROUGH, MILL_SEMI_FINISH, and MILL_FINISH methods specify different Part Stock and Tolerance values by default.
TURNING
Turning methods let you specify common part stock, tolerance, cut method, and feeds machining parameters. Turning and centerline drilling methods also let you specify collision settings and specify an automatic engage and retract.
CENTERLINE drilling
Centerline drilling methods let you specify common part stock, tolerance, cut method, and feeds machining parameters. Turning and centerline drilling methods also let you specify collision settings and specify an automatic engage and retract.
WEDM_METHOD
Wire EDM methods let you specify common tolerance and feeds machining parameters.
DEPOSITION
Deposition methods let you specify common tolerance, feeds, and deposition parameters.
Location
Lets you select a previously defined method parent group. NX creates the new method in the parent group you select. Select None to place the new method in the Unused Items folder.
Name
System Name
Lets you create your own name for the method group, which helps you to organize the methods in a way that works for you.
User Define Name
Lets you create your own name for the method, which helps you to organize the methods in a way that works for you.
Note:
Operation and group names may contain only letters, numbers, periods, underscores, tildes, spaces, and dashes.
Note:
Cannot contain the following characters !, @, *, ?, ". :, <, >, ', |, \.

The Specify Colors option allows you to display each different type of tool motion in an individual color to help in visual validation of the tool path Avoidance Control and Feed Rates.
Motion Types
Rapid
Red
Approach
Blue
Engage
Yellow
First Cut
Cyan
Stepover
Green
Cut
Cyan
Traversal
Blue
Retract
White
Departure
Blue
All Motions
Common Color
White
Set All Motions to Common Color
Sets all colors to White

Part stock is the amount of material to be left on the part after machining. This value will be inherited by operations that are created under the method parent. You can override the inherited value by entering a new value in the operation. Each of the processors have specific ways in which they apply the part stock. For documentation on how part stock works in each processor go to the documentation on the specific processor.  
Procedure
Go to the Machining Method View.
Edit a method, such as MILL_ROUGH, with a double-click or MB3→Edit.
The system displays a MILL_METHOD dialog containing the part stock.
Enter a new value for the part stock.
Click OK.
Any operation that inherits their stock from this method now inherits the new stock and needs to be regenerated.

Intol and Outol define an allowable range the tool may use to deviate from the Part surfaces. The smaller the values, the more accurate the cut. Intol allows you to specify the maximum amount by which the tool may penetrate through the surface. Outol allows you to specify the the maximum amount by which the tool may avoid contacting the surface.

Some parameters are passed down from group to group and from group to operation. For example, an operation or a Method group inherits display and tolerance parameters from another Method group. Not all operations can be placed in all Method groups. Different operations can inherit different parameters.
Method inheritance can be overridden in an operation. For example, if an operation inherits intol from a method group and you change the intol in the operation, the inheritance of the intol parameter is turned off.
The graphic below explains this in greater detail. From this graphic you can see the following:
The MILL_FINISH parent contains the stock and tolerance information.
The BLUE parent contains the display color and feed rate information for the two operations listed below it.
The GREEN parent contains the display color and feed rate information for the three operations listed below it.
The operations listed below the BLUE parent inherit the stock and tolerance information from MILL_FINISH and the display color and feed rate information from BLUE.
The operations listed below the GREEN parent Inherit the stock and tolerance information from MILL_FINISH and the display color and feed rate information from GREEN.
There are two methods to see the status of a parameter:
The Inheritance Status icon .
The inheritance list
The Inheritance Status Icon
The Inheritance Status icon beside many parameters tells you at a glance if the parameter is inherited or locally set in the operation. This icon has two states:
Local
The value is locally defined in the current dialog (for example, the operation dialog).
Inherited
The parameter is inherited from a parent object. When you modify this parameter, you see that the icon changes to the Local mode, meaning that it is no longer inherited.
Note:
Hover with the mouse over the input field to see the origin of the inherited value.
Hover with the mouse over the icon to see if the parameter is local or inherited.
Double-click on the icon to easily switch between local and inherited status.
The Inheritance List
You can also use the inheritance list to see where an operation is getting its method. To access the inheritance list, choose Details in the Operation Navigator. The system displays the Details Panel containing the inheritance list.

Engage is the feed rate given for the tool movement from the Engage position to the initial cutting position. This feed rate also applies to the return feed rate when the tool returns to the workpiece after lifts. An Engage feed rate of zero causes the tool to engage at the Cut feed rate.
Cut
Cut is the feed rate given for the tool movement while the cutter is in contact with part geometry.
Retract
Retract is the feed rate given for the tool movement to the Retract position from the final tool path cutting position. A Retract feed rate of zero causes the tool to retract at the Rapid feed rate for linear moves and at the Cut feed rate for circular moves.
First Cut
First Cut is the feed rate given for the initial cutting pass. (Subsequent passes feed at the Cut feed rate value.)
Note:
For Automatic Lathe Groove, the First Cut is also the feed rate for every Plunge cut into full material.

Approach is the Feed Rate given for the tool movement from the Start Point to the Engage position. In Planar and Cavity Milling operations that use multiple levels, the Approach feed rate is used to control the feed from one level to another.
In Surface Contouring, Approach is the feed rate given to the move prior to the engage move. This move may come from either a Start move or a Traversal move.
In Drill and Lathe Groove modules, an Approach feed rate of zero causes the tool to move at the Cut feed rate if specified minimum clearance is zero; otherwise, the Rapid feed rate is used.
In the other modules, an Approach feed rate of zero causes the tool to move at the Rapid feed rate if the engage method is specified; otherwise, the Engage feed rate is used.
Departure
Departure represents the feed rate for the moves out of the hole (or groove) used to clear out the chips in Lathe Groove and Lathe Drill.
In Surface Contouring, Departure is the feed rate given to the move after a retract move. This move may go to a Traversal move or may be a return move.
Thread
Thread is currently unavailable for all processors and is permanently greyed out.
Stepover
Stepover is the feed rate for the cutter as it moves to the next parallel pass. This does not apply if the tool lifts from the work surface. Therefore, the Stepover feed rate applies only to modules allowing Zig-Zag tool paths.

Return is the feed rate for the tool move to the Return Point. A Return feed rate of zero causes the tool to move at the Rapid feed rate.
Side Cut
The Side Cut option applies only to the Lathe Groove module. It controls the sideways cutting movements for By Level Zig-Zag, Left to Right, and Right to Left cut methods. It does not control the plunging and contouring movements. The Side Cut feed rate does not apply to Plunge cut methods.
Traversal
Traversal (Planar Milling and Cavity Milling) is the feed rate used for fast horizontal non-cutting tool motion when the Transfer Method option on the Engage/Retract dialog box has a status of Previous Plane (instead of Clearance Plane).
Traversal feed rate is used only when the tool is the Vertical Clearance distance above the uncut surface and the Horizontal Clearance distance away from any cavity islands or walls. This protects part surfaces during tool transit and the tool may move without lifting to the Clearance Plane.

Change Feed Rate Units allows you to specify tool motion in terms of inches per minute, inches per revolution, or None. When you select this option you can specify Feed Rate Units for:
Each type of tool movement
All non cutting tool movements
All cutting tool movements
Or you may use Set All to None to set all feed rate units to None.
Note:
The Change Feed Rate Units option only appears in the older style menu boxes.
Feed Rates and Engage/Retract parameter interaction are illustrated in the following Feed Rates figure.
Set Non-Cut Units
Set Non-Cut Units allows you to set all non-cutting feed rate units to IPM, IPR, or None (or MMPM, MMPR, or None for metric parts).

Set Cut Units allows you to set all cutting feed rate units to IPM, IPR, or None (or MMPM, MMPR, or None for metric parts).
Note:
In the older style menus Set Non-Cut Units and Set Cut Units are accessed for modification through the Change Feed Rate Units option described below.
Feed Rates
Note:
This figure does not apply to Surface Contouring. For Surface Contouring, see Non-Cutting.

Feed Rate values can differ for the several types of tool movement during the progress of the tool path. Feed rates can be defined at the boundary level and at the boundary member level.
You can enter Feed Rates in the following ways:
Inches per minute (IPM)
Inches per revolution (IPR)
Millimeter per minute (MMPM)
Millimeter per revolution (MMPR)
Note:
The default feed rates are 10 IPM (English Units) and 10 MMPM (metric units)
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
From within a [Milling operation] or Mill Method parent group dialog box.
Location in dialog box
[Milling operation]→Path Settings group→Feeds and Speeds→Feed Rates
Create Method dialog box→OK→Mill Method dialog box→Path Settings group→Feeds
Note:
Feed Rate options common to all machining modules except Wire EDM. For Wire EDM Feed Rate options refer to Feed Rates in Wire EDM.
Note:
When you change the feeds and speeds on a posted operation, notice that the status in the Operation Navigator changes from complete  to repost . You must repost the operation to change its status back to complete .

Use the Create Program command to create a Program group. NX provides one for you but you create additional Program parent groups.
Program groups enable you to group and order operations for output. For example, suppose you have a part where you have a setup to machine the top side and a different set up to machine the bottom side. You can create a separate Program group for each setup.
A program:
Is equivalent to a tape file.
Usually contains multiple operations and generates all tool paths for these operations.
Specifies the order in which to run the operations.
You must have a program group to output a CLSF or to postprocess multiple operations. Create a group for each program to output. NX then outputs the operations to CLSF files and postprocessing files in the specified order.
The Program Order View is the only view of the Operation Navigator in which the order of the listed operations is relevant or important. All operations in a program appear below the program group, and are listed in the order in which they are executed on the machine tool.
Requires post processing to create the actual commands that are sent to the CNC controller.
It is suggested practice to create multiple program parent groups, and name them according to the programs that are output. For example, you can create one program group for roughing, and another program group for finishing. When you are ready to generate your output, selecting the program parent selects all of the operations assigned to that parent group.
The following graphic is an example of the Program Order View. In the furthest left hand column, under Title, you can see all the program parents. The parents are expanded so you can also see the operations within the programs. In this hierarchy, PROGRAM_GROUP is the parent of ROUGHING and GREEN_TOP_AREA
Program Order View
Note:
When generating operations, make note that the Unused Items parent is meant as a clipboard only. If you want to generate an operation, move it under one of the other program parents.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Program
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Program group

The Create Program dialog box allows you to create program groups to contain various operations. A program group becomes a parent when you place operations or other programs inside it.
Type
Type list
Lets you select the template part to use. Most of the template parts contain program templates.
Program Subtype
The subtype is the type of program group used to group operations for output.
PROGRAM
Creates a new program group.
MERGE_PATH, MERGE_PATH_ADDITIVE
Creates a program group for merging tool paths.
For more information on merging tool paths, see Combining tool paths
For more information on the Merge Path dialog box, see Merge Path dialog box
OPTIMIZED_NC
Creates a program group that lets you optimize tool paths.
For more information on optimizing tool paths, see Optimization.
For more information on the Optimized NC dialog box, see Optimization.
Location
Lets you select a previously defined program parent group. NX creates the new program in the parent group you select.
Name
Lets you create your own name for the program group. This helps you to organize your program in a way that works for you.
System Name
Lets you create your own name for the method group. This helps you to organize the methods in a way that works for you.
User Defined Name
Lets you create your own name for the method group. This helps you to organize the methods in a way that works for you.
Note:
Operation and group names may contain only letters, numbers, periods, underscores, tildes, spaces, and dashes.
Note:
Cannot contain the following characters !, @, *, ?, ". :, <, >, ', |, \.

Start Events
Operator Message Status
Creates a machine stop command that displays the operator message text.
Operator Message
Lets you enter text to display when the machine stop command is activated.
Process Pattern
You must customize the Program dialog box to add the Process Pattern group.
Pattern Feature
Lets you select a pattern feature for NX to reference when creating the tool path instances. Displays a list of all available pattern features. You can also select None to remove the tool path instances.
Pattern Sequencing
Displays a list of the pattern instances. Select an instance and click the arrow buttons to manually move the instance up or down in the sequence list.
Sequence
Optimization
Specifies how to reorder the geometry sequence.
Closest
Creates a path that moves from each location to the next closest location.
Shortest Path
Creates a path that travels the shortest overall distance.
Primary Direction
Creates a tool path that is arranged in a grid using a zig or zig-zag pattern to minimize tool travel. Whenever possible, NX keeps the transition motions parallel to the axis or vector that you specify as the primary pattern direction.
Reorder List
Applies the selected Optimization option to the list.
Note:
The dialog box displays the default settings each time you open it. Sequencing commands are actions that NX performs when you click Reorder list. When you click OK to exit the dialog box, NX saves the resulting sequence without remembering the settings.
Reverse List
Reverses the order of the listed tool path locations.
Reload List From Pattern
Loads the sequence defined by the pattern feature. This option lets you experiment with sequencing and then return to the original sequence.
Output
Pattern MCS Locations
Outputs the MCS locations from the feature pattern with the tool path.
Output Order
All Operations per Instance
NX machines each instance completely before moving on to the next instance.
All Instances per Operation
NX machines all instances with each operation.
Output Subroutines
Outputs a subroutine for each instanced operation. This option requires a customized postprocessor.

The tool paths in your program can reference an existing Modeling pattern feature. All Modeling pattern options are supported. In the Process Pattern group of the Program dialog box, you can:
Specify which Modeling pattern to reference.
Reorder the Modeling instances manually or apply one of the Optimization options.
If you choose to output the pattern MCS locations, you can also output subroutines if your postprocessor is set up for it.
Note:
NX does not create new operations. Instead it patterns the tool path of all operations in the program. The pattern can then be used for postprocessing and simulation.
The following example uses two pattern features:
The first pattern feature creates a small circular pattern with four instances.
The second pattern feature creates a larger circular pattern that adds five instances of the first pattern.
Part with feature to machine
Patterned operations
Animation of tool path pattern
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
You must customize the Program dialog box to add the Process Patterning customizable item.
The part file must contain the Modeling pattern features that control the operation instance locations.
Dialog box
To specify the Modeling pattern feature and reorder instances:
Program dialog box→Process Pattern
Operation Navigator
To display and animate the patterned tool paths:
Right-click the selected operation→Tool Path→Display Pattern

Click here to download the parts.
This hands-on workflow shows how to pattern the operations within a program.

Document Title: 1 Examine the CAD Pattern Feature objects
Document Body:
This example uses two pattern features:
The first pattern feature creates a small circular pattern with four instances.
The second pattern feature creates a larger circular pattern that adds five instances of the first pattern.

Open 01-0005M.
Examine the first feature pattern.
In the Part Navigator, show the Datum Coordinate System (6) node.
Note:
Some nodes are omitted to improve clarity.

Datum Coordinate System (5)

Pattern Feature [Circular] (8)

Click the Hide Status icon to display the node in the graphics window.
Show the Pattern Feature [Circular] (7) node.
Model History

Examine the second feature pattern.

Datum Coordinate System (6)

Datum Coordinate System (6)
Pattern Feature [Circular] (7)
