Document Title: 2 Customize the Program dialog box to add the Process Pattern group
Document Body:
You must customize the Program dialog box to pattern a process.
In the Program Order view of the Operation Navigator, right-click the PROGRAM_PATTERNED node, and choose Object→Customize ....
Under Items to Add, from the Dialog Item Type list, select Customizable Item.
From the list, select Process Patterning.
In the Items to Add group, click Add to Dialog .
In the Customize Dialog dialog box, click OK to save your changes to the dialog box.

Document Title: 3 Apply the CAD pattern to the machining program
Document Body:
Double-click the PROGRAM_PATTERNED node.
In the Program dialog box, under Process Pattern, from the Pattern Feature list, select Pattern Feature (Circular)(7).
There are 4 instances in the list. Select each instance.
In the Program dialog box, under Process Pattern, from the Pattern Feature list, select Pattern Feature Circular 8.
There are 24 instances in the list (the 4 instances in Pattern Feature Circular 7 times the 6 instances of Pattern Feature Circular 8).
Reorder a few instances manually.
Click Reload List from Pattern to reset the pattern to the original instance order.
From the Optimization list, select Shortest Path.
Click Reorder List to apply the selected optimization option, then click OK.

In the Operation Navigator, select the FLOOR_WALL operation and notice the pattern symbols.
The pattern display is controlled by the Display Selected Objects setting. This example assumes that the Display Selected Objects check box is selected.
Display Selected Objects =
Display Selected Objects =
The color of the patterned display is controlled by the Feature Sequence customer default.
Tip:
To find a customer default, choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults, and click Find Default .
Choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing.
In the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box, on the User Interface tab, clear the Display Selected Objects check box and click OK.
Right-click in the graphics window and choose Refresh.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the FLOOR_WALL operation and choose Tool Path→Display Pattern.
Zoom in to the start of the tool path.
Choose Home tab→Tool Path Animation group→ Play and review the tool path for a few instances.
Click on different sections of the tool path to see the animation update.
Choose Home tab→IPW group→Display IPW , and click Play.
The patterned tool path is ready to use for postprocessing and simulation.

Programs enable you to group and order operations for output. For example, a program may include all the operations required to machine the top view of a part.
A program:
Is equivalent to a tape file.
Usually contains multiple operations and generates all tool paths for these operations.
Specifies the order to run the operations.
Requires post processing to create the actual commands that are sent to the CNC controller.
You can create multiple programs. For example, you can group operations by rough, finish, part shift, file size.
In the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator, all operations in a program appear below the program group, and are listed in the order they will be executed on the machine tool.
The Program Order View is the only view of the Operation Navigator in which the order of the listed operations is relevant or important.
In the operation you can:
Select the Program parent.
Create a new Program parent for this operation.
Edit the selections in a previously defined parent group.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Program
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Program group

You can use the MERGE_PATH or MERGE_PATH_PLANAR program to combine two or more operations into a single operation to improve machining efficiency.
Using the Create Program command to create a new program group and then adding operations to it, you can combine operations.
Selecting operations in the Operation Navigator and then using the Create Program dialog box, you can combine operations.

Note:
The operations you merge must all use the same tool.
NX sets the feeds and speed of first operation in the merge path group as the feeds and speed of merged tool path.
Ensure that you merge only those planar mill operations that have the same tool axis direction.
You can copy a merge program to create a copy of all the child operations of the group for reusing operations.
NX generates the tool path for all the copied child operations when you generate a tool path for the parent merge program.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Program
Location in dialog box
Type group→mill_planar→MERGE_PATH_PLANAR
Supports only the Planar Mill and Planar Profile 2D Wireframe Processor operation subtype
Type group→mill_multi_axis→MERGE_PATH
Type group→mill_multi_blade→MERGE_PATH
Operation Navigator
To copy: Right-click the merge program and choose Copy
To paste: Right-click the program group and choose Paste

Click here to download the part.
This hands-on procedure shows how to create a MERGE_PATH program group to combine multiple operations into a single operation.
Unzip and open merge_path_1.prt.
Make sure you are in the CAM Advanced role.
Resource bar→Roles tab →Content folder→CAM Advanced .
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the BLADE_SEMI_FINISH_3_PASSES operation and select Replay .
This is a Blade Finish operation, with 3 cut levels, and it leaves 0.5000 blade stock.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the BLADE_FINISH_15_PASSES operation and select Replay .
This is a Blade Finish operation, with 15 cut levels, and it leaves 0.0000 blade stock.
You can combine these two operations to create the following sequence:
Semi-finish pass #1
First set of five finish passes
Semi-finish pass #2
Second set of five finish passes
Semi-finish pass #3
Third set of five finish passes
From the Ribbon bar, in the Insert group, select Create Program .
In the Create Program dialog box, from the Type list, select mill_multi_blade.
In the Program Subtype group, select Merge Path .
Note:
The Merge Path program subtype is also available from the mill_multi_axis type.
Click OK.
In the Merge Path dialog box, in the Merge Type group, set the Sort Order to By Contour Count.
In the List group, click Add New Set .
In the Contours box, type 1 and press Enter.
Click Add New Set .
In the Contours box, type 5 and press Enter.
Click OK.
A MERGE_PATH program group is created.
Drag and drop the BLADE_SEMI_FINISH_3_PASSES and BLADE_FINISH_15_PASSES operations to the MERGE_PATH program group.
Right-click the MERGE_PATH group and select Generate.
From the Ribbon bar, in the Display group, select Tool Path Report .
In the Tool Path Report dialog box, select each of the three cut levels and observe the tool path sequence in the graphic window.
Select Level-1.


Select Level-2.


Select Level-3.
Click OK.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the MERGE_PATH program group and select Edit.
Select the second operation in the list, and in the Lag box, type 2 and press Enter.
The Lag command allows you to stagger the overlap of merged tool paths.
Click OK.
Right-click the MERGE_PATH group and select Generate.
From the Ribbon bar, in the Display group, select Tool Path Report .
In the Tool Path Report dialog box, select each of the four cut levels and observe the tool path sequence in the graphic window.
Select Level-1.


Select Level-2.


Select Level-3.


Select Level-4.
Note:
It is easier to view the individual cut levels if Options→Display is set to Selected Only.
(Optional) In the Merge Path dialog box, enter different values for Lag to observe how the values affect the overlap between the tool paths.
Click OK.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the MERGE_PATH program group and select Edit.
In the Merge Type group, from the Sort Order list, select By Concatenation.
Click OK.
Generate the MERGE_PATH program group.
From the Ribbon bar, in the Display group, select Tool Path Report .
The tool paths are sequenced according to their order in the program group. The first three levels are the semi-finishing operations, followed by the finishing operations.

Note:
Parameters differ from operation to operation. This topic lists some of the broader, common nodes, or groups. For operation-specific information, refer to the individual dialog box topics.
Path Settings
Merge Type
These options let you control the method NX uses to sort the tool paths.
Sort Order
By Contour Count
Available only for mill_multi_axis operation type.
Lets you sequence tool paths in groups, according to a count order.
By Concatenation
Lets you sequence tool paths in the same order in which they are added to the program group.
List
Available when Sort Order is set to By Contour Count.
These options let you control the method NX uses to sort the tool paths.
Contours
Lets you specify groups of tool paths according to a count order.
Lag
Lets you stagger the overlap of merged tool paths.
Non Cutting Moves
Smoothing
Override With Smooth Connections
Lets you replace most aspects of non-cutting moves creation with a semiautomatic method that is intended to generate safe, smooth, and efficient motions. Your input values influence the output motions; however, the automation may adjust the final shape.
Smooth Length
Available when you select the Override with Smooth Connections check box.
Determines the target length that is used when there is enough room, or the end point is safe with respect to part clearance, or the end points of cutting motions are open.
Smooth Height
Available when you select the Override with Smooth Connections check box.
Determines the target lift of the transition.
The lift is done along the tool axis, but is also affected by the part normal. This option uses the same considerations as the Smooth Length option. If the calculated length is shorter, then the height is proportionally shorter.
Max Stepover
Available when you select the Override with Smooth Connections check box.
Determines the stepover distance at which the smooth motion changes from a single segment at the stepover feed rate to three segments at the retract, traversal, and engage feed rates.
Tolerance
Available when you select the Override with Smooth Connections check box.
Sets the allowed deviation of the output linear moves from a calculated smooth spline. As the tolerance decreases, the number of output steps in the tool path increases and the motion becomes smoother.
To determine the tolerance, choose one of the following options.
Minimize Points—Approximates the calculated spline with a minimal number of straight steps. This method is recommended for old controllers.
From Cutting—Uses the specified Intol and Outtol values for cutting moves to control the number of straight steps required for the stepover. Output is typically a lot of lines of code with very smooth motion. This method is recommended for multi-axis operations.
Specify—Lets you specify a smoothing tolerance that generates the number of straight steps that you find acceptable.
Engage
Available only when you clear the Override with Smooth Connections check box in the Smoothing node.
Open Area
Open areas are regions where the tool can reach the current cut level, before removing material.
Initial
Controls the initial move of the operation to the first open area cut region or level.
Retract
Available only when you clear the Override with Smooth Connections check box in the Smoothing node.
Open Area
Open areas are regions where the tool can reach the current cut level, before removing material.
Final
Specifies the parameters for the last retract moves that follow the cutting moves.
Avoidance
From Point
Specifies the initial tool position at the start of a new tool path. NX outputs a FROM command as the first entry in the tool path.
Point Option
None—Does not use a specified From point.
Specify—Sets the From Point location. You can either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Tool Axis
None—Sets the From Point tool axis to 0,0,1.
Specify—Sets the Tool axis orientation. You can either select geometry or use the Vector Constructor to orient the tool axis.
Start Point
Point Option
None—Does not use a specified Start point location.
Specify—Sets the Start point location. You can either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Return Point
Point Option
None—Does not use a specified Return point location.
Specify—Sets the Return point location. You can either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Go Home Point
Specifies the final tool position. NX outputs a GOHOME command as the final entry in the tool path. The postprocessor always interprets the GOHOME command as a Rapid move.
Point Option
None—Does not use a specified Gohome point location.
Same As From—Uses the specified From point location as the Gohome point location.
GOHOME - No Point—Uses the GOHOME move defined in the postprocessor. The default value is (0,0,0). The point is not displayed in the tool path.
Specify—Sets the Gohome point location. You can either select a predefined point or use the Point Constructor to specify a point.
Tool Axis
None—Sets the From Point tool axis to 0,0,1.
Specify—Sets the Tool axis orientation. You can either select geometry or use the Vector Constructor to orient the tool axis.
Transfer/Rapid
Part Safe Clearance
Defines an additional clearance that the non-cutting portions of the tool may not encroach.
Common Clearance
Clearance Option
Use Inherited—Selects the clearance plane specified at the MCS level.
Plane—Specifies the clearance plane for this operation.
Transfer/Rapid
Smooth Transfer Move Corners
Applies smoothing between transfer moves and adjacent approach or departure moves.
Smooth Transfer Move Corners
Available when you select the Smooth Transfer Move Corners check box.
This is the dimension that NX applies to the smooth path. You can specify either the radius value in the current units, for example, mm, or a percentage of the tool's diameter (% Tool Diameter).
Tolerance
Sets the allowed deviation of the output linear moves from a calculated smooth spline. As the tolerance decreases, the number of output steps in the tool path increases and the motion becomes smoother.
From Cutting—Uses the specified Intol and Outtol values for cutting moves to control the number of straight steps required for the stepover. Output is typically a lot of lines of code with very smooth motion. This method is recommended for multi-axis operations.
Specify—Lets you specify a smoothing tolerance that generates the number of straight steps that you find acceptable. Use this method if the other two options do not satisfy your needs.
More
Check for Non Cutting Collisions
Detects collisions with part and check geometry. All applicable stocks and safe clearances are added to part and check geometry for the collision checking. NX always attempts a backup move to avoid collisions if the original move gouges. If a gouge-free traversal move cannot be made, a warning is issued.

Document Title: Generating and reviewing your tool path
Document Body:
There are several ways in which you can generate an operation tool path. You can generate tool paths for:
A single operation from the operation dialog box.
One or more operations from the following locations:
Operation Navigator
Home tab→Operations group
Menu→Tools
You must wait for the operations to finish generating before you can continue working.
One or more operations in the background as a parallel process while you continue working in the current part file. The Generate in Background command is available in the same locations as the Generate command.
A single operation or group in the background as a batch process. You must close the part file associated with the batch process. You can work in another part file while the batch process runs. You can reopen the part file associated with the batch process only after the batch process is complete.
Generating changed operations only
When you generate multiple operations within a program group, you can choose to generate only the operations that are changed. You exclude operations with up-to-date tool paths with a status of either Complete or Repost .
To enable this functionality, set the Force Regerate customer default or manufacturing preference.
Tip:
To find a customer default, choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults, and click Find Default .
In cases where separate operations share the same blank and therefore have an IPW relationship, if one of the operations has an out-of-date tool path, NX generates all the operations.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Actions group

Document Title: Displaying and generating milling tool paths automatically
Document Body:
You can display and update tool paths automatically while programming these milling operations:
Planar Mill
Planar Profile 2D
Profile 3D
Solid Profile 3D
Automatic tool path display provides immediate feedback as you create or edit milling operations.
To enable automatic tool path generation, in the main dialog box, select Automatic Generate .
To disable automatic tool path generation, in the main dialog box, select Generate .

You can turn automatic tool path generation on or off by selecting Preferences→Manufacturing→Operation→Tool Path Generation→ Automatically Generate
You can turn automatic tool path generation on or off by selecting Customer Defaults→Manufacturing→Operation→Tool Path →Tool Path Generation→ Automatically Generate

The tool path updates each time the cut pattern or other parameter is changed. In the example, the cut pattern is changed in a Planar Mill operation.
Cut Pattern = Follow Periphery
Cut Pattern = Zig Zag

Note:
The automatic tool path generation will only be triggered when you change parameters in the operation dialog box.
You can click Automatic Generate to manually generate a tool path from an operation that supports automatic tool path generation.
When Journal is active, automatic tool path generation is not supported.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in dialog box
Automatic Generate

Document Title: Hands-on: Display and generate tool paths automatically
Document Body:
Click here to download the part.
This hands-on procedure shows how to display and generate milling tool paths automatically when you change parameters within the operation.
Procedure
Unzip and open automatic_toolpath_generation_1.prt.
Make sure you are in the CAM Advanced role:
Resource bar→Roles tab →Roles palette→Content - Industry Specific folder→CAM Advanced.
In the Operation Navigator, in the Program Order view, right-click PLANAR_MILL and select Edit.
The existing tool path is displayed in the graphics window.
In the dialog box, in the Actions group, from the drop-down list, select Automatic Generate if it is not already displayed.
Note:
You can manually generate operations if you select Generate .
In the Main node, in the Main group, from the Cut Pattern list, select Zig Zag .
The tool path displays and generates the new cut pattern automatically.
In the Percent of Flat Diameter box, enter 20.0000.
Click OK.
The tool path updates, adding more stepover moves.
In the Part Stock box, enter 0.3000.
Click OK.
The tool path updates, leaving more stock on the side walls.
Make changes to other parameters in the operation, such as Cut Direction, Cut Angle, or Non Cutting Moves, to further observe the tool path updates.

Use the Generate in Background command to generate operations in the background while you continue working. Select any number of operations at the same time, and they count as one parallel process.
Using the Generate in Background command is helpful in these circumstances:
Your computer has multiple cores or processors, and you want to use them to speed up tool path processing.
Your computer has a slow processor, and you do not want to wait for complex tool paths to generate before working on another operation.
Note:
The part must remain open in the current session. You can continue to work on it or work on another part, but you cannot close the part. This is different than batch processing, which requires you to close the part and wait until the batch processing is complete to open the part.
The Generate in Background command is not supported in the Virtual Desktop Infrastructure environment.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Select the operations→Generate in Background

Batch processing generates tool paths, postprocesses groups and/or operations, and generates shop floor documentation. You can process all three outputs at one time, or create each output individually. You can use batch processing to:
Generate multiple outputs from one command.
Work on another project while the processing takes place.
Schedule the processing for the most convenient time, or when the system is most free. You do not need to be present.
Note:
Windows systems terminate batch processes if the user logs out during processing. Lock your workstation instead of logging out if you need to leave before the batch processing is complete.
If you use batch processing on a regular basis you can add the Batch Processing icon to the Home tab→Operations group. See Add a command to a group
Running a batch process in the background
When you run a batch process with the Background option:
The batch process automatically saves the part file when it is complete.
For the best results, do not continue working on the submitted part while batch processing runs in the background, because the batch process can overwrite your changes, or you could overwrite the batch process changes.
The batch process generates a log file with a name that has your part name and a .log extension, for example my_part.log. This log file contains information about the selected operations and groups, start time, end time, and whether the process is successful or not. You can check the log file to see the status of a batch process running in the background.
The batch process sends an e-mail with the log information to you when the processing is complete.
Note:
If the system crashes before or during the batch process, you only lose the work of the batch processing, you do not lose the work that was done before running the batch. When the system is restored, you will need to open the part and re-submit the groups or operations for batch processing.

Save your part file.
In the Operation Navigator, select the groups and operations to submit for batch processing
Choose Menu→Tools→Batch Processing.
In the Batch Processor dialog box, select the desired output options.
To:
Do this:
Generate tool paths
Select the Generate Tool Paths check box.
Note:
Valid tool paths are required to postprocess or create shop documentation.
Postprocess the operations
In the Postprocess group, select the Postprocess Programs or Operations check box.
Click Select Postprocessor.
In the Postprocess dialog box, select a postprocessor from the Postprocess Programs or Operations list.
Click OK.
Create shop documentation
In the Shop Documentation group, select the Shop Documentation check box.
Click Select Report Format.
In the Shop Documentation dialog box, select a report format from the Report Format list.
Click OK.
In the Settings group, from the Processing Mode list, select Background.
From the Priority list, select an option.
Click OK.
Click OK when the following warning is message displayed:
Batch Submitted, Do Not Save Work Part
Note:
If the submission fails, the following warning is displayed:
Fail to Submit Batch Job
Close the part file without saving.
Wait for the e-mail notice that processing is complete, or check the log file. The log file is in the same folder as your part file and has the part name with a .log extension.

Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Generate Tool Paths
Generate Tool Paths
(Default output setting) Generates the tool paths for the selected programs or operations. You must generate tool paths or have existing valid tool paths to postprocess or create shop documentation for the selected operations .
Note:
If no program groups or operations are selected, all operations in the setup are processed.
Postprocess
Postprocess Programs or Operations
Only single program groups or operations are output with this option.
Select Postprocessor
Lets you select a postprocessor from the Postprocess Programs or Operations dialog box.
Shop Documentation
Shop Documentation
Generates documentation for the entire manufacturing setup.
Select Report Format
Lets you select a report format from the Shop Documentation dialog box.
Settings
Processing Mode
Background
Saves the part file and submits it for batch processing in the background. This is the default.
Foreground
Processes the part interactively without saving the file. You cannot perform any other interaction until the processing is complete.
Minutes to Delay
Specifies the number of minutes you would like to delay the job. For example, if it is 5:00 P.M. and you would like the job to run at 6:30 P.M. when the system will be more free, enter 90.
Priority
Prioritizes the importance of your batch job. High priorities are processed first, Medium priorities (default) are processed second, and Low priorities are processed last.

Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Postprocess Programs or Operations
Lists postprocessors (.pui files) available for the current CAM session.
Output File
File Name
Specifies a folder path and file name for the postprocessor output file. The default folder path is the current work part folder. The default file name is your part name with a .ptp extension.
Browse for an Output File
Lets you search for a different path.

Note:
See Common dialog box options for common options not discussed here.
Report Format
Lets you select the format (text or html) and content for the report.
Output File
File Name
Specifies a folder path and file name for the shop floor documentation output file. The default folder path is the current work part folder. The default file name is your part name with a .txt or .html extension.
Browse for an Output File
Lets you search for a different path.

Document Title: Comparing Generate in Background and Batch Processing
Document Body:
Frequent questions
Generate in Background
Batch Processing
What is the path to the command?
Operation Navigator→right-click the selected operations→Generate in Background
Home tab→Operations group→Batch Processing
Tools menu→Batch Processing
What tasks can I perform?
Generate
Generate
Postprocess
Create Shop Docs
What can I select?
One or more operations
A single group or operation
How many processes can I run?
As many as you want. One to four will calculate, based on the customer default setting. The remainder are placed in a queue.
One per part
Can I delay processing?
No, but there may be a delay when multiple processes are running.
Yes, you can enter a time delay.
Do I need to stay logged in?
You must stay logged in.
You must stay logged in.
Must the NX session be open?
The current session must stay open.
You can close the current session.
Can I keep working in the work part?
Yes
The work part must remain open.
No
You must close the work part and not open it again until the batch process completes.
How can I see the progress in the process?
Watch the operation status icons.
Watch the batch process log file.
How am I notified when the process is finished?
Watch the operation status icons.
You will receive an Email.
How do I know if there is success or there are errors?
If the tool path status looks incorrect, right-click the operation and choose Information to check the diagnostics.
Check the batch process log file.
Where can I see the results?
The results are available immediately in the work part.
Open the part after the batch finishes.
How does this process work?
The software:
Saves a copy of the work part.
Starts another NX session in the background.
Opens the saved copy of the work part in the new NX session.
Generates the operations.
Merges the resulting tool paths and IPWs into the original part.
Deletes the copy of the work part.
The software:
Saves the work part.
Starts another NX session in the background.
Opens the original work part in the new NX session.
Generates the operations, postprocesses, or.creates shop docs.
Saves the original work part.

Actions
Generate
Generates the tool path.
Replay
Refreshes the graphics window and replays the tool path.
Verify
Provides options for animating the tool path.
List
Displays a text listing of the tool path in an Information window.

Document Title: Customizing the tool path display for an operation
Document Body:
You can customize the tool path display for an operation to control:
How the tool is displayed.
The tool display frequency.
The tool path colors.
The display of additional information, such as feed rates.

Use the Edit Display command to specify how the tool, tool holder, and tool path are displayed in the graphics window.
The availability of the Process Display Parameters options varies depending on the machining module you use.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Create or edit an operation or method parent
Operation Navigaror
Double-click the operation
Location in dialog box
Options group→Edit Display

Tool
Tool Display
None
2D
3D
Axis
Frequency
Sets the frequency of the tool display.
3D tool display with a frequency set to 1
3D tool display with a frequency set to 25
Pattern
Enables tool holder display during tool path Generation and Replay. You can design a tool holder in the Modeling application, save it as a Pattern, and then use it in an operation to visually check for interference with the part during machining.
Specify
Lets you to select the desired Pattern, define the display frequency of the Pattern, and shift the position of the Pattern in relation to the Tool Alignment Point by adjusting the X Delta, Y Delta, and Z Delta values.
Pattern File
Sets the part file to use for Pattern Data. You can either enter the name of a part file or you can select from a list of part files. The part file you select must be saved as Pattern Data.
Frequency
Sets the frequency of the pattern display.
Delta X, Delta Y, Delta Z
Shifts the starting position of the pattern with an offset distance in the X, Y, or Z direction in relation to the tool alignment point.
Path
Path Display Colors
Lets you set the color of the display of each type of tool motion to help in visual validation of the tool path.
The All Motions, Common Color, lets you set all the tool motions to a color you select from the Color dialog box.
The Set all Motions to Common Color sets all colors to white.
Speed
Sets the rate of the tool display movement. You can move the slider to set a relative value between 1 and 10. A speed of 1 is the slowest; a speed of 10 is the fastest.
Path Display
Sets how the tool path is displayed in the graphics window.
Solid
Dashed
Silhouette
Fill
Silhouette Fill
% Tool
Sets the percentage of the tool that is engaged in cutting.
Path Normal
Sets the output of a silhouette normal to the tool axis or to a user-specified vector. Choose between the two options, Tool Axis and I,J,K.
More
Feed Rates
Displays the feed rate at each move.
Arrows
Displays arrows indicating cut direction.
Line Numbers
Displays the line number only in a CLSF replay.
Path Generation
Determines the cut region and tool path display characteristics for a generated tool path.
These options are not available for Point-to-Point machining.
Display Cut Region
Available in Planar and Cavity Milling only.
Displays the curve defining the machinable region or regions for each cut level before processing the tool path.
Pause After Display
Available in Planar Milling, Cavity Milling, and Fixed and Variable Contour operations only.
Pauses the processor after displaying the machinable region or the tool path at each cut level.
Refresh Before Display
Available in Planar Milling, Cavity Milling, and Fixed and Variable Contour operations only.
Removes all existing temporary screen displays before displaying the generated tool path.
Suppress Path Display
Does not display the generated tool path.

Pattern
Pattern allows you to display a tool holder during tool path Generation and Replay. You can design a tool holder in the Modeling Application, save it as a Pattern, and then use it in the operation to visually check for interference with the part during machining.
To create a Pattern, you must first start a part file and then design the tool holder. For the part file to be used in Manufacturing as a Pattern, you must specify that it be saved as Pattern Data as follows:
File→Options→Save Options. . .→Pattern Data Only
You must then save the part file:
File→Save→Part
When you Generate the tool path, the system retrieves the specified Pattern, positions the origin point of the Pattern on the Tool Alignment Point, and aligns the Work Coordinates of the Pattern with the Machine Coordinates of the part as illustrated in the following figure.
The Tool Alignment Point is calculated for Mill tools and Lathe tools as follows:
Mill - The Tool Alignment Point is calculated as the Display Tool Height (Z Delta) distance from the centerline bottom of the tool as illustrated below.
Pattern and Mill Tool Alignment
Lathe - The Tool Alignment Point is calculated as the Display Tool Length (X Delta) and the Display Tool Width (Y Delta) distance from the cutting tip of the tool. This point is the corner of the tool that is opposite to the cutter. For groove tools, it is the corner opposite the Tool Track At position as illustrated below.
Pattern and Lathe Tool Alignment
In both cases, you should be aware of the alignment position when you establish the origin of the Pattern when using the X Delta, Y Delta, and Z Delta default values.
You can shift the position of the Pattern in relation to the Tool Alignment Point by adjusting the X Delta, Y Delta, and Z Delta values under the Specify option (described below). This enables you to avoid gouging the part with the Pattern.
Note:
By design, the system does not automatically flip a lathe tool pattern based on the type of work (ID/OD) or the side of the centerline on which the tool path lies (unlike normal tool display). Instead, the system aligns the MCS of the Pattern file with the MCS of the work part and displays the Pattern accordingly. To display a tool pattern in the 4th quadrant of the work part, the user must set the MCS of the Pattern file such that the tool pattern is at the proper orientation in the 4th quadrant.
Specify
Specify enables you to select the desired Pattern, define the display frequency of the Pattern, and shift the position of the Pattern in relation to the Tool Alignment Point by adjusting the X Delta, Y Delta, and Z Delta values.
Pattern File
Pattern File enables you to designate the desired Pattern by keying in an existing part file name or selecting from a list of part files. (the part file must be saved as Pattern Data). Although the Selection field in the subsequent dialog box will accomodate as many characters as you need to designate the desired Pattern, the system only reads up to 31 characters. If the specified part file is in the current folder, the part file name may contain up to 31 characters. If the specified part is not in the current folder, the sum of characters in the path name and the part file name may contain up to 31 characters.
Pattern definition rules
When you Generate the tool path, the system retrieves the specified Pattern, positions the origin point of the Pattern on the Tool Alignment Point, and aligns the Work Coordinates of the Pattern with the Machine Coordinates of the part as illustrated in the following figure..

Options
Edit Display
Controls the tool path display options such as color and type of tool display.
Customize Dialog
Specifies the parameters (text fields, buttons, and option menus) that appear in the dialog.
Analysis Tools
For Planar Milling and Cavity Milling operations
Accesses the Analyze Tool dialog box which lets you visually inspect cutting areas for any anomalies in the tool path.

Use the Tool Path Analysis command to analyze a variety of multi axis tool path parameters and identify potential problems before the part is cut.
You define an analysis type and a set of ranges. NX displays the tool path colors according to the colors of the defined ranges.
For example, you can analyze your tool path for segment length. Very short segments can indicate the presence of spikes, and very long segments may be difficult to process with some machine controls.
You can select multiple operations and do a comparative analysis.
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Tool Path Analysis

Type
Segment Length
Analyzes the length of tool path segments. Very short segments can indicate the presence of spikes, and very long segments may be difficult to process with some machine controls.
Lead Angle
The lead angle is the angle between the tool axis and the direction of the tool path.
Delta Lead Angle
The delta lead angle is the change of the angle between the tool axis and the direction of the tool path. Sudden changes in the delta lead angle can lead to surface finish imperfections.
Swiveling Axis Angle
The swiveling axis angle is the angle between the tool axis and the ZM direction. For some machine tools, this angle represents the A or B axis.
Swiveling Axis Speed
The swiveling axis speed is the speed of the change of the angle between the tool axis and the ZM direction.
Rotary Axis Angle
The rotary axis angle is the angle between the tool axis and the XM direction. For some machine tools, this this angle represents the C axis.
Rotary Axis Speed
The rotary axis speed is the speed of the change of the rotary angle.
Define Ranges
Number of Ranges
Specifies the number of ranges in the tool path. The number of ranges must be between 1 and 7.
Min/Max Limits
Automatic
Automatically extracts the Minimum and Maximum values from the tool path.
Specify
Allows you to manually set the minimum and maximum range values. These values are preserved when you compare multiple operations.
Divisions
Automatic
Equally divides the ranges between Minimum and Maximum.
Logarithmic
Uses logarithm analysis to divide the ranges.
Statistical
Uses statistical analysis to divide the ranges.
Specify
Allows you to manually set all range values other than the Minimum and Maximum.
Range Colors and Limits
Below Limits
Lets you assign a color to any value that is outside of the Minimum or Maximum limits.
Minimum/Maximum
Shows the minimum value, the maximum value and the values of the ranges in between. The number of ranges depends on the value you set in the Number of Ranges list.
Reset colors
Restores the range colors to their default values.
Settings
Display Color Legend
Displays the ranges and their colors in the graphics window.

You can use the Measure dialog box to measure the distance between two points on a tool path or between a point on a path and a geometry object.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
An operation with a valid tool path
Location in dialog box
Analysis→Measure→Object to Measure

Document Title: Ribbon bar options to verify tool paths
Document Body:
The Ribbon bar includes options to help you verify tool paths.
The Display group includes options for managing the display of tool paths and the option to display tools in the machine.
For example, you can choose to show or hide non cutting moves, and configure the tool path colors for different motion types.
Note:
To activate Display Tool in Machine, choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing. On the Operation tab, in the Edit Operation group, select Allow Display Tool in Machine.
Also you must be using a machine that is capable of Machine Powered Programming.
The Tool Path Animation group contains the controls to start or stop the animation, and to control the animation speed.
The IPW group, contains options to manage the in-process workpiece (IPW) for a selected operation.
You can control the IPW display, analyze the IPW, change the IPW resolution, or delete the IPW.

Use the options in the Display group of the Home tab to manage the display of tool paths when you select or edit an operation.
Use the Display Tool Path option to display selected tool paths.
Note:
You can select a point on a displayed tool path. NX moves the tool to the selected location. Use one of the Snap Options to further control point selection.
Show Non Cutting Moves
Shows or hides the non-cutting motions.
Note:
If you set both Show Cutting Moves and Show Non Cutting Moves to off, NX deactivates the path display for operations that you select in the Operation Navigator.
Tool Path Report
Opens the Tool Path Report dialog. You can select individual GOTO points, or an entire cut level, and display them in the graphics window.
Show Levels
Displays the first level in the selected toolpath and makes the following options available:
Previous Level
Displays the level before the currently displayed level.
Next Level
Displays the following levels, one at a time, ending at the bottom level.
Tool Display Type drop-down
Tool
Displays the parametric tool and holder.
Tool without Holder
Displays the parametric tool without the holder.
Tool Assembly
Displays the parametric model of the tool assembly.
Tool and Assembly
Displays the solid model of the tool assembly, if one is available.
Axis
Displays a line along the tool axis vector.
Point
Displays only the small circle at the selection point.
More drop-down
Opens a palette containing the following groups of options.
Color By group
Motion Type
Use the Motion type option to retain the display behavior of versions previous to NX 9.0.2.
Tool path motions are displayed in the colors that you set in the Options→Edit Display→Path Display Colors dialog box. You can assign colors to different motions, such as engage, retract, rapid, and cutting moves.
The example shows the default colors by motion type.
Tool
Use the Tool option to display the non-rapid moves of tool paths in a different color for each tool.
The example shows paths colored by tool. The first two paths are shown in blue, and then there is a tool change. The third path, which uses a new tool, is shown in green.
Motion Output Type
Use the Motion Output Type option to display a tool path in different colors for each motion type, such as rapid, engage, or cut. You can change the color for each motion type.
Configure Tool Path Colors
Opens the Path Colors Configurator dialog box.
Allows you to assign a color to each finding displayed with the option Tool Path Findings.
Operation
Use the Operation option to display the non-rapid moves of tool paths in a different color for each operation.
In the example, the path for the FACE_TOP operation is rendered in a blue shade, the path for the CAVITY_TOP operation is a green shade, and the path for the CAVITY_MILL operation is a yellow shade.
Tool Path Findings
Use the Tool Path Findings option to display gouges in tool paths, and findings in robotics operations such as limit violations, unwinds, and reach failures.
In the example, the gouges are colored according to the settings in the Tool Path Findings dialog.
Tool Path Analysis
Use the Tool Path Analysis option to display motions of tool paths in a different color for each analysis method.
In the example, the motions are colored according to the Swiveling Axis Angle analysis option.
Snap Options group
Point
Selects the point on the tool path nearest to the selection cursor.
Pictures show the point being selected, and the Axis tool display mode.
Nearest End Point
Selects the nearest GOTO point on the selected tool path segment.
Pictures show the point being selected, and the Axis tool display mode, with the tool snapped to the nearest end point.
End Point
Selects the destination GOTO point on the selected tool path segment.
Pictures show the point being selected, and the Axis tool display mode, with the tool snapped to the end point in the direction of travel.
Points Display group
End Point
Displays a dot at the end points of motions. Use it to judge the density of GOTO points.
Contact Points
Displays the tool path where the tool contacts the part surface.
Show Tool Center
Applies to ball nose cutters only.
When off, NX displays the tool path at the tool tip. This is the normal, default display.
Tool Axis at End Point
Displays the tool axis at each point in the tool path.
Display Path group
Use the Show Cutting Moves option to show or hide the cutting motions.
Use the Replay Tool Path option to replay selected tool paths.
Use the Trace Tool Axis option to display the tool axis.
You can display the tool axis at locations you select in the tool path, or display the tool axis throughout the entire tool path.
Note:
You can use the File→Preferences→Manufacturing Preferences→Visualization tab→Path Display commands to set the Tool Axis Trace Length and Tool Axis Trace Color preferences.
Customer defaults for tool and operation colors
The Color by Tool or Operation defaults control the default colors and order for tool path display by tool and by operation.
The Rapid Motion, Color and Font defaults control the font and color for rapid motions. Rapid motions are now red and dashed by default.
Note:
The Path Display and Selection customer defaults allow you to set the initial state of the display and selection of the tool path.
Note:
Some motions, such as Traversal, may be set to Rapid. In those cases, in the Motion Type display mode, the color for the motion type as defined in the operation is used, and the dashed font is used.
Tip:
To find a customer default, choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults, and click Find Default .
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Select an operation in the Operation Navigator
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Display group

Use the Tool Path Animation group of the Home tab to manage the animation of tool paths when you select or edit an operation.
Note:
Use the options in the Display and IPW groups of the Home tab to manage the display and in-process workpiece of the animation.
Play
Step Forward
Play to End of Motion
Pause
Play Backward
Step Backward
Play to Start of Motion
Speed
The Tool Path Animation controls allow you to:
Find the controls in one convenient place, and in multiple contexts.
Animate the tool from any picked location on the path.
Stop the animation at any location, including the middle of a motion.
Note:
Current tool tip coordinates and feed rate are displayed on the cue status bar when the animation is paused.
Set the animation speed from a slider control.
Note:
With animation, the tool path feed rate is not taken into account. All motions are interpolated according to distance, rather than time.
  Note:
Play and pause buttons are now combined into one button.
As soon as you click one of the play buttons, the Pause button appears.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Select an operation in the Operation Navigator
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Tool Path Animation group

Use the IPW group of the Home tab to manage the in-process workpiece (IPW) when you select or edit an operation.
Display IPW
Lets you see the IPW at any selected point in the tool path. The IPW is updated dynamically while the tool path plays forward. If you play the tool path backwards, the IPW remains visible, but is not updated. You can select multiple tool paths when you use this option.
3D IPW Drop-down
Analyze IPW
Shows the color coded workpiece after generating the tool path for the selected operation.
Show 3D IPW
Displays the 3D IPW for Mill Turn and Milling operations.
Show Spinning 3D IPW
Displays the spun shape of the workpiece after the tool path generating the selected operation.
Create IPW Facet Body
Creates a facet body from the current state of the IPW. You can pause the tool path animation or select a point on the tool path to create a facet body from the IPW.
Save IPW as
Saves the in-process workpiece associated with the highlighted operation as a separate 3D model.
Parallel Create 3D IPW
Creates the 3D IPW for the selected operation in the background during an interactive Tool Path Animation session.
Delete 3D IPW
Deletes the 3D IPW of an operation.
Select 2D IPWs
Allows selection of 2D IPWs in Turning operations.
Enhance IPW Resolution
Enhances the resolution in a specific area of the IPW.
Display 2D IPW
Enables the display of the 2D IPW in Turning operations.
IPW Resolution
Sets the IPW resolution used in Tool Path Animation.
Coarse
Medium
Fine

The Tool Axis at End Point command lets you view the tool axis alignment at different points on the tool path. The tool axis and end point display are permanent until you turn the option off.
You can visually evaluate the tool axis in the tool path at specific locations or by observing the tool axis progressions. These progressions can be on cutting motions on the machining surfaces or on non-cutting motions in the air. For example, the displayed tool axis could show progression around the fillets or corners, alignment with respect to curved surfaces, or a change of alignment between two cutting surfaces during non-cutting motions. Tool Axis at End Point is especially useful for five-axis machining.
Use Tool Axis at End Point with other commands to help you evaluate the display. You can do the following:
Change the tool axis trace length in the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box.
Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing→Visualization tab→Path Display group→Tool Axis Trace Length
Use Show Levels to display a single level and move up or down the tool path levels.
Use the Tool Path Report command to evaluate the tool path at specific levels or GOTO points.
Tip:
Set the Display option to Selected Only to display individual GOTO points within a level.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Tool Axis at End Point

Use the options in the Operations group of the Home tab to display, modify, and check tool paths.
Generate Tool Path
Allows you to generate the tool path.
Verify Tool Path
Gives you various options to animate the tool path.
Note:
Legacy function. A customer default controls the availability of this option.
Gouge Check
Allows you to gouge check selected segments of the tool path. Each gouge reported is a set of continuous tool path segments.
Simulate Machine
Gives you various options to simulate tool motions on a machine.
Validity Report
Allows you to validate a program before postprocessing and machining a part.
Post Process
Allows you to generate the NC program for a specific machine controller.
More
Opens a list of additional options to display, modify, and check tool paths.
Recently Used group
Allows you to select an option that you used recently.
Utilities group
Post Configurator
Allows you to create and edit postprocessors.
Tool Path group
Parallel Generate
Allows you to generate operations in the background while you continue working.
Edit Tool Path
Allows you to make corrections or modifications to a generated tool path. See Tool Path Editor.
List Tool Path
Displays a text listing of the tool path in an Information window.
List Findings
Groups consecutive motions that share a finding, such as a gouge, into a folder in the report.
Synchronize
Allows you to modify your NC program to optimize idle times and tool usage for a multi-channel machine.
Feed Rates
Allows you to define the feed rates and spindle speeds.
Optimize Feed Rate
Allows you to vary feed rates to maintain a constant material removal rate.
Tilt Tool Axis
Allows you to avoid tool holder collisions in surface contouring, cavity milling, and Zlevel operations.
Divide Tool Path
Allows you to divide an existing operation into two or more operations, each limited to a maximum cutting time or distance, or to one or more selected motions.
Divide by Holder
Allows you to split a single tool path into multiple tool paths using tools of different lengths to avoid collisions and to machine the entire cut area.
Output CLSF
Allows you to output the program or operation as a CLSF file (.cl).
Delete Tool Path
Allow you to delete the tool path for the selected operation.
Batch Processing
Allows you to generate tool paths, NC programs, and shop floor documentation.
Notes
Allows you to add multiple lines of informative text to any operation.
Shop Documentation
Allows you to create a report of machining operations.
Machine Code group
Program Manager
Allows you to manage and edit the NC programs used in machine code simulation.
Delete Machine Code
Allows you to delete the machine code stored for the operation.
Work Instructions group
Author Work Instructions
Allows you to create job process sheets that NX can automatically update.
Publish Work Instructions
Allows you to direct NX to publish all of the Work Instructions job process sheets for the selected node.
Delete Work Instructions
Allows you to direct NX to delete all of the Work Instructions job process sheets for the selected node.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Select an operation or program group in the Operation Navigator
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Operations group

The Validity Report allows you to quickly confirm that all the required steps to create a valid operation are completed before you postprocess and machine a part.

The Operation Validity Report dialog box can display the status of these operation validity checks:
S
Summary
Gouge
Holder Part Collision
Holder IPW Collision
Tool Rapid IPW Collision
Has Tool Path
Suspect Path
Feeds and Speeds
Robot Rules Applied
Note:
To have a validity check considered in the summary column of the Operation Validity Report dialog box, set the appropriate Validity Report customer defaults, and restart NX.
Note:
To set the visibility and order of the columns in the Operation Validity Report dialog box, select a column header, right-click the mouse, and select Configure Columns.
The validity check status icons are:
Pass
The validation check was applied to the operation and no problems were detected. In the Summary column, all of the validity checks selected as a customer default have passed.
Fail
The validation check was applied to the operation and failed. In the Summary column, at least one validity check that is selected as a customer default has failed.
Not Checked
The validation check has not been applied to the operation. In the Summary column, not all of the validity checks selected as a customer default have been performed.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Select an operation or program group in the Operation Navigator.
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Operations group→Validity Report
Customer default
Manufacturing→Operation→Validity Report tab→[Validity check]

Use the Verify command to verify your tool path by playing an animation of only the tool path or both the tool path and material removal. Animating material removal helps you verify that the cutter is cutting the specified portions of the raw material.
The Tool Path Visualization dialog box opens when you choose this command. The following animation options are available in that dialog box:
Replay
3D Dynamic
You also have options to control tool movement and the display during the animation.

Note:
You must activate the Show Verify command in the Customer Defaults→Manufacturing→Simulation & Visualization node to use Verify.
Verify does not support IPW visualization or 3D Dynamic Tool Path Verification in Wire EDM operations. In the Tool Path Visualization dialog box, the 3D Dynamic tab is grayed out and the options are not accessible.

Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Tool paths must be generated.
Command
Verify Tool Path
Operation Navigator
[Operation or Program]→Right-click→Tool Path→Verify
Top Border bar
[Select operation or program]→Home tab→Tool Path→Verify
Menu
[Select operation or program]→Tools→Operation Navigator→Tool Path→Verify
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Actions group→Verify

Document Title: Single blank for tool path animation
Document Body:
Tool Path Animation uses only the blank of the first operation in a selected program to update the displayed in-process workpiece (IPW), regardless of whether the operations used different blanks to generate tool paths.
IPW material removal is consistent with that of Verify, allowing you to fully transition to Tool Path Animation.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
A blank must be defined
Ribbon bar
