The Tool Path Visualization dialog box opens when you click Verify in an operation dialog box.
Retained settings
NX retains the Tool Path Visualization dialog box settings throughout the NX session, with the following exceptions:
Settings in dialog boxes that you open from the Tool Path Visualization dialog box are not retained.
The slider value that controls the listing in the tool path listing window is not retained.
Note:
Depending which dialog box option is selected, you can also use the arrow keys to do other tasks, for example:
Adjust a slider value
Change a list selection
Dialog box options
The following table lists options in the main dialog box, and options that are common to the Replay and 3D Dynamic tabs.
Common Options
Available regardless of which tab is selected.
Path Listing
Lists the tool path motions for the operation you are replaying in 9-line pages.
When the Replay tab is selected, if you select a point in the graphics window, the corresponding line is highlighted in the list. Select a line in the list to move the tool to the corresponding location in the graphics window.
List slider
Controls which page of 9 motion lines is displayed in the list. The upper limit of the slider reflects the number of 9-line pages in the tool path.
Use the slider to scroll through all of the GOTO and CIRCLE motions in the tool path.
Feed Rate
Displays the Feed Rate for the current move.
Animation Speed
Controls the speed for the tool path replay.
When the slider is selected, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts:
Left arrow key = slower
Right arrow key = faster
Click beside the slider to change it toward the click location.
Slider changes do not take effect until the current motion block is complete.
Animation Controls
Let you control the tool path animation.
When a button is selected, you can use the following keyboard shortcuts:
Left arrow key = step backward
Right arrow key = step forward
Page up key = next operation
Page down key = previous operation
You can hold an arrow key for continuous motion.

Separate options are available to control the tolerances for tilting and facet accuracy so that you can specify a tighter tolerance for faceting and a looser tolerance for tilting. Increasing the tilt tolerance to a value of 0.1 or 0.15 can give acceptable quality while significantly improving performance.
Chordal Tolerance controls the tolerance for circular motions and the tolerance for tool, IPW, and blank faceting. The default value is 0.05 mm.
Tilt Tolerance controls the tolerance for tool axis tilting, and the default value is 0.05 mm.
NX approximates 5-axis movements with angular steps. This tolerance specifies the maximum deviation from the plane, for each step, as the tool axis changes.
The Chordal Tolerance and Tilt Tolerance settings are saved with the part file. You can change the values in two locations:
In Customer Defaults to change the session preferences. These settings affect only new parts.
In Manufacturing Preferences to change the values for an open part.
Tip:
To find a customer default, choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults, and click Find Default .
To find the preferences, choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing→Geometry→In Process Workpiece Tolerances.

Use the Replay options in the Tool Path Visualization dialog box to view a replay of the NC program. You can view the cutter at each program location. Because a replay does not include material removal, it is the faster of the animation techniques that are available in the Tool Path Visualization dialog box.
You can use the Replay options to:
Display the tool or tool assembly for one or more tool paths.
Display the tool as a wire frame, a solid body, or a tool assembly.
Display gouges if they exist and also view a report on the gouges.
Control the tool path display.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing.
Prerequisite
Tool paths must be created.
Command
Verify Tool Path
Location in dialog box
Tool Path Visualization dialog box→Replay tab.

Display Options
Allows you to choose how the tool is displayed in the graphics window while you are replaying.
Tool
Specifies the display style for the tool.
Wireframe
Point
Axis
Tool
Assembly
For the Assembly option, the part file that contains the solid tool or tool assembly must be in the tool graphics folder. If NX cannot find the tool, it displays the same as Tool.
2D Material Removal
Available for turning operations.
Show Previous IPW
Motion Display
Tool Path
Specifies the display style for the tool path.
All
Displays the entire tool path.
Current Level
Displays the tool path for the current cut level.
Start to Current Motion
Displays the tool path from the start to the
current position of the tool.
Next n motions
Displays the specified number of tool path
motions ahead of the current location.
+/ – n Motions
Displays the specified number of tool path
motions ahead of and behind the current
location of the tool.
Collision
Displays the most recent rapid motion of the
tool that moved through the IPW.
  Gouge and Collision Settings
Opens the Gouge and Collision Settings dialog box.
Gouge checking is available for milling, drilling and turning operations. In a series of operations, gouges are only reported for the supported types of operations.
Gouge checking displays message boxes to inform you about the following:
Negative part offsets that are greater than the tool radius
Tools other than milling and drilling tools.
You can choose whether to cancel, or to continue to run with some limitations.

Document Title: Gouge and Collision Settings dialog box
Document Body:
Gouge Checking
Check for Gouges
Turns gouge checking on or off.
Collision Checking
Check Tool and Holder
Checks for tool holder collisions when gouge checking.
Tool shape for Checking
Tool Shape
Tool Parameters
Uses the parameters for the tool, shank, and holder in gouge checking and collision calculations.
Solid Assembly
If an assembly model of the solid tool and holder are available, NX uses the solid bodies in gouge checking and collision calculations. Otherwise, you get a warning message and the tool parameters are used.
Gouge Check Stock
Automatic
Uses the minimum value for part stock, wall stock, and floor stock that is defined in the cutting parameters for each operation that you check. If you have non-uniform stock, NX displays a warning.
Note:
NX does not display this warning in Area Mill, Zlevel, and Cavity Mill operations. Non-uniform gouge check is supported for these operations.
User Defined
Makes the Gouge Check Stock box available for input. You can input a value for one time use.
The value reverts to the automatic value that NX selects from the operation parameters when you next open the dialog box.
Gouge Check Stock
Displays the read-only stock value when Automatic is selected, or lets you specify a stock value when User Defined is selected.
Gouge and Collision Settings
Display Gouges
Highlights gouges in the graphics window.
List Gouges when Finished
Lists all gouges found in an information window after the animation stops or after a single step

3D Dynamic material removal displays the moving tool and tool holder along one or more tool paths showing the material being removed. This mode also allows you to zoom, rotate, and pan in the graphic window. Blank geometry is used to represent the rough material or raw stock.
You can use the 3D Dynamic options to:
Display the tool or tool assembly for one or more tool paths.
Display the tool as a wire frame, a solid or a tool assembly.
Check for collisions and display them if they exist and also view a report on the collisions.
Control the tool path display.
Note:
The 3D Dynamic verification checks for collisions with the IPW in rapid mode and holder collisions with the IPW. It does not check by default for gouges against the part and does not list them. You can check for gouges using the Verify→Replay command.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing.
Prerequisite
Tool paths must be created.
Command
Verify Tool Path
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Actions group→Verify

Tool Display
Specifies the display style for the tool.
Wireframe
Point
Axis
Tool
Assembly
For the Assembly option, the part file that contains the solid tool or tool assembly must be in the tool graphics folder. If NX cannot find the tool, it displays the same as Tool.
Tool Path
Specifies the display style for the tool path.
All
Displays the entire tool path.
Current Level
Displays the tool path for the current cut level.
Start to Current Motion
Displays the tool path from the start to the
current position of the tool.
Next n motions
Displays the specified number of tool path
motions ahead of the current location.
+/ – n Motions
Displays the specified number of tool path
motions ahead of and behind the current
location of the tool.
Collision
Displays the most recent rapid motion of the
tool that moved through the IPW.
  IPW Resolution
Lets you set the resolution for the in-process workpiece (IPW) process.
Course
Generates a low resolution model of the IPW. With this resolution, the generation of the IPW is fast.
Medium
Generates a medium resolution model of the IPW. The option requires more time than Coarse.
Fine
Generates a model of the IPW with the highest resolution. This option takes the longest time to generate.
Note:
The resolution is only used for milling operations and is insensitive for turning operations.
Display Options
Display Options contains the following options:
Number of Motions
Sets the number of motions to be displayed ahead of the tool, fo the Next n Motions and +/- n Motions display options
Pause at Each Level
Allows multi-level paths to pause after each level.
Animation Accuracy
Allows the settting of Fine or Course. When the Course option is used the IPW is redrawn in Fine resolution when the animation stops.
IPW Color
Defines the color on the IPW.
IPW Translucency
Defines the translucency of the IPW. The translucency can be in the range from 0 (= opaque) to 100 (=invisible).
Note:
Color and translucency changes take effect after you stop and restart he animation.
IPW
Specifies if and how to save the IPW.
None
Saves neither the IPW nor a body.
Save
Saves the IPW with the operation. You can use the IPW can later be used as Input IPW to another operation or can be displayed from the Operation Navigator.
Note:
The Save options is available only for milling operations
Save As Component
Saves the IPW as a solid or faceted body in a separate part file. Each body is stored in its own reference set.
When you verify multiple operations, NX saves a separate component part file for each operation.
Create
Creates the selected type of body. You can create multiple faceted solid bodies.
Delete
Deletes the selected type of faceted body.
Analyze
Opens the Analyze dialog box. You can use the options in that dialog box to analyze the measurements in your operation. The measurements are computed on a faced body for milling operations and on a solid body of revolution for turning operations
Show 3D, Show Spinning 3D
Let you choose whether to view the rotated or non-rotated IPW. This is helpful for mill turn parts.
Show Spinning 3D
Show 3D
Check for IPW Collisions
Checks for rapid motion collisions with the IPW.
Check Tool and Holder
Checks tool holder collisions at any speed.
Collision Settings
Opens the Collision Settings dialog box.
Reset
Re-initializes the 3D Dynamic property page to its original state.
The 3D Dynamic material removal display is refreshed.
The first operation of a series is made the current operation.
Reset must be selected to re-run the 3D Dynamic Material Removal.
Suppress Animation
Displays the end result of the animation, without playing the animation.

IPW Collision Settings
Pause on Collision
Animation pauses when the tool collides with the IPW at rapid speed. The animation pauses when the tool holder collides at any speed.
Check Between Operations
Generates motions internally for the transition from one operation to the next, and checks these motions for collision.
Check on Tool Change
Activates collision checking between operations when a tool change occurs.
Check on Tool Axis Change
Activates collision checking between operations when the tool axis changes.
Note:
The 3D Dynamic verification checks for collisions with the IPW in rapid mode and holder collisions with the IPW. It does not check by default for gouges against the part and does not list them. You can check for gouges using the Compare command.

Orientation
Orientation
Lets you orient the enhancement box relative to the blank and the part geometry.
MCS
Uses the existing machine coordinate system.
Specify CSYS
Lets you specify a coordinate system other than the MCS.
Limits
XM-, XM+, YM-, YM+, ZM-, ZM+
Allows you to enter values to resize the box, or displays updated values if you resize the box using the handles in the graphics window.
Enhancement Factor
Low→High
Use the slider to increase or decrease the amount of the enhancement resolution.
Action
Execute
Enhances the IPW resolution within the selected box.
Refit Enhancement Box
Recalculates the enhancement box according to the current view orientation and zoom factor.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in Simulation Control Panel dialog box
Simulation Settings group
Location in Verify dialog box
3D Dynamic tab

Document Title: Create an IPW color plot for a Milling operation
Document Body:
Before you can create an IPW color plot, you must have a 3D Dynamic model. You can generate this model when you play an animation using 3D Dynamic options in the Tool Path Visualization dialog box.
In the Tool Path Visualization dialog box, click the 3D Dynamic tab
Click Play .
The material is removed and the IPW is created.
Click Analyze.
Tip:
Notice the top of the color scale indicates the greatest stock thickness.
To identify the material depth at different locations, click the desired location on the part.

What is it?
The Manufacturing Compare Tool lets you compare two revisions of the same part. You can use the differences to find related operations of the relevant part using the Machining Feature Navigator and check if something needs to be modified.
In the Manufacturing Compare Tool, you can:
Use filters to compare the revisions based on criteria such as an object's name, properties, or parent-child relationships.
Change the configuration of the columns. You can also use the Configure Columns command to create a custom column configuration.
Select a feature, and it remains selected when you switch to the Machining Feature Navigator.
Use the Find Related Operations command to automatically select operations in the Operation Navigator that machine the selected feature.
Use the Fit View to Selection command to easily locate a feature in the graphics window that you want to compare.
When you select the graphics window tab for a part file, it becomes the active revision. When the Synchronize Graphical Views command is active, the Manufacturing Compare Tool synchronizes the actions, such as sorting, scrolling, or filtering, in the navigator view for both revisions.
For all comparisons, the text for an object displays in the same color font in both revisions.
Example:
Compare Object Names, selecting the active revision
To view the differences between versions, you can display the Description column as shown in the previous example, or you can hover over an object to see the tool tip.
Example:
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
The CAM setup and parts to machine must follow the master model structure, with WAVE linked geometry, that is recommended for CAM.
Resource bar
Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator tab

Load the two part revisions to compare.
We recommend that you load only the two part revisions that you are comparing.
In the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator, click Load First Revision .
Click Load Second Revision .
If they are not already selected, activate Synchronize Graphical Views and Color Ancestors Containing Differences .
Expand the hierarchy of either revision.
The compare tool synchronizes the actions in the other revision when you change one revision.
Activate the filters you need to compare the revisions.
Select from the following:
Compare Object Names
Compare Parent-Child Relations
Compare Child Order
Compare Properties
Select a column configuration that displays the information you wish to review.
Right-click a header in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator, and choose Column Configuration→Feature, Full Columns Configuration, or Default.
Default displays the Title, Comparison, and Description columns.
Feature displays information on the feature status.
Full Columns Configuration displays all the attributes.
Activate filters to limit the information displayed.
Use these commands to control how the compare tool analyzes the data strings.
Match Case
Ignore White Space Characters
Use the Show Only Properties with Differences command to hide columns with identical property values.
Use the Configure Columns command to hide columns that do not have useful information for your analysis.
Review the feature or features with differences.
Review the Description column or tool tip information.
In the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator, select the feature to analyze.
Choose Menu→View→Operation→Fit View to Selection to find your feature in the graphics windows.
In the active revision, right-click the feature node and choose Find Related Operations to switch to the Operation Navigator and view the operations used to machine the feature.
You can also choose Find Related Tools to view the tools used to machine the feature.
Tip:
Select the graphics window tab of a part file to make it the active revision.
Close the part files or minimize the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator when you are done comparing revisions.
To minimize the compare tool, do the following:
Right-click a header in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator and choose Collapse All.
Click Load First Revision .
This step reloads the part file and loads only the root node in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator, so that the compare tool stops processing the features.

Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator commands
Load First Revision
Loads a part file into the Compare Tool as the first revision.
Load Second Revision
Loads a part file into the Compare Tool as the second revision. The selection order is not important.
Compare Object Names
Compares the object names in the Title column.
Displays the text for an object in green font if the object name differs in the two revisions. Also displays Difference: name in the Description column, and in the object's tool tips.
Compare Parent-Child Relations
Compares the parent-child relations within the hierarchy structure.
Displays the text for an object in a bold red font if the immediate parent object differs in the two revisions, or if the object has different children in the two revisions. Also displays Difference: parent in the Description column, and in the object's tool tip.
Compare Child Order
Available when Compare Parent-Child Relations is selected.
Compares the child order, or the sequence within a group.
Displays the text for an object in a bold red font if the order of the object's children differs in the two revisions. Also displays Difference: child in the Description column, and in the object's tool tip.
Compare Properties
Compares the properties, including any associated attributes, for each object in the hierarchy.
Note:
Compare Properties compares the text strings that define each property. Select the Match Case or Ignore White Space Characters to control how the Manufacturing Compare Tool analyzes the strings.
Show Only Properties with Differences
Available when Compare Properties is selected.
Shows only the property columns where the first and second revisions have different values. This simplifies the display.
Match Case
Matches case when comparing strings.
Ignore White Space Characters
Ignores white spaces when comparing strings.
Color Ancestors Containing Differences
Displays the Title and Comparison text for an object in blue font if the revisions for that object do not have differences, but one or more of the descendants of that object have differences.
Expand/Collapse to Show Only Differences
Expands the hierarchy for objects that have differences in their descendants to show the specific differences. Collapses the hierarchy for objects that do not have differences in their descendants.
Synchronize Graphical Views
Synchronizes the graphics view for both revisions, so that any viewing change in one view also applies to the other view.
Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator node commands
The following commands are available when you right-click a feature or feature group node in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator.
Find Related Operations
Available when you select a feature node in the active part file.
Opens the Operation Navigator and selects the operation nodes that belong to the machining feature you selected in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator.
Find Related Tools
Available when you select a feature node in the active part file.
Opens the Operation Navigator and selects the tool nodes that belong to the machining feature you selected in the Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator.
Columns
The Manufacturing Compare Tool Navigator has the same columns as the Manufacturing Feature Navigator, plus the following:
Comparison
Displays one of the following for each object in the revision versions:
No entry
The object is identical in the first and second revision.
Different in green font
The object has one or more properties that are different in the second revision panel. The differences display in the Description column, and in the object's tool tip.
Example:
Comparison: Difference: property values: X_ORIENTATION_L, Y_ORIENTATION_L Has differences in descendants
Unique in red font
The object is unique to this model. Only appears in this model displays in the Description column, and in the object's tool tip.
Description
Displays the status of the feature. If there are differences between the two revisions, displays the differences.
Example:
Status: Up to Date Difference: property values: DIAMETER_1, Geometry Status

The time that you spend on manually generating NC job process sheets could be as much as half the total time required to create a complete NC package. To maintain the process sheets you must manually synchronize multiple inputs and this process can be error prone. It is also easy to overlook automatic changes to the NC program. To create job process sheets that NX can automatically update, use the Documentation operation or the Author Work Instructions command.
In a typical workflow you create a Documentation operation where you create job process sheets with information such as setup instructions, a tool list, and an operation list for the overall program. You place the Documentation operation at the beginning of the program. You then use the Author Work Instructions command to create and attach job process sheets to individual CAM operations. NX updates all associative data in your job process sheets, for example:
Drafting sheets
Tool information
Tool and operation lists
MOM variables
Lightweight section views
When your workflow is complete, you can publish the job process sheets as PDF or HTML files. When you select a program to publish the work instructions, NX adds all of the process sheets in their program order, and links them to the table of contents. You can select a single operation to publish only the process sheets required by that operation.
Operation Navigator
There is a separate column in the Operation Navigator to show you which operations have work instructions assigned to them. In the following example, the GENERAL_SETUP operation is a Documentation operation. Work instructions are added to the CAVITY_MILL and FLOOR_WALL_IPW operations using the Work Instructions command.
Name
Path   
Work Instructions   
Time
PROGRAM
01:56:01
GENERAL_SETUP 
00:30:00
MILL   
01:13:26
CAVITY_MILL   
00:17:58
FLOOR_WALL_IPW   
00:05:36
FIXED_CONTOUR   
00:12:31
VARIABLE_STREAMLINE   
00:28:29




The Time column includes a separate Manual value that shows the time you add for tasks such as measuring or cleaning.
CAVITY_MILL   
00:17:58
00h 15m 56s Cutting
00h 00m 02s Non Cutting
00h 02m 00s Manual
00h 17m 56s Total

Note:
Do not include Documentation operations as the target for the following commands, as unexpected results may occur.
Parallel Generate
Replay
Object Transform
Simulate
Gouge Check
Verify
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
You must install the wkhtmltopdf utility in your C:\Program Files\wkhtmltopdf folder to export the work instructions as a PDF. Version 0.12.5 is recommended. This version of the wkhtmltopdf utility is available at https://github.com/wkhtmltopdf/wkhtmltopdf/releases/0.12.5/
Command
Create Operation
Documentation
Location in dialog box
Creating a Documentation program:
Create Operation dialog box→Type list→work_instructions→Operation Subtype group→Documentation
Adding work instructions to a CAM operation:
Right-click the operation→Work Instructions→Author

Document Title: Associative and non-associative work instruction information
Document Body:
Work instructions can contain associative and non-associative information. NX updates associative information. You must update non-associative information manually.
Associative information that is updated automatically
NX updates the following information as the part file is updated.
MOM variable values
Operation specific product views
Tool and operation lists
Attributes for components
NX updates the following information when the source file is updated.
Image files
Hyperlinks
Non-associative information that you must update
Estimated time to complete tasks
Rich text and standard text

Setup instructions
Tool sheet

First step
> 1. Create a Documentation operation for the general setup instructions

Document Title: 1. Create a Documentation operation for the general setup instructions
Document Body:
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Operation .
In the Create Operation dialog box, set the following operation parameters:
Type group
List = work_instruction
Operation Subtype group
Documentation
Location group
Program = PROGRAM
Tool = NONE
Geometry = NONE
Method = NONE
Name group
general_setup
Click OK.
In the Documentation dialog box, in the Instruction Sheets group, under Name, SHEET_1 is selected by default.
SHEET_1
If you work on a single monitor, you may not want continuous updates to the HTML preview. To prevent htese updates, in the Preview group, clear the Preview check box. To review each process sheet after you create it, click Display .
In the Format group, select General Instructions.
SHEET_1
In the Sheet Title box, type General Instructions.
The default sheet title is operation name – Sheet n, where n is the sheet number. Changing the sheet title to match the format name helps you to manage your sheets.
The General Instructions sheet contains predefined instructions that apply to every job. Your administrator defines the content.

In the Name list, select a sheet.
In the Sheet Actions group, click or .
The names in the list always reflect the order in which the sheets will be published in the PDF. To identify a sheet, look at the name you assigned to it in the Sheet Title box.
In the Time group, type 1800.
You enter the time in seconds. This is the estimated time to complete all of the manual tasks required for the general setup before machining. You will enter additional time to the work instructions for each operation to account for any manual tasks required by that operation.
Click OK to save your documentation operation.
Move the documentation operation to the beginning of the program.

Next step
> 9. Publish the work instructions

This example publishes the work instructions for the general setup and all operations within the program group to a PDF file. NX publishes all of the Work Instructions job process sheets for the selected node. You can select a single operation to publish only the job process sheets required by that operation.
Note:
You must install the wkhtmltopdf utility in your C:\Program Files\wkhtmltopdf folder to export the work instructions as a PDF. Version 0.12.5 is recommended. This version of the wkhtmltopdf utility is available at https://github.com/wkhtmltopdf/wkhtmltopdf/releases/0.12.5/
In the Operation Navigator, select the PROGRAM_1 node.
Choose Home tab→Operations group→More→Publish Work Instructions.
In the Publish Work Instructions dialog box, in the Output Format group, click PDF.
In the Output File group, click Browse and navigate to the folder to save your file.
Your administrator sets an environment variable to control where you can publish Work Instructions output. By default, the location is the same folder that contains your manufacturing setup assembly part file.
Name the file.
Select the Open File After Publishing check box.
In the PDF Options group, set your formatting options.
Click OK.

Document Title: Author Work Instructions command and Documentation operation
Document Body:
You use the Documentation operation to create an operation that contains job process sheets and manual task information for the overall program. You use the Author Work Instructions command to create and attach job process sheets to a selected CAM operation.
Within both the Documentation and the Author Work Instructions dialog boxes, the steps to create job process sheets and control their formatting and organization are the same.
When you open either dialog box, there is one sheet with the default name [operation name] - Sheet1. The default name appears in the Sheet Title box. As a best practice, rename each sheet so that you know its purpose. The sheet title is the table of contents entry when you publish the work instructions.
The warning symbol indicates that the sheet is not yet formatted.
When you select an option from the Format list, the sheet status changes to .
Sheet formats
Each sheet format includes unique components. The available components depend on the object that you select in the Name list. For example, the Setup Instructions sheet includes a component to capture the product view.
Sheet components
When you select a sheet component in the Name column, NX displays the available options in the component group.
For example, if you select a view component, NX displays view options.

Document Title: Author Work Instructions and Documentation dialog boxes
Document Body:
Note:
Your administrator may customize the dialog box with different contents.
Instruction Sheets
Name
Lists the sheets and sheet components.
Format
Displays the formats that you can apply to the selected instruction sheet.
General Instructions
Includes predefined instructions that apply to all setups, such as Maintain the work station in a clean and neat manner.
Setup Instructions
Includes a view of the setup and instruction text.
Setup Instructions with Image
Lets you add an image file to the setup.
Tip:
Export screen captures as image files, so that you can add them to instruction sheets.
Tools
Includes a drawing sheet and text.
Operations
Includes a view of the tool path, a drawing sheet, and text.
Operation List
Includes a view of the tool path, instruction text, and a drawing sheet.
Tool List by Name, Tool List by Number
Lets you add up to 2 drawing sheets and a tool list.
OWI_TEXT_1
Lets you enter text or insert text from a file. You can save your completed instructions to a text file to reuse in another operation.
Insert Variable
Displays a list of the available MOM variables. NX inserts the selected MOM variable in the instruction sheet. When you publish the work instruction sheet, it displays the current value of the MOM variable.
Insert Text from File
The text file format must be UTF-8 for all languages except English.
Save Note as Text File
Saves the text you entered for the OWI_TEXT_1 component as a file that you can reuse.
Insert Hyperlink
OWI_IMAGE
Lets you select an image file from the operating system.
OWI_OPER_LIST
Adds a list of operations from the selected program group to the instruction sheet.
OWI_PROD_VIEW
OWI_PATH_VIEW
Lets you add a camera view to the instruction sheet. You can select an existing camera view or capture a new view.
Capture current view
Captures the current view, including point of view, visibility of linked bodies, and assembly component visibility. Adds the view to the Select Camera list. OWI_PATH_VIEW also captures the tool path, even if it is not displayed in the graphics window.
Activate captured view
Activates the camera view captured for the OWI_PATH_VIEW or OWI_PROD_VIEW component.
Restore previous view
Restores the graphics window to the view in use before activating any work instruction views.
Display Tool
Lets you select a location along the path, at which to display the tool.
OWI_DWG
Lets you select a drawing sheet from a list that includes all drawings within the part file.
For help on adding drawing sheets for your tools, see:
Add a view from a different part
Sheet Actions
Lets you add new instruction sheets and control the sheet order.
Time
Lets you specify how much time to allow for manual tasks such as measuring or cleaning.
The Time column in the Operation Navigator includes a separate manual value that shows the time you add.
Preview
Preview
Updates the HTML display continuously for instruction sheets as you make changes.
Display
Updates the HTML display. Use this option with the Preview check box cleared to avoid continuous updates in the instruction sheet display.

Machine Stop
Active
Creates a machine stop command that displays the operator message text.
Operator Message
Lets you enter text to describe the manual task that must be performed.
Insert Variable
Displays a list of the available MOM variables. NX inserts the selected MOM variable in the operator message. When you postprocess the manual control operation, the machine code displays the current value of the MOM variable.
Documentation
Work Instructions
Opens the Author Work Instructions dialog box.

The following list includes the Work Instruction files required for all templates, and the files that define the standard Tool List by Name template sheet supplied with NX. The files for the other template sheets are omitted for clarity.
owi_template_tool_list_by_name_files
File folder that contains the sheet component files for the Tool List by Name template.
path_image.png
Placeholder image for the OWI_PROD_VIEW and OWI_PATH_VIEW components. You can replace this image when you customize your templates.
filelist.xml
owi.dat
Controls the templates available in the Format list in the Work Instructions dialog box.
owi_excel.tcl
TCL file required by all templates.
owi_excel.tpl
TPL file required by all templates.
owi_quicktext.txt
Contains the text available in the Author Work Instructions and Documentation dialog boxes, and in the Quick Text list.
owi_template_tool_list_by_name.htm
Template HTML file. Excel generates the file when you publish the template.
owi_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl
TCL file required to publish the Tool List by Name template. Every template has an associated TCL file. The names of the Excel file and the TCL file must match.
owi_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx
Excel file for the Tool List by Name template. You edit this file to change the sheet format.
publish_owi_excel.tpl
TPL file required to publish all templates.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
File location
(Default) $UGII_BASE_DIR\mach\resource\owi
The environment variable UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR defines the location of the Work Instruction template files.

Document Title: Work Instruction Excel template file commands and format
Document Body:
Work Instruction template commands
Within a template file, the OWI_ commands call the different sheet components. To include multiple instances of the same component, number the components sequentially. For example, if you need a text block, enter OWI_TEXT_1 in a cell. If you need three text blocks, enter OWI_TEXT_1, OWI_TEXT_2, and OWI_TEXT_3 in their respective cells.
OWI_DWG_1
Inserts a drawing component.
OWI_OPER_LIST_1
Inserts an operation list.
OWI_PATH_VIEW_1
Inserts a captured camera view that includes the tool path.
OWI_PROD_VIEW_1
Inserts a captured camera view of the manufacturing setup.
OWI_TEXT_1
Inserts a text block where the user can enter text, insert mom variables, insert hyperlinks, or insert text from a file.
OWI_TOOL_LIST_1
Inserts a tool list.
OWI_IMAGE_1
Inserts an image file that the user selects. Supported file types are .bmp, .jpg, .gif, .png, and .tif.
${mom_owi_manual_time}
Inserts the time entered in the Estimated Time to Complete Task box of the Documentation dialog box.
${mom_attr_PART_PARTNUM}>OP:${mom_attr_PART_MFG_OP}
Inserts the PARTNUM and PART_MFG_OP attributes. You can delete this command if you do not use the attributes.
mom_attr commands extract attributes defined for your part in the Displayed Part Properties dialog box.
Tip:
To view the part attributes:
Assembly Navigator,→right-click the setup assembly→Properties→Attributes tab
###xx###
Indicates a sheet formatting command.
${}
Indicates a call to a mom variable.
Example Excel template file
This example shows the contents of the owi_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx file for the Tool List by Name template. Sheet formatting commands appear in red text.
###PAGE_CONTENT_LENGTH###, 9, IN
Sets the page length at 9 inches. The valid length units are IN and MM.
###REPEAT_TITLE###, No
Specifies that only the contents between ###BODY_START### and ###TITLE_START### are repeated at the top of each page. For this example, the sheet title is repeated. If you enter Yes, everything between ###TITLE_START### and ###TABLE_START### is also repeated at the top of each page.
The code between ###TITLE_START### and ###TABLE_START### is considered the title section of the template.
Path Image
The path_image.png file is a placeholder image for the OWI_PROD_VIEW, OWI_PATH_VIEW, and OWI_DWG components. The graphic in the template must fit within the borders of the cell or merged cells where you insert it. This is so that the captured camera view or drawing also fits within the assigned borders in the work instruction sheet.
For this tool list example, NX repeats everything between ###TABLE_START### and ###TABLE_END### for each tool. In an operation list sheet, NX repeats the code for each operation.
There are formatting requirements for the operation list and tool list table row. The first column must be one of the following:
Index, my_index
Operation Name, mom_operation_name
Tool Name, mom_tool_name
Tool Number, mom_tool_number
If you do not use Index, then the first column is the table key. For example, if the first column contains mom_tool_name, then mom_operation_name lists all operations that use that tool.
If the first column is Index, then the second column is the table key and must contain one of the following:
mom_operation_name
mom_tool_name
mom_tool_number
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
File location
(Default) $UGII_BASE_DIR\mach\resource\owi
The environment variable UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR defines the location of the Work Instruction template files.

Note:
This procedure is for administrators and requires write permissions to the template files folder.
The default Tool List by Name template contains two drawing sheets. This example adds two drawing sheets to your custom template using Excel 2013. You will also customize the text that is available in the Quick Text list.
First step
> 1. Prepare the files

Exit your NX session if it is running.
Locate the template files.
The following variable defines the location for work instruction template files: UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR. For a standard installation, this location is mach\resource\owi
This example shows the files necessary to customize the standard Tool List by Name template sheet supplied with NX. The other files in the work instructions template directory are omitted for clarity.
owi.dat
owi_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl
owi_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx
Copy the .tcl and .xlsx files shown and name the copies as follows:
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx
Save a copy of the owi.dat file as a backup.
In the owi.dat file, copy the following line and paste it at the bottom of the file.
Tool List by Name, ${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_excel.tpl
Edit the line to reference your new template sheet.
Custom Tool List by Name, ${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_excel.tpl
In this code:
Custom Tool List by Name is the name of the template sheet.
${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl references the TCL file associated with the Excel file that defines your template.
${UGII_CAM_WORK_INSTRUCTION_DIR}owi_excel.tpl references the TCL file required to process the templates. All the standard templates reference the same file. You can customize this file also, but it is not necessary.
Next step
> 2. Modify the template

Open the owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx file in Excel.
Create two merged cells large enough to add your new drawings.
In the example shown, each drawing is in a merged cell that is 17 rows tall and 8 columns wide.
In the two merged cells, enter OWI_DWG_3 and OWI_DWG_4.
These commands insert the third and fourth drawings. Each instance requires a unique identifier, and you must number them consecutively.
Copy the Path Image graphic to the merged cells.
Save the Excel file but do not close it.
Final step
> 3. Publish the template

Choose File→Save As and select the template file location.
In the Save As dialog box, from the Save as type list, select Web Page.
Select Republish Sheet.
Confirm that the Save As file location is still correct.
Choose Tools→Web Options.
In the Web Options dialog box, on the Encoding tab, from the Save this document as list, select Unicode (UTF-8).
Click OK.
Click Save.
In the Publish as Web Page dialog box, in the File name box, confirm that the file location is still correct and change the file name to owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.htm.
Click Publish.
NX creates the template .htm file and a folder for template specific files.
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name_files
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.htm
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.tcl
owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.xlsx
Review the owi_custom_template_tool_list_by_name.htm file to confirm that your template is OK.
If not, make your corrections and republish the spreadsheet.
Save and close the Excel file.
In the work instructions template folder, modify the owi_quicktext.txt file.
Delete the standard text and replace it with the frequently referenced text used at your company. Each line in the file is an entry in the Quick Text for the templates that use the OWI_TEXT_1.
The updated text will be available in the Author Work Instructions and Documentation dialog boxes, in the Quick Text list.
Start NX and check your customized sheet format in the Author Work Instructions or Documentation dialog box.
If there are issues with your template, exit your NX session before correcting the Excel file and republishing the template.

Document Title: Work instructions in Teamcenter Integration for NX
Document Body:
When you publish work instructions, Teamcenter manages the PDF and HTML file names for you. When you save the part file, NX displays the PDF file that you generated in the Import ME Datasets for Part dialog box.
Teamcenter displays the imported .pdf file in the hierarchy of the program or operation where you added the work instruction sheets. The following example shows the work instructions created for a cavity milling operation.
000123/A
CAVITY_MILLING
WorkInstructionsPdf

Use the Shop Documentation command to create a report of machining operations. The report is output in text or HTML format, and can be used by machine operators, tool crib workers, and others who need specific information about the NC program.
You can create the report from any of the four Operation Navigator views: Program Order View, Machine Tool View, Geometry View, or Machining Method View. You can also customize the information that you want to see. To create the report, you can either select individual object nodes in the Operation Navigator, or you can select the highest level group node to select a set of objects. The information is extracted from the displayed view, and can include:
Part geometry and material
Control geometry
Machining parameters
Control parameters
Machining sequencing
Machine tool setup
Machine tool control events
Post commands
Tool parameters
Tool path information
Note:
Each time you create Shop Documentation , NX generates facet bodies. To reduce the size of your part file, delete the facet bodies before saving it.
File size
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
You must be in a Milling, Turning, Drilling, Holemaking or Wire EDM operations.
Commands
Create shop documentation:
Shop Documentation
Delete facet bodies:
Faceting

You can output the shop documentation using the customized template.
Tip:
Remember, you must close any currently open output windows before generating another output.
To print images with a white background, set the background color before you output the shop documentation.
Menu→Preferences→Background
In the Program Order View in the Operation Navigator, select the program to output.
Program
CAVITY_MILL
Choose Operations tab→More→Shop Documentation.
The contents of the Report Format list may vary, depending on how your templates were customized.
From the Report Format list, select Operation List Select (HTML/Excel) or select the user interface text that you specified in the .dat file.
Click Browse for an Output File and specify a directory you can write to.
In the Shop Documentation dialog box, click OK.
The text and MOM variable changes you made to the customized template are reflected in the output, as shown in the example.
Note:
The HTML output is viewed in the default browser. To open the output in Excel, edit the shopdoc_excel.tcl file inside the excel_templates folder in UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR (typically …\MACH\resource\shop_doc\excel_templates) to define the location of your Excel executable. If you open the output in Excel, you should deactivate Display Output.
Program Sheet
Part name:
output_setup
Dwg name:
Housing Cover
Material:
HSM P20
Part number:
20042–1203
Machine:
3ax_sinumerik
Program type:
Mill
Pictures:
Description:
Index
Operation Name
Tool Name
Path Image
1
CAVITY_MILL
MILL20R3
Close the Information window.

When you print the .html output file from Excel, you must make the Page Break Preview area coincide with the page break markers. The Page Break Preview area determines the content of each sheet of paper.
In the Excel .html output file, click the View tab.
On the Workbook Views toolbar, click Page Break Preview .
In the Welcome to Page Break Preview messsage box, if it is displayed, click OK.
Drag the dashed blue lines to define the contents of the page.
The page should be defined by solid blue lines.
Choose Print, and in the Print dialog box, click OK.
On the Workbook Views toolbar, click Normal.
Click Close to close the shop documentation output window.

Report Format
List box
Lists the default shop documentation template formats.
Operation List Select (HTML/Excel)
Operation List Select (TEXT)
Tool List Select (HTML/Excel)
Tool List Select (TEXT)
Output File
File Name
Displays the default output file name. The default name is based on the location and name of the part file.
You can edit the file name or browse to an existing output file to overwrite it with the new output.
Browse for an Output File
Lets you browse for an output file or type the name of the output file to be created.
Settings
Display Output
Opens the Information window for TEXT output or the browser window for HTML output. If you open the output in Excel, you should deactivate Display Output, otherwise the output is displayed in both an Excel and browser window.
Review Tool
Determines whether the NX Post Debug lister window is opened after output is complete.
Selecting On opens the debug tool.
Selecting Off does not open the debug tool.

You can generate a shop documentation report as an HTML or a text file.
HTML
Use the HTML format when you want to display graphics and use links to lead you to more detail within the operation. You can view the HTML document in a browser or post it on the internet to share it with others.
The HTML report is displayed in Microsoft Excel™ if the path to Excel is set in your shopdoc_excel.tcl file. If the path is not set or if you do not have Excel on your computer, the HTML report is displayed in your web browser.
The Excel files used to create the HTML/Excel templates are stored in the MACH/resource/shop_doc/excel_templates folder. You can customize the Excel file to create new templates. Each Excel file has two sheets. The second sheet contains MOM variables and descriptions that you can copy and paste into the appropriate cells in the first sheet. This enables you to edit the templates even if you are not familiar with MOM.
Text (ASCII)
Use the text format when you want to print the document and distribute paper copies. Graphics are not included in the text report.
You can customize a Text templates in TCL.

Pre-NX 8 templates are not visible in the NX because you can use the default templates to create a report of machining operations from any of the four Operation Navigator views. Pre-NX 8 templates generate reports only for a single view. If you want to use pre NX 8 templates, remove the comment sign (#) in the shop_doc.dat file . The file is located in MACH\resource\shop_doc.
Default Templates
Description
Operation List Select (HTML/Excel)
Produces a report on the operations. The results are output in a table which you can display in Microsoft Excel™ or web browsers. You can customize this template in Excel.
Operation List Select (TEXT)
Produces a report on the operations. You can customize this template in TCL.
Tool List Select (HTML/Excel)
Produces a report on the tools. The results are output in a table which you can display in Microsoft Excel™ or web browsers. You can customize this template in Excel.
Tool List Select (TEXT)
Produces a report on the tools. You can customize this template in TCL.
Pre NX 8 Templates
Description
Operations List
Produces a report for each program in the Program Order View of the Operation Navigator. The report lists operation names, descriptions of the operations, and the names of the tools used in each operation. You can generate the report in either text or HTML format. This report can help a machinist prepare the job.
Tool List
Produces a report of the tools that were imported into the NC program from the tool library and that are visible in the Machine Tool View of the Operation Navigator. The report includes the data within each tool. You can generate the report in either text or HTML format. This report helps the NC Programmer identify the tools that are available for an NC Program.
Note:
Some of the listed tools may not be used in operations.
Operation List by Method
Produces a report on the operations as they appear in the Machine Method View of the Operation Navigator. The report lists the operations in sequence. You can generate the report in either a text or HTML format. This report can be used for reviewing your NC program.
Unique Tool List by Program
Produces a report only on the tools that are used to machine the part in each program. These tools and their data are listed in the order that they are used. Each tool is listed only once, even if it is used in more than one operation in a program. Tools that are not used in machining the part are not listed.
You can generate the report in either text or HTML format. This report can be useful for machinists and tool crib personal to prepare the needed tools for setup.
Advanced Operations List
Produces a report that is similar to the report produced by the Operations List template, except that a graphical image of each operation is added. You can generate the report in HTML format only.
Note:
Before you select Advanced Operations List, be sure to size the graphic window and orient the part so that it is not obstructed by the Operation Navigator or anything else in the window.
Tools and Operations
Produces a report that lists the tools in the part file, and the operations in which each tool was used in the actual NC program. You can generate the report in HTML format only. This report can help a machinist get a better understanding of knowing what tool is associated with what operation.
Advanced Web Page
Produces a report that can be used as a setup sheet that provides images of each tool path, and a page of parameters for each tool. The setup sheet takes information from all of the views of the Operation Navigator. The report can be output in HTML format only. This is a sample of a framed web page that can be used as the basis for customization. You may want the output to go to a separate folder, since many files may be created. You need to open the created file in your local web browser to view the output. This web page provides details for the machinist about how a job can be prepared.
Note:
Before running the Advanced Web Page option, be sure to size the graphic window and orient the part so that the graphic is not obstructed by the Operation Navigator or anything else in the window.
Advanced Web Page Mill Turn
Produces a report similar to the Advanced Web Page, plus it includes additional tool parameters for Turning tools. This report can help a machinist prepare the job.
Export Tool Library to ASCII datafile
Use to create an ASCII tool library file containing all the tools in the part. If you were previously using part files as your tool libraries, this option will help you convert your library to a text file. This file can be used as a library, or the content can be pasted into an existing tool library file. The location of the library file that is created is determined by the template, and is displayed in the listing device. Further instructions are represented in the Listing dialog.
Note:
The Export Tool Library to ASCII datafile functionality was written as a converter for pre-V16 tools. We do not maintain it for later releases. Therefore, parameters added in later releases are not supported by the datafile. For example, the 'Size' (IC) parameter was introduced in V18 and ASCII export does not supported it.

Document Title: Customize the Shop Documentation template data file
Document Body:
You can customize how the list of the shop documentation templates appear in the Shop Documentation dialog box. You can remove, reorder, or add to this list of templates.
The shop_doc.dat is a resource file that controls the list of available shop documentation templates located in the Report Format list on the Shop Documentation dialog box. This file organizes the formats into the order in which they appear in the Report Format list and controls the look of the report output.
Below is an example of what the contents in the shop_doc.dat file looks like:
Operation List Select (HTML/Excel), ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_template_English_operation_list_select.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_excel.tpl Operation List Select (TEXT), ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}shopdoc_oper_list_text.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_excel.tpl
Tool List Select (HTML/Excel), ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_template_English_tool_list_select.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_excel.tpl Tool List Select (TEXT), ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}shopdoc_tool_list_text.tcl, ${UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR}excel_templates\shopdoc_excel.tpl
In the template list, the “#” in front of the old templates indicate that they have been commented out and do not appear in the UI.
# - Other excel templates -

Making Changes To The File
If you rearrange, add, delete, or comment out items from this file, it will change the display order in the Report Format list on the Shop Documentation dialog box. For example, if the Tool List (HTML) preformatted template  is never used by your company, just delete it or comment it out from this list in the shop_doc.dat file and it no will longer appear in the Report Format list on the Shop Documentation dialog box dialog.
For each pre-formatted template in the shop_doc.dat, two files are specified: the Template File, and the Event Handler. The Template file can be identified by the extension .tpl and the Event Handler can be identified by the extension .tcl. All of these Template files and Event Handler files as well as the shop_doc.dat files must be located in the shop_doc_folder or contain complete file paths. The following are some suggestions for customization:
To make small changes to an existing format, you can edit the existing Template file.
For larger changes you can make a copy of the Event Handler and Template file and add a new entry to the .dat file. Then make a change to the copies.
Note:
WARNING: Prior to the first time you customize any files make a copy of the entire shop_doc folder and give it a different name. All customizing changes should be made in this new folder. Otherwise, when a new version of NX is loaded, it overrides all your customized changes. Update the environment variable in the ugii environment file to point to your new folder.
Configuration File
To customize the available formats in the Shop Documentation scroll bar, make all your changes in shop_doc.dat file.
Warning:
WARNING: Remember, if you are making any changes in the dialog it is easiest to keep all the Template and Event Handler files in the shop_doc folder. If you do not do this, you will receive an error and your customizations will not work.

The Template file defines the content and the format of a document. That is, it defines what information is in your Shop Documentation and what it looks like according to your customization.  
Note:
The Template file is where we recommend you do most of your customization changes. This is because less complex programming needed to customize a format in the Template file and yet it still leads to productive results.
The Template file contains only comments, literals, and commands. They are explained further below.
Comments
Literals
Commands

Comments are used by the people reading or writing the customized files. They are used to add readability and description to the template file, but are not output to Shop Documentation. They help you remember later why you wrote it the way you did. Comments are preceded by # as seen below.
# This Template File generates # a Setup Summary Sheet. #==================================

Literals are used to output text to the documentation. Literals can contain literal text and mom variables. MOM variables are Tcl variables, and begin with a $. If you want something to appear exactly as entered, use a literal. One example would be a title of a chart. When used with MOM variables, this provides a fill in the blank functionality. The current part is $mom_part_name or

The current part is $mom_part_name

The Event Handler defines what action is to be taken for each event. The Event Handler allows for logic programming where you can redefine what actions take place for each event. The Event Handler provided in the standard NX installation provides generally accepted actions for most machining events and therefore does not usually need customization. We suggest that you do not customize in this file unless you require complex changes and you are experienced in Tcl.
Customization of Shop Documentation can be done completely in the Template file, or it can be done in both the Template file and the Event Handler. But Customization cannot be done completely in the Event Handler.
Unlike the Template file, the Event Handler contains only valid Tcl commands. These can be standard Tcl commands or MOM extensions to Tcl. The Event Handler gives additional support to the Template file when there is a large amount of logic involved in the document. If your customization requires a large amount of detailed instructions, and you are experienced in Tcl, the customization can be done in the Event Handler. This way the Template File does not become too difficult to read with too many detailed instructions.
For more information on the MOM extensions to Tcl see Commands.

Commands tell the system to take an action. When you use Tcl commands you must enclose them in brackets [...]. These commands can be standard Tcl, or MOM extensions. MOM extension commands all begin with MOM_. The three main MOM extension commands are: MOM_cycle_object, MOM_list_oper_path, and MOM_do_template_file.
MOM_cycle_object
This is the most essential MOM command. Click the link to learn more about it.
MOM_list_oper_path <operation_name> <event_handler> <definition_file> <output_file>
This command lists the tool path of an operation. It allows you to customize how the tool paths are listed.
This command allows you to postprocess an operation using an existing postprocessor (Tcl and Def file). You can use it to include the actual machine code in the output, or to capture the output of user defined events. If the output file is not specified, the system uses the output file.
Here is an example of its use to list a path in the CLSF format:
set list_tcl [MOM_ask_env_var UGII_CAM_TOOL_PATH_DIR]clsf.tcl
set list_def [MOM_ask_env_var UGII_CAM_TOOL_PATH_DIR]clsf.def
MOM_list_oper_path $mom_operation_name $list_tcl $list_def 
  MOM_do_template_file <template_file>
This command reads and evaluates a template file.
Note:
If you use HDRF='filename', BDYF='filename', or FTRF='filename' then MOM_do_template_file is invoked automatically with filename as its argument.
List of MOM Commands There are many other MOM commands that work for Shopdocs. Click the link to view the list.

MOM_cycle_objects [command string]
This command cycles through the currently active part file in an NX session to extract information about certain objects. The command_string specifies the objects search and specifies what to do with the information extracted. The object is always the first word in the command_string.
MOM_cycle_objects
MOM_cycle_objects is used to systematically search through the CAM objects in the setup. The objects can be cycled in any of the four views.
Object Retrieval
Based on the specified object type, MOM_cycle_objects loads all the parameters and attributes that belong to each object in a class.
Object Selection
The retrieved contents of each object may be subject to a selection process specified by a query expression. Only the object containing a parameter(s) or an attribute(s) that satisfies the query criteria is passed onto the next step.
Data Enhancement
In addition to the default contents, the information of each object may be enhanced by deriving new data from the existing one based on the specified instruction (Header Body Footer).
Presentation
This is the end result of all of the format choices you have made.  The information is generally divided into header, body and footer. The header section contains the introductory statements regarding a particular class of objects. The body section contains the detailed description of each individual object. And the footer section presents the ending statements about this class of interest.
Syntax of MOM_cycle_objects
Object Retrieval is conducted based on the specified object type. Object Selection, Data Enhancement, and Presentation is performed based on a list of keywords. The syntax of the command is shown in the following section.
When you expand the command string and cycle multiple objects you receive a command format that is displayed below:
MOM_cycle_objects 
   {object_type keyword=string keyword=string  
       {object_type keyword=string keyword=string  
           {object_type keyword=string keyword=string  
                {...
                }
           }
       }
   }
Object Types
The system defines object types for the setup, for each view, and for most of the objects that the system can encounter while cycling. In general, the system starts cycling at the setup level and then proceeds to one of the four views. From there it cycles for specific object types or for MEMBERS, depending on the command string.  
Although the system cycles all objects, it can only use these object types in the command:
SETUP
PROGRAMVIEW
GEOMVIEW
METHODVIEW
MACHVIEW
MEMBERS
OPER
TOOL
If you use MEMBERS all objects at the current level are cycled regardless of their type. For example, if the object is a group, then its members are cycled. When all the members of the group have been cycled, then each member within each member of the group is cycled. The system continues cycling until all the objects are cycled.
When you use members, since any object type can be found, use the special tcl procedures for each object, as shown in the MOM_cycle_objects procedures chart.  
For more information, please read more about object types.
Keywords
Default Header, Body and Footer Procedures
During the execution of MOM_cycle_objects, the following event handlers (Tcl procedures), if supplied, are triggered automatically for each object type to present the header, body and footer descriptions:
proc MOM_objectType_HDR (Header)
proc MOM_objectType_BODY (Body)
proc MOM_objectType_FTR (Footer)
The object type can be any of those found in mom_rm_names.c. You have to supply all the necessary event handlers for the object types being interrogated.
These default headers, bodies and footers, if present, are executed before the ones specified by using the keywords (HDRT, BDYT and FTRT) discussed in the Keywords section.
Note:
The Unused Items group is a special system group and is not cycled like other MEMBERS.
Object Hierarchy
The hierarchy of the CAM objects dictates the types of sub-objects that are interrogated under certain object types. This hierarchy is best seen by looking in the Operation Navigator.
We see in the Operation Navigator that in a given SETUP there are four views: Program Order View, Machine Tool View, Geometry View, and Machining Method View, which correspond to views organized by the Program, Method, Geometry and Machine Tools respectively. In each view there are a variety of object types that may appear. For example, in Machine Tool View we have a Machine Tool. Under Machine Tool are Cutting Tools, and under Cutting tools are the operations.
Operation Navigator ->Machine Tool View or the Tool View Icon
Use the Operation Navigator to view the hierarchy and its various creation dialogs to determine exactly which object types can appear in a view and how those object types may be arranged with respect to each other.
Tables
A common format for Shop Documentation is tables. Tables within the documentation are defined in three sections: header, body, and footer. The header and footer are usually constant titles for the tables and therefore you can use literals. The body includes the variable data in the table. Because the data changes in this case, you can use the Tcl commands.

With each object type you can use optional keywords. Each keyword is assigned a string. Multiple keywords should be separated with a space.
The chart below lists the valid keywords:
QRY
This defines a query to limit the scope of selected objects.
INST
This defines special instructions for the object that is being cycled.
HDRT
Text output when cycling of this object type starts.
BDYT
Text output for each object cycled.
FTRT
Text output when cycling of this object type ends.
HDRF
File containing output when cycling of this object type starts.
BDYF
File containing output for each object cycled.
FTRF
File output when cycling of this object type ends.
When objects are cycled, output can be controlled in three ways.
Header, Body and Footer text (HDRT, BDYT, FTRT).
Header, Body and Footer text from an external file (HDRF, BDYF, FTRF).
Object Header Body and Footer procedures in the Event Handler.
The first two options (which use HDRT, BDYT, FTRT, HDRF, BDYF, FTRF) are available for each object that is encountered while cycling.
For the third option only certain procedures are called, depending on what object you have encountered while cycling. These procedures are named MOM_<object_type>_HDR, MOM_<object_type>_BODY and MOM_<object_type>_FTR.
The HDR and FTR procedures are called if the object type is in the command. The BODY procedure is called for every object that is encountered. For example, if you cycle MEMBERS, MOM_MEMBERS_HDR is called for the beginning of the first member. Then MOM_OPER_BODY is called for each OPER encountered, and MOM_MEMBERS_FTR is called at the end of the last member.
If you cycle OPERs, then MOM_OPER_HDR is called for the first OPER, MOM_OPER_BODY is called for each OPER, and MOM_OPER_FTR is called after the last OPER.
For more information see Header, Body, Footer.
For information on all the available special procedures see MOM_cycle_objects procedure chart.

This is an example of cycling objects in this Program View.
This is the command to cycle all the tools that are attached to operations in the Program View and display their names:  
[MOM_cycle_objects 
   {SETUP
     {PROGRAMVIEW 
      HDRT='----- Start of Tools -------'
      FTRT='------ End of Tools --------'
        {MEMBERS
           {TOOL
            BDYT='Name = $mom_tool_name'
           }
         }
      }
   }
]
Use this command to cycle objects in the Program View shown below.
This example outputs this list of events.
This example produces this output:
----- Start of Tools -------
Name = UGTI0202_025
Name = UGTI0201_013
Name = UGTI0203_016
Name = UGTI0203_018
------ End of Tools --------

The first argument of the MOM_cycle_objects command is the object type. The object type specifies what type of objects are to be interrogated. Some examples of object types are listed below:
SETUP
PROGRAMVIEW
METHODVIEW
GEOMVIEW
MACHVIEW
OPER
TOOL
MEMBERS
Objects reside in different classes within the hierarchy and are interrogated in a nested fashion as shown below:
{ ... {objectType1 {objectType2} ... }.
ObjectType2 is nested in objectType1.
{SETUP {MACHVIEW {TOOL}}}
TOOL is nested in MACHVIEW, which is nested in SETUP.
This command asks for all the TOOLs in the MACHVIEW (Tool View) of the SETUP, whether they are used by an operation or not.
The use of MEMBERS allows for general, flexible MOM_cycle_objects arguments that can handle a variety of NX data hierarchies. Nest MEMBERS inside an object type to see all the members that belong to that object type, as shown below:
{SETUP {PROGRAMVIEW {MEMBERS}}}
This command asks for all the members that belong to PROGRAMVIEW.
The meaning of MEMBERS depends on the object type, as shown below.
{SETUP {PROGRAMVIEW {MEMBERS {OPER {TOOL}}}}}
The SETUP is comprised of many programs. If MEMBERS appears in the MOM_cycle_objects argument, the command cycles through each individual program searching for all the MEMBERS within each program. In this case MEMBERS includes:
Groups of operations within the programs
Each individual operation within the groups of operations
The tools within each operation
In this example, when the software searches for MEMBERS, it:
Searches for all program groups that are under the PROGRAMVIEW root.
Searches for any OPERs that are contained in each program group.
Searches for all the tools in the operations.
In any view, when OPERs are cycled, the TOOL used by the OPER can be cycled. If MEMBERS are cycled, and the member is an operation, the tool is cycled. If the member is not an OPER, no tool is available, and the cycling continues as shown below.
[ MOM_cycle_objects { SETUP { PROGRAMVIEW { MEMBERS { TOOL } } } } ]
This example cycles all the members in the program view, looking for tools.

The expression specified in the QRY (query) key word is used to impose further constraints to the objects selection. A QRY expression may contain multiple relational expressions combined with logical operators. The syntax is as follows:
QRY='relational_exp logical_oprelational_exp . . .'
The logical operator (logical_op) can be either && (logical-AND) or || (logical-OR).
Each relational expression (relational_exp) is defined below:
[source_operand] relational_op[target_operand]
 The available relational operators (relational_op) are listed below:
Operator
Definition
>
greater
>=
greater or equal
<
less
<=
less or equal
==
equal
!=
not equal
&=
string equal
&!
string not equal
The source_operand is an expression containing Tcl variable(s). Both source_operand and target_operand should be enclosed in a pair of square brackets [...]. When a string comparison (&= or &!) is performed, the target_operand should follow the syntax of the Regular Expressions in Tcl.
The following example extracts the information about a list of tools with names starting with T and diameter greater than 0.5:
[MOM_cycle_objects 
       {TOOL
        QRY='[$mom_tool_name] &= [^T.*$] &&[$mom_tool_diameter] > [0.5]'        } ]
Only the retrieved parameters and attributes that belong to the default contents of an object may be subject to the query examination. The enhanced data such as tool path Max/Min box or Start and End positions may not be used in the query expression.
Note:
The MOM variables containing the retrieve parameters and attributes for each object can be viewed using the Review Tool.

INST (instruction) specifies special actions the system performs on each object. The instructions generally produce additional information from the existing default contents of an object. Enhanced information, such as an image file of the geometry or the machining time of a tool path, may also be presented in a document.
The following instructions have been implemented for different object types in CAM:
Object Type
Instruction
Definition
SETUP
PART_GIF
PART_GIF  generates an image file, in .gif format, of the part geometry of the setup. The variable $mom_setup_part_gif_file contains the name of the .gif file
OPER
PATH_GIF
GEOM_GIF
PATH_GIF generates an image file of the operation's tool path. This instruction causes an existing tool path to be replayed automatically. The variable $mom_operation_path_gif_file contains the name of the file.
GEOM_GIF generates an image file of the geometry used in an operation. The variable $mom_operation_geometry_gif_file contains the name of the file.
Note:
When using GEOM_GIF the system captures the images without refreshing the display. When using PATH_GIF the system refreshes the display and the replays the tool path before capturing the image. Therefore, if you are using both instructions, use the GEOM_GIF instruction first.
The following example extracts the information about the operations and generates a .gif file for each tool path:
[MOM_cycle_objects {OPER INST='PATH_GIF' }]
You can specify that multiple instruction tokens serve the same object type in an INST expression to perform various actions while cycling through a class of objects. Separate tokens with spaces or commas.

The presentation format for the object class information can be described in terms of Header, Body, and Footer. When the classes of objects in different hierarchy are interrogated recursively, the presentation of the data can be illustrated as follows:
MOM_cycle_objects command uses six keywords to accomplish this task of presenting the data:
HDRT HDRF (header)
BDYT BDYF (body)
FTRT FTRF (footer)
Here are some examples of how headers, bodies and footers are used. Note that we do not have SETUP body processors because a part has exactly one SETUP. Body processors are called for each object of the specified object type. If there is only one object of this type, you can either put the processor in the Header or Footer.
 [MOM_cycle_objects
      {SETUP HDRT='Setup for Part $mom_part_name' FTRT='End of Documentation for $mom_date'
           {OPER HDRT='These Operations are contained in this Setup'                 BDYT='Operation: $mom_oper_name'                 FTRT='End of Operations'
            }
      }
 ]
  In this case when MOM_cycle_objects executes, the following is executed automatically:
The variable $mom_part_name is translated, inserted into the HDRT for SETUP and then the HDRT for SETUP is printed.
The OPER's HDRT is printed.
For each operation in the Setup do
If the Tcl script contains a procedure named MOM_OPER_BODY then execute it.
Translate $mom_oper_name, insert into the OPER's BDYT and then print the OPER's BDYT.
Print the OPER's FTRT.
Translate $mom_date, insert into SETUP's FTRT and print the SETUP's FTRT.
Note that for Body processing the Tcl procedure, if it exists, is executed first followed by the BDYT or BDYF. Of course, you do not need a BDYF or BDYT. If you do not have an object type Body procedure or a BDYT or BDYF for that object then there is no output generated for that object type. This could be useful if you want all the TOOLs in a SETUP in the order in which they are used but did not want to see the operations in which they are used. If this were the case you could use something like the following and have an empty MOM_OPER_BODY Tcl procedure.
[MOM_cycle_objects
{SETUP 
  {OPER 
     {TOOL 
       HDRT='Tool Heading'
       BDYT='Tool Name: $mom_tool_name'
      }
   }
 }
]
 For an example of using MEMBERS consider the following:
 [MOM_cycle_objects
  {SETUP
    HDRT='CAM Part Dump for $mom_part_name
       {MEMBERS
         HDRT='This part contains the following:'
         BDYT='Object: $obj_type, $obj_type_name, $obj_name'
       }
   }
]
In this case when MOM_cycle_objects is executed the following is executed automatically:
Translate mom_part_name, insert into SETUP's HDRT and print the HDRT.
For the SETUP object:
Print the MEMBERS HDRT.
Get all the corresponding BODY that belongs to the MEMBER and for each of these objects:
Perform the Tcl procedure for the object type of this object.
Translate the variables obj_type, obj_type_name and obj_name, insert them into the MEMBERS BDYT and print the MEMBERS BDYT.
Let OBJECT be the current object and repeat all the steps within step 2.
Note:
Note that in step 2, if the current object is of type OPER then the Tcl procedure MOM_OPER_BODY is executed. If it is of type TOOL then MOM_TOOL_BODY is executed. These procedures exist in the Tcl script whose name is supplied in the CAM configuration file.
Note:
Since the Tcl procedure is executed first, you can define variables in the Tcl procedure and then use them in the BDYT text.
