MOM_Part_Documentation
This procedure is executed implicitly, and the Template file is not executed. This procedure by passes the normal shop documentation process, and passes complete control to your Tcl program. This is for advanced programmers only.

You can use text literals to describe the header, body or footer. The text can contain literals, variables and Tcl commands. The following is an example of how this is done:
 [MOM_cycle_objects {OPER HDRT='Operation List'   HDRT='**************'   HDRT=' '   HDRT='---------------------------------------'   BDYT='Operation: $mom_operation_name $mom_operation_type' FTRT='---------------------------------------'       {TOOL       BDYT=' Tool:  $mom_tool_name'       BDYT=' Diameter: $mom_tool_diameter'       BDYT=' Length: $mom_tool_length' FTRT=' '   }   } ] 
Result
For an NX part containing two CAM Operations, the result is as follows:
Operation List **************
-------------------------------------
Operation: p1 Rough Pocket
  Tool: T1   Diameter: 2.0   Length: 6.0
Operation: p2 Finish Pocket   Tool: T2   Diameter: 1.0   Length: 4.0   ---------------------------------------
Using Text Files
You can also read the text from an external files as shown in this example.
 [MOM_cycle_objects {OPER HDRF='my_header.txt'   BDYT='Operation: $mom_operation_name $mom_operation_type' FTRT='---------------------------------------'      {TOOL       BDYF=' my_body.txt' FTRT=' '       }   } ]
  File my_header.txt
   Operation List ************** --------------------------------------
  File my_body.txt
  Tool:  $mom_tool_name Diameter: $mom_tool_diameter   Length: $mom_tool_length
The output is the same as the first example.

You can use Tcl commands and extended commands in place of the text literals as in the following excerpt from the example in the schematic:
BDYT='[format "%-6s %-13s %-5s" $mom_operation_name $mom_operation_type $mom_tool_name]'
Format is a Tcl command that formats the output according to the specification.
The following is an example of how you can mix the use of statements and commands:
[MOM_cycle_objects   {OPER   HDRT='Operation List'   HDRT='**************'   BDYF='oper_body.tpl'   } ]

Abort
Procedure Name
MOM_abort <message>
Description
This function causes MOM to write message to the syslog and then terminate by ERROR_raising().
Input
message
Example
MOM_abort "Error occurred. Postprocessing has been aborted."
Adding User Function To TCL  
Procedure Name
MOM_extend_translator shared_library_name entry_point_name
Description
This function allows MOM to be able to call the function named entry_point_name in the shared library named shared_library_name. That function can then extend the translator from which it was called. It will do this by calling a User Function function named UF_MOM_extend_translator(param, extension_name, extension_entry_point). The param will be passed into entry_point_name as the first argument. The signature of entry_point_name is the same as ufusr. The extension_name is the name of the function as it will appear in a Tcl script. The extension_entry_point is the actual address of the function to be called by the interpreter when interpreting the extension_name call.
Input
shared_library_name entry_point_name
Example
 MOM_run_user_function [MOM_ask_env_var UGII_CAM_AUXILIARY_DIR]ugp_adv_kins.dll ufusr
Ask Environment Variable
Procedure Name
MOM_ask_env_var <variable name>
Description
This extension allows you to determine how the environment variable "variable name" is set.
Input
variable name
Example
set path [MOM_ask_env_var UGII_CAM_POST_CONFIG_FILE]
Ask Event Type
Procedure Name
MOM_ask_event_type
Description
Returns the name of the current event. This is the last event that the event generator executed.
Input
None
Example
set event[MOM_ask_event_type]
Ask Expression Variable
Procedure Name
MOM_ask_ess_exp_value <variable_name>
Description
NX has an Expression module. This allows users to define variables and expressions and then use those variables as parameters for NX entities such as Modeling features.
This MOM function provides access to the variables of the NX Expression module, i.e., it returns the value of the NX Expression variable.
Input
variable name
Example
MOM_ask_ess_exp_value diameter
Ask Library Attributes
Procedure Name
MOM_ask_library_attributes <LIBRARY_KEY> <libref> <db_alias>+
Description
Retrieves attributes from the specified library. The library key is the entry in the CAM configuration file for the desired library. The db_alias can be found in the definition file for that library. The returned values are placed in the array $mom_lib_attr_value.
Input
library key, libref, db_alias(s)
Example
global mom_lib_attr_value mom_libref
MOM_ask_library_attributes LIBRARY_TOOL $mom_libref Type SubType
MOM_output_literal "Type = $mom_lib_attr_value(Type)"
MOM_output_literal "SubType = $mom_lib_attr_value(SubType)"
Ask Part Units
Procedure Name
MOM_ask_part_units
Description
This command sets the units of the current work part in a variable mom_part_units. The possible values for mom_part_units are "metric" or "english".
Input
None
Example
global mom_part_units MOM_ask_part_units set part_units $mom_part_units
Close Output File
Procedure Name
MOM_close_output_file <filename>
Description
This extension allows you to suspend writing output to a particular file until it is opened again.
Input
file name
Example
MOM_close_output_file $mom_output_doc_file2
DEBUG Mode
Procedure Name
MOM_set_debug_mode <ON | OFF>
Description
This will activate, deactivate, and resume the debugger. Like any TCL extension, this command may be called from any place in the TCL script.
If ON, the debugger will activate by initializing with data entered in the debugger dialog or stdout.
If OFF, the debugger will be deactivated.
Input
debug attribute
Example
MOM_set_debug_mode ON
MOM_set_debug_mode OFF
Delete File
Procedure Name
MOM_remove_file <file_name>
Description
This command deletes a file with the given name. The permissions on the file that is being asked to be removed should be compatible for removal.
Input
file name
Example
MOM_remove_file file_name
Do Template File
Procedure Name
MOM_do_template_file <template_file_name>
Description
This command opens the specified Shop Documentation template file and executes each line in the file accordingly.
Input
Template File Name
Example
 MOM_do_template_file tool_list.tpl
List User Defined Events
Procedure name
MOM_list_user_defined_events < Start/End > < operation_name > < Definition > <Event_handler> [<output>]
Description
This extension allows you to output/list Userdefined events defined in the operation.
Input
Start - String "Start" indicates list of start of operation Userdefined events
End -  String "End" indicates list of end of operation Userdefined events
Operation_name - Opearation name for which Userdefined events lists will be output
Definition - definitions file
                example :- The definition file should contain following data.
                                   MACHINE TEST
                                   FORMATTING
                                   {
                                   }
Event_handler - The event handler file. This file should contain
                "MOM_info_user_defined_event" procedure.
                example:- The MOM_info_user_defined_event procedure is defined as
                below.
                proc  MOM_info_user_defined_event {} {
                      global  mom_ude_command_string
                      MOM_output_literal  $mom_ude_command_string
                }
Output - The output file where Userdefined events will be  listed. Specification of this
         file is OPTOINAL. If NOT specified , the Userdefined events lists were output
         in mom output file (As defined in the Manufacturing part report dialog).
Example
         MOM_list_user_defined_events "Start" $mom_operation_name \
         "$mom_source_directory\\test_info.def" "$mom_source_directory\\test_info.tcl" \
         "c:\\Temp\\XYZ.txt"
Log Message
Procedure Name
MOM_log_message <message>
Description
This function causes MOM to write a message to the syslog.
Input
message
Example
MOM_log_message "Postprocessing Terminated"
Open Output File
Procedure Name
MOM_open_output_file <filename>
Description
This extension allows you to redirect output to other output files.
If the file "filename" does not exist, a new one will be created with that file name.
Input
file name
Example
MOM_open_output_file $mom_output_doc_file2
Output Literal
Procedure Name
MOM_output_literal "string" {BUFFER}
Description
This extension outputs a list of literals and variable as a single line. If BUFFER is present then only place "string" in the output buffer. Do not send it to the output yet.
Input
String
Example
MOM_output_literal "Start of path $mom_path_name"
 Output Text
Procedure Name
MOM_output_text <literal> {BUFFER}
Description
This extension outputs a list of literals and variables as a single line, just like MOM_output_literal, except that no sequence number is output.
If BUFFER is present then only place string in the output buffer. Do not send it to the output yet.
Input
String
Example
MOM_output_text "Start of path $mom_path_name"
Output To Listing Device
Procedure Name
MOM_output_to_listing_device <"string">
Description
If running in an interactive NX session, this extension outputs "string" to the listing window, otherwise it does nothing.
Input
string
Example
MOM_output_to_listing_device "Error occurred while postprocessing."
Restart Upon Return
Procedure Name
MOM_restart_upon_return
Description
Instructs the event generator to restart event generation immediately after the current event handler returns. Restarts at the first event of the post.
Input
None
Example
MOM_restart_upon_return
Run User Function
Procedure Name
MOM_run_user_function <shared_library_name> <entry_point_name>
Description
This function causes MOM to call the function named entry_point_name in the shared library named shared_library_name. That function can then extend the translator from which MOM_run_user_function was called. It will do this by calling a User Function function named UF_MOM_extend_translator( param, "extension_name", extension_entry_point ). The param will be passed into entry_point_name as the first argument. The signature of entry_point_name is the same as ufusr. The extension_name is the name of the function as it will appear in a TCL script. The extension_entry_point is the actual address of the function to be called by the interpreter when interpreting the extension_name call. (See Tcl_CmdProc.)
Input
shared_library_name - Full path name of the shared library where entry_point_name resides.
entry_point_name - Name of the entry point to execute.
Example
MOM_run_user_function /usr/local/shlib/lib.sl extendInterp
Source Tcl File
Procedure Name
MOM_source <filename>+
Description
Includes the specified tcl files at run time.
Input
filename(s)
Example
MOM_source my_header.tcl
MOM_dump {syslog|stdout}
MOM_ask_unique_filename

When customizing your own shop documentation you can specify the output file extension, such as txt or html. If you do not specify an extension, the system uses txt by default and no file extension is displayed in the dialog. Specify the extension in the Event Handler and Definition file.
To set your own file extension use the method below.
In the beginning of the Event Handler (.tcl), insert the following commands:
set mom_source_directory [MOM_ask_env_var UGII_CAM_SHOP_DOC_DIR]
source "$mom_source_directory/shopdoc_header.tcl"
 
#=============================================================================
proc MOM_Start_Part_Documentation {} {
#=============================================================================
    global mom_sys_output_file_suffix
    set mom_sys_output_file_suffix "txt"
    Open_Files
}
Change the file extension by modifying the line "set mom_sys_output_file_suffix" above. Change "txt" to the default extension of your choice.
In the beginning of the Template file (.tpl), insert the following command:
[MOM_Start_Part_Documentation]

MOM variables are dynamic, and change based on the operation. They may be added or changed with each release.
Note:
Some variables related directly to the tool path are available only during postprocessing, and are not available in Shop Documentation. If you need to use these, you should use the postprocessor to generate your shop documentation.
There are many variables available while a shop document is being generated. Different variables are available, depending on what objects are being cycled. For example, mom_tool_diameter is available for a milling tool, but would not be applicable for another object, such as a program or operation. The list on the second sheet of the spreadsheet is for reference only. You can use variable names there for copy and paste if they are applicable to your operation.
Attributes
The system assigns mom variables so that you can access attributes. These variables are named as shown in the table below where <name> represents the original attribute name.
Mom Variable
Event
Class
Description
mom_attr_PROGRAMVIEW_<name>
MOM_PROGRAM_BODY
Attribute
User defined program group attributes.
mom_attr_TOOL_<name>
MOM_TOOL_HDR
Attribute
User defined tool attributes.
mom_attr_OPER_<name>
MOM_MEMBERS_HDR
Attribute
User defined operation attributes.
mom_attr_PART_<name>
MOM_Part_Documentation
Attribute
User defined part attributes.
Review Tool
The best way to determine the available variables is to use the review tool. To activate the review tool, select On from the Review Tool list in the :Settings group of the Postprocess dialog box,
When you output a Shop Documentation, there is some delay, and then the review tool begins with three columns.
Column one displays all the events that were generated.
Choose an event in column one, and column two displays the variables set by that event.
Column three is used only for Post, and can be ignored.
Generating Shop documentation also produces a debug file which contains a list of all events generated and all the mom variables that were set by the events.  When you are finished debugging your Shop Document, simply comment out the above lines in the Tcl file.
When debug mode is on, an additional file <unique_name>_debug.out is generated, containing a log of all events that were generated, and all the mom variables that were set by the events. The following sample is a portion of the file, showing the variables set for a tool header event.

Shop documentation output is created from customizable templates. Microsoft Excel™ is used to customize the templates, making them easy to create and modify.
The tasks for this workflow are:
Edit and save the Excel (.xlsx) file under a new name.
Create a new .htm file that the system will use as a template.
Create a new .tcl file for the new template.
Edit the .dat file to determine what you see in the user interface and which .tcl file to use.
Create output using the customized template.
Note:
Template customization requires write access to files in the \MACH\resource\shop_doc\ and \MACH\resource\shop_doc\excel_templates\ directories.

Document Title: Open the shop documentation Excel file
Document Body:
Each template has three files associated with it: an .htm file, a .tcl file, and an .xlsx file. Companies often customize the content and names of these files. If you do not see the file mentioned in step two, open the Excel (.xlsx) file on which you will base your customized template.
Open an Explorer window and navigate to the \MACH\resource\shop_doc\excel_templates\ folder.
Open the shopdoc_template_English_operation_list_select.xlsx file.

You can make text edits and edit MOM variables. The mom_vars file contains many of the MOM variables that you can use to customize the template. Each variable has a description.
Edit the title. If the title in your template reads Program Sheet, type Die Program Sheet.
Filter column B for tools.
At the top of column B, select Class.
On the toolbar, select, Filter.
At the top of column B, click the button next to Class and clear the Select All check box.
Scroll down the Check Filter column and select the Tool check box.
Click OK.
Find the MOM variable for the tool diameter.
At the top of column A, select A .
On the toolbar, click Find .
In the Find and Replace window, type dia in the Find what field and click Find All.
In the Find and Replace window, in the Value column, select mom_tool_diameter .
This will highlight the MOM variable in column A.
Close the Find and Replace window.
Copy the text, mom_tool_diameter, from column A.
At the bottom of the spreadsheet, click the shopdoc_template_English tab.
The table for this template cycles MOM variables on operations. That is, one row is populated for each operation in the program.
In the table, replace mom_oper_tool by pasting mom_tool_diameter in its place .
Be sure to retain the brackets.
You will do one more simple text edit.
In the column heading, change Tool Name to Tool Dia.
You can also edit the following parameters in the Excel file:
PAGE CONTENT LENGTH
This parameter, determines the distance in inches or mm between the “Page : ${cur_page} of ${total_pages}” markers in the .html output. The value must be a positive real number.
REPEAT TITLE Yes/No
This parameter, lets you to repeat the title block on each page. The title block includes all content between ###BODY START### and the first ###TABLE START### markers.
You can paste graphic images such as a company logo anywhere in the file.
Note:
PART_GIF and PATH_GIF graphic tokens may be copied or deleted, but may not be edited.
You can output Part Attributes that were specified in NX using the (File tab→Properties→Attributes) command, by using the following format in the template: ${mom_attr_PART_title/alias}.
For example, suppose the following Title/Alias and Value options are specified in NX:
The following variable is used in the template: ${mom_attr_PART_PARTNUM} and the output will be: 20042–12.

Document Title: Rename and save the Excel file
Document Body:
You can save the Excel file under a new name to create a new .xlsx file.
Note:
The option names may be different in your Excel version, but you should be able to follow the steps.
In Excel, choose Save As.
Make sure that the Save in list is set to the excel_templates folder.
In the file name box, type my_template.
Make sure that the Save as type list is set to Excel Workbook (*.xlsx).
Click Save.

You can create an .htm file from the Excel file that you saved. The system uses the .htm file to generate output.
Note:
The option names may be different in your Excel version, but you should be able to follow the steps.
In Excel, choose Save As.
Make sure that the Save in list is set to the excel_templates folder.
Make sure that the File Name box shows my_template.xlsx.
From the Save as type list, select Web Page (*.htm; *html)
Next to Save:, select Republish: Sheet.
Be sure the Save in list is set to the excel_templates folder.
Click Save.
You have created two files and the system has created a folder to support the .htm file.

You need to create a tcl file that matches the same name as the .htm file. By using the same name, the .tcl file determines which .htm file to process when you select a Report Format in the Shop Documentation dialog box.
Copy shopdoc_template_English_operation_list_select.tcl (or the equivalent .tcl file to the .xlsx file you edited).
Rename the copy my_template.tcl.
You have created three files so far.
Here is a quick review of the files you created:
.xlsx (Excel) file containing your edits on sheet 1 and all available MOM variables on sheet 2. This is your working file.
.htm template the system uses to create the shop documentation output.
.tcl file that determines which .htm file to process when you select a Report Format in the Shop Documentation dialog box.

The shop_doc.dat file determines what you see in the NX Shop Documentation user interface, and specifies which .tcl file to use for the selected report format.
Open the \MACH\resource\shop_doc\ folder.
Locate the shop_doc.dat file and open it in a text editor.
Each line in the file corresponds to an existing template. The pound sign (#) indicates templates that are commented out and do not appear in the user interface.
Notice that line 1 references shopdoc_template_English_operation_list_select.tcl.
Copy all of the text in line 1 (or the line that corresponds to the .xlsx file you initially edited) and paste it as a new line at the bottom of the list.
The user interface text appears before the first comma.
Replace the existing user interface text with what you wish to see in the Report Format list of the Shop Documentation dialog box.
Scroll to the right and find the reference to the .tcl file.
Replace this name with the name of the .tcl file that you just created.
Save and close the shop_doc.dat file.

Native NX has ASCII-based databases for cutting tools, holders, machine tools, and feeds and speeds data. You can use the example data provided as a basis for building your own databases.
In Teamcenter manufacturing process management, Resource Manager is used by NC programmers, process planners, and tool designers on a daily basis to store, modify, and retrieve information about the resources they use in their respective processes. Refer to the Teamcenter documentation, under Managing Manufacturing Data, for more information.
Access to libraries from within NX is the same for native NX or Teamcenter Integration for NX. You can:
Store and classify tool, device, machine, and feeds and speeds data for the Manufacturing application.
Base a custom data structure and data on the existing structures and data.
Retrieve data into NX parts and CAM operations.
Export tools and holders to a native NX database.
The libraries allow access to the following types of information:
Cutting tools
Tool holders
Machine devices
Machine tools
Machining data
You can use the libraries as provided, or you can add or modify data and data structures to meet your needs.

Document Title: Updating library resources based on the revision rule
Document Body:
Use the Update Resource Revisions command to update library tools, machines, and devices based on the selected revision rule. NX does the following:
Retrieves the required revision of each object from the Teamcenter database.
Updates the objects, including their library references, in the Operation Navigator.
Changes the status of any affected operations to Regenerate .
Example:
Revision Rule = Latest Working
NX tool current version = MILL_1010_101/A
Teamcenter tool latest version = MILL_1010_101/B

MILL_1010_101_A
FLOOR_WALL
   MILL_1010_101_B
FLOOR_WALL
Operation Navigator, Machine Tool view
Note:
When running the update, NX supports the separator character between item and item revision that is configured in the Teamcenter preference FLColumnCatIVFSeparatorPref.
Library search results
NX can also filter library search results to show only the tools, machines, and devices that match a selected revision rule. Use the Filter Search Result Revisions customer default.
Example:
Revision Rule = Latest Working
Libref
Libref
mill_1010_101/A
mill_1010_101/B
mill_1010_101/B
Filter Search Result Revisions
Filter Search Result Revisions
Tip:
To find a customer default, choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults, and click Find Default .
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
You must run Teamcenter Integration for NX.
Command
Assembly Load Options , Update Resource Revisions

Each library has a definition file that is divided into two parts, a set of data field and alias definitions that defines attributes that appear in the Search Criteria and Search Result dialog boxes, and a class hierarchy that controls the appearance of the Library Class Selection dialog box.
When you change a definition file, you must save the file and restart NX to see the effect of your changes in the dialog boxes.
Each library has it’s own definition file in the folder structure defined by UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR.
Library in
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR
Native NX definition file
Teamcenter definition file
Tools
tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii.def
tool\inclass\dbc_inclass_tlas.def
Holders
tool\ascii\dbc_holder_ascii.def
Use the native NX file
Devices
device\ascii\dbc_device_ascii.def
device\inclass\dbc_inclass_device.def
Machines
machine\ascii\dbc_machine_ascii.def
machine\inclass\dbc_inclass_mach.def
Feeds and Speeds
feeds_speeds\ascii\feeds_speeds.def
Use the native NX file
Part Materials
feeds_speeds\ascii\part_materials.def
Use the native NX file
Tool Materials
feeds_speeds\ascii\tool_materials.def
Use the native NX file
Cut Methods
feeds_speeds\ascii\cut_methods.def
Use the native NX file

Each attribute in a database has a unique name. Attributes are referenced in the definition file and Tcl scripts by a unique alias. For example, scripts can search for attributes only by their unique alias.
Alias keywords
Keyword
Usage
DB_ALIAS <alias>
This statement begins each attribute definition. The word following the DB_ALIAS keyword is the alias for the attribute. It is case sensitive, and it must be unique in the database.
DB_ID <attribute name>
The word following the DB_ID keyword is the unique attribute name that appears in FORMAT statements in the database.
DB_ID_TYPE <type identifier>
Valid type identifiers include:
d
A floating point decimal number
i
An integer
s
A text string
OPTIONS
An optional keyword that you can use to provide a list of valid values. This list appears in the Search Criteria dialog box using the same text or values that you provide.
OPTIONS_IDS
This keyword must appear if the OPTIONS keyword is used, but not without it. In the column for the attribute DB_ID, provide a list of values to appear in DATA statements in the database, . The list must be ordered the same as the corresponding list after the OPTIONS keyword.
DIALOG_NAME “<title>”
The title that you provide appears in the Search Criteria dialog box.
RSET_NAME “<title>”
The title that you provide appears in the Search Result dialog box.
#
The # symbol denotes a comment line. Do not use comments inside the DB_ALIAS alias { } structure. You can use comments before a definition structure to explain its purpose.
Note:
In Teamcenter engineering process management, all DB_ALIAS entries must correspond to attribute parameters that are defined in Teamcenter engineering process management.
Examples
To define the attribute for cutter flute direction, with the column title FD in FORMAT statements in the tool_database.dat files, and the alias FluteDirection, we use this code format:
        DB_ALIAS  FluteDirection
        {
           DB_ID       FD 
           DB_ID_TYPE   s
           OPTIONS     "right" "left"
           OPTIONS_IDS "R" "L"
           DIALOG_NAME "Flute Direction"
           RSET_NAME   "Flute Direction"
        }
To define the attribute for cutter flute length, with the column title FLEN in FORMAT statements in the tool_database.dat files, and the alias FluteLength, we use this code format:
        DB_ALIAS  FluteLength
        {
           DB_ID       FLEN 
           DB_ID_TYPE   d
           DIALOG_NAME "(FL) Flute Length"
           RSET_NAME "(FL) Flute Length"
        }
To define the attribute for the number of cutter flutes, with the column title FN in FORMAT statements in the tool_database.dat files, and the alias NumberOfFlutes, we use this code format:
        DB_ALIAS  NumberOfFlutes
        {
           DB_ID       FN 
           DB_ID_TYPE   i
           DIALOG_NAME "Number of Flutes"
           RSET_NAME   "Number of Flutes"
        }

The class hierarchy reflects the structure of your data in the database and determines which attributes will be included in the Search Criteria and Search Result dialog boxes. The Class Hierarchy section is at the end of the definition file.
The class hierarchy is a structure that shows the types and subtypes of data in the library, tools, holders, or devices. Types and subtypes have almost the same format, with the exception that subtypes are included in type definitions.
In this example, before the closing brace of CLASS TOOL, a few classes beginning with CLASS MILLING are defined. Before the closing brace of CLASS MILLING, several classes, beginning with CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE are defined.
CLASS TOOL
{
   TYPE QRY
   QUERY  "[DB(libref)] != [0]"
   DIALOG libref
   RSET   libref Descr MaterialDes 
   UI_NAME "Tool"

   CLASS MILLING
   {
      TYPE QRY
      QUERY  "[DB(Type)] == [02]"
      DIALOG libref Diameter TaperedSDia Descr
      RSET   libref Descr Diameter TaperedSDia MaterialDes
      UI_NAME "Milling"

      CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE 
      {
        TYPE QRY
        QUERY  "[DB(SubType)] == [01]"
        FILE "qry=shank_mill_schema;rset=shank_mill_schema;" 
        DIALOG libref Diameter FluteLength CorRadMill TaperAngleB TaperedSDia Material Holder Descr
        RSET   libref Descr Diameter FluteLength CorRadMill TaperAngleB TaperedSDia MaterialDes HolderDes HolderRef
        UI_NAME "End Mill (non indexable)"
      }
The UI_NAME statement in each class appears in the Library Class Selection dialog box, in the hierarchy established by the definition file.
Class keywords
Keyword
Usage
CLASS name
{
}
The name by which the class is referenced in Tcl code and data files. It is case sensitive and may not contain spaces.
TYPE QRY
Required internal command, which may not be changed.
QUERY "[DB(keyword) condtional operator xx]"
In the CLASS TOOL definition, by testing that DB(libref) is not zero, the code tests whether libref appears in the database.
In Type definitions, tests the Type against xx, where xx is in the database value that is mapped to an NX internal value, the UGT attribute. Similarly, the SubType is checked against the mapped UGST attribute.
In Teamcenter engineering process management, xx is the class id of the class that your administrator creates in the Classification Administration Module.
FILE
Refers to the icon graphic that appears in the Search Criteria dialog box. The examples show internal graphics, where the quotes contain one or more graphic references separated by semicolons (;). To include a custom graphic, you must include the full path to a suitable file in the .bmp format.
DIALOG
Identifies a list of attributes to include in the Search Criteria dialog box. The attributes are identified by their alias, which is defined in the first section of the file.
RSET
Identifies a list of attributes to include in the Search Result dialog box. The attributes are identified by their alias.
UI_NAME
Defines the text that appears for the class or subclass in the Library Class Selection dialog box.

Document Title: Cutter, tool holder, and device libraries
Document Body:
You can store tools in and retrieve tools from the cutting tool, tool holder, and device libraries. All three libraries have the same structure, and you use and customize them in the same way.
When you use the libraries, you can define a tool once, and reuse the definition whenever you need it.
When you retrieve objects from a library, you:
Specify a classification, such as mill, turning tool, or drill.
Specify parameters to filter the results, such as diameter, length, or tip angle.
Select a tool, holder, or device that matches your criteria.
Cutting tool libraries
A cutting tool library classifies cutting tools and stores tool parameters. NX uses these parameters to display standard tools and calculate material removal in simulations. A solid model of a standard tool need not exist. Use the solid tool library if the dimensions are non-standard.
If a cutting tool has a holder defined, NX loads the tool holder when it loads the tool.
Cutting tools can have an optional associated part file which NX can use to display a tool. This is usually an assembly of the components used to make up a tool, such as tool and holder, cutting inserts, and so on. The graphics folder of the tool library, $UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR\tool\graphics, contains several examples of cutting tools.
   ugt0202_001      ugt0102_008         ugt0101_001
Tool holder libraries
A tool holder library stores definitions for parametric tool holders for milling, drilling, and turning tools. You can save holders to a holder library by exporting them from the Holder tab of the tool editing dialog box. On the same tab, you can retrieve a holder for use with a tool that you are editing. If there is a holder defined for a library tool, it is retrieved with the tool.
User-defined bull-nose cutter in user-defined holder
Solid tool libraries
A solid tool is a solid model or assembly that is used as a tool in a Generic Motion operation. The shape of the tool is defined by the solid model, and not by traditional parameters like diameter. For example, you may model probes, painting heads, or other similar devices. Tracking points determine what point on the solid follows the programmed path. All solid tools are library tools.
User-defined probing tools
If you have a tool that is not defined by the standard dimensions for tools and holders, you can create a model and define it as a solid tool. An NX part or assembly is added to a new folder in the $UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR\tool\graphics folder.
Device libraries
A machine device is mounted on a machine tool to extend the range of actions that the machine can perform. Typical devices are turrets, heads, tail-stocks, steady-rests, parts catchers, tool calibration probes, or part transfer robots. The actions of a device are controlled in the NC program. You can store machine devices in a device library and retrieve them onto your machine in your CAM session.
You can retrieve a device to a specific pocket by selecting the pocket before you retrieve the device.
                sim16_RightAngle-Head,                                sim16_AC-Head
                sim16_Vertical-Head-assy
dev01_001
User-defined contouring head
Customization
You can extend the classifications, such as milling, drilling, chuck, and head. You can add the tools, holders, and devices that you use to the appropriate library. Tools and device part files contain kinematic information which defines their mounting position and orientation on the machine tool for simulation. You use the Machine Tool Builder application to define the tool mount and device mount junctions. For tool carrier devices such as heads, you can define an additional pocket component with a junction for the placement of the cutting tool.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Create Tool
Location in dialog box
Library group→Retrieve Tool from Library or Retrieve Device from Library

Document Title: Retrieve a tool from a library
Document Body:
This example describes how to retrieve a twist drill from a native ASCII library. The procedure for other tools follows the same pattern of steps. The procedure to retrieve a device is very similar.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Library group, click Retrieve Tools from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, expand a node, and select the tool subtype that you want to find.
For example, expand the Drilling node, and select Twist Drill.
Click OK.
(Optional) In the Search Criteria dialog box, in the Search Parameters group, enter data to filter the search.
For example, if the Library Units list is set to Millimeter, in the Diameter box, type 8. If the Library Units list is set to Inch, in the Diameter box, type 0.75.
You can enter exact values or a simple range of values using <, >, <=, or >=. If you enter >=6 in the Diameter box, the search is narrowed to tools with a diameter that is greater than or equal to 6.
In the Actions group, click Count Matches .
The number of matches is shown in parentheses after the Count Matches label.
You can click List Results to preview the tools that will be displayed in the Search Results dialog box.
If there are too many results or no results, refine the search criteria and count matching tools again until you are ready to proceed.
Click OK.
In the Search Result dialog box, from the Matching Items list, select the tool that you require.
You can click Display to see a preview of a selected tool. The display does not change until you click Display again, or leave the dialog box. You can select the Preview check box to automatically see the display of each tool that you select.
The tool holder for the selected tool is also shown, if one is defined.
Part, blank, and fixture geometry are hidden to clarify the example drill previews.
With a tool selected, click OK.
The tool is added to your part, and is displayed in the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator.
The Create Tool dialog box remains open. You can continue to add or retrieve tools, or click Cancel to close the dialog box without creating another tool.

Document Title: Retrieve a tool or device into a specific pocket or holder
Document Body:
When you retrieve a tool or device from the library, by default, it is inserted into the first available pocket or holder in your setup. You can select the target pocket or holder into which to retrieve the tool or device.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
You can also right-click a pocket or carrier node in the Operation Navigator, and choose Insert→Tool.
In the Location group, select the target pocket or holder from the Machine Tool View list.
Only pockets and holders that are not at full capacity are available in the list.
If there is available capacity in the tool pocket or holder that you right-click in the Operation Navigator, it becomes the target location by default.
Complete the specification for a new tool, or choose one or more library tools.
Tools that you specify are inserted into the specified pocket, depending on its capacity. Tools in excess of the capacity of the specified pocket or carrier are inserted into available pockets that appear in the list below the specified pocket.
Note:
When you specify a carrier as the location:
If the HLD field in the tool_database.dat file is empty, or the Holding System Name box in the Pocket dialog box is empty, NX places the tool under the pocket.
If the HLD field and the Holding System Name box both have values, but they do not match, NX places the tool under the carrier.

Document Title: Example: Retrieve a turning tool with a selection criterion
Document Body:
This example shows how to find and retrieve an OD turning tool with a nose radius that is greater than 0.01575 inches, and to specify pocket 2 as the target location.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Location group, select POCKET 2.
In the Library group, click Retrieve Tools from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, under the Turning node, select OD Turning and click OK.
In the Search Criteria dialog box, in the Search Parameters group, from the Library Units list, select Inch.
In the (R) Nose Radius box, type > 0.01575.
In the Actions group, click Count Matches
NX searches for tools with a nose radius that is greater than the specified value. There is 1 tool that meets the search criteria.
Click OK.
In the Search Results dialog box, select the ugti0101_017 tool and click OK.
The cutting tools in the Matching Items list are derived from the dbc_tool_ascii.def file in the location specified by the variable UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR. You can add, modify, or remove tools. .
In the Machine Tool View of the Operation Navigator, expand the Carrier node, and then expand the POCKET_2 node.
The tool that you retrieved is now available for selection.

Document Title: Retrieve a mill tool holder from the library
Document Body:
You can retrieve a mill tool holder from the tool holder library and assign it to the current tool.
In the tool parameters dialog box, click the Holder tab.
In the Library group, click Retrieve Holder from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, select the Milling, Drilling node, and click OK.
In the Search Criteria dialog box, if you know all or part of a custom Libref or a custom Type, enter it to filter the results, and click OK.
In the default ASCII library, all mill holders are type 1, subtype 0, and their libref starts with HLDI001_.
In the Search Result dialog box, select the holder that you want and click OK.
Note:
There is no validation to ensure that the parameters of the holder and the tool are compatible. There are example tool assemblies provided, on which you can base custom tool assemblies to better meet your needs for simulation and verification.
The holder libref appears in the Holder Library Reference box.

Class Description
Shows the name assigned to the type and subtype of tool that you selected. The text is defined in the corresponding .def file, for example, dbc_tool_ascii.def, holder_ascii.def, dbc_inclass_tlas.def, and so on.
Legend
The Legend for each subclass shows the parameters as drawing dimensions. The graphic shows the legends for some common subclasses.
Search Parameters

Parameters vary with the type of tool and are fully described by the legend.
Common non-graphical parameters are described here.
Leave value boxes blank to accept any value for the corresponding parameter.
Library Units
Specifies Inch or Millimeter.
Libref
Sets the unique LIBRF for the tool that you want.
Tool parameter
Set the values for the tool diameter, point angle, corner radius and so on. You can enter exact numeric values or simple expressions such as the following for a one-sided range:
>25, <=10, >= 5.0, !=0
Material
Filters by the specified tool material.
Holding System
Filters by the specified holding system.
Description
Sets text that must appear in the description field, DESCR, in the database.
Additional Search Criteria subgroup
Enter Query
Lets you enter a complex expression, for example, to specify a double-ended range of sizes, for example:
[DB(Diameter)] < [.5] && [DB(Diameter)] > [0.2]
Actions
List Results
Available after you click Count Matches.
Lists tools that match the search criteria in the Information window.
Clear Query
Removes all search filters.
Count Matches
Displays the number of database entries that match the specified search criteria. If you enter no filters, you see the number of tools in the specified subclass.

Document Title: Turning tool tips and tracking points
Document Body:
To calculate a tool path, NX needs to know the size and shape of the tool, the location of the tool with respect to the machine, and what point on the tool the machine operator will set up as the local coordinate system offset.
Two points in space locate the tool with respect to the machine:
A reference point on the turret face that will move to programmed coordinates in the absence of any offsets.
In NX, you identify this point as the tool mount junction. The axes of the tool assembly, the tool mount junction, and the tool tip junction are coplanar in the XY plane of the tool assembly. For consistency with milling kinematics, we recommend that the X-axis points in the direction in which the tool, holder, device, or insert is moved into the object that holds it. For turrets of all types, this direction is typically radial towards the centerline.
A point at the tool tip, which must be one of 9 possible tracking points.
In NX, you identify this point as the tool tip junction.
Tracking point locations
The machine operator can measure points where the tool contacts the workpiece along the X-axis and Z-axis of the machine. The operator will use this information to provide offset information to adjust the machine’s positioning from the tool mount reference point to the tool tip reference point.
Tracking point numbers
Tracking point P9 is the center point of the radius at the nose of the tool.
The tool tip junction usually coincides with one of the turning tracking points P1 through P8.
The tool tip junction and the tool mount junction must be coplanar with the XY plane of the tool holder and must lie at Z=0.
To calculate the correct position of the tracking points, the junctions must be oriented by the rule shown in the following image, where the X-axis and Y-axis are the same as the tool mount junction in the assembly.
The arc:
Is concentric with the tool tip radius.
Is equal in radius to the tool tip radius.
A box that is aligned with the X and Y axes of the tool assembly (see Create a solid turning tool assembly for export to a library) is constructed such that it is tangent to the arc at the center points of all four sides, as shown.
The corner points of the box are numbered counterclockwise, starting with the point that is on the upper right when the axes are aligned as shown.
The tangent points are numbered counterclockwise starting with the point on the X+ axis of the box, tracking point P5, as shown.
Tracking points for grooving tools
The user must define the P number for radius R1 and set the tool tip junction (with the correct orientation) to the correct position at radius R1.
NX automatically calculates the tracking point for radius R2, according to the tool tip junctions and the tool parameters.
Note:
For grooving tools the tool tip junction must be defined.
Grooving tools with tracking points radius IDs and P numbers
Topside OD Grooving
Underside OD Grooving
Topside ID Grooving
Underside ID Grooving
Topside Face Grooving
Underside Face Grooving

Here you define which items are to be considered in your search in the Search Criteria Dialog. This is a fully customizable dialog (see Customizing the Search Criteria Dialog). The following is an explanation of the most commonly found items in the dialog.
Search Criteria
Legend
This sketch outlines the parameters found in all items in the subclass. It is a visual aid in inputting the parameters for the search.
Library Units
The ASCII database is divided into English and metric units. Here you may select which you would like to use.
Various Parameters and Input Fields
The search will be limited by your entries into these fields.
Description
Lets you search for tools by entering a text string. NX returns tools with descriptions that contain the text. It is not necessary to enter operators or wild cards.
Additional Search Criteria
You can specify ranges of values or specific parameters not found in the dialog.
List Results
Result Info provides you with an information window which lists all the parameters which appear in the Search Criteria Dialog and their values. This function is not available until Count Matches has been performed.
Clear Query
You can remove all entries in the Search Criteria Dialog by using the Clear button.
Count Matches
By pressing the Count Matches button, the system will return the number of items in the database which match the search criteria which you have entered. If you enter no search criteria, pushing the Count Matches button will return the number of all the items in that subclass.
Additional Search Criteria
You can input an entire query string in this field. Each query string consists of a series of search criteria which are joined by logical operators "and" (&&) and "or" ( || ). These search strings must follow an exact syntax. For example:
[DB(alias_1)] c.op. [value] l.op. [DB(alias_2)] c.op.[value]
where:
alias_1 and alias_2
the names of the DB alias (the parameters) as they are found in the definition file of the corresponding DBC event handler (.def file).
c.op
comparable operators : <, >, <=, >=, ==, !=
l.op
logical operators: and (`&&), or ( || )
For example, a search query based on the following string
[DB(Diameter)] < [.5] && [DB(Diameter)] > [0.2]
would produce a range of values where the diameter lies between 0.2 and 0.5 mm.
Range of Values
When inputting information into the Search Criteria Dialog, the system allows you to input a range of values. The syntax for these ranges is as follows:
Search Parameter Syntax
> x
Searches for all tools with a value greater than x
< x
Searches for all tools with a value less than x
x
Searches for all tools with a value equal to x

Document Title: Create solid milling tool assembly for export to a library
Document Body:
You can export a solid milling tool assembly, or solid drilling tool assembly, to a native NX or Teamcenter library.
You can start your milling tool assembly with a 3D model that you create or download.
If you download models from the tool vendor, you will probably have to rework or recreate the tool model to correct the orientation and the number of bodies in the part.
After you complete the tool assembly, all solid bodies should be in component part files, with no body in the assembly part file.
The assembly file name must be unique and must exactly match the libref of the tool in the tool database. For example, the graphics for the tool called ugt0201_096 would be in a file called ugt0201_096.prt. When you use this procedure, NX automatically names the part file or assembly file structure correctly.
Note:
When you use this method to export a tool assembly, the orientation of the base components with respect to the XY plane and origin of the absolute coordinate system of the part file are optional. However, it is recommend to follow these rules as a best practice.
Create one part file in NX and model the tool with two solid bodies in the XY plane. Make the tool axis parallel to the X-axis and the tool tip at the absolute origin of the part (X=0, Y=0 and Z=0).
Create the first solid body for the cutting portion.
Create a separate solid body for the non-cutting portion.
In the image, the yellow body is the cutting portion of the tool.
In a separate part file, model the tool holder in the XY plane, with the tool axis parallel to the X-axis and the spindle gauge point at the absolute origin of the part (X=0, Y=0 and Z=0).
During simulation, the gauge point is where the holder is aligned with the tool mount junction in the kinematic model of the machine tool. Typically, NX uses the center of the spindle face as the tool mount junction. It is often easiest to use the center of the mounting face as the gauge point; however, if you want extreme accuracy in the simulation, you can allow for the gap that may exist between the tool holder and the spindle face on the actual tool.
In the image, the origin is at the spindle gauge point.
In the image, the origin is adjusted for a gap between the holder face and the spindle face
Create a 3D tool assembly and save it in your working location.
To maintain Teamcenter compatibility, follow these rules:
Place no solid bodies in the tool assembly file.
Make the name of the tool assembly unique. This name must match the planned name for the tool in your library.
Make the first component the tool. This component should have two solid bodies for the cutting and non-cutting portions of the tool.
Make the second component the tool holder.
Add additional components if required. For example, you have the option to model screws, clamps, extensions, and so on.
Position the tool in the holder using a fixed location if so equipped, or using the recommended insertion depth.
Place all the geometry you want to be displayed in NX CAM on Layer 1.
In NX Manufacturing, add a CAM setup and create a parametric tool in the 3D tool assembly file.
The tool and holder parameters must exactly match the cutting and non-cutting parts of the 3D tool assembly that lie below the spindle gauge point in order to permit proper tool holder collision detection during simulation.
If you create the complete parametric tool component (not just the portion of the tool extended out from the holder), use the tool insertion offset parameter on the holder tab (OS) to match the distance the tool is set into the holder of the 3D tool assembly.
Note:
NX uses the parametric tool and holder to calculate tool motions and to check for collisions while generating a tool path. NX only uses the 3D tool assembly in machine simulation.
It is recommended to set the Tool Number value to 0 on the Tool tab of the tool dialog box.
When the tool is retrieved from the library, the tool number should not be the same number assigned to an existing tool in the setup.
In the Library group, in the Library Reference box, specify the library reference.
Select the Export Tool Part File check box.
Selecting this check box makes additional options visible on the tool tab to define the tool mount junction, tool tip junction and the cutting portion of the tool.
Note:
If you edit the tool assembly part of an existing tool in the library, then NX will select the Export Tool Part File check box by default.
Under Junctions, in the Specify Mounting row, click CSYS Dialog to define the tool mount junction.
Orient the X-axis of the junction in the direction the tool assembly mounts into the machine spindle.
Note:
For tool assemblies or devices that mount directly on a turret, the axes orientation and location of the tool mount junction must match the axes orientation and location of the tool mount junction defined on the turret in the machine model kinematics. It is recommended the X-axis points into the turret and the Y-axis is parallel to the XY-plane of the actual lathe workplane on the machine.


Under Junctions, in the Specify Tool Tip row, click CSYS Dialog to define the tool tip junction.
Orient the X-axis of the junction along the tool rotation axis.
Note:
On mill or mill-turn machines:
For milling tools with standard holders, the X-axes of the tool tip and tool mount junctions are collinear.
For milling tools with angled holders, the X-axis of the tool tip junction is equal to the escape direction of the tool from the holder.
Under Cutting Portion of Tool, click Select Object and select the solid body representing the cutting portion of the modeled tool.
Click Export Tool To Library .
All of these activities are done for milling tools at the time of export:
Creates a new entry in the tool database file.
Creates a new folder for the tool assembly in the tool graphics library location. The folder name is the same as the tool assembly file.
Creates a copy of the tool assembly file and the component files in the tool assembly folder.
Creates the tool kinematic structure in the tool assembly file that includes:
Tool mount and tool tip junctions.
Spin information for cutting and non-cutting bodies.
Creates revolved bodies in the tool assembly file for the cutting and non-cutting portions of the tool.
Note:
The tool graphics library location in NX is defined by the environment variable UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_GRAPHICS_PATH.
The default directory for the tool graphics library is MACH\resource\library\tool\graphics.
You can view the tool kinematic structure of the tool by opening the 3D tool assembly file located in the tool graphics library with Machine Tool Builder.
Close the 3D tool assembly file without saving it.
The current work part is no longer needed to define the library tool. If you need it for other purposes, you can save it somewhere in your local working environment.
Caution:
Do not save the work part manually in the MACH\resource\library\tool\graphics folder. NX automatically saved the part in the correct location when you exported the tool part file.
Test the tool assembly in a new CAM setup and create the tool from the library.
As soon as you click on the new tool in the machine tool view, it should display the tool assembly.
Check that the tool tip position and tool mount position are displayed correctly during machine simulation of a toolpath.
Note:
If you need to make a change to this library tool, edit the 3D tool assembly file in the tool graphics library.

Document Title: Create a solid turning tool assembly for export to a library
Document Body:
Start your turning tool assembly with a 3D model that you create or download.
Note:
If you download models from the tool vendor, you must rework or recreate the tool model to correct the orientation and the number of bodies in the part.
After you complete the tool assembly, all solid bodies should be in component part files, with no body in the assembly part file.
Align the tool assembly on the XY plane of the absolute coordinate system, with the XY plane of the tool mount and tool tip junctions coplanar at Z = 0.
Note:
In certain complex tools, the tool mount and the tool tip are not in the same plane. The general rule is that you must design the tool mount and tool tip junction in such a way that the XY plane of the tool tip junction is coplanar with the actual lathe workplane on the machine when the mounted tool is cutting.
Place the cutting portion of the tool in the first component part file.
If the tool has a non-cutting portion, for example, if an insert is permanently brazed onto a holder, model the non-cutting portion as a separate body and place it in the same component file.
Place a tool holder that accepts interchangeable tools in a second component part file.
(Optional) Place additional non-cutting bodies, such as tool extensions, clamping mechanisms, adapters, and so on, in other component part files.
Note:
Place all the geometry you want to be displayed in NX CAM on Layer 1.
If the tool tip edge is modeled as a spline or ellipse, construct an arc or circle to approximate its location.
The center of the arc is tracking point P9.
The image below shows the WCS at the P9 position. If you created a temporary arc, and you intend to identify P9 as the tracking point, create a point at WCS 0,0,0.
Start the Manufacturing application, and choose the cam_general configuration and the turning setup.
Define a parametric cutting tool that exactly matches the size and shape of the cutting portion of your tool assembly.
You can dynamically position the tool insert to verify when the parameters are correct.
If the display of the insert created by the tool dialog is inside the wrong plane, it is good practice to adjust the MCS inside the geometry view to match the plane of the 3D tool insert.
On the Tracking tab, create the tracking point for this tool, which is P4 in this example.
On the Holder tab, set the Holder Angle value to 0.0 and confirm that the Use Turn Holder check box is not selected.
On the Tool tab, adjust parameters as necessary to make the parametric tool exactly match the modeled tool.
Use analysis measurements, object information, and direct overlay to make sure the parameters are correct.
In the tool dialog box, click OK to complete the tool definition.
In the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, verify that the tool name is correct and double-click the new tool to edit it.
On the Tool tab of the tool dialog box, in the Numbers Group, verify that the Tool Number value is set to 0.
In the Library group, in the Library Reference box, specify the library reference.
Select the Export Tool Part File check box.
Selecting this check box makes additional options available. You can now define the tool mount and tool tip junctions, and select the cutting portion of the tool.
Note:
Store the tool assembly part file you want to export in a location separate from the tools provided with your local NX installation.
If you edit the tool assembly part file of an already existing library tool, which is located in the mach\resource\library\tool\graphics folder, then only adjust the parameters of the mount and tool tip junction inside the Machine Tool Builder.
In this case the tool tip must reflect the correct tracking point. Export the tools in this case with theExport Tool Part File check box cleared, and save the part file.
Under Junctions, in the Specify Mounting row, click CSYS Dialog and specify the arc center of the cylinder that is inserted into the turret, as shown.
Tip:
You might need to set the Selection Scope value to Entire Assembly.
If the assembly is correctly positioned and oriented, this location matches the absolute coordinate system and the current location of the WCS.
Note:
It is required that the tool length is along the X-axis, and the width is in the Y-axis.
All used devices must follow the this orientaion rule.
For tool assemblies or devices that mount directly on a turret, the axes orientation and location of the tool mount junction must match the axes orientation and location of the tool mount junction defined on the turret in the machine model kinematics.


In the Specify Tool Tip row, click CSYS Dialog to define the tool tip junction, which is always be P9. This allows NX to calculate the correct tracking point automatically.

Independent of the specified tracking point P Number, which is defined on the tracking tab of the tool creation dialog box, select the center of the corner radius (P9) to define the origin of the tool tip junction. NX automatically moves the origin to the actual location of the first tracking point, which is P4 in this example. The XY plane of the tool tip junction defines the work plane of the tool, which coincides with the actual work plane on the machine when the tool is cutting.
Note:
Do not select the tracking point you define on the tracking tab of tool dialog box.
The export function automatically adjusts the tool tip position to the correct tracking point.
If you wish to check your exported tool tracking point, navigate to mach\resource\library\tool\graphics and verify the tool tip position inside the Machine Tool Builder.
If you created a temporary arc or circle to specify the tool tip, delete it now so it will not appear when the tool is retrieved from the library.
Under Cutting Portion of Tool, click Select Object and select the modeled tool insert, as shown.
Note:
All the additional components and solids are used as non-cutting elements.
In the Tracking Point dialog box, click No.
Click Export Tool To Library .
In the Select Target Class dialog box, specify the class for your tool, for example UG_TURNING_STD, and click OK.
NX does the following:
Creates a new tool entry with the specified Library Reference in the tool_database.dat file of the ASCII tool library.
Creates a copy of the current assembly part file in the mach\resource\library\tool\graphics folder. The name of the part file matches the name of the specified tool libref.
Read the information in the Export Tool to Library dialog box, and click OK.
Close the assembly part file.
The current work part is no longer needed to define the library tool. If you need it for other purposes, you can save it somewhere in your local working environment.
Caution:
Do not save the work part manually in the mach\resource\library\tool\graphics folder. NX automatically saved the part in the correct location when you exported the tool part file.
Test the tool assembly during simulation with an appropriate machine tool model to be sure that it is correct.
Caution:
The MRL or ASCII library data must match the graphics for the tool in the part file. For example, if the part file shows a topside tool, you must classify the tool as topside in the MRL or ASCII library.
You can import solid turning tool assemblies into a Teamcenter library.

Document Title: Export a tool as a part file
Document Body:
You can create a new tool part file that contains solid bodies from a parametric tool definition.
In the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, right-click a single parametrically defined tool and choose Object→Export Part.
NX saves the tool as a single part file with the default name [tool name].prt. The part file contains a separate solid revolved feature for the flute, neck, shank, and holder definitions.
Note:
This functionality is available only in native NX for rotational tools. It does not apply to Turning tools.
A Modeling license is not required.
Wave linking is not available. The solid features are based on tool parameters, and are not associative.

Document Title: Modify a library tool with a solid tool assembly
Document Body:
Open the tool assembly part file that is located in the mach\resource\library\tool\graphics folder.
The assembly is your current work part.
Start the Manufacturing application.
Retrieve the library tool that references the tool assembly part file.
In the tool dialog box, enter your changes.
Export the modified tool.
This last step updates the existing entry in the tool_database.dat file and saves your changes to the tool assembly part in the mach\resource\library\tool\graphics folder.
Close the assembly part file without saving it.
Caution:
Do not save the part manually by clicking Save .

Document Title: Create milling tool holders for export to a library
Document Body:
You can model tool holders for milling machines singly or as a family of parts. You can apply the process described here to cutting tools and other non-cutting objects that you may want to display, such as retention knobs.
If you obtain solid models from the manufacturer, you may still have to move the body to the correct position and orientation.
Model the part of the tool holder that fits into the spindle of your machine tool, from the tool change flange to the hole for the retention knob.
Model the part so that the absolute coordinate system is at the spindle gauge point, and the part is oriented in the XY plane with the tool axis along X.
The sketch shown is dimensioned for the common dimensions of DIN2080 tool holders. The important dimensions, to the X– side of the CSYS, are the 31.5 radius and the 10 mm thickness of the flange.
Everything to the X+ side of the CSYS is for display only – it is inserted into the spindle and thus plays no part in collision checking.
For most standard taper tool holders, the taper is 3.5 units in 12, or 7 units in 24. You can model the taper angle very accurately by entering atangent(7/48) when you dimension the half-angle shown. The sketch will not show the formula; it will show 8.3 degrees.
Revolve the sketched section to create a body for the unchanging element of your machine’s tool holders.
Details such as holes and drive slots are acceptable, but they are not necessary.
Sketch the part of the holder or holder family that varies with each cutting tool.
Most manufacturers provide a table of the important dimensions.
Revolve and unite the varying part of the tool holder.
If you do not plan to create a family of tool holders, you can stop here.
If you have several holders that match the pattern of the sketch, create named dimensions with meaningful names, and edit the sketch to use these dimensions directly or in formulas.
In the Modeling application, choose Tools tab→Utilities group→Spreadsheet .
NX is locked from any interaction while the spreadsheet is open.
In Excel, on the Add-Ins tab, choose Extract Expr.
All of the expressions in the part are copied to the spreadsheet. You need only the data that matches values in the manufacturer’s chart.
Delete all rows except the ones that contain the named expressions that you created to match the holder manufacturer’s chart.
The spreadsheet should look something like this:
Fill in the values for your other holders in the family, so that each column beside the expression names contains the values for one possible configuration of the holder.
Your spreadsheet might look like this.
In Excel, on the Add-Ins tab, choose Options→NX Preferences.
Clear the Use Fixed Update Range check box, and click OK.
Select the rows and columns that contain expression names and possible sets of values, as shown.
On the Add-Ins tab, choose Define Expr Range.
This identifies a named range of spreadsheet cells that NX can use to update the part.
You can now test your model to see if the members of the family can be created without errors.
Arrange the spreadsheet so that you can see columns of values and the NX graphics window.
Select the cells that comprise any single column of values other than the currently modelled configuration.
On the Add-Ins tab, choose Update NX Part.
If there are no modelling or other issues, the part updates to the selected configuration.
Repeat the cell selection and update process to test all configurations.
In the spreadsheet, below each column of values, enter the full path and part name where you would like the family member saved.
For example, you could enter C:\temp\h9001, and so on. Do not worry about the display.
If the part names form a sequential numeric pattern, you can use auto-fill to populate the row.
When you complete the row of part names, select all cells containing expression names, values, and part names, as shown.
On the Add-Ins tab, choose Define Fmly Rng.
This identifies a named range of spreadsheet cells that NX can use to update the part and save as a member of the family.
On the Add-Ins tab, choose Build Family.
In the graphics window, the part is continuously updated and the status line reflects the member being saved.
(Optional) Select the cells that correspond to the configuration that you consider to be the default, and update the part.
When the updates are complete, close the spreadsheet.
In NX, in the Exit Spreadsheet dialog box, click OK to save your spreadsheet data.
You now have a set of parts that you can use in solid tool assemblies for your library.

Document Title: Construct tracking points when the insert has a rake angle
Document Body:
In NX we place turning tool assemblies on the work plane of the lathe, and on that plane we create the two important kinematic junctions, the tool mount junction and the tool tip junction. These junctions establish the relationship between the machine and the cutting tool that is needed to create programs.
In general, CAM programming systems assume that the tool tip is coplanar with the work plane of the lathe; however, manufacturers often add a rake angle to a tooling insert. The angle is chosen to be suitable for machining the material for which the cutter is intended.
CAM programming systems typically project the tool tip to the work plane, and in NX we do the same.
When you define a tracking point for a cutting tool whose face does not lie in the XY plane of the tooling assembly, you must project the tool tip radius, create an approximating arc, and use that arc to construct required tracking points.
If there is not already an XY datum plane in the tool assembly, create one.
Zoom in the view on the tool tip radius.
If the tool tip radius is an arc or an ellipse, create the center point.
Curve tab→Curve group→Point
Type = Arc/Ellipse/Sphere Center
Project the edge that corresponds to the tool tip radius, and the center point, to the XY datum plane.
Curve tab→Derived Curve group→Project Curve
Projection Direction group→Direction = Along Face Normal
Settings group→Associative =
Input Curves = Replace (The edge can only be copied — you will see a warning)
Curves or Points to Project group→Select Curve or Point
Objects to Project to group→Select Object
Create a circle to approximate the tool tip.
If necessary, hide the tool body as you work.
It is usually acceptable to use the nominal tool tip radius if it is known. For example, if the radius appears to be 0.799 mm, you could round it to 0.8 mm, which is a common nominal radius.
Move the WCS to the center of the new circle and proceed to create a tracking point as described in Turning tool tips and tracking points and Create a solid turning tool assembly for export to a library.
Delete temporary curves, except the point at the tracking point location.

Document Title: Exporting tools to the native ASCII library
Document Body:
The cutting tool library lets you store all data pertaining to cutters for your machining operations. The tool library has an independent classification system and tool parameters. The tool classes and parameters are recognized when you export tools to the cutting tool library.
When you export a tool that you build in your CAM session to the library:
The tool is written into the tool_database.dat ASCII file that matches the units of your part.
If the cutting tool has a holder defined, NX saves a reference to the tool holder with the tool. The next time you retrieve this tool, the holder is retrieved with it. If the tool holder is new or modified, it is saved to the holder library.
You can save a meaningful description of your tool that is available each time you reload the tool.
You can set the initial number used to create the libref with the Starting Number for User Librefs customer default.
The first user tool library reference is either the Starting Number for User Librefs value, or one more than the highest library reference, whichever is greater.
Examples:
Starting Number for User Librefs = 1001
Highest libref = 584
The first user tool is ugt0203_1001.
Starting Number for User Librefs = 1001
Highest libref = 1015
The first user tool is ugt0203_1016.
Warning:
You must have write access to the library files to export to ASCII libraries.
To retrieve a tool from the tool library, see Retrieve a tool from a library.
Where do I find it?
Export tool to ASCII Tool library
Application
Manufacturing
Inch tool database file
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ENGLISH_DIR\tool_database.dat
Metric tool database file
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_METRIC_DIR\tool_database.dat
Location in dialog box
[Tool] dialog box→Library group→Export Tool to Library
Starting Number for User Librefs
Application
Manufacturing
Menu
File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults
Location in dialog box
Manufacturing→Tools→Libraries tab

Document Title: Export a tool to the native ASCII tool library
Document Body:
Note:
You must have write access to the ASCII libraries to export tools.
Create an NX tool with the dimensions, shank, holder, and other parameters that you want to save in the library.
The tool dialog box is displayed. You can go directly to step 7 and export your tool. All other actions that you can take in the tool dialog box are optional.
On the Tool tab, in the Description group, enter a description of your tool.
The description appears in the DESCR field of the database file.
Click Material to specify a tool material.
The materials that you can select are the default materials and any custom materials that you have added to the machining data database.
In the Numbers group, define the tool number, length adjustment register, and cutter compensation register in one of the following ways:
(Recommended) If you use tools in pockets, set the values to 0. When NX retrieves the tool, it inherits the values specified for the pocket.
If you want the tool to retain the same values regardless of where it is retrieved from, enter the values here.
The numbers that you enter become the defaults for the TLNUM, ADJREG, and CUTCOMREG fields in the tool database. When the tool is retrieved from the library, users can accept the defaults or override them to output other values in a program.
Caution:
When you simulate tool paths, you will get error messages if you have tools with the same number, or if an operation inherits a tool number of 0.
In the Information group, in the Catalog Number box, enter a vendor or other catalog reference.
This text does not correspond to a field in the database and it is not saved in the library.
In the Library group, in the Library Reference box, type a unique identifier for the tool.
If you do not enter a library reference, NX uses the next available library reference number in the tool library, or the Starting Number for User Librefs customer default value, whichever is greater.
In the Library group, click Export Tool to Library .
If the current tool library reference, the LIBREF field in the database, already exists in the library, a dialog box is displayed. Do one of the following:
To overwrite the existing tool definition, click Replace.
If no data differs from the data in the dialog box, the tool is not exported.
To accept an arbitrary new tool number, which is the next number available in the sequence, click Create.
To return to the tool dialog box and assign a different library reference, click Cancel.
If you are exporting a new tool and it is not clear in which tool class it belongs, NX opens the Library Class Selection dialog box. Select an appropriate library class.
If there are additional parameters in the library that are not defined with the tool, NX prompts you to fill in the missing data.
In the Template Attributes dialog box, from the Holding System list, select the appropriate holding system.
The default option None allows the tool to be retrieved into any pocket.
When the export is successful, the Export Tool to Library message box notifies you of the tool LIBREF and the library in which the tool was created. If kinematics were created, such as a tool mount junction, you are notified of that as well. To read more details in the log file, use the Menu→Help→Log File command.

Document Title: Exporting tool holders to the native tool holder library
Document Body:
Click Export Holder to Library to export the tool holder to the tool holder library.
Note:
This feature is available only in native NX.
NX uses the current value of the library reference or libref field to identify the holder data in the library. You can also add a description of the tool holder that is saved with the tool holder.
Note:
Export Holder to Library is a customizable item on the tool dialog box. To see this option in the tool dialog, right-click on the tool in the Operation Navigator and choose Object → Customize from and update the dialog item from the current template; or customize the dialogs and add the option.
If you create a holder without previously retrieving a holder from the library, and do not enter a libref, the software automatically generates a unique library reference value. Following the export, the software-generated libref is displayed in the Library Reference box. If the current holder libref already exists in the library, you must either replace the existing definition or create a new holder. If you select Replace and no data differs from the data in the dialog, the holder is not exported.
Warning:
You can export a holder only if you have write access to the library.

Document Title: Create a solid probing tool for export to a library
Document Body:
Open the part file that contains the tool model. This can be a single solid body or an assembly.
Start Manufacturing with a solid_tool setup.
Choose Application tab→Manufacturing .
In the Machining Environment dialog box, from the CAM Session Configuration list, select cam_general.
From the CAM Setup to Create list, select solid_tool.
Click OK.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, from the Type list, select solid_tool. In the Tool Subtype group, click GENERIC or PROBE .
Tip:
These options can be customized.
If solid_tool is not available, select Browse, and navigate to mach/resource/template_part/metric or mach/resource/template_part/english. Select solid_tool and click OK.
In the Location group, from the Machine Tool View list, select Generic Machine, None or a pre-defined machine.
In the Name group, type a name for the tool you are creating. This is the name that appears in the Operation Navigator and has a 30 character limit.
Click OK.
In the Generic Solid Tool or Probe Tool dialog box, click the Tool tab.
In the Mounting Junction group, define the mounting junction to determine the location and orientation of the solid tool in relation to the machine tool.
Select the CSYS in the graphics window, or click CSYS Dialog and then select the coordinate system located at the mounting face of the generic tool or probe tool.
The X-axis must point along the spindle towards the machine. For lathe machines, the X-Y plane should be parallel to the lathe work plane.
If necessary, click the Tracking tab and Select Tracking Point.
Select the tracking point.
Valid geometry is the face of a tool end or the sphere on a probe. This must be physical geometry. The inferred geometry options are not available.
(Probes only) Define the stem.
Click Specify Vector.
Select the vector pointing along the stem.
Click Select Top Face
