Select a face to define the end of the stem.
(Optional) Enter Adjust and Cutcom Register values if you require them for programming.
Offsets are not required. Specify the X Offset, Y Offset and Z Offset values when you want output that is relative to a spindle or turret reference point for the machine.
(Optional) Define the tracking point name using up to 128 characters.
(Optional) Click Add New Set to add more tracking points.
The list shows you the existing tracking points.
Click the Tool tab.
In the Description box, enter a description of 128 characters or less.
Click Material and select a material from the Tool Material list.
Note:
For probing tools, the default material is RUBY.
(Optional) In the Information group, in the Catalog Number box, enter a reference number of 128 characters or less.
Export the tool to the library.
Click Export Tool to Library .
In the Template Attributes dialog box, select a number from the Holding System list. The holding system selected here must match the holding system specified for the tool pocket that you will place the probe in.
Click OK.
NX copies the entire part file or assembly to the tool library graphics area, and creates a tool data record that references the graphics file. You may also want to save the part file for future reference or changes.
Probe tool mounted in machine

Document Title: Create a solid stamping tool for export to a library
Document Body:
Open the part file that contains the tool model. This can be a single solid body or an assembly.
Start Manufacturing with a solid_tool setup.
Choose Application tab→Manufacturing .
In the Machining Environment dialog box, from the CAM Session Configuration list, select cam_general.
From the CAM Setup to Create list, select solid_tool.
Click OK.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, from the Type list, select stamping_tool.
If stamping_tool is not available, select Browse, and navigate to mach/resource/template_part/metric or mach/resource/template_part/english. Select stamping_tool.prt and click OK.
In the Tool Subtype group, click STAMPING .
Tip:
These options can be customized.
In the Location group, from the Machine Tool View list, select GENERIC_MACHINE, None, or a pre-defined machine.
In the Name group, type a name for the tool you are creating. This is the name that appears in the Operation Navigator and has a 30-character limit.
Click OK.
In the Stamping dialog box, click the Tool tab.
In the Mounting Junction group, define the mounting junction to determine the location and orientation of the solid tool in relation to the machine tool.
Select the CSYS in the graphics window, or click CSYS Dialog and then define a coordinate system that is located at the mounting face of the stamping tool.
The X-axis must point along the spindle towards the machine. This example selects the face shown to define the mounting junction.
Click OK to save the mounting junction.
Define a tracking point.
On the Tracking tab, click Select Tracking Point .
Select the tracking point.
This example selects the edge shown to define a tracking point at the center of the circle.
Valid geometry is the face, curve, edge, or point of a tool end. This must be physical geometry. The inferred geometry options are not available.
(Optional) Enter Adjust and Cutcom Register values if you require them for programming.
Offsets are not required. Specify the X Offset, Y Offset, and Z Offset values when you want output that is relative to a spindle or turret reference point for the machine.
(Optional) Define the tracking point name using up to 128 characters.
(Optional) Click Add New Set to add more tracking points.
The list shows you the existing tracking points.
Click the Tool tab.
In the Description box, enter a description of 128 characters or less.
Click Material and select a material from the Tool Material list.
(Optional) In the Information group, in the Catalog Number box, enter a reference number of 128 characters or less.
Define the cutting surfaces.
In the Library group, click Select Cutting Geometry .
Select the solid body that represents the cutting portion of the stamping tool.
(Optional) Select the color that NX applies to the in-process workpiece faces cut by the stamping tool.
Export the tool to the library.
Click Export Tool to Library .
NX copies the entire part file or assembly to the tool library graphics area, and creates a tool data record that references the graphics file. You also have the option to save the part file in a separate location for future reference or changes.
Example:
Message displayed:
ugt0404_1001 created in metric tool library Tool kinematics were created Tool part file saved
Tool data record in tool_database.dat file:
#CLASS STAMPING
FORMAT LIBRF T ST UGT UGST DESCR TLNUM
#-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
DATA | ugt0404_1001 | 04 | 04 | 11 | 03 | custom_stamp_1 | 0
#END_DATA
Click OK as required to close the open dialog boxes.

See Common dialog box options for common options not described here.
Tool page
Mounting Junction determines the orientation and location of the solid tool relative to the machine tool.
Specify CSYS
Establishes the coordinates for the solid tool.
Description lets you type a description and assign a material for the tool.
Material
Lets you select a material from the Tool Material list.
Numbers lets you assign a tool number.
Information lets you add commercial information for reference.
Catalog Number
Lets you enter a catalog number up to 128 characters long.
Library
Library Reference
Lets you assign a unique library reference number. Leave this box blank for NX to assign the number for you.
Export Tool to Library
Lets you place the solid tool into the NX library.
Tracking page
Tracking Point
Name
Lets you enter a name for the tracking point.
Select Tracking Point
Lets you select a face to define the tracking point.
Adjust Register
Cutcom Register
Lets you assign any register values used by some post processors.
Offsets
Lets you assign any offset values required by the used by some post processors.
Add New Set
Lets you add more tracking points
List
Displays the tracking points and lets you reorder or delete tracking points.

See Common dialog box options for common options not described here.
Tool page
Mounting Junction determines the orientation and location of the solid tool relative to the machine tool.
Specify CSYS
Establishes the coordinates for the solid tool.
Description lets you type a description and assign a material for the tool.
Material
Lets you select a material from the Tool Material list.
Numbers lets you assign a tool number.
Information lets you add commercial information for reference.
Catalog Number
Lets you enter a catalog number up to 128 characters long.
Library
Library Reference
Lets you assign a unique library reference number. Leave this box blank for NX to assign the number for you.
Export Tool to Library
Lets you place the solid tool into the NX library.
Tracking page
Tracking Point
Name
Lets you enter a name for the tracking point.
Select Tracking Point
Lets you select a face to define the tracking point.
Stem
Specify Vector
Establishes the direction of the probe sensor associated with this tracking point.
Stem vector for the selected tracking point (1)
Select Top Face
Lets you select a face (2) to define the length of the sensor (how far the probe extends).
Adjust Register
Lets you assign any register values used by some post processors.
Offsets
Lets you assign any offset values required by the used by some post processors.
Add New Set
Lets you add more tracking points
List
Displays the tracking points and lets you reorder or delete tracking points.

Document Title: Use environment variables to define library locations
Document Body:
The standard NX locations of the libraries in NX Library are specified in the ugii_env_ug.dat file.
If you would like to point to a different location for these libraries, change the path in the ugii_env.dat file which lets you cusomize NX. The values defined in ugii_env.dat take precedence over the standard NX values.
The environment variable for the tool library is:
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ENGLISH_DIR or
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_METRIC_DIR
The environment variable for the machine library is:
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_MACHINE_DATA_DIR
The environment variable for the device library is:
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DEVICE_DATA_DIR
The environment variable for feeds and speeds data is:
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_FEEDS_SPEEDS_DATA_DIR

The Library Tool Data File
The ASCII files, which are used to store the library data, are identified by the following environment variables. The actual file paths can be seen by going to Menu→Help→ NX log file.
For tools:
${UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ENGLISH_DIR}\tool_database.dat
${UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_METRIC_DIR}\tool_database.dat
For holders:
${UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ENGLISH_DIR}\holder_database.dat
${UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_METRIC_DIR}\holder_database.dat
For machines:
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\machine\ascii\machine_database.dat
For devices:
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\device\ascii\device_database.dat
For feeds and speeds:
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\feeds_speeds\ascii\feeds_speeds.dat
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\feeds_speeds\ascii\cut_methods.dat
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\feeds_speeds\ascii/part_materials.dat
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\feeds_speeds\ascii\tool_materials.dat
For setups:
${ UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\template_dir\template.dat
The ASCII Data File is a list of records. The general structure of a record is:
record-type parameters
There are two record types which are referred to by the following keywords:
FORMAT
DATA
A FORMAT record describes the list of parameters ( DB_IDs) to be found in the subsequent DATA records and consists of the keyword FORMAT followed by a list of attribute identifiers. The attribute identifiers are used as DB_ID values within the DB_ALIAS structures of the Definition File (dbc_tool_ascii.def). You can define your own attribute identifiers which you need to describe your tools. The FORMAT line includes all the parameters which you wish to input for each data record in that class. For example:
FORMAT
 LIBRF
 T
UGT
UGST
ST
DESCR
MATREF
MATDES
HLD
HLDDES
DIA
FLEN
FN
HEI
DB_IDs used in FORMAT statement above:
LIBRF
Library Reference
T
Tool Type
ST
Tool SubType
UGT
NX Internal Type
UGST
NX Internal Subtype
DESCR
Description
MATREF
Reference to cutter material table
MATDES
Cutter material description
HLD
Holding system (Type of Machine Adapter)
HLDDES
Holding system description
DIA
Diameter
FLEN
Flute Length
FN
Number of Flutes
HEI
Height
Note:
A hash sign (#) indicates a comment - everything after this sign to the end of the line is ignored.
Each DATA record contains the data for one tool in the database. A DATA record consists of the keyword DATA followed by a list of attribute values separated by '|'. The DATA record corresponding to the above FORMAT line might look like this:
DATA | ugt0201_001 |02| 01|01|01| End Mill |TMC0_00006|HSS-Co5-TiN | 320 | Steep Taper 20 | 10.5 | 35.3| 4| 55
In the data record:
There must be the same number of parameters as there are DB_IDs in the FORMAT line above (an empty parameter is permissible).
Each parameter must be separated by the pipe symbol ( | ). At the end of the record there is no pipe symbol.
The first non blank character after DATA must be a pipe symbol.
If a record does not start with either FORMAT or DATA, it is treated as continuation of the previous FORMAT or DATA record.
The following attributes are common to all tool types and subtypes:
Attributes Common to all Tool Types and Subtypes
LIBRF
Unique identifier (library reference) for a tool
T
Classification type of a tool.
ST
 Classification subtype of a tool.
UGT
NX Internal Type
UGST
NX Internal Subtype
DESCR
Short tool description
MATREF
Reference to cutter material table (tool_materials.dat)
MATDES
Cutter material description
HLD
Holding system for mounting tool to machine . HLD is used to check whether the tool can be mounted to a pocket of the tool carrier of the machine. The HLD value here has to match one of the holding systems specified in the pocket definition in the postprocessor .def file of the machine.
If you are using this attribute to mount a device to a device holder in a machine tool model, the HLD value has to match the holder system under which you classified the device holder in the Machine Tool Builder application.
HLDDES
Holding system description
Warning:
  The attributes LIBRF, T, ST are mandatory.

NX libraries have a standard classification hierarchy to meet many common classification needs. A class that is nested inside another class is called a subclass. In the tool database, the top-level class is the tool. In the device library, the top-level class is the device, and so on.
For example, in dbc_tool_ascii.def, the parent class is TOOL. The parent class and each subclass is defined with a CLASS statement. Within the TOOL class, the subclass MILLING is defined, and within the MILLING class, further subclasses are defined, such as END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
Each top-level subclass has a type that is identified by the T field. Each tool type has subtypes that are identified by the ST field.
Example:
Tool type:
Milling with T = 02
Subtypes:
End Mills Non-indexable with ST = 01
End Mills Indexable with ST = 02
Each type T must be mapped to a corresponding NX internal data type, UGT, and each subtype ST must be mapped to a corresponding NX internal data subtype, UGST.
Example:
The Milling tools class with T = 02 has a Chamfer Mills Non-indexable subclass with ST = 05. The tool class and subclass are mapped to the NX internal data type Mill by the settings:
UGT = 01
UGST = 05
Tools that belong to each subtype are grouped in the database by these statements:
#CLASS NAME_OF_CLASS

#END_DATA
The #CLASS statement is followed by a class name that is identified in the definition file for the library, for example, in dbc_tool_ascii.def file.
The next line after a #CLASS statement is the FORMAT statement, which lists all of the attributes for the class. The attributes are explained in comments at the beginning of the database, and are often referenced in Tcl code and other files by an alias which makes the code easier to read. A custom type must include at least the following attributes:
Common Aliases
Attribute
Alias
Description
LIBRF
Libref
A unique library reference that identifies the tool.
T
Type
Identifies the high level classification in the library, for example, milling, drilling, turning, or solid tools.
ST
SubType
Identifies the subtype of the class for the data, for example, barrel mills, spot drills, face grooving, or probing tools.
UGT
UG Tool Type
Maps your tool type to an NX internal type.
UGST
UG Tool SubType
Maps your tool subtype to an NX internal subtype.
Note:
To see what types and subtypes are used in the other libraries, open their respective database.dat files in a text editor. The types and subtypes are explained in comments at the beginning of the file.
If you require an expanded hierarchy, you must determine the requirements for enhancing this classification. The table shows how some common tool library types and subtypes are classified.
Library Types and Subtypes used in ASCII files
Library Type
Attribute T
Library Subtype
Attribute ST
MILLING
02
End mill non-indexable
1
MILLING
02
End mill indexable
2
DRILLING
03
Twist drill
1
DRILLING
03
Center drill
22
TURNING
01
OD turning
1
TURNING
01
ID turning
2
SOLID
04
Generic
01
SOLID
04
Probe
02

The example procedures at the right show you how to add a new class, MY_END_MILLS, to the milling tools database.
The MY_END_MILLS class is based on the END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE class.
Tool
Milling
My End Mills ← ← ←
End Mill (non-indexable)
End Mill (indexable)
Ball Mill (non-indexable)
Chamfer Mill (non-indexable)
Spherical Mill (non-indexable)
Face Mill (indexable)
T-Slot Mill (non-indexable)
Barrel Mill
5 Parameter Mill
7 Parameter Mill
10 Parameter Mill
Thread Mill
Mill Form Tool
Drilling
Turning
Solid
  For information on additional tool classes, see Mapping New Classes/Subclasses.
First Step
> 1. Back up the library files

Before you begin to customize a tool library, create backup copies of the following files:
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\english\tool_database.dat
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\metric\tool_database.dat
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii.def
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii_export.tcl
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\ug_library\dbc_tool_general.tcl
Next Step
> 2. Add MY_END_MILLS tools to the database

Document Title: 2. Add MY_END_MILLS tools to the database
Document Body:
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\english folder, open the file tool_database.dat.
In the comments at the beginning of the file, check the ST column for available subtypes.
#    T   Lib Type    ST  Lib Subtype                         UGT  UG Type        UGST  UG Subtype
For this example, because 75 is not used as a subtype for end mills, you will assign it to your new class.
Add your new class to the table to document it.
#    02  Milling     75  My End Mills          01   Mill         01    5 Parameter
In the # Milling Tools area, add these lines:
#CLASS MY_END_MILLS
#END_DATA
Note:
The #CLASS and #END_DATA statements are parsed by Tcl code. Do not include extra space characters, particularly at the end of the statement where you may not notice them.
Copy the FORMAT statement from the non-indexable end mill class, #CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE, and paste it between the new class identifier #CLASS MY_END_MILLS and the end of data statement, #END_DATA so the result is similar to this:
#CLASS MY_END_MILLS
FORMAT LIBRF T ST UGT UGST DESCR MATREF MATDES TLNUM ADJREG CUTCOMREG HLD HLDDES DIA FN HEI ZOFF DROT FLEN TAPA TIPA COR1 CTH HOFF ZMOUNT RIGID TSDIA TSLEN TSTLEN RAMPANGLE HELICALDIA MINRAMPLEN MAXCUTWIDTH HLDREF TPREF
#END_DATA
Because the FORMAT statement may change in any new release, you should copy a FORMAT statement from the tool type on which you are basing your new class. in this example, the new class is based on #CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
You are not going to copy or modify a tool record. The preferred practice is to export tools from NX. This assures that the data is correctly formatted.
Tip:
To help you to identify the data fields if debugging is needed, you can include comment lines to show field separators adjacent to fields in the format statement, as shown in this partial line.
FORMAT LIBRF T ST UGT UGST DESCR
#-—-—-—|--—-—|-|-—|-—-|-—-—|
You can use extra spaces in the FORMAT and DATA statements to align data fields with keywords, as shown here:
FORMAT LIBRF           T    ST   UGT  UGST
#------+----------–--–-+----+----+----+----
DATA   | ugti0000_1001 | 02 | 75 | 01 | 1  
The database record is now set up for you to create and export a new tool of this class from within NX.
Save the file.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\metric folder, open the tool_database.dat file and repeat steps 2 through 6.
Next Step
> 3. Add MY_END_MILLS to the Library Class Selection dialog box

Document Title: 3. Add MY_END_MILLS to the Library Class Selection dialog box
Document Body:
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\ folder, open the file dbc_tool_ascii.def.
In the The Class Hierarchy area, add the following lines within CLASS MILLING, after CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
CLASS MY_END_MILLS
      {
        TYPE QRY
        QUERY  "[DB(SubType)] == [75]"
        FILE "qry=shank_mill_schema;rset=shank_mill_schema;" 
        DIALOG 
        RSET 
        UI_NAME "My End Mills"
      }
The attribute aliases in the DIALOG line determine the attribute input in the Search Criteria dialog box.
The attribute aliases in the RSET line determine the attribute input in the Search Result dialog box.
Copy the content of the DIALOG and RSET lines from CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE, the class on which you are basing your new class.
This assures that the proper parameters are available to the users. The content may differ from release to release.
Save the file.
Next Step
> 4. Add the MY_END_MILLS subtype in the tool build

Document Title: 4. Add the MY_END_MILLS subtype in the tool build
Document Body:
There may be hard-coded checks for the class that you care customizing, for example, in order to add a parameter to specific sub-classes.
The ASC_build_end_mill procedure includes such a check. You must add your subclass to the checking code.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\ folder, open the file dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl.
Find the line that contains this comment:
# Output tip angle for end mill
In the next line, you must provide for the possibility that an end mill has your new subtype, 75. You will insert a logical or condition.
Change the next line that checks end mill subtypes to determine whether to add a tip angle. Change it from this:
if {$asc_lib_subtype == 1 || $asc_lib_subtype == 2} {
to this:
if {$asc_lib_subtype == 1 || $asc_lib_subtype == 2 || $asc_lib_subtype == 75} {
Find the line that contains this comment:
# Relief Length and Relief Diameter for Ball Mill Non-Indexable
Add the line that contains MY_END_MILLS.
Change it from this:
if { ($asc_lib_subtype == 1 && $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE") ||
($asc_lib_subtype == 2 && $dbc_class == "END_MILL_INDEXABLE") ||
($asc_lib_subtype == 3 && $dbc_class == "BALL_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE")} \


to this:
if { ($asc_lib_subtype == 1 && $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE") ||
($asc_lib_subtype == 75 && $dbc_class == "MY_END_MILLS") ||
($asc_lib_subtype == 2 && $dbc_class == "END_MILL_INDEXABLE") ||
($asc_lib_subtype == 3 && $dbc_class == "BALL_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE")} \
Save the file.
Next Step
> 5. Enable export for MY_END_MILLS

In the \MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii folder, open the dbc_tool_ascii_export.tcl file.
In the holding system area, add MY_END_MILLS to the list of classes that use holding systems.
#  First, add Holding system for all classes which use it
    switch -- $dbc_class \
    {
        "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE" -
        "END_MILL_INDEXABLE" -
        "MY_END_MILLS" -
In the proc ASC_build_tool_record area, add MY_END_MILLS.
Since MY_END_MILLS has the same attributes as the other end mills, you can use the existing build procedure, ASC_build_end_mill.
        "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE"
        {
            set asc_lib_subtype 1
            set asc_nx_subtype 1 
            ASC_build_end_mill
        } 
        "MY_END_MILLS"
        {
            set asc_lib_subtype 75
            set asc_nx_subtype 1 
            ASC_build_end_mill
        }
Do not forget to edit the subtype to 75.
Save the file.
Next Step
> 6. Map MY_END_MILLS to the class hierarchy

Document Title: 6. Map MY_END_MILLS to the class hierarchy

Document Body:
You will make additional edits in the file dbc_tool_general.tcl. These changes permit the ugti prefix before the tool number to reflect the type and subtype. For example, without this code, the prefix would be ugti0000_. With this code, the prefix includes the library type T and subtype ST: ugti0275_.
Locate these comment lines:
#
# Milling tool subtypes (I=Indexable, NI Non Indexable)
# 
You are going to insert to code to define your custom subtype after the code that sets non-indexable and indexable end mills.
After the line that reads set uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL) "2", insert this line:
   set uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS) "75"
The first few lines of code should read like this:
#
# Milling tool subtypes (I=Indexable, NI Non Indexable)
# 
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_END_MILL)      "1"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL)       "2"
   set uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS)     "75"
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_BALL_MILL)     "3"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_BALL_MILL)      "4"
In proc UGLIB_ask_class_type_and_subtype { }, in the code that handles $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE", insert code to handle $dbc_class == "MY_END_MILLS".
    } elseif { $dbc_class == "MY_END_MILLS" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS)
The first few lines of code should look like this:
#  Start with milling tools
    if { $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(NI_END_MILL)
    } elseif { $dbc_class == "MY_END_MILLS" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS)
    } elseif {$dbc_class == "END_MILL_INDEXABLE" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL)
Save the file.
Your new class is added to the database.
You should test the class by exporting a tool and retrieving it.
If errors occur, refer to the TCL_ERROR feedback in your log file.
Final Step
> 8. Test the MY_END_MILLS class

When you customize NX, you should always test your changes.
You should test the class by exporting a tool and retrieving it.
If errors occur, refer to the TCL_ERROR feedback in your log file.
In NX, edit a tool that does not belong to a library. If necessary, create a new tool.
To determine whether a tool belongs to a library, in the editing dialog box, on the Tool tab, in the Library group, verify that the Library Reference box contains no text.
If the tool belongs to a library, the value of the libref field for the tool in the database is shown.
Click Export Tool to Library .
In the Select Target Class dialog box, select MY_END_MILLS, and click OK.
If the tool is successfully exported, the Export Tool to Library message box display the tool number that was assigned, and the library to which the tool was exported.
In the Export Tool to Library message box, click OK.
In the tool editing dialog box, click Cancel.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Library group, click Retrieve Tool from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, under the Milling node, select My End Mills and click OK.
In the Search Criteria dialog box, click Count Matches .
There should be only one match, the tool you just exported as a test.
Click OK.
In the Search Result dialog box, in the Matching Items list, your newly exported tool should appear. The tool should have ugti0275_xxxx in the Libref column, where xxxx is the next available tool number for user library references.
In the Search Result dialog box, in the Matching Items list, select the tool and click OK.
Your imported tool appears in the part.
The Workflow Add a new tool class is complete.

Document Title: Add a new class with a custom attribute
Document Body:
In this example you will add a new class, COMPANY_END_MILLS, to the milling tools database.
You will add a new text-valued attribute named companyid. This could be used for inventory control or shop floor reference.
The COMPANY_END_MILLS class is based on the END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE class.
First Step
> 1. Back up the library files

Before you begin to customize a tool library, create backup copies of the following files:
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\english\tool_database.dat
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\metric\tool_database.dat
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii.def
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii_export.tcl
${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\ug_library\dbc_tool_general.tcl
Next Step
> 2. Add COMPANY_END_MILLS to the database

In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\english folder, open the file tool_database.dat.
In the overview table area, add your new class, COMPANY_END_MILLS, to the table to document it. The subtype is 76.
#    02  Milling     76  Company End Mills          01   Mill         01    5 Parameter
In the # Milling Tools area, add the new class.
#CLASS COMPANY_END_MILLS
#END_DATA
Copy the FORMAT line from the class on which your new class is based. In the example, this is #CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
In the FORMAT line for the class COMPANY_END_MILLS, insert the CID field after the UGST field and before the DESCR field. The first part of the line should look like this:
FORMAT LIBRF         T    ST   UGT  UGST CID DESCR
#                                        –——
Save the file.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\metric folder, open the tool_database.dat file and repeat steps 2 through 6.
Next Step
> 3. Define the new attribute

The new attribute, CompanyID, identifies a tool throughout your company.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\ folder, open the file dbc_tool_ascii.def.
In the DB_ALIAS area, copy the LIBRF alias and us it as a template to create a new alias for CompanyID.
 DB_ALIAS  libref 
        {
           DB_ID        LIBRF
           DB_ID_TYPE   s
           DIALOG_NAME "Libref"
           RSET_NAME   "Libref"
        } 
DB_ALIAS  companyid 
        {
           DB_ID        CID
           DB_ID_TYPE   s
           DIALOG_NAME "Company ID"
           RSET_NAME   "Company ID"
        }
DB_ALIAS defines the text string that is used in Tcl procedures and elsewhere in the dbc_tool_ascii.def file to refer to the attribute.
DB_ID defines the attribute’s column title that is used in the FORMAT statement in the database.dat files.
DIALOG_NAME defines the caption that appears in the Search Criteria dialog box.
RSET_NAME defines the caption that appears in the Search Results dialog box.
Save the file, but keep it open for the next procedure.
Next Step
> 4. Add COMPANY_END_MILLS to the Library Class Selection dialog box

Document Title: 4. Add COMPANY_END_MILLS to the Library Class Selection dialog box
Document Body:
Continue to edit the file dbc_tool_ascii.def.
Search for the comment that contains The Class Hierarchy.
In the structure CLASS MILLING, after the definition CLASS END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE, add this code:
CLASS COMPANY_END_MILLS
      {
        TYPE QRY
        QUERY  "[DB(SubType)] == [76]"
        FILE "qry=shank_mill_schema;rset=shank_mill_schema;" 
        DIALOG
        RSET
        UI_NAME "Company End Mills"
      }
Notice that the subtype value 76 is going to be used for the new class.
Add the attributes for the Search Criteria dialog box in the DIALOG line by copying the DIALOG attributes from the class END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
In the DIALOG line for COMPANY_END_MILLS, insert the alias for the new attribute, companyid, after the alias libref:
        DIALOG libref companyid Diameter FluteLength CorRadMill TaperAngleB TaperedSDia Material Holder Descr
Add the attributes for the Search Results dialog box in the RSET line by copying the RSET attributes from the class END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE.
In the RSET line for COMPANY_END_MILLS, insert the alias for the new attribute, companyid, after the alias libref:
        RSET   libref companyid Descr Diameter FluteLength CorRadMill TaperAngleB TaperedSDia MaterialDes HolderDes HolderRef
Save the file.
Next Step
> 5. Add the COMPANY_END_MILLS subtype in the tool build

Document Title: 5. Add the COMPANY_END_MILLS subtype in the tool build
Document Body:
There may be hard-coded checks for the class that you care customizing, for example, in order to add a parameter to specific subclasses.
The ASC_build_end_mill procedure includes such a check. You must add your subclass to the checking code.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii\ folder, open the file dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl.
Find the line that contains this comment:
# Output tip angle for end mill
In the next line, you must provide for the possibility that an end mill has your new subtype, 76. You will insert a logical or condition.
Change the next line that checks end mill subtypes to determine whether to add a tip angle. Change it from this:
if {$asc_lib_subtype == 1 || $asc_lib_subtype == 2} {
to this:
if {$asc_lib_subtype == 1 || $asc_lib_subtype == 2 || $asc_lib_subtype == 76} {
If you did the previous example, the statement will look like this:
if {$asc_lib_subtype == 1 || $asc_lib_subtype == 2 || $asc_lib_subtype == 75} || $asc_lib_subtype == 76} {
Save the file.
Next Step
> 6. Enable export for COMPANY_END_MILLS

In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii folder, open the file dbc_tool_ascii_export.tcl.
In proc ASC_ask_missing_aliases, declare the new attribute COMPANY_ID.
    global dbc_libref
    global companyid
You must not insert the dbc_ prefix for user-defined attributes. The prefix is reserved for the default set of attributes.
In proc ASC_ask_missing_aliases, in the holding system area, add COMPANY_END_MILLS to the list of classes that use holding systems.
#  First, add Holding system for all classes which use it
    switch -- $dbc_class \
    {
        "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE" -
        "END_MILL_INDEXABLE" -
        "MY_END_MILLS" -
        "COMPANY_END_MILLS" -
In proc ASC_ask_missing_aliases, in the class specific attributes area, add the companyid attribute for the COMPANY_END_MILLS class.
#  Now for more class specific attributes
if { [string compare $dbc_class "COMPANY_END_MILLS"] == 0 } \
{
    set dbc_tmp_aliases($dbc_att_count) "companyid"
    if {$db_row > -1} \
    {
        set dbc_template_attributes($dbc_att_count) [ASC_ask_att_val companyid $db_row "" "" flag]
    } else \
    {
        set dbc_template_attributes($dbc_att_count) ""
    }
    incr dbc_att_count
}
In proc ASC_build_tool_record, add COMPANY_END_MILLS.
Because the class COMPANY_END_MILLS has the company ID attribute in addition to those for other end mills, you must insert one of the following cases in the switch -- $dbc_class code, depending on how you plan to handle the build procedure when $dbc_class is COMPANY_END_MILLS.
If you plan to modify the existing build procedure, ASC_build_end_mills, insert this statement:
        "COMPANY_END_MILLS"
        {
            set asc_lib_subtype 76
            set asc_nx_subtype 1
            ASC_build_end_mill
        }
If you plan to create a new build procedure for company end mills, ASC_build_company_end_mill, insert this statement:
        "COMPANY_END_MILLS"
        {
            set asc_lib_subtype 76
            set asc_nx_subtype 1
            ASC_build_company_end_mill
        }
Save the file.
Next Step
> 7. Write a build procedure for the new COMPANY_END_MILLS class

Document Title: 7. Write a build procedure for the new COMPANY_END_MILLS class
Document Body:
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii folder, open the file dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl.
Copy the procedure proc ASC_build_end_mill, and rename it to create the new build procedure proc ASC_build_company_end_mill.
In the new procedure proc ASC_build_company_end_mill, declare the new attribute.
proc ASC_build_company_end_mill { } \
{
    global dbc_libref
    global companyid
You must not insert the dbc_ prefix for user-defined attributes. The prefix is reserved for the default set of attributes.
Add the new attribute to the tool record. Place the append command where you want the record inserted. In this case, it is immediately after the UG type and subtype fields.
#  Initialize the record with its libref
    set new_tool_record "DATA | $dbc_libref"
#  Add the library and UG type and subtype fields
    append new_tool_record " | 02 | $asc_lib_subtype | 01 | $asc_nx_subtype"
#  Add the Company ID
    set asc_lookup_alias "companyid"
    ASC_find_template_alias
    if {$asc_alias_index > -1 } \
    {
        append new_tool_record " | $dbc_template_attributes($asc_alias_index)"
    } else \
    {
        append new_tool_record " | "
    }
Save the file.
Next Step
> 8. Modify an existing build procedure for the new COMPANY_END_MILLS class

Document Title: 8. Modify an existing build procedure for the new COMPANY_END_MILLS class
Document Body:
You can include an if statement in an existing build procedure so that your new attribute is processed only for your new tool class.
The build procedure proc ASC_build_end_mill requires only a small change to build COMPANY_END_MILLS.
In the ${UGII_BASE_DIR}\MACH\resource\library\tool\ascii folder, open the file dbc_tool_build_ascii.tcl.
In proc ASC_build_end_mill, declare the new attribute companyid.
proc ASC_build_end_mill { } \
{
    global dbc_libref
    global companyid
You must not insert the dbc_ prefix for user-defined attributes. The prefix is reserved for the default set of attributes.
Locate this code:
#  Initialize the record with its libref
    set new_tool_record "DATA | $dbc_libref"
#  Add the library and UG type and subtype fields
    append new_tool_record " | 02 | $asc_lib_subtype | 01 | $asc_nx_subtype"
After the code shown, insert code to process companyid only for COMPANY_END_MILLS, subtype 76.
#  Add the Company ID attribute if the tool class is COMPANY_END_MILLS
    if { $asc_lib_subtype == 76} \
    {
        set asc_lookup_alias "companyid"
        ASC_find_template_alias
        if {$asc_alias_index > -1 } \
        {
            append new_tool_record " | $dbc_template_attributes($asc_alias_index)"
        } else \
        {
            append new_tool_record " | "
        }
    }
Save the file.
Next Step
> 9. Map COMPANY_END_MILLS to the class hierarchy

Document Title: 9. Map COMPANY_END_MILLS to the class hierarchy

Document Body:
You will make additional edits in the file dbc_tool_general.tcl. These changes permit the ugti prefix before the tool number to reflect the type and subtype. For example, without this code, the prefix would be ugti0000_. With this code, the prefix includes the library type T and subtype ST: ugti0276_.
Locate these comment lines:
#
# Milling tool subtypes (I=Indexable, NI Non Indexable)
# 
You are going to insert to code to define your custom subtype after the code that sets non-indexable and indexable end mills.
After the line that reads set uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL) "2", insert this line:
   set uglib_tl_stype(COMPANY_END_MILLS) "76"
The first few lines of code should read like this:
#
# Milling tool subtypes (I=Indexable, NI Non Indexable)
# 
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_END_MILL)      "1"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL)       "2"
   set uglib_tl_stype(COMPANY_END_MILLS) "76"
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_BALL_MILL)     "3"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_BALL_MILL)      "4"
If you did the previous example, the code will look like this:
#
# Milling tool subtypes (I=Indexable, NI Non Indexable)
# 
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_END_MILL)      "1"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL)       "2"
   set uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS)     "75"
   set uglib_tl_stype(COMPANY_END_MILLS) "76"
   set uglib_tl_stype(NI_BALL_MILL)     "3"
   set uglib_tl_stype(I_BALL_MILL)      "4"
In proc UGLIB_ask_class_type_and_subtype { }, in the code that handles $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE", insert code to handle $dbc_class == "COMPANY_END_MILLS".
    } elseif { $dbc_class == "COMPANY_END_MILLS" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(COMPANY_END_MILLS)
If you did the earlier example, the first few lines of code should look like this:
#  Start with milling tools
    if { $dbc_class == "END_MILL_NON_INDEXABLE" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(NI_END_MILL)
    } elseif { $dbc_class == "MY_END_MILLS" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(MY_END_MILLS)
    } elseif { $dbc_class == "COMPANY_END_MILLS" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(COMPANY_END_MILLS)
    } elseif {$dbc_class == "END_MILL_INDEXABLE" } \
    {
        set dbc_class_type $uglib_tl_type(MILL)
        set dbc_class_subtype $uglib_tl_stype(I_END_MILL)
Save the file.
Final Step
> 11. Test the COMPANY_END_MILLS class

When you customize NX, you should always test your changes.
You should test the class by exporting a tool and retrieving it.
If errors occur, refer to the TCL_ERROR feedback in your log file.
In NX, edit a tool that does not belong to a library. If necessary, create a new tool.
To determine whether a tool belongs to a library, in the editing dialog box, on the Tool tab, in the Library group, verify that the Library Reference box contains no text.
If the tool belongs to a library, the value of the libref field for the tool in the database is shown.
Click Export Tool to Library .
In the Select Target Class dialog box, select COMPANY_END_MILLS, and click OK.
In the Template Attributes dialog box, in the Attributes to Assign group, in the Company ID box, type a value. For example, you could enter ACME-123.
Click OK.
If the tool is successfully exported, the Export Tool to Library message box display the tool number that was assigned, and the library to which the tool was exported.
In the Export Tool to Library message box, click OK.
In the tool editing dialog box, click Cancel.
Choose Home tab→Insert group→Create Tool .
In the Create Tool dialog box, in the Library group, click Retrieve Tool from Library .
In the Library Class Selection dialog box, under the Milling node, select Company End Mills and click OK.
In the Search Criteria dialog box, click Count Matches .
There should be only one match, the tool you just exported as a test.
Click OK.
In the Search Result dialog box, in the Matching Items list, your newly exported tool should appear. The tool should have ugti0275_xxxx in the Libref column, where xxxx is the next available tool number for user library references. There should be a Company ID column, and it should contain the value you typed earlier.
In the Search Result dialog box, in the Matching Items list, select the tool and click OK.
Your imported tool appears in the part.
The Workflow Add a new class with a custom attribute is complete.

The items you see in these dialogs are determined in the following files:
Tools:
for ascii: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/tool/ascii/dbc_tool_ascii.def
for Teamcenter: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/tool/inclass/dbc_tool_ascii.def
Machines:
for ascii: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/machine/ascii/dbc_machine_ascii.def
for Teamcenter: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/machine/inclass/dbc_machine_ascii.def
Devices:
for ascii: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/device/ascii/dbc_device_ascii.def
for Teamcenter: ${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/device/inclass/dbc_device_ascii.def
Feeds and speeds:
${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/feeds_speeds/ascii/feeds_speeds.def
${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/feeds_speeds/ascii/cut_methods.def
${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/feeds_speeds/ascii/part_materials.def
${UGII_BASE_DIR}/MACH/resource/library/feeds_speeds/ascii/tool_materials.def
These files are composed of two parts: a listing of DB_ALIASes and the class hierarchy. In order to include the attributes of the new class/subclass in the Search Criteria and Search Result Dialogs, as well as including the class itself in the Class Selection Dialog you must:
include each attribute in the listing of DB_ALIASes
include the new class/subclass in the class hierarchy

Document Title: Using custom parameters on library tools
Document Body:
The tool library can contain more parameters than are used in the NX tool definition. When you retrieve a tool in NX, the relevant parameters are mapped to the tool object in the part file. Postprocessors and shop documentation can directly read all parameters in the database. Database parameters are visible in NX only if they are assigned a location in the dialog box in the dialog box template file. You can customize NX to add additional parameters to a tool that you retrieve from the tool library. You can define these additional parameters either in Tcl code or as fields in the tool database.
Flow of parameters from database to end user
An NX postprocessor and shop documentation can read tool parameters directly from the tool database.
When you add custom parameters to a class, the postprocessor and the shop documentation can query their values.
NX maps tool parameters form the database to tool objects. The tool dialog box provides user access to the parameters. NX transfers these values to the postprocessor and to shop documentation as MOM variables.
If your custom parameters are things like a text string that describes the plant where a tool is available, or the tool crib within a plant where the tool is stored, you could transfer it directly to the machinist in the form of postprocessor-created comments or shop documentation.
If you want the NX CAM programmer to see and edit these custom tool parameters, you need to add them to the tool dialog box. With custom parameters in the dialog box, instead of the flow of information being directly from the library to the post, it goes through the NX CAM programmer.
Note:
It is not necessary to customize your tool library database to provide parameters that do not have a varying value. You can do that entirely within Tcl by following the example provided.
The chart shows the flow of parameters between the tool library, the template part that determines the user interface, the NX CAM tool, and postprocessor or shop documentation.
To add user parameters that do not exist in the library, you must:
Create a program called dbc_tool_ud_data.tcl in the folder that is identified by the UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ASCII_DIR environment variable.
In the program, define the parameters, including the user interface, variable names, data types, default values, and user interface labels.
A sample Tcl file is provided, dbc_tool_ud_data_sample.tcl. When you retrieve a library tool, this program creates one new user parameter of each type. It includes two examples of how to provide an existing tool parameter for user modification.

This example describes how to create custom user-defined parameters for library tools.
In the folder described by the environment variable UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_TOOL_ASCII_DIR, copy and rename the file dbc_tool_ud_data_sample.tcl to dbc_tool_ud_data.tcl.
The program that handles tool parameters, dbc_tool_ascii.tcl, contains code that sources this file if it exists.
Test the action of the sample program before you make modifications.
In a new NX session, retrieve a tool from the tool library.
Note:
Custom user-defined tool parameters apply only to library tools.
In the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, right-click the tool that you retrieved and choose Information.
The bottom of the listing should contain the following lines:
User Tool Parameters
 Sample Integer = -1
 Sample Double = -1.000000
 Sample Toggle (Boolean) = True
 Sample Text (String) = default text
 Sample Option List = Yes
Depending on the type of tool that you retrieve, it may also contain lines similar to the following:
 Taper Angle (Library TAPA) = 0.000000
 Tip Angle (Library TIPA) = 0.000000
In a plain text editor, open dbc_tool_ud_data.tcl and examine the program for the following procedures.
Note:
A plain text editor is one that does not add hidden formatting characters to the file. A few examples of plain text editors are Notepad, Notepad++, and TextPad.
The program begins with a number of utility procedures. There is no reason to change any of these.
Notice the common structure that is used for parameters: name, type, value, and label become elements in a row of the parameter array.
proc SetParameter { name pType value label } is called for integers (pType="i"), decimal number or double numbers (pType="d"), Boolean values (pType="b"), and text strings (pType="s").
proc SetOptionParameter { name value values label } is called for the more complexly structured option lists (pType="o"). Here, value is the default value that appears in the list, and values is an array of possible values. The type parameter is not needed; in Tcl, everything is a string, so it does not matter.
The next procedure, AskAttVal { attId dbRow outputFormat defaultValue flagRef }, gets the value of a parameter from a row in the database and returns a flag indicating failure or degrees of success.
The procedure FindEntry {} gets a row of data from the database.
The procedure DBC_ud_data {} is the area that you can customize.
In the body of the DBC_ud_data procedure, after the variable declarations and the initialization of a variable that tracks the number of parameters, set dbc_ud_num_parameters 0, remove or comment out lines for parameter types that you are not going to use.
Add rows or modify the sample rows for data types that you require.
For data types “i”, “d”, “b”, and “s”, new data is created by a simple procedure call of the format:
SetParameter "parameter name" "type" numeric_value "Label"
or
SetParameter "parameter name" "type" "boolean or string value" "Label"
For the option list, you must set values and value before you call SetOptionParameter. Notice that the method used to set the default value value is the statement set value [lindex $values 0]. The second argument to lindex is a reference to the zero-based index of the default choice, within the array of possible values choices. For the example list with the values { "Yes" "No" "Maybe" }, valid values for the second argument of the lindex command are 0, 1, and 2. If you used 3, you would get an error message because the array reference would be out of bounds.
Save the program, and, in a new NX session, retrieve a tool from the tool library to test your changes.
If you want to read fields from the tool database and define those as user defined parameters, follow the example at the end of the procedure; otherwise, you can safely delete or comment out this section of code.
The example uses specific parameters TAPA and TIPA if they apply to the tool that is retrieved. It uses the return value of the AskAttVal procedure to determine whether or not to create a parameter.
Save the program, and, in a new NX session, retrieve a tool from the tool library to test your changes.
This procedure adds user parameters to library tools as they are retrieved and makes them available to the postprocessor and to shop documentation.
Note:
This program does not:
Modify your database
Apply to tools created in NX
Make parameters visible to NX users

Document Title: Add a user interface for custom tool parameters
Document Body:
Currently, you must customize the dialog boxes for each type of tool template for which you require user parameters.
This example describes the process of adding parameters to all mill tools in the metric library. The procedure for the English unit library is identical, except for the location of the template file. The procedure to add parameters to other tool types is the same.
In NX, navigate to your UGII_CAM_TEMPLATE_PART_METRIC_DIR and open library_dialogs.prt.
In the Machine Tool view of the Operation Navigator, scroll down to the MILL tool.
Generally, scroll to the template for the first type of tool to which you are going to add parameters.
Right-click the node and choose Object→Customize.
In the Customize Dialog dialog box, in the Items Used list, expand the tab page on which you want the user parameters to appear.
Select the group to which you want to add the user parameters as a subgroup.
For this example, select the Dimensions group under Tab Page: Tool.
You can also make the user parameters a separate group. You will come to that step in a moment.
In the Items to Add group, from the Dialog Item Type list, select Customizable Items.
From the Items to Add list, select User Parameters.
If the option is not available, it has already been added somewhere in the dialog box.
Click Add to Dialog .
The Items Used list should resemble this:
– Tab Page: Tool
   + Group: Legend
   – Group: Dimensions
         (D) Diameter
         (R1) Lower Radius
         (B) Taper Angle
         (A) Tip Angle
         (L) Length
         (FL) Flute Length
         User Parameters
   + Group: Description
   + Group: Numbers
   + Group: Offsets
   + Group: Information
   + Group: Library
+ Tab Page: Shank
+ Tab Page: Holder
+ Tab Page: More
    Display
You can click Move Up and Move Down as many times as necessary to position a dialog box item that is selected in the list.
(Optional) To place the User Parameters group below the Dimensions group and above the Description group, click Move Down once.
The Items Used list should resemble this:
– Tab Page: Tool
   + Group: Legend
   + Group: Dimensions
      User Parameters
   + Group: Description
   + Group: Numbers
   + Group: Offsets
   + Group: Information
   + Group: Library
+ Tab Page: Shank
+ Tab Page: Holder
+ Tab Page: More
    Display
You can click Move Up and Move Down as many times as necessary to position a dialog box item that is selected in the list.
Repeat the steps from Object→Customize to this step for every type of tool to which your user parameters apply.
Save and close the template part.
In NX CAM, verify that newly added library tools have a User Tool Parameters group.
In this example, the User Tool Parameters group is in the dialog box below the Dimensions group and above the Description group.

Document Title: Attributes for new tool classes and subclasses
Document Body:
Every tool type within NX requires its own minimum set of attributes that must appear within its FORMAT line in the tool_database.dat file. These attributes appear in the tool dialog boxes in the Manufacturing application. You can add attributes, but you cannot leave any of the mandatory attributes out.
The mandatory attributes depend on the NX internal type/subtype (class/subclass) to which the library type/subtype has been mapped. If you add a new tool type to the tool_database.dat file, you must map your new type/subtype to a Manufacturing type/subtype.

The Manufacturing processors include tool information in their tool path calculations. These processors recognize a limited number of tool classes and subclasses. Those recognized are found in dbc_tool_general.tcl. When you set up a class hierarchy in the Library, it is essential that you map any class you use or create to one of these internal Manufacturing tool classes. The standard Library installation performs the mapping shown below. In an ASCII database, the system uses the UGT and UGST attributes. In Teamcenter, you perform the mapping by using the pull-down menu in attribute number -5110, UG tool type.
Note:
Legacy tool types are for tools converted from old part file tool libraries.

How the Manufacturing Resource Library maps attributes
The tables for mandatory parameter show how Manufacturing Resource Library (MRL) attributes are mapped to attributes in NX Manufacturing. If multiple MRL attributes can map to a single NX attribute, the tables indicate the mapping precedence.
In the following example, the Manufacturing Resource Library maps the cutter length, dbc_cutter_height(0) to the MRL attributes in the following order of precedence.
-45260 DCL Cutting Diameter Length if it exists.
-45002 Nomin. Setup X if it exists.
If the MRL Default Value column lists the attribute as Mandatory, the attribute does not have a default value. You must enter the value in Teamcenter.

The following is a list of mandatory attributes for a 5-Parameter Milling Tool. The data for these attributes must be contained in the .dat file. If you would like to include any of these attributes as search criteria, they must also be defined as a DB_ALIAS in the .def file.
Note:
If an attribute is Mandatory, it does not have a default value. You must enter the value in Teamcenter.
* These parameters do not appear in the dialog but the DBC variable must be set.
Special case 1: SIG1, DC1N, and DCNN are defined. The relevant tool assembly classes are counter sinking tools and center drills.
Special case 2: PRFA is defined. The relevant tool assembly classes are chamfer and engraving milling tools.
Special case 3: KAPR is defined. The relevant tool assembly classes are face mills indexable and angle mills.
5-Parameter Milling Tool
Library Type (ASCII File Attribute T) = 02
Library Subtype (ASCII File Attribute ST) = 90

Here is a list of mandatory attributes for a Chamfer Mill tool. The data for these attributes must be contained in the .dat file. If you would like to include any of these attributes as search criteria, then they must also be defined as a DB_ALIAS in the .def file:
Note:
If an attribute is Mandatory, it does not have a default value. You must enter the value in Teamcenter.
* These parameters do not appear in the dialog but the DBC variable must be set.
Special case 1: KCH and CHW are defined. These attributes are not yet added to the MRL tool assembly classes.
Special case 2: PRFA is defined. The relevant tool assembly classes are chamfer and engraving milling tools.
Special case 3: KAPR is defined. The relevant tool assembly classes are face mills indexable and angle mills.

Step Drill
Here is a list of the mandatory parameters for a step drill. The data for these attributes must be contained in the .dat file. If you would like to include any of these attributes as search criteria, then they must also be defined as a DB_ALIAS in the .def file.
The step drill parameters used by NX and the NX Library vary. You must input the parameters shown below. The system then uses these parameters to calculate those parameters required by NX.
Note:
If an attribute is Mandatory, it does not have a default value. You must enter the value in Teamcenter.
* These parameters do not appear in the dialog but the DBC variable must be set.
Drill step parameter values are stored in the segmented_tool_database.dat file.
Example:
FORMAT     LIBRF      T STYPE SEQ    DIAM        HEI        ANGLE        RAD
DATA | ugt0304_1002 | 1 | 1 | 0 |  12.00000 |  10.00000 |   0.17453 |   0.00000
DATA | ugt0304_1002 | 1 | 1 | 1 |  20.00000 |  20.00000 |   0.00000 |   0.00000
DATA | ugt0304_1002 | 1 | 1 | 2 |  30.00000 |  30.00000 |   0.05236 |   0.00000
DATA | ugt0304_1002 | 1 | 1 | 3 |  40.00000 |  40.00000 |   0.06981 |   0.00000
