Document Title: Customizing CAM libraries in native NX
Document Body:
The files that configure a native NX library are located in the path defined by several levels of environment variables. You can set any of the variables, other than UGII_BASE_DIR, according to the amount of customization that you intend to perform. UGII_BASE_DIR should always define the location where NX is installed.
UGII_BASE_DIR\MACH\resource\library
UGII_CAM_BASE_DIR\resource\library
UGII_CAM_RESOURCE_DIR\library
UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_DIR
UGII_CAM_RESOURCE_DIR\ug_library
The figure shows the library structure:
library
    device
    feeds_speeds
    machine
    tool
...
ug_library

When you customize a library, you can modify .dat files, .def files, and sometimes .tcl files.
.dat data files
The .dat files contain the data for each library.
tool\english\tool_database.dat, tool\metric\tool_database.dat, tool\english\holder_database.dat, and tool\metric\holder_database.dat contain the tool and holder data.
machine\ascii\machine_database.dat contains machine tool data.
device\ascii\device_database.dat contains the machine devices.
feeds_speeds\ascii\feeds_speeds.dat contains the feeds and speeds data.
.def definition files
Each definition file contains two parts. The first part defines the DB_ALIAS list, which lists attributes that appear in the Search Criteria dialog box and maps them to data types. The second part defines the class hierarchy that appears in the Library Class Selection dialog box.
tool\ascii\dbc_tool_ascii.def
tool\ascii\holder_ascii.def
machine\ascii\dbc_machine_ascii.def
device\ascii\dbc_device_ascii.def
feeds_speeds\ascii\feeds_speeds.def
.tcl Tcl scripts
These scripts perform tasks such as parsing variables to define complete file names, setting variable values, defining procedures, and sourcing shared scripts.
Warning:
Modify these files only if you are skilled in Tcl programming.

The Cloud Connect Tool Manager is a graphic-based interface that makes it easy for you to manage tools, components, and tool assemblies.
Use the Tool, Component, and Tool Assembly modules in Cloud Connect Tool Manager to manage your tools in the NX tool libraries. Each of these modules has several display modes and search filters to control the view of items in the displayed list. When you create or edit a tool, component, or assembly, the wizard style interface provides a dynamic preview for editing and validation.
You can also use Access Tool Vendor to connect to an approved vendor's website, and download tools to the NX tool libraries.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Cloud Connect Tool Manager
Ribbon Bar
Home tab→Tools group→Cloud Connect Tool Manager

Four Cloud Connect Tool Manager modules allow you to manage tools, components, and tool assemblies.
Tools
This module allows you to create, edit, and delete tools in the library. You can also send tools directly to your current CAM setup part file with Send tool to NX.
Components
This module allows you to create, edit, and delete components in the library.
Tool Assembly
This module allows you to create, edit, and delete tool assemblies in the library. You can also send tool assemblies directly to your current CAM setup part file with Send tool to NX.
Access Tool Vendor
This module allows you to select a tool from a vendor catalog, and download the tool to the NX tool library or to your CAM setup part file. You can select ...send to NX tool to see a preview of the tool.

Document Title: Cloud Connect Tool Manager dialog box
Document Body:
Using this dialog box, you manage tools, components, and tool assemblies.
Cloud Connect Tool Manager
Side bar (1)
Commands to select the tool, component, assembly, or vendor modules.
Siemens
For the current session, returns to the previous selection in the Cloud Connect Tool Manager history.
Tools
Filters to show tools in the NX tool library. This module allows you to create, edit, and delete tools in the library. You can also send tools directly to your current CAM setup part file with Send tool to NX.
Components
Filters to show components in the NX tool library, such as holders. This module allows you to create, edit, and delete components in the library.
Tool Assembly
Filters to show tool assemblies in the NX tool library. This module allows you to create, edit, and delete tool assemblies in the library. You can also send tool assemblies directly to your current CAM setup part file with Send tool to NX.
Access Tool Vendor
Filters to show links of approved tool vendors. This module allows you to select a tool from a vendor catalog, and download the tool to the NX tool library or to your CAM setup part file.
When you select a tool from the catalog, select ...send to NX tool to see a preview of the tool. In the preview window, select one of these options to continue:
Import to Library
Import and Send to NX
Cancel
Import Existing Assembly Data
Imports a tool with holder from the tool database to the assembly database.
Info
Displays information about the current software version.
Ribbon bar (2)
Commands to manage the items in the displayed list.
Display mode. Allows you to click to select a display mode.
Card
Displays a card view of each item in the window. The item cards are displayed in rows, and each card contains a graphic, name, description, and additional information such as the NX library reference (Libref).
List with Summary
Displays a summary view of items in the window. The item cards are displayed vertically in the left section of the window, and each card contains a graphic, name, description, and additional information such as the Libref.
When you select an item in the displayed list, the middle section of the window displays a table of editable parameters, and additional information. The right section of the window displays a graphic of the tool, component, or assembly and the editable dimensions.
Table
Displays all the editable parameters for each item in a tabulated list in the window.
Table with Summary
Displays all the editable parameters for each item in a tabulated list in the left section of the window.
When you select an item in the displayed list, the middle section of the window displays a table of editable parameters, and additional information. The right section of the window displays a graphic of the tool, component, or assembly and the editable dimensions.
New
Allows you to create a new tool, component, or assembly in the NX tool library.
For example, in the Tool module this displays the Create New Tool dialog box. You can define the tool parameters that are displayed in the General, Cutter, Shank, and More panes.
Edit
Allows you to edit the parameters of the selected tool, component, or assembly in the NX tool library.
For example, in the Tool module this opens the Edit tool dialog box. You can edit the tool parameters that are displayed in the General, Cutter, Shank, and More panes.
Duplicate
Allows you to create a duplicate of the selected tool, component, or assembly in the NX tool library.
Delete
Allows you to delete the selected tool, component, or assembly from the NX tool library.
Send tool to NX
Sends the selected tool or assembly to the active part in NX.
More Commands
Displays the list of commands.
Units (3)
Selects the metric (mm) or English (inch) database of the NX tool library.
Filters (4)
Allows you to filter the items shown in the displayed list.
Manufacturing type
Allows you to select Milling or Drilling from the dropdown list.
Tool or component type
Allows you to select the tool or component type from the dropdown list.
Add Search Criteria
Allows you to enter a text string for a name, or parameter with search conditions, such as >10.
List (5)
The resulting list of tools, components, or tool assemblies that are displayed after the filters are applied.
Note:
The display of items in a vendor catalog is controlled by the vendor website.

The Machining Data library stores machining parameters for reuse. It sets the speed, feeds, depth of cut, and stepover values based on the current cutting conditions. The Machining Data library improves on the Feeds and Speeds library (which only sets the speed and feed values) for milling. To efficiently cut similar parts, determine the optimum parameter settings for your cutting conditions, and add them to the Machining Data Library. Any user can then apply these settings to his/her operations. The library uses three primary inputs from the operation: Tool Material, Part Material, and Cut Method. The secondary inputs are Tool Diameter and Tool Length.
Note:
Machining Data libraries are typically set up by a site administrator. You must have write access to the library files to edit them.
Turning operations do not use the Machining Data libraries. Turning operations use the Feeds and Speeds library.
What Parameters are Stored
The Machining Data library stores the parameters listed in the following tables.
Parameters Input from the Operation and Matched to Library Records
Primary Filters (exact match)
Secondary Filters
Tool Material
Cut Method
Part Material
Tool Diameter
Tool Length
In the operation, the tool material, diameter, and length are inherited from the Tool parent, the Cut method is inherited from the Method parent, and the Part material is inherited from the geometry parent or the setup. All three of these parents must have valid library entries for you to use the machining data system to set the operation's cutting parameters. Please see Accessing the Cut Method Library for more information on setting the Cut method, Part Material, and Tool material.
Parameters Output from the Library to the Operation
Cut Depth*
Stepover*
Surface Speed
Feed per Tooth
Speeds - % of Cut feed rate
Approach
Engage
First Cut
Stepover
Retract
Return
Departure
* Cut depth and stepover values are optional for individual machining data records.
To set the values, select the Cut Depth or Stepover check boxes.
If you do not set the values, NX saves the machining record with a -1 entry in the Cut Depth and Stepover columns. The -1 tells NX not to set a value.
Standard Machining Data Library data
The Machining Data library contains fully defined high speed machining (HSM) operation data for combinations of the following:
Tool Material
HSM Carbide Ball Mill, Solid, TiAlN Coated (Libref: TMC0_00021)
HSM Carbide End Mill, Solid, TiAlN Coated, < 5% corner (Libref: TMC0_00022)
HSM Carbide Bull Nose, TiAlN Coated, > 5% corner (Libref: TMC0_00027)
Bull Nose Inserted (Libref: TMC0_00023)
End Mill Inserted, (Libref: TMC0_00025)
Ball Mill Inserted, (Libref: TMC0_00026)
End Mill Misc, hard cut, extra long (Libref: TMC0_00028)
Cut Method
HSM Rough Milling (Libref:OPD0_00021)
HSM Semi Finish Milling (Libref:OPD0_00022)
HSM Finish Milling (Libref:OPD0_00023)
Part Material (with proven machining data)
P20, Prehardened, 33–33 HRc (Libref: MAT0_00600)
M416, Prehardened, 40–44 HRc (Libref: MAT0_00700)
H13, Prehardened, 50-54 HRc(Libref: MAT0_01100)
A2/Calmax, 58 Hrc (Libref: MAT0_01200)
D2, 58-61 HRc (Libref: MAT0_01300)
High Tensile 7079 Aluminum (Libref: MAT0_ 02100)
Copper (Libref: MAT0_02200)
Tool Diameter ranging from 1 mm  (0.0394 in)  to 25 mm (0.9449 in)
Tool Length ranging from 3 mm (0.1181in)  to 168 mm (6.6142 in)
Note:
Not all combinations of tools and part material are available.
Use the End Mill tool type for tools with corner radii that is less than 5% of the tool diameter.
Use the Bull Nose tool type for tools with corner radii ranging from 5% to 20% of the tool diameter.
Only use the End Mill tool type (with no corner radii) for wall and floor finishing. Set the type to Bull Nose for regular roughing.
Tool length/diameter ratios of 3 and 5 are supported. Machine data for all other length/diameter ratios are interpolated.
References to Other Libraries
The Machining Data Library references entries within other manufacturing libraries. These libraries are shared with the feeds and speeds system, so changes to these tables may affect both feeds and speeds and machining data calculations. Modifying or deleting an entry within the Machining Data Library doesn't affect the referenced entry in any other library. The Machining Data Library references the following libraries (tables):
Part Material
Tool Material
Cut Method
Cutting Tools
Machine Tools (Machines)
In addition, if you have used the feeds and speeds system to store machining data, you can import data from the Feeds and Speeds library into the Machining Data library.
Sample Entry
A sample entry for a P20 Mold Steel part (MAT0_00464), cut with an HSM Carbide Ball Mill (TMC0_00021), using the HSM Rough Milling cut method (OPD0_00021) ), and displayed in inches, would be:
Libref
Diameter
Length
Cut Depth
Stepover
Surface Speed
Feed per Tooth
THSO_00299
.9449
2.8346
0.1504
0.1890
853.0184
0.0087
Approach %
Engage %
First Cut %
Stepover %
Retract %
Return %
Departure %
0
80
60
60
0
0
0
Note:
 Library values are stored in both inch and metric units. You can display values in either units.

Feeds and speeds information results from a combination of cut method, tool material, part material and depth of cut information. Each of these information types is stored in a separate library.
The Feeds and Speeds library contains records of surface speed and feed per tooth recommendations. Each of these records is based on a part material tool material, cut method and depth of cut.
Note:
The Feeds and Speeds library is provided for legacy operations and turning operations. The Machining Data library replaces the Feeds and Speeds library for milling, provides more functionality, and should be used for new work. See The Machining Data Library for more information.
Note:
Automatic feed and speed calculation is not supported for user defined milling tools.
Reset from Table
You can access the Feeds and Speeds Library by using the Reset from Table button in the feed rates dialog. When you select this button for an operation the following takes place.
The system reads the part material from the geometry parent.
The system reads the tool material from the tool parent.
The system reads the cut method from the method parent.
The system reads the depth of cut from the operation.
The system sends these four values to the Feeds and Speeds Library.
NX Library searches the Feeds and Speeds Library for a matching record.
The library returns recommendations for surface speed and feed per tooth.
The feed rates dialog calculates the spindle speed and various feed rates based on the processor you are in. Each processor determines which feed rates are calculated. Some feed rate values are set as percentages of cut feed rate. This relationship is defined in the event handler. You can also manually enter the other feed rate values. See the documentation for the feed rates dialog in each processor.
Note:
You can only use the Reset from Table option if you have already set the cut method, tool material and part material.
Note:
Once you have used Reset from Table, the feed rates that are calculated using the Feeds and Speeds library are no longer inherited from the method parent.
There are two ways to access the feed rates dialog:
From the operation dialog box.
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Object→Feed Rates
Note:
If you select multiple operations, NX uses the calculation for the first operation for all the selected operations. For operations that use different tools, part materials, or cut methods, select each operation individually.
For more information on the feed rates dialog see the feed rates section in the Object-Start Post, End Post, feed rates section.
Accessing the Cut Method Library
Set the cut method in the Cut Method Dialog. This dialog may be reached in the following ways:
In the Operation Navigator method view, at the location where you want to access the Cut Method Library, choose Insert→Method.
Choose Menu→Insert→Method.
Use the Create Method icon .
then
Press OK or Apply to open the Method Dialog.
Choose the Cut Method button to open the Search Result dialog of the Cut Method Library.
Select desired cut method from the Cut Method Library.
Accessing the Tool Material Library
Set the tool material in the Tool dialog. This dialog may be reached in the following ways:
Double-click on an existing tool in the tool view of the Operation Navigator.
In the Operation Navigator tool view, right-click where you want to access the Tool Material Library, and choose Insert→Tool.
Use the Create Tool icon .
then
Select the Material button to open the Search Result Dialog for the Tool Material Library.
Select the desired tool material from the Tool Material Library.
Accessing the Part Material Library
You can set the part material either from the setup, or in a Workpiece or Mill_Geom geometry group . If you have not selected the part material in the geometry group, the group inherits the material from its geometry parent or the setup. The material in the setup is the default material for geometry groups.
To set the part material in the setup, choose Menu→Tools→ Part Material and select the desired part material from the Part Material Library.
To set the part material at the geometry group level go to the Workpiece or Mill_Geom Dialog. This dialog may be reached in three ways:
Double-click on an existing workpiece in the geometry view of the Operation Navigator.
In the Operation Navigator geometry view, right-click where you want to access the Part Material Library, and choose Insert→Geometry.
Use the Create Geometry Icon and select Workpiece or Mill_Geom.
then
Select the Material button to open the Search Result Dialog for the Part Material Library.
Select the desired tool material from the Part Material Library.

You can make changes to the Machining Data for a native NX ascii library.
In the library, you can make these edits:
Add or modify machining parameters based on part material, tool material, and cut method.
Enter machining data for a specific library tool.
Import from the Feeds and Speeds Library.
Import known machining data from a comma separated value (csv) file.
Delete records.
Note:
If machining data is managed in Teamcenter, you can edit in Teamcenter Resource Manager.
Machining Data libraries are typically set up by a site administrator. You must have write access to the library files to edit them.
Because you can't undo individual edits, use the Apply button to save your work as you go.
Setting machining data values to zero
The table shows the resulting operation settings when you set certain parameter values to zero.
Parameter
Machining Data Record setting
Result: Feeds and Speeds setting in the operation
Approach
0
Rapid
Engage
0
Rapid
First Cut
0
100 %Cut
Stepover
0
100 %Cut
Retract
0
Rapid
Return
0
Rapid (Not shown in the operation dialog box.)
Departure
0
Rapid (Not shown in the operation dialog box.)
Note:
Last Cut and Cross Over
The Last Cut and Cross Over parameters are not shown in the machining data library, but NX automatically sets them to 100 %Cut in drilling operations only.
If required, manually change values after applying the machining data.
Traversal
Traversal is not supported in the machining data library. You must manually set this parameter in the operation or in the machining method group.
Operations inherit parameters from the machining method group.
First Cut and Step Over
To avoid rapid motions when the tool contacts the target part, set First Cut and Step Over motions to 100% of the cut feed rate in the milling or drilling operation.
Motions set to Rapid are non-interpolated G0 motions.
Motions set to %Cut are interpolated G1 motions.

Document Title: Add a Machining Data Library entry
Document Body:
Choose Home tab→Tools group→Edit Machining Data Libraries .
In the the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box, click the Machining Data tab.
In the Primary Filters group, from the Tool Material list, select a material.
From the Cut Method list, select a cut method.
From the Part Material list, select a material.
If you don't see the cut method or material you need, go to the appropriate tab and add the item.
Select the Input Units.
Click Insert.
In the Edit Machining Data Record dialog box, fill in the appropriate fields.
Note:
NX assigns a unique Library Reference string. You can change this to any unique identifier and the system checks for duplicates before saving the record.
If you select a record on the Machining Data tab before you click Insert, NX copies the selected record's values to the new entry. You can use this feature to enter similar records more efficiently.
You must assign values greater than zero for the Tool Diameter, Tool Length, Cut Depth, and Stepover parameters.
Cut depth and stepover are optional parameters. To set the values, select the Cut Depth or Stepover check boxes. If you do not set the values, NX saves the machining record with a -1 entry in the Cut Depth and Stepover columns. The -1 tells NX not to set a value.
You can define surface speed in two ways. Either enter the value directly in the Surface Speed box, or enter a Spindle Speed value and NX calculates the surface speed for you. The Spindle Speed value is not saved with the data record.
You can define the feed per tooth in two ways also. Either enter the value directly in the Feed per Tooth field, or define Cut feed rate, Number of Flutes, and feed rate Units. The feed per tooth is calculated for you. (The  Cut feed rate, Number of Flutes and feed rate Units values aren't saved with the data record.)
Click OK to save the record and return to the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box.
Click Cancel to return without saving the record.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.

Document Title: Add material to the Machining Data Library
Document Body:
Pick Insert to add a new material.
Enter a name and description for the material. You can accept the default Library Reference or assign a different one. Note: The system won't accept a duplicate Library Reference.

Document Title: Add tool machining data to the Machining Data Library
Document Body:
You can assign machining values to tools in the tool library. If NX finds data stored for the library tool, it will apply those values, and not do any other calculations.
Note:
Use this method only when you always want a specific tool to use the same speed, feeds, depth of cut, and stepover values regardless of the part material or cut method.
If there aren't any Tool Machining Data entries, NX searches for other entries in the Machining Data Library.
To assign machining data to tools from the tool library:
Choose Home tab→Tools group→Edit Machining Data Libraries .
In the the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box, click the Tool Machining Data tab .
Click Insert.
Select a tool class from the Library Class Selection dialog (for example: Milling, Thread Mill).
Select the tool in one of the following ways:
If you know the library reference, enter it in the Libref box and press Enter.
Click OK to see a listing of available tools.
In the Search Result dialog box, select the tool and click OK.
Enter the appropriate values in the Edit Machining Data Record dialog box.
Note:
The Library Reference field is inactive. You can't edit this value because it is a link to the tool library.
Click OK to save the record and return to the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box.
Click Cancel to return without saving the record.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.

Document Title: Import data to the Machining Data Library
Document Body:
Importing Library Entries
You can import from these sources:
A comma delimited text file *.csv
The current feeds and speeds library feeds_speeds.dat
Another machine_data.dat file
Import from a text File
Use this when you have machining data stored in some other system, or other file, or use a spreadsheet to manage your machining data. For example, you may have machining data from a tooling supplier that you want to put in to the machining data library. The text file must be comma-delimited, and the field structure must match the field structure of the Machine Data Library.
A sample file called sample_machining_data.csv is located in UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_FEEDS_SPEEDS_ASCII_DIR folder. Prepare your data so that it matches the format of this file.
To import from a text file:
In the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box, click the Import tab.
Click Import Text File.
In the Import Text File dialog box, navigate to and select the text file to import.
Click the Machining Data tab and review the entries that you imported.
If the text file had partial data, select each record and click Modify to add missing values.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.
Import from the feeds and speeds library
Importing from the feeds and speeds library saves time creating records if you want to move data stored in the feeds and speeds library to the machining data library. To import from the feeds and speeds library:
In the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box, click the Import tab.
Click Import Feeds and Speeds.
NX displays the number of records processed in the Information window.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.
Import from another machining data library
In the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog box, click the Import tab.
Click Import Machining Data.
In the Import Machining Data Library dialog box, navigate to and select the text file to import.
In the Information window, review the number of data items that were imported.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.

To modify machining data records:
On the Edit Machining Data Libraries dialog, Machining Data page, select a material from the Tool Material pull-down menu.
Select a cut method from the Cut Method pull-down menu.
Select a part material from the Part Material pull-down menu.
Select the Input Units.
Select a record.
Pick Modify and fill in the appropriate fields on the Edit Machining Data Record dialog.
Pick OK to save the record and return to the Machining Data page. Or, pick Cancel to return to the Machining Data page without saving the record.
When done, select OK or APPLY one last time to save the changes into the libraries.  No data will be saved into any of the libraries until one of these two buttons is pressed.
To modify Cut Method, Tool Material, Part Material, Tool Machining Data or Machines:
Select the tab for the desired library page.
For Tool Machining Data, select the input units.
Select a record.
Pick Modify and fill in the appropriate fields on the edit dialog.
Pick OK to save the record and return to the library page. Or, pick Cancel to return to the library page without saving the record.
When done, select OK or APPLY one last time to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until one of these two buttons is pressed.
Note:
For Machines, you can only modify the Rigidity parameter.

Select the tab for the desired library page.
Select a record.
Click Delete.
Click OK or Apply to save the changes into the libraries.  No data is saved into any of the libraries until you press one of these buttons.
Warning:
If you delete a Cut Method, Tool Material, or Part Material entry that is referenced by machining cata records, NX displays a warning message that shows the number of machining data records that will also be deleted. Click Yes to continue, or No to cancel the delete.  
The following do not have dependencies within the library and do not generate a warning message before deletion:
Cut method, tool material, or part material entries that aren't referenced by a machining data record.
Individual machining data records, or Tool Machining Data records.
If you delete records by mistake, and want to restore them, you must cancel out of the Machining Data Library dialog box. You will lose all edits that you made since the last time you clicked Apply.
The cut method, tool material, and part material libraries must each contain at least one entry. You can't create a machine cata record without this information. If you attempt to delete the last record in any of these libraries, NX displays a warning message and ignores the delete attempt.

Document Title: Set Machining Parameters in an Operation
Document Body:
You can use the Machining Data Library to set parameters in an operation as follows:
set the machining data from the feed rates dialog
set the machining data from the Operation Navigator
automatically update the machining data
To set machining data from the library, an operation must have the following defined:
part material
cut method
tool material
Note:
Cut depth and stepover are optional parameters in the Machining Data library. If these parameters are not defined in the library, NX does not change the respective values for the operation.
Setting from the Feed and Speeds Dialog
To set machining data from an operation:
Create a new operation or edit an existing operation.
If necessary, select a tool for the operation.
Pick Feed Rates on the main operation dialog.
On the Feed and Speeds dialog, pick Set Machining Data.
Customizing an Operation Dialog to Set Machining Data
For convenience, the set machining data button is a customizable item that can be added to the main operation dialog.
For more information on customizing dialogs, see Customizing Dialogs Overview.
Setting Machining Data from the Operation Navigator
To set machining data from the Operation Navigator:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Object→Set Machining Data.
Automatically Updating Machining Data
To ensure that machining data is always updated from the library, choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing→Operation tab→ Machining Data group and select the Automatically Set in Operation check box.
When an operation is created, if the part material, tool material, tool diameter, tool length, and cut method are defined, the machining parameters are calculated and set automatically, just as if you had picked the "Set Machining Data" button in the Feed and Speeds dialog. Whenever one of the input parameters changes, the parameters are set again from the library. For example, if you change the tool diameter, all the parameters are recalculated.
If you override a value in the operation, this is lost when the data is reset from the library.

The Machining Data Libraries dialog box provides an interface for the following libraries:
Machining Data
Cut Method
Part Material
Tool Material
Tool Machining Data
Machines
Note:
You can modify only the Rigidity value for existing machines. Older machines that are less rigid than an ideal machine have greater tool deflection and may require reduced feed rates.
Enter a Rigidity value of less than 1. NX multiplies the Machining Data library values by the Rigidity value to reduce feed rates to optimal values for the machine.
Select a tab to access that library's data. Or, select the Import tab to import data from a text file or the Feeds and Speeds library.
Hint - Because you can't undo individual edits, use the Apply button to save your work as you go.  
Note:
The Import feature only imports existing data into the Machining Data library. You must confirm that the library references exist in the other libraries. If they don't, you can insert the required information. See Editing the Machining Data Library.

Document Title: Machine Data Library Parameter Matching and Interpolation
Document Body:
Matching Parameters
For an operation to retrieve data from the library, its Tool Material, Cut Method, and Part Material (the primary filters) must exactly match entries in the library. Once these are matched, the system looks for matches to Tool Diameter and Tool Length (the secondary filters).
Tool Length (L) includes tool length and shank length without the holder offset.
Tool Length （L) = Tool Length + Shank Length - Holder Offset (OS)
The library returns parameter values as follows:
Is there a close match for Tool Diameter (D) and Tool Length (L)?
Yes: Assign the stored parameter values to the operation.
If not, is there a close match for Tool Diameter, and the operation's Tool Length value is between two library record Tool Length values?
Yes: Interpolate between the two Tool Length records.
If not, is there a close match for Tool Length, and the operation's Tool Diameter value is between two library record Tool Diameter values?
Yes: Interpolate between the two Tool Diameter records.
If not, is the operation's tool deflection (based on the tool diameter and length) between two records that have a similar deflection?
Yes: Interpolate between the two records.
If the system is unable to find two records with similar deflection to interpolate between, the system returns the machining data for the closest similar record without interpolating.
Interpolating Parameter Values
When an operation's Tool Diameter and Tool Length values do not exactly match library records, the software interpolates between records before assigning parameters values to the operation. The system searches for tools that have a similar deflection.
Sample Interpolation 1
Tool Material = TMC0_00021, HSM Carbide Ball Mill
Cut Method = OPD0_00021, HSM ROUGH MILLING
Part Material = MAT0_00464, P20 Mold Steel
Operation tool diameter = .1575 in
Operation tool length = .7500 in
There is an exact match for tool diameter and the operation's tool length falls between two records. The system would interpolate the output parameter values to be between the two records as follows:
