NX displays an alert message to warn you that all items in the explorer tree must be in an explorer node.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: Geometry
Group: Geometry
Group: Tool
Click Move Up again.
The Geometry group moves into the explorer node and the alert message disappears.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: Geometry
Group: Geometry
Group: Tool
Repeat steps 3 and 4 for each group of parameters that you want to access from the explorer tree.
For convenience, we recommend that you do not add the Actions group to the explorer tree.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: Geometry
Explorer Node: Tool
Explorer Node:Tool Axis
Explorer Node: Path Settings
Explorer Node: Machine Control
Explorer Node: Program
Explorer Node: Options
Group: Actions
Click OK to accept the changes and close the dialog box.
The Actions group is visible when any node is selected in the explorer tree because it was not placed within the explorer hierarchy.
Default Floor Wall dialog box
Floor Wall dialog box with an explorer tree

Document Title: Convert a dialog box to the explorer tree format
Document Body:
In this example, the dialog box to customize is a Rough Turn OD operation.
Access the Customize Dialog dialog box in one of these ways:
In the operation dialog box, in the Options group, click Customize Dialog .
In the Operation Navigator, right-click the operation and choose Object→Customize.
In the Items Used group, notice the structure.
Group: Geometry
Group: Cut Strategy
Group: Tool
Group: Tool Orientation
Group: Path Settings
Group: Machine Control
Group: Geometry
Group: Program
Group: Description
Group: Layout and layer
Group: Options
Group: Actions
In the Reset group, click Convert to Explorer .
In the Items Used group, notice the structure.
Explorer:
Group: Actions
Click OK to accept the changes and close the dialog box.
The Actions group is visible when any node is selected in the explorer tree because it was not placed within the explorer hierarchy.

Document Title: Tips for adding an explorer tree to a dialog box
Document Body:
Before you begin to customize your dialog box, it is helpful to note the parameters you need to add to the explorer tree. This will help you find all of the corresponding customizable items.
The following table shows the customizable items for non-cutting moves, which you can add to the explorer tree for a Floor Wall operation. Each customizable item adds the collapsible group and its parameters to the selected explorer tree node. The correct items will vary depending on your operation type and subtype.
Tab
Customizable Items
Engage tab
Closed Area, Open Area, Initial Closed Area, Initial Open Area
Retract tab
Retract, Final
Transfer/Rapid
Clearance, Between Regions, Within Regions, Initial and Final
Avoidance
From Point, Start Point, Return Point, GOHOME Point
More
Collision Check, Cutcom Parameters
Feeds and Speeds
To add the parameters from the Feeds and Speeds dialog box to an operation dialog box, or to add the parameters from the Feeds dialog box to a method dialog box, select the Feed items customizable item.

See Common dialog box options for common options not described here.
Items to Add
Dialog Item Type
Customizable Item
Lists options from lower level dialog boxes that you can move into the customized dialog box.
Group
Creates a collapsible group.
Sub Dialog
Adds a sub-dialog where you can place additional parameters.
Explorer
Adds an empty explorer tree to the dialog box.
Explorer:
An explorer tree lets you organize a complex dialog box to access parameters more efficiently. For example, you can move parameters from a sub-dialog box to a node in the explorer tree of the operation dialog box.
Explorer Node
Adds a node to the explorer tree.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: [label]
You can nest explorer nodes up to 5 levels deep.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: 1
Explorer Node: 2
Explorer Node: 3
Explorer Node: 4
Explorer Node: 5
Any items you add to the explorer tree must be within an explorer node.
Explorer:
Explorer Node: Tool Axis
Tool Axis
Tab Page
Divides the dialog box into tabbed pages.
Use tabs to make the dialog box shorter.
Scrolled Area
Creates a scrolling window.
Note:
The number of items, including separator lines, that can appear at one time is specified in the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box in the Number of Items before Scrolling preference.
For example, if Number of Items before Scrolling is set to four, and you add seven items to the scrolled area, only four of the seven items can appear at one time.
Tip:
To find the preference, choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing, and click the User Interface tab. The preference is in the Dialog Box group.
Group Area
Creates a group that lets you place icons in rows.
Label
Specifies a string of up to 25 characters.
Tip:
 To add a blank line to the dialog box, create a Label item with only blank spaces. The blank line is one character high.
Separator
Creates a horizontal divider line.
Start Events, End Events
Adds the Start of Path Events or End of Path Events options.
All Other Items
Adds the All other Parameters button to the main dialog box. The All other Parameters dialog box contains all the available items that are not currently added to the main dialog box.
Picture
Specifies a graphic file.
Note:
The Bitmap Name value must either be an icon in the system or a .bmp file in the NX bitmaps folder. The location is defined by the UGII_BITMAP_PATH variable.
You must restart NX to see a bitmap if it is added to the operating system during the current session, or its name is changed during the current session.
User Defined Move Type
Available for Probing and Generic Motion operations.
Adds a custom sub-operation to the list of available sub-operations.
Search
Allows you to search for available items to add to a dialog box. You can enter multiple search strings, separated by a blank space. The search strings are not case sensitive. Removing the search string displays all the available items.
Initial Group State
Specifies whether the selected group is open or closed when you create an object using this dialog box as a template. After creation, dialog box memory controls whether the selected group is open or closed.
Add to Dialog
Moves the currently selected items from the Items to Add list to the Items Used list. The selected items remain selected in the Items to Add list. If a Customizable Item is moved to the Items Used list, the next item in the Items to Add list is selected.
Items Used
Specifies the options to display in the dialog box.
Tip:
To move an item from the Items Used list to the Available Items list, or from the Available Items list to the Items Used list, double click the item you want to move.
List
Specifies the options to be displayed in the dialog box. When you create an operation, all of the template operation options are in the Items Used list.
Note:
Some items contain more than one parameter. Stepover Method, for example, contains both the Stepover list and the value entry box. These two parameters work together and cannot be separated.
Most dialog box groups are separate items, but some are part of a larger customizable item. For example, Projection Vector.
Sub-Operation Manager group
Available for Probing and Generic Motion operations.
Lists the available sub-operations.
Note:
You cannot delete a sub-operation from the Sub-Operation Manager group. Clear the check box to remove a sub-operation from the Type list of the Create Move Subop dialog box.
Delete
Removes the selected items from the Items Used list. NX adds Customizable Item items to the Items to Add list.
The removed entries remain selected in the Items to Add list.
Move Up / Move Down
Move the selected entry up or down one line in the Items Used list box.
Note:
You cannot move a sub-operation outside of the Sub-Operation Manager group.
Customize Sub Dialog
Available for Probing and Generic Motion operations.
Opens the Customize Sub Dialog dialog box. Lets you add, delete or reorder parameters for the sub-operation selected in the Sub-Operation Manager list.
Note:
Customize Sub Dialog is unavailable if you select a sub-operation that is used in an existing Generic Motion or Probing operation within the part file. You cannot customize a sub-operation that has already been used in
Reset
Update from Template
Updates the dialog box from the latest template.
Convert to Explorer
Converts the current dialog box into an Explorer style dialog box.
Remove Customization
Resets the dialog box to the state that existed at the start of the session.
Preview
Display Dialog
Displays a preview of the customized dialog box.

Use the Customize from command to customize one or more dialog boxes for operations, tools, geometry, machining methods, and programs.
In the Update Customization dialog box you can customize a dialog box from:
Another dialog box in your work part.
For example, after you customize a Ball Mill dialog box, use the Ball Mill dialog box as a template to give the dialog boxes for other ball mills the same layout.
A dialog box in another part.
The latest NX template.
Note:
The Unused Items nodes, the Geometry root node, and the Method root node cannot be customized.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Operation Navigator
Right-click the selected object→Object→Customize from
Location in dialog box
[Operation] dialog box→Options group→Customize Dialog

Document Title: Customize from another dialog box in your work part
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click on any object and choose Object→Customize From.
In the Update Customization dialog box, from the Objects in Work Part list, select the object to be updated.
You can select an operation, tool, geometry group, machining method, or program.
In the Copy Customization From group, from the Objects in list, select Work Part.
From the Copy Customization From list, select the object from which you want to copy the customized options and layout.
In the Preview group, click Display Dialog to confirm the changes.
Click OK.
Tip:
To customize more objects, click Apply and repeat the steps.

Document Title: Customize from a dialog box in another part
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click on any object and choose Object→Customize From.
In the Update Customization dialog box, from the Objects in Work Part list, select the object to be updated.
You can select an operation, tool, geometry group, machining method, or program.
In the Copy Customization From group, from the Objects in list, select Browse.
Select the part file that contains the dialog box from which you want to copy the customized options and layout.
The part file must contain the same type of object that you selected in the Objects in Work Part list. For example, if you select a Cavity Milling operation in the Objects in Work Part list, the part file to copy from must contain a Cavity Milling operation.
From the Copy Customization From list, select the object to copy from.
In the Preview group, click Display Dialog to confirm the changes.
Click Apply to update and continue selecting objects to update.
Click OK to update and exit the dialog box.

Document Title: Customize from the current template part to update the dialog box
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click on any object and choose Object→Customize From.
In the Update Customization dialog box, from the Objects in Work Part list, select the object to update.
You can select an operation, tool, geometry group, machining method, or program.
In the Copy Customization From group, from the Objects in list, select Template.
Click OK.

Document Title: Update all the dialog boxes in a work part from the current template part
Document Body:
In the Operation Navigator, right-click on any object and choose Object→Customize From.
In the Update Customization dialog box, in the Objects in Work Part group, click Select All .
In the Copy Customization From group, from the Objects in list, select Template.
Click OK.

Document Title: Update dialog boxes from the template parts automatically
Document Body:
To ensure that you have the most current dialog boxes, NX can update from the current templates automatically.
To update during the current NX session:
Choose Menu→Preferences→Manufacturing.
In the Manufacturing Preferences dialog box, click the User Interface tab.
On the User Interface tab, in the Dialog Box group, select the Always Update Dialog Boxes check box.
To update every time you enter Manufacturing:
Choose File tab→Utilities→Customer Defaults.
In the Customer Defaults dialog box, select Manufacturing→User Interface.
In the Dialog Boxes tab, select the Always Update Dialog Boxes check box.
Selecting this option may cause a delay when entering manufacturing.

Objects in Work Part
List
Displays all the available, customizable operations, tools, method, geometry, and program order groups in the current work part file.
Tip:
You can change the selection in the Update Customization dialog box. A typical workflow would be the following:
Select an object from the Objects in Work Part list.
Select an object from the Copy Customization From list.
Click Apply.
Repeat.
You can also select multiple items of the same type. For example, select several tools at once to customize from another tool.
Select All
Selects all objects in the work part. Use this option to update from the template.
Copy Customization From
Objects in
Specifies where the object to copy from is located.
Template
Selects the current template part file.
Note:
Template objects are not displayed in the Copy Customization from list.
Work Part
Selects your current work part file.
Browse
Lets you select a part file.
List
Displays the objects that you can customize from.
For example, if you select a ball mill tool from the Objects in Work Part list, and Work Part from the Objects in list, the Copy Customization From list displays all tools in the current work part.

Items to Add
Dialog Item Type
Group
Adds a collapsible group.
Double
Adds a double-precision input box.
Integer
Adds an integer input box.
String
Adds an empty text input box.
Boolean
Adds a check box for parameters with on/off conditions.
Enumeration
Adds a selection list. Each line in the Enumeration Items box is a selection in the list.
Vector
Adds vector options.
Point
Adds point options.
Initial Group State
Specifies whether the selected group is open or closed when you create an object using this dialog box as a template. After creation, dialog box memory controls whether the selected group is open or closed.
Add to Dialog
Moves the currently selected items from the Items to Add list to the Items Used list. The selected items remain selected in the Items to Add list. If a Customizable Item is moved to the Items Used list, the next item in the Items to Add list is selected.
Items Used
Specifies the options to display in the dialog box.
Tip:
To move an item from the Items Used list to the Available Items list, or from the Available Items list to the Items Used list, double click the item you want to move.
List
Specifies the options to be displayed in the dialog box.
Move Up /Move Down
Move the selected entry up or down one line in the Items Used list box.
Delete
Removes the selected items from the Used Items list.
Reset
Reset to Default
Replaces all custom parameters with a single Standard Parameters integer input box.

The Machine tab includes machine-related commands in the NX Manufacturing applications.
The following commands are available in the Edit group on the Machine tab on the Ribbon bar.
Retrieve Machine from Library : Enables you to retrieve an existing machine from the library and position a part on it.
Browse Machine on Post Hub : Enables you to open the Post Hub window to browse and download a machine to your system.
Import Machine to Library : Enables you to import a downloaded machine from your system to the machine library in NX.
Export Machine Kit : Enables you to export a machine from the machine library in NX to your system.
Open Machine Assembly : Enables you to open the machine assembly in a new window tab. You can manage the machine in the Assembly Navigator.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing

Document Title: Retrieve a machine to position part
Document Body:
You can use the Retrieve Machine from Library command from the Ribbon bar on the Machine tab to retrieve an existing machine from the library and position the part on the selected machine.
Prerequisites
Open a part in the NX Manufacturing application.
Procedure
Select the Machine tab.
On the Ribbon bar, click Retrieve Machine from Library .
NX displays the Library Class Selection dialog box.
Select the class of machine in the Class to Search group and click OK.
NX displays the Search Result dialog box.
Select the machine from the Matching Items group and click OK.
NX displays the Part Mounting dialog box.
Set the following details:
In the Placement group, from the Positioning list, select the option to position the part onto the machine.
In the Settings group, select the Show Machine check box to show the machine in the graphics window.
In the Settings group, adjust the Machine Translucency slider to manage the machine translucency.
In the Placement group, from the Layer Option list, select the option to control the visibility of the mounted head by layer.
Note:
Available when you select the Orient Machine Zero to main MCS and Use Part Mount Junction from the Positioning list.
Click OK.
NX retrieves the selected machine from the library and positions the part on the machine.

Placement
Positioning
Orient Machine Zero to main MCS
Coincides the machine zero junction on your machine to the main MCS in your part. This is especially useful when retrieving a machine into older CAM parts that contain a main MCS but no machine. This option is only available if the part contains a main MCS.
Use Assembly Positioning
Uses standard Assembly positioning to position the part onto the machine.
Use Part Mount Junction
Moves the machine to the part so that the part mount junction in the existing machine coincides with the part mount junction in the new machine.
Position Part on Machine
Positions the part on the machine using a bounding box or a bounding cylinder as a reference point. You can specify a coordinate system for the part with reference to the bounding box or bounding cylinder and use it to position the part on the machine.
Use Old Machine Transformation
Moves the machine to the part so that the part mount junction in the existing machine coincides with the part mount junction in the new machine.
Keep Assembly Constraints
Moves the machine to the part so that the part mount junction in the existing machine coincides with the part mount junction in the new machine.
Create Part Mount Junction
Allows you to create a part mount junction in the part that you want to mount to the machine. This is a quick way to perform the same steps required to create and classify a part mounting junction with the part. This option is only available if the part does not yet contain a part mounting junction.
Settings
Show Machine
Lets you show or hide the selected machine in the graphics window. If the Show Machine check box is selected, the machine is displayed in the graphics window and you can manage the machine translucency.
Machine Translucency
Lets you adjust the translucency of the selected machine in the graphics window.
Layer Option
Lets you control the mounted head's visibility by layer using the standard NX options, if applicable.
Available when you select the Orient Machine Zero to main MCS and Use Part Mount Junction from the Positioning list.

Document Title: Download and import a machine from Post Hub
Document Body:
You can use the Browse Machine on Post Hub command to download a machine to your system and use the Import Machine to Library command to import the machine that you have downloaded to NX.
Prerequisites
Open a part in the NX Manufacturing application.
Procedure
Select the Machine tab.
On the Ribbon bar, click Browse Machine on Post Hub .
NX displays the Post Hub window tab in NX.
For the required machine, click Download.
Post Hub downloads a zip file of the machine in the default downloads directory of your system.
Close the Post Hub tab.
Select the Machine tab, and on the Ribbon bar, click Import Machine to Library.
In the Browse for machine tool kit dialog box, navigate to the folder containing the downloaded machine file, select the machine file type from the list, and select the machine file from the available files list.
Click OK.
NX displays the Import Machine Kit dialog box with the output directory selected for the new machine to be imported to the NX library.
Click OK
NX displays the information window, indicating the status of machine import. You can now select and use the imported machine by using the Retrieve Machine from Library from the Ribbon bar.

Allows you to import machine kit files that have been exported from an NX machine library (.mtk) or downloaded from Post Hub (.zip).
Note:
Importing a machine kit overwrites any existing machine data for a machine, device, or tool with the same name. You have the option to import any device or tool that is included in the kit.
Import Settings
Output Directory
Shows the currently configured installed_machines folder, UGII_CAM_LIBRARY_INSTALLED_MACHINES_DIR. You can change the destination folder if necessary.
List Report
Opens the Information window with a list of the files that were imported, after the import is complete.
Information
Name
The machine name to be shown in the machine tool library.
Provider
Taken from the metadata for the kit. The default value is the name of the user who exported the kit.
NX Version
The NX version from which the kit was exported.
Date
The date on which the kit was exported.
Machine Folder
The name of the folder that is added in the installed_machines folder.
Thumbnail picture
Shows the machine tool preview image that was saved with the assembly.

You can use the Export Machine Kit command to export the selected machine to your system as a .mtk file.
Prerequisites
Open a part in the NX Manufacturing application with a machine kit retrieved from the library.
Procedure
Select the Machine tab.
On the Ribbon bar, click Export Machine Kit .
NX displays the Export Machine Kit dialog box.
In the Output Directory, browse and select the directory for exporting the machine kit.
(Optional) In the Content group, manage files and folders as needed, using the Add File , Add Folder , Create Folder and Delete options.
Select the List Report check box to list the contents of the machine kit in the Information window.
Click OK.
NX exports the selected machine to the specified output directory.

Creates a zipped file that contains the files and folders that are needed to simulate and postprocess a selected machine tool library entry. The file has the extension .mtk but you can open it with a utility such as 7-zip. Use it to send kits to another computer.
Note:
Set the customer default Export Machine Model with STEP File to create a STEP file of the machine model when you export a machine kit
Machine Kit
Name
Sets the name of the .mtk file to be created. The machine kit name must be unique in the output directory.
Output Directory
Sets the location where the .mtk file is created.
Content
Tree diagram

 machine name
  graphics
  cse_driver
  postprocessor
custom
 device
  device_1
 tool
  tool_1
Lists the files to be included in the output.
graphics
Collects part files under ...\machine\installed_machines\[machine name]\graphics.
cse_driver
Collects files under ...\machine\installed_machines\[machine name]\cse_driver, including .mcf, .ccf, .ini, and .py files.
postprocessor
Collects files under ...\machine\installed_machines\[machine name]\postprocessor, typically a subfolder that contains .tcl, .cdl, .def, .pui, and other postprocessor-related files.
custom
Provides a location where you can add extra files, such as instructions or other useful files.
device
Collects part files under ...\device\graphics used in the machine.
tool
Collects part files under ...\tool\graphics used in the machine.
Add File
Available when you select a folder.
Lets you browse to a file to add to the selected folder in the kit.
Add Folder
Available when you select a folder.
Lets you browse to a folder to add to the selected folder in the kit.
Create Folder
Available when you select a folder.
Creates a new folder in the kit under the selected parent folder. For example, you could create a samples folder and include test files.
Delete
Removes the selected file or selected folder and all its contents from the kit.
Rename
Available when you select a folder.
Lets you rename the selected folder.
Settings
 List Report
When selected, NX displays the content of the kit in the Information window.

You can use the Open Machine Assembly command to open the machine assembly in a new window tab. You can manage the machine in the Assembly Navigator.
In the new window tab you can use the commands available in the Machine Kits and Smart Machine Kits group on the Ribbon bar to manage the machine. After you have modified the machine, you can close the new window tab, and NX updates the machine in the open part file.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Open Machine Assembly

Document Title: Machine Control and User Defined Events
Document Body:
Use the Machine Control options to add postprocessor commands to your tool path.
In the User Defined Events (UDEs) group, the Start of Path Events and End of Path Events options allow you to add UDEs at the start and end of your tool path.
In the Motion Output group, the Motion Output Type option lets you to specify the output format for tool motion.
The Machine Control options are interpreted by NX Post when creating output for a machine code file or a CLSF file.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Location in dialog box
[Milling/Turning operation] dialog box→Tool, Prg, & Machine Control node

User Defined Events (UDEs) provide a way to capture information in a tool path for use in the postprocessor. They can be placed at the start or end of any tool path or on an object. The most common use is in an operation, to produce post commands during output to the CLSF or postprocessor. NX provides several pre-defined events for this purpose. For example, there are events to turn coolant on or off, and to add an operator message.
Events are defined in a .cdl file. The file can contain as many events as desired. This file is specified as a part of the Machine Definition. The default .cdl file is located in the mach→resource→user_def_events folder in the standard system installation.
Note:
Each .cdl file requires a Machine command before the Event definitions.

A set of common User Defined Events (UDEs) are included with NX to provide special instructions to the machine tool within the tool path. UDEs are often used to generate machine code, usually for auxiliary functions. The postprocessor interprets the events and creates output to the NC code file or CLSF file.
Note:
Your machine tool and postprocessor may not support all UDEs in this list.
Events
Description
Auxfun
Lets you to output an auxiliary function code (M code) to the machine tool controller, and corresponds to the AUXFUN/ command. You can to enter any number from 0 to 99 in the Auxfun Value box.
Clamp
Lets you clamp an axis when the axis is not moving.
Coolant On
Lets you add coolant events.
Coolant Off
Cancels coolant events.
Cutter Compensation
Lets you add Cutter Compensation events. Use this event only if the cutter compensation specified in the operation dialog box does not work for your application.
Dwell
Lets you add dwell events.
Head
Lets you define the head that is to be referenced.
Insert
Lets you add a note.
Instanced Operation Handler
This UDE can be used to output subroutines and transformations for instanced operations. Requires a highly customized post processor.
Tool Length Compensation
Lets you select tool length offsets.
Lock Axis
Lets you constrain tool axis motion.
Extra Tool Change
Lets you add an extra tool change.
Operator Message
Lets you send a message that will be displayed for the operator to read, and corresponds to the DISPLY/ command.
Optional Skip Off
Lets you deactivate the Opskip function.
Optional Skip On
Lets you activate the output of a slash (/) at the start of each line of output for the BLOCK DELETE function of the controller.
Optional Stop
Lets you add an optional stop.
Origin
Lets you establish the location of the machine reference system zero point in relationship to the part coordinate system zero.
Power
Lets you set the power level by entering a value in the Power Register box.
Pprint
Lets you print remarks on the postprocessor verification listing device.
Prefun
Lets you output a preparatory function code (G code) to the machine tool controller.
Rotate
Lets you rotate the table or head.
Select Head
Lets you define which head is to be used for merging.
Sequence Number
Lets you control the sequence number output.
Set Axis
Lets you position the ZAXIS or WAXIS.
Set Modes
Lets you define the dimensional output mode and the type of output under contouring mode.
Set Polar
Lets you define the dimensional output mode and the type
Extra Spindle On
This event is provided only for legacy programs with multiple Spindle UDEs. The first Spindle UDE becomes Spindle Marker, and the subsequent Spindle UDEs are converted to Extra Spindle On. Extra Spindle On should not be used for new programs. Spindle events are generated automatically from the entries in the Feed Rates dialog box.
Spindle Off
Lets you deactivate the spindle.
Stop
Lets you issue a program stop.
User Defined
Lets you manually enter events which are needed but are not contained in the Available list box.
Tool Preselect
Lets you position the tool prior to the tool change
Load Workpiece
Lets you load a part into the spindle.
Workpiece Takeover by Spindle 2
This UDE can be used to initiate a work piece transfer to the second spindle. Requires a highly customized post processor.
Unload Workpiece
Lets you remove a part from the spindle.
Zero
Lets you specify the G code that is output before the Zero move.
Goto
Lets you enter a Goto point.
Spindle Marker
Lets you specify where you want the system to output the spindle event.
From Marker
Lets you establish the tool path starting position in terms of the MCS.
Tool Change Marker
Lets you specify the order of post command output relative to the Tool Change.
Start Marker
Lets you specify the order of post command output relative to the Start Point.
Approach Marker
Lets you specify the order of post command output relative to the final approach move.
Return Marker
Lets you specify post command output relative to the RETURN motion.
GoHome Marker
Lets you specify post command output relative to the GOHOME motion.
Events unique to Wire EDM
Description
Cut Wire
Cut Wire allows you to unload the wire by cutting it.
Flush
Flush allows you to control the flushing cycle.
Flush Tank
Flush Tank allows you to control the flush tank.
Thread Wire
Thread Wire allows you to execute an EDM wire threading sequence.
Wire Angles
Wire Angle allows you to define the wire angle constant.
Feed Rate
Feed Rate allows you to control the feed rate.
Wire Guides
Wire Guides sets the upper and lower wire guide positions and corresponds to the SET/ command.
Events unique to Sinumerik controllers
For more information on Sinumerik events and cycles, see Events and cycles for Sinumerik controllers in NX
Description
Sinumerik 840D
Sets default settings including tolerance, high speed machining parameters, five axis orientation parameters, and whether the feed rate is defined in a variable.
DNC Header
Makes the NC output file accessible to the Siemens Motion Control Information System (MCIS).
Sinumerik Program Control
Lets you call external subroutines.

This dialog box opens when you:
Select Edit next to Start of Path Events or End of Path Events in the Tool, Prg & Machine Control node of a Milling or Turning operation dialog box.
Select User Defined Events in the Main node of a Mill Control or Lathe Control operation dialog box.
Events Available
You can add User Defined Events (UDEs) in the Events Available list to your operation or CAM object.
Search
Lets you enter text to filter UDEs.
Add new event
Opens a dialog box for the event selected in the list so that its parameters can be defined. Once defined, the event is added to the Events Used list.
Events Used
The list of UDEs that are interpreted by the postprocessor during postprocessing. Many of the events are used to output additional machine information.
Edit
Lets you review or edit the parameters for the event selected the list.
Information
Opens an Information window that shows the parameters for the events selected the list.
Delete, Move Up, Move Down
Lets you delete, move up, or move down one or more events in the list. Selected events can be moved up or down one position at a time.
Tip:
To select a range of events, hold Shift and in the Events Used list, select the first and last event you want in the range of events.

When you open a part or reload machine, an information message is displayed when a user-defined event (UDE) is out-of-date.
In the User Defined Events message dialog box, the name of the UDE that is out-of-date is displayed (1), and you can select Show Details (2) to display a list of operations (3) associated with the UDE.
Note:
To fix an out-of-date UDE, you must delete the existing UDE, and add a UDE from the current list of available UDEs for the postprocessor.
Why should I use it?
When a UDE is out-of-date, the postprocessor has changed and the output from postprocessing may not be correct.
Where do I find it?
Application
Manufacturing
Command
Post Process
Ribbon bar
Home tab→Operations group→Post Process

Machine control events are specific User Defined Events (UDEs) that allow you to provide special instructions to the machine tool within the tool path. These UDEs may be specified at the start of a tool path, at the end of a tool path, and even in the middle of a path. In general, UDEs activate postprocessor commands in the order in which you specify them.
In a CLSF output file, the Start of Path Events post commands are output before the first GOTO command. End of Path Events post commands are output at the end of the tool path. The commands ORIGIN and CUTCOM have special placement rules. See the discussion of these commands for more detailed information.
If you specify a FROM or START POINT (as avoidance parameters), the default output position for postprocessor commands is after the FROM and before the START POINT. An ORIGIN command will precede the FROM position. For example:
If you specify a RETURN or GOHOME (as avoidance parameters), the default output position for postprocessor commands is after the RETURN and before the GOHOME. For example:
Note:
This default positioning can be overridden by specifying positioning markers.

These Machine Control options are available in Milling and Turning operation dialog boxes.
User Defined Events (UDEs)
Start of Path Events and End of Path Events let you add machine control events such as coolant or other post commands to the start and end of your operation.
Copy From
Lets you copy special post commands from another operation or from an operation template.
Edit
Lets you add post commands to the start or end of the path.
For some operations, you can define UDEs at the following levels:
Boundaries.
Boundary members. These are identified using Custom Boundary Data.
Boundary groups.
Motion Output
Lets you convert linear, arc, and curve data generated in an operation to other motion types when you postprocess the tool path.
Milling operation options
Linear Only
In this mode, circular motions are linearized, that is, split into small linear segments. No CIRCLE/GOTO events are output to the tool path.
Arc — Perp to Tool Axis
Generates all of the possible circular tool motions that lie in planes that are normal to the tool axis.
Arc — Perp/Par to Tool Axis
Generates all of the possible circular tool motions that lie in planes that are normal or parallel to the tool axis.
Nurbs
Generates all of the possible circular tool motions and Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline curves where posssible.
Available for Fixed-axis Surface Contouring, Planar Milling, Cavity Milling, Face Milling, Floor Wall Milling, Groove Milling.
Lets you control the surface finish by determining how accurately the tool path follows Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline curves (Nurbs).
Nurbs causes the tool to drive along Non-Uniform Rational B-Spline curves (up to order 4 [degree 3] cubic splines) rather than along approximate line/arc segments. This option should be used for fixed axis machining, when the tool axis is aligned with the ZM axis, to perform high speed operations requiring a very smooth and accurate surface cut (particularly on contoured surfaces) and when your Fanuc, Seimens, Heidenhain, or Fidia UNC control supports Nurbs input. The finished part should not deviate from the design geometry more than the specified Intol/Outtol if the defined Fitting Control Tolerance is within the Intol/Outtol band. If a smoother tool path is desired, you can specify a tighter Fitting Control Tolerance. When using this option, the tool displays only at the beginning and end of each cutting pass regardless of the specified Display Frequency.
See User Defined operations and CLSF for the Standard B-Spline Format.
Sinumerik Spline
Outputs splines for Siemens Sinumerik controllers. The Sinumerik Spline output is optimized for Zig cut patterns in finishing operations, and is best suited for the Area Mill drive method.
The spline format uses G2 continuity where possible. This helps to ensure that the tool paths run smoothly. The tool path is expected to run faster and produce a smoother surface finish. The spline may also be used with other controllers.
Turning operation options
Linear Only
In this mode, circular motions are linearized, that is, split into small linear segments. No CIRCLE/GOTO events are output to the tool path.
Circular
Circular motions are not split into linear motions, but output as one single CIRCLE/GOTO event.
Machine Cycle
Circular motions are not split. In addition, a CYCLE/ON event is add added to the start of the tool path and a CYCLE/OFF event is added at the end of the path.
Note:
Circle records output to the CLSF or NC file are generated from either selected geometry or the postprocessor. If the radius of the circle is outside the range defined in the postprocessor, then the postprocessor outputs a warning indicating that the radius is out of range. The warning does not indicate an error since the postprocessor automatically converts the arc into one or more linear segments.

You can set coolant separately for Open Area and Closed Area regions in an operation.
If coolant is activated for a region, the coolant is deactivated automatically at the end of the region. This coolant setting is available for many milling operations such as Adaptive Milling, Cavity Mill, Floor and Wall, and Planar Mill.
The default coolant types for regions in an operation are: FLOOD, MIST, THRU, AIR, and AIR_THRU. These coolant types correspond to coolant user defined events (UDEs) that you can place at the start and end of operations. The UDE to activate the coolant is placed at the start of the region, and a UDE to deactivate the coolant is placed at the end of the region.

Document Title: Edit start and end of path events
Document Body:
You can edit the Start of Path Events and End of Path Events in operations.
In an [Operation] dialog box, in the Tool, Prg & Machine Control node, click Edit next to Start of Path Events or End of Path Events.
In the User Defined Events dialog box, click an event from the Events Available list and click Add new event .
In the [Event] dialog box, select the parameters for the event and click OK.
The event is added to the Events Used list in the User Defined Events dialog box.
Click the event in the Events Used list and then click Edit .
Update the parameters as desired.
In the [Event] dialog box, click OK to save the event changes.
In the User Defined Events dialog box, click OK to save all the user defined events.

When you postprocess an operation, the manufacturing output manager (MOM) does the following:
It generates user-defined events.
It uses event parameters to sets MOM variables and other variables that you define for the event.
It communicates the event data directly to any postprocessor.

Placement markers are special events that you can insert into your operations’ start and end event lists. When you generate an operation, the events are output in a sequence. Markers represent milestones in this sequence, including:
Spindle commands.
Tool change commands.
Motions to and from avoidance geometry.
When you place your events before a marker, the event output is made before the line of NC output associated with the marker. When you place events after a marker, the event output is made after the line of NC output associated with the marker. If the CAM object that corresponds to a marker is not defined, then the placement of that marker has no significance to the output order of events.
The following markers are relevant when you define Start Events:
Spindle Marker
Tool Change Marker
From Marker
Start Marker
Approach Marker
Start Motion Marker
Note:
The Start Motion Marker conflicts with the markers Start Marker and Approach Marker. If you add the Start Motion Marker, the other two markers are not available. If you first select one of the other two markers, the Start Motion Marker is not available.
The following markers are relevant when you define End Events:
Return Marker
Gohome Marker
End Motion Marker
Note:
The End Motion Marker conflicts with the markers Return Marker and Gohome Marker. If you add the End Motion Marker, the other two markers are not available. If you first select one of the other two markers, the End Motion Marker is not available.

When you post process a tool path, the user-defined event data is output in the following default order:
Start of program
User-defined events (UDEs) attached to the program
Start of parent group (program, machine tool, geometry, method)
UDEs attached to the parent group
UDEs attached to the geometry with program, machine tool, geometry, method commands
UDEs attached to the method with Start Events
UDEs attached to the cutting tool with Start Events
UDEs attached to the machine tool with Start Events
Start of operation
Tool change (not Load tool)
UDEs attached to the operation with Start Events
Initial move
UDEs attached to the operation with End Events
End of operation
UDEs attached to the geometry with End Events
UDEs attached to the method with End Events
UDEs attached to the cutting tool with End Events
UDEs attached to the machine tool with End Events
End of program

A custom user defined event (UDE) is a machine control event that you add to operations and CAM parent objects in NX. You use custom UDEs to output required machine-specific control information that you cannot configure with the default options that are available. For example, you can add a UDE to output a custom clamping code or a fixture positioning code.
In NX, you can attach custom UDEs as object start events or object end events for the following:
An operation
A CAM parent object such as: program, method, tool, machine tool, or geometry.
The UDEs are defined in files with a .cdl extension. The definition of these events includes the required variables and the user interface specification. You must configure the .cdl file to be read in the NX Manufacturing environment so that your events are visible in NX.
An event handler is custom TCL code that corresponds to the UDE and is saved with the postprocessor. During postprocessing, NX Post passes the UDE data to the postprocessor as events and variables. The event handler must interpret the value of the variables that you define and create the machine controller output that you require.
Note:
There are tools available in Post Configurator to help you create custom user defined events and event handlers.

EVENT <name>
Defines an event with the name that you enter after the EVENT keyword.
POST_EVENT <post_name>
(Optional) Writes the event to the NC output file with the name shown after the POST_EVENT keyword. If this keyword is not specified, NX outputs the post event name specified after the EVENT keyword.
UI_LABEL <ui_name>
Specifies the title of the NX dialog box for the event.
UI_HELP
(Optional) Specifies two text strings. The first string is the title that appears beside the help button in the dialog box that appears in NX when a user adds your event. The second string is a URL that points to an HTML file that provides useful information about your event. You need not place the two strings on the same line.
Note:
The format for a URL that points to a local file is "file://localhost/path".
The two slashes that precede the local host name are required. For example, if the file is on the user’s computer, the URL is "file:///path".
CATEGORY
(Optional) Specifies one or more machining modes in which the event is relevant. If this keyword is not specified, the event is relevant in all machining modes. The possible values are the following:
Mill
Drill
Lathe
WEDM
PARAM <param_name>
Specifies an event parameter with the name specified after the PARAM keyword.
TYPE
Specifies the parameter type. The possible values are:
i
An integer with a standard default value of 0.
d
A real number with a standard default value of 0.0
s
A string with a standard default value of an empty string.
o
An option list. The first value you specify becomes the default in the list.
b
A Boolean with a standard default value of FALSE.
p
A point. NX does not apply a default value.
v
A vector. NX does not apply a default value.
g
A group of parameters. NX does not apply a default value.
l
A graphic to illustrate the event. NX does not apply a default value. The value is a lower case L.
DEFVAL <default value>
(Optional) Specifies the default value or string for a parameter. If this keyowrd is not specified, NX applies the standard default for the parameter type. For example, if the variable is an integer, it uses the default integer value.
TOGGLE
(Optional) Specifies that the parameter is optional. The keyword TOGGLE must be followed by On or Off to set the default condition. If the TOGGLE keyword is not specified, the parameter is mandatory.
OPTIONS
Available only when the parameter TYPE is o. Mandatory for TYPE o.
Specifies a list of options for the parameter. The format is text strings separated by commas.
UI_LABEL param_ui_name
(Optional) Specifies the parameter name that is displayed in the NX dialog box. If <param_ui_name> is not specified, NX inserts a default name.

Document Title: Add user defined events to the NX Manufacturing environment
Document Body:
You must configure a .cdl that contains your user-defined events to be read in an NX Manufacturing environment definition file so that your events are visible in NX.
This example shows how to create a custom user defined event (UDE) file that contains the following:
A bitmap graphic to illustrate the custom event.
A link to an HTML file to support your custom event. This file provides online Help.
Grouped parameters.
Create a bitmap graphic, name.bmp, to illustrate your custom event and place it in the folder pointed to by the environment variable UGII_BITMAP_PATH.
Create a custom UDE file, name.cdl, to define your custom events and place it in the folder pointed to by the environment variable UGII_CAM_USER_DEF_EVENT_DIR.
Tip:
To create the file, edit the output .cdl file so that it contains only your custom user-defined events.
When you save a postprocessor, the associated .cdl file contains all of the user-defined events that are available in your post, including the events provided in the standard ude.cdl file.
#example .cdl file for UDEs
MACHINE FANUC
EVENT test_event
{
   UI_LABEL "Test Event"
   PARAM command_status
   {
      TYPE o
      DEFVAL "Active"
      OPTIONS "Active","Inactive","User Defined"
      UI_LABEL "Status"
   }
   PARAM my_picture
   {
      TYPE l
      DEFVAL "my.bmp"
   }
}
Locate the default user defined event file.
The default file is ${UGII_CAM_USER_DEF_EVENT_DIR}ude.cdl. The keyword USER_DEFINED_EVENTS in a manufacturing configuration file, for example, ${UGII_CAM_CONFIG_DIR}lathe.dat, determines the default .cdl file and the corresponding Tcl code file to be used for user-defined events.
In the .cdl file, in the next non-comment line after the MACHINE keyword, enter one or more statements to include other files.
The format to include a file is:
INCLUDE {file specification}
For example:
INCLUDE {$UGII_CAM_USER_DEF_EVENT_DIR/Siemens_Cycles.cdl}
Caution:
If you use a library machine tool, be aware that the definition file for the machine's default postprocessor also contains a pointer to a user-defined event file. The code that points to the file is, by default, the following:
INCLUDE {$UGII_CAM_USER_DEF_EVENT_DIR/ude.cdl}
You must edit any files with conflicting pointers to remove the conflicts.
This method of implementing your events has the following advantages:
It minimizes the effort required when you configure a new NX release.
It makes it much simpler to manage potential conflicts due to the pointer in library machine tools.
If NX is already running when you add a custom user-defined event file, you must reread the manufacturing environment to which you added the events.
(Optional) Create an online Help file, name.html, to support your custom event and place it in the folder pointed to by the environment variable UGII_CAM_USER_DEF_EVENT_DIR.
(Optional) Edit your name.cdl file to include a help statement.
MACHINE FANUC
EVENT test_event
{
   UI_LABEL "Test Event"
   UI_HELP "More about my test event" 
           "file:///D:/customization/resource/user_def_event/my_help.htm" 
   PARAM command_status
   {
      TYPE o
      DEFVAL "Active"
      OPTIONS "Active","Inactive","User Defined"
      UI_LABEL "Status"
   }
   PARAM my_picture
   {
      TYPE l
      DEFVAL "my.bmp"
   }
}

You can include a graphic in the dialog box that appears in NX when a user adds your event to illustrate the meaning of parameters in the event.
The graphic must be a 16-color BMP file.
The recommended width is 280 pixels.
The default folder in which to place the graphics is UGII/bitmaps. If you want to place the graphic in a different folder, you must supply the path. To avoid parser errors, do not include the backslash \ character in your path name.
The following is a code example to include a bitmap in the ude_xxx.cdl file, where xxx stands for your custom name.
PARAM illustration
{
  TYPE l
  DEFVAL  "xxx.bmp"
}

To create a dialog box group in the dialog box for your user defined event, set the TYPE keyword to g in a parameter definition.
The following is a code example for a parameter group in a .cdl file.
PARAM group_start_1
{
  TYPE g
  DEFVAL    "start_open"
  UI_LABEL  "My Group"
}
# Parameter group content
# Consists of definitions for parameters in the group
PARAM group_end
{
  TYPE g
  DEFVAL  "end"
}
Dialog box with group open
Dialog box with group closed

Document Title: Import a part with CAM objects
Document Body:
Choose File tab→Import→Part
In the Import Part dialog box, select the Import Cam Objects check box.
Select the part to import.
The software imports the operations and the Method, Program, Tool, and Geometry groups into the current part file. All objects inside these duplicated groups are imported and appended to the end of the existing groups.
On import:
Operations with identical names are renamed.
Method, Program, and Tool groups with identical names and identical parameters are not imported to avoid duplication.
Method, Program, and Tool groups with identical names but different parameters are renamed.
Geometry groups with identical names are imported and renamed.
Once the merge is complete, the software displays a report identifying those objects that were identical and not merged, and those that were renamed.

Document Title: Export a Polygon File to simulate with a third party package
Document Body:
Choose File tab→Export→Polygon File.
Step 1: Specify Output File Parameters
The Geometry Definition option displays the following dialog box. Most of these options pertain to triangulating the solid or sheet bodies. Once you have specified these parameters, you will select OK to specify the .ply output file name.
In order to process the solid or sheet bodies, the system must determine surface adjacencies, triangulate each surface making sure all edge vertices match, and determine normals to the triangles which point toward the outside of the surfaced body. To process the selected bodies, the system directly triangulates them and then outputs the triangles and normals to the .ply output file for use with Vericut. The coordinates of the triangulated in the .ply output file are in the Absolute Coordinate System.
Triangulated Body
The accuracy of the triangulation processing for surfaces is dependent upon three factors: 1) the edge tolerance used in Bounded Plane Creation, 2) the trim tolerance used in Trim Surface, 3) the triangulation tolerance.
The edge and trim tolerances determine how accurately the surface edges stored in the data base are positioned in relation to the true edges. Triangles along the edge of a surface have one or more vertices on the edge stored in the data base. Thus, inaccuracies in the edges stored in the data base result in inaccuracies in triangles along the edge of a surface.
It is imperative that you understand and set the tolerances correctly. Triangle Tol (triangulation tolerance) determines how smooth the approximation of the surface/solid will be. The smaller this number, the more triangular facets the system will generate as it attempts to simulate smoother contoured surfaces (see the Triangulation Tolerances figure). Adjacency Tol (adjacency tolerance) determines when two surfaces meet along an edge. You must be sure to coordinate this adjacency tolerance with other tolerances used throughout NX.
The Edge Tolerance used in Bounded Plane Creation and the Trim Tolerance used in Trim Surface determine the number of curve segments stored in the data base as an approximation of a surface edge. The smaller the tolerance, the more numerous the curve segments used to approximate an edge. When the system processes the triangulation of the surfaced model, it creates at least one triangle for each curve segment. As a result, the edge tolerance and surface trim tolerance determine the lower bound of the number of triangles produced. The number of triangles is the key determining factor in the speed of the processing.
Given the minimal set of triangles determined by the edge and trim tolerance, the Triangulation Tolerance determines how many more triangles are needed to obtain the accuracy desired.
To obtain the best performance possible, use the largest edge, trim, and Triangulation Tolerances possible to meet your needs. This will allow the system to correctly determine the adjacencies and to sufficiently provide accurate triangular approximation of the surfaces.
Each option in the Geometry Definition dialog box is described below.
Geometry
This option is always set to Part and cannot be changed.
Output Type
Output Type allows you to specify the type of file in which the system stores the output. This option toggles between Binary and Text.
Text creates an ASCII text output file that you can read and edit, although it takes up more memory space than a binary file.
Binary creates a binary output file. This produces the file in a more compact and efficient form, but which you cannot read or understand without some translation. The system defaults to this option.
Triangle Tol
Triangulation Tolerance allows you to enter a tolerance value which determines:
how closely the triangles approximate the surface contours
how close the sides of the triangles which lie along the edges are to the edges of the surface
The smaller the value you enter, the more triangles the system will generate as it simulates smoother contoured surfaces. More triangular facets require more processing time.
Triangulation Tolerances
English part values must range from .0001 to .1 inches with a default of .02. Metric part values must range from .0025 to 2.5 mm with a default of .5.
Adjacency Tol
Adjacency Tolerance allows you to enter a value which the system uses to determine if two surfaces will be attached to one another. The distance between two surface boundaries, as found in the data base, is calculated. If that distance is less than the Adjacency Tolerance, the two boundaries are considered to be coincident and the two surfaces are considered to be attached along that boundary. The default value for the Adjacency Tolerance is .005 for English parts, .12 for metric parts.
The Adjacency Tolerance has no affect on the speed of processing the solids.
A boundary, as found in the data base, is an approximation of the true surface edge. For example, when a cylinder is trimmed by a bounded plane which is not perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder, the true edge of the cylinder is an ellipse, but the system stores an approximating curve in the data base rather than an actual ellipse. This curve is accurate to within the trim tolerance specified when the surface was trimmed.
Elliptical Trim of a Cylinder which Results in an Approximating Curve
As a result, you must coordinate the setting of the Adjacency Tolerance with the trim tolerance used in Trim Surface (and similarly, the edge tolerance used in Bounded Plane Creation)
Use the following as rough guidelines for specifying Adjacency Tolerances.
Note:
 To avoid encountering problems with the Adjacency Tolerance, you must design NX parts with these general guidelines in mind:
When creating a bounded plane, use an edge tolerance which is less than or equal to one-half the Adjacency Tolerance.
Likewise, when trimming a surface, use a trim tolerance which is less than or equal to one-half the Adjacency Tolerance you will use.
To produce reasonable results, set the edge and trim tolerances within a range from .001 to .0025 for English parts, .0254 to .0635 for metric parts.
For the Adjacency Tolerance, set the value within a range from .0001 to .05 English, .0025 to 1.2 metric.
There is one exception to these rough guidelines. If, when creating the part:
the edge tolerance in bounded plane creation and the trim tolerance in surface trim is less than or equal to the default tolerance of .01 inches
and the edges of two adjacent surfaces are endpoint to endpoint coincident (i.e., the 3D endpoints of the two edges coincide)
then these edges will always be correctly identified as adjacent regardless of the setting of the Adjacency Tolerance.
For example, the adjacencies for all surfaces created by the Automatic Surfacing function within NX will be correctly determined because in this case adjacent surface edges are always endpoint to endpoint coincident and the edge tolerance used by Automatic Surfacing in the creation of bounded planes is .01 inches.
Note:
Edges whose length are smaller than the Adjacency Tolerance can cause adjacency problems if they are not endpoint to endpoint coincident. So it is best to construct surfaces so that adjacent edges are endpoint to endpoint coincident whenever possible. Not only will it help the correct determination of adjacencies, but it will also speed up the computation of those adjacencies.
In general, any surface construction tolerance should be approximately 50% of the smallest machining tolerance (i.e., Intol/Outtol tolerance).
The system handles these edges whose length is less than the Adjacency Tolerance in the following manner:
If an edge has length less than the Adjacency Tolerance and the neighboring edges are not endpoint to endpoint adjacent, the system displays the error message More Than 2 Edges Adjacent. In most cases, the output file will be successfully processed by Vericut.
Small Edge Length Produces an Error
If an edge has length less than the adjacency tolerance and the neighboring edges are endpoint to endpoint adjacent, the system correctly determines the adjacencies.
Adjacencies Correctly Determined Along a Small Edge
Max Triangle Edge
Maximum Triangle Edge allows you to assign a maximum triangle edge length for generated triangles. This option toggles between OFF and on, with OFF being the default. When turned on, this option activates the Triangle Edge Size field below. When turned OFF, the system applies no limit to the triangle size.
For normal rapid prototyping use, this option can usually be set to OFF. However, when the resulting .ply file is used for some other application (such as Vericut), it may be necessary to apply a maximum triangle size.
Triangle Edge Size
Triangle Edge Size sets the value of the maximum triangle edge size. This value has no affect if the Maximum Triangle Edge option is OFF. If it is ON, the system guarantees that no triangle edge will exceed the specified value.
Triangle Display
Triangle Display allows you to temporarily display the triangles used to create the Vericut simulation. This option toggles between OFF and ON, with OFF the default. When turned ON, this option gives you the ability to visually check the triangulation of the entities for smoothness and any potential problems. The system displays the triangles in the current system display color.
Step 2: Specify Output File Name
Once you have specified each option in the Geometry Definition dialog box, select OK. The system then displays the following dialog box and prompts you to name the .ply output file.
The system automatically appends the default extension .ply to the file name if the file is binary. It appends the default extension .txt to the file name if the file is a text file.
The system checks to see if the entered file name currently exists. If it does (or if you select an existing name in the list), the system prompts you to either:
Use Other Name
Replace It
Append to It
You can use Append to It to put two related parts into one Vericut file.
Step 3: Select Geometry
After you specify the output file name, the system displays the Class Selection dialog box with the mask set to only allow selection of solid bodies and sheet bodies. In this step, you will select the bodies to which the system will apply the triangulation. The geometry you select represents the material to be simulated as illustrated below.
Selecting Part vs. Stock Geometry
Generally, you will select the modeled Blank Geometry to simulate the removal of stock.
Error Messages
The system may also display error messages if problems were encountered in processing the selected surfaces or solids. These are NX error messages.
For all error messages, the system highlights the offending edge, surface, or solid face, and then prompts you to either Continue Displaying Errors or Discontinue.
Choose Continue Displaying Errors for the system to resume highlighting each offending edge, surface, or solid face. Choose Discontinue to stop the output of this error message.
When the system has finished the processing of this error message it continues with subsequent processing and produces a Vericut output file.
The following error messages are non-fatal:
Edges Not Shared By Two Surfaces
Any edges which are not shared by two surfaces are detected. The system highlights all such edges of a surface and displays this error message.
There are two conditions which generate this message:
Two surface edges that should be adjacent are found not to be. This may be caused by inexact modeling, or a violation of the guidelines for specifying adjacency tolerances. A single surface file is acceptable to Vericut for Auto Difference checking. Refer to the Vericut documentation for a description of the Auto Difference option.
The edge is part of a support structure and you do not want the edge to be attached to any other edge. In this case, consider the message to be only a warning and continue running the process.
Normals Cannot Be Automatically Determined
When calculating the normals for surfaces, you choose a base surface to establish a correct normal for the model. If your selection of surfaces contains more than one body (a body being a group of surfaces that are all attached to one another), the system highlights all surfaces that are not connected via a chain of surfaces to the base surface and displays this error message. The system then continues the processing and will use the normals stored in the NX data base for all offending surfaces. Note that the normals for such surfaces may be incorrect.
The following figure shows a part containing two separate bodies of surfaces. Since the second body selected is not connected by a chain of surfaces to the base surface, the system highlights it and displays the error message.
System Interaction when it Cannot Determine Normals
If the surfaces highlighted are merely support structures, consider the message to be merely a warning; you can still use the output. Otherwise, make sure all the normals for all highlighted surfaces are correct. The Append to It option is ideally suited for handling this situation. Run the process once for each body, appending to the previous output file.
Fatal Errors
The following error messages are fatal. The resulting output file may not be processed successfully by Vericut.
More Than 2 Edges Adjacent
If more than two surfaces coincide along an edge, the system highlights the offending coincident edges and displays this error message. There are two conditions which can generate this message:
The edge has length less than the adjacency tolerance and the neighboring edges are not endpoint to endpoint adjacent. In most cases, the output file will be processed successfully by Vericut.
Three or more surfaces meet along this edge.
Degenerate Surface
Certain surfaces can be constructed in NX but are degenerate. The system highlights all such surfaces and displays this error message. There are five ways in which a surface can be degenerate.
If the surface only consists of two boundary curves which coincide (see Example A).
If two of the boundary curves of a surface coincide (see Example B)
If a hole was trimmed into a surface that lies directly on one boundary (see Example C)
If a hole crosses a surface boundary (see Example D)
The distance between a hole and the periphery is less than two times the edge tolerance used in Bounded Plane Creation or the trim tolerance used in Trim Surface (see Example E).
Ways in which a Surface is Degenerated
Unable To Triangulate Surface
The system cannot triangulate the surface due to surface being corrupted, or because of a programming error.
Unable To Triangulate Solid Face
The system cannot triangulate the solid due to a programming error.
Virtual Memory Exhausted
If at any time during processing a dynamic memory call runs out of space, the system immediately stops the process, frees all dynamically allocated space, and displays this error message.

In Teamcenter Integration for NX, the Teamcenter data management tool runs as a separate process at the same time as NX. Since the two programs communicate, you can create, store, and access your NX data within the Teamcenter database.
CAM configurations in Teamcenter Integration for NX Manufacturing
Teamcenter Integration for NX Manufacturing combines the power of NX Manufacturing with the power of Teamcenter in storing and retrieving data in a controlled fashion. Within Teamcenter Integration for NX Manufacturing, there are different methods to access Manufacturing data.
Creating a new CAM setup part file
When Manufacturing is not active and you use File→New→Manufacturing in NX to create a CAM setup part, the configuration is defined in nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax.
Example:
<Filename>@DB/mill_planar_assy_inch/A</Filename>
            <Configuration>${UGII_CAM_CONFIG_DIR}cam_teamcenter_ascii_library.dat</Configuration>
            <LibraryClassPath>SETUP_TEMPLATE;GENERAL</LibraryClassPath>
The nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax file can be stored in Teamcenter, or on the operating system. NX uses the file on the operating system if your NX installation is not set up to use the pax files inside of Teamcenter.
The same rules for all other pax files apply to this file.
When you open a non-CAM part in managed mode and then switch to Manufacturing, NX uses the configuration defined in template_part_planner.dat to create a new CAM setup part. The template_part_planner.dat file is stored in the Teamcenter UGCAMTemplateData data set.
Beginning with NX 1980, the part planner data set file is version specific, so that you can access the correct template files when your company runs multiple versions of NX in managed mode.
Example:
Release
Part planner file
Example template entry in part planner file
NX 1980
template_part_planner_NX1980.dat
@DB/mill_planar_inch_NX1980/A
NX 2007
template_part_planner_NX2007.dat
@DB/mill_planar_inch_NX2007/A
Note:
If the version-specific file is not added, NX uses the configuration defined in the template_part_planner.dat file.
In Teamcenter, the template_part_planner.dat and template_part_planner_[NX version].dat files are stored as Named References in the following location:
User = infodba
Dataset = UGCAMTemplateData

If a CAM configuration is not defined, NX displays the Machining Environment dialog box so that you can select a CAM session configuration. You can select cam_part_planner_mrl if the Manufacturing Resource Library (MRL) is installed with your Teamcenter installation. Select cam_teamcenter_ascii_library if MRL is not installed.
When you are in an active NX Manufacturing session, NX uses the current CAM configuration to create a new setup part.
Opening an existing CAM setup part file
When you start a new NX session in managed mode, and open an existing CAM setup part, NX uses the cam configuration file defined in UGII_CAM_CONFIG.
Your site may use a standard library type of cam configuration to ensure that other cam data, such as posted code files, are imported into Teamcenter. If so, set UGII_CAM_CONFIG to point to the same cam configuration .dat file that is defined in the nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax file. This step ensures that NX uses the same cam configuration whether you create a new setup, or you retrieve and reopen an old setup.
UGII_CAM_IMAN_TYPE_TEMPLATE
The UGII_CAM_IMAN_TYPE_TEMPLATE environment variable points to an .opt file that contains a list of template parts. The default .opt file is cam_teamcenter_general.opt.
When a Manufacturing setup part cannot find the type template data from template_part_planner.dat, NX uses the list of template parts in the .opt file that UGII_CAM_IMAN_TYPE_TEMPLATE points to.
Example:
A Manufacturing setup part is imported from Native NX to NX in managed mode.
In this case, NX is unable to find the type template data.
UGII_CAM_IMAN_TYPE_TEMPLATE points to cam_teamcenter_general.opt, the default file.
NX uses the template files listed in cam_teamcenter_general.opt.
Where do I find it?
Product
NX
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Teamcenter installation

Document Title: Synchronizing NX CAM to Teamcenter custom user tooling data
Document Body:
In Teamcenter Integration for NX, you can define custom attributes to be synchronized between NX CAM and Teamcenter. Examples include pocket ID, tool description, technology data, and adjust register. Details are available in the Teamcenter documentation.
To view the Teamcenter documentation, do the following:
Go to the Teamcenter documentation landing page.
From the Restrict content to version list, select the current Teamcenter release.
In the Filter By Document Title box, enter part planner.
Select the Part Planner product documentation link.
In the search box, type one of the following topic titles:
Synchronize NX CAM to Teamcenter custom user tooling data
Preferences for synchronizing NX CAM to Teamcenter custom user tooling data
Installing NX CAM to Teamcenter custom user tooling data synchronization
In the search results, select the topic you need.
Where do I find it?
Product
NX
Application
Manufacturing
Prerequisite
Teamcenter installation

Import the current manufacturing templates into Teamcenter.
Define the manufacturing templates that are available to use in Teamcenter.
There are two different methods to access the newly imported manufacturing templates.You want to read the same set of template parts regardless of how you access the templates.
When the TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_<version> preference is set, the nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax file defines the manufacturing templates that are available to use in Teamcenter.
Use the Edit the PAX file procedure to define the Teamcenter templates.
Note:
When the pax file defines the available templates, you choose File→New in NX to create a CAM setup.
It is not necessary to store and manage the pax file in Teamcenter. You can store the pax on your operating system, and NX will use it from there if the site is not set up to use the pax files inside of Teamcenter. All the same rules for this pax file apply as for any others.
When the TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_<version> preference is not set, the template_part_planner.dat file defines the available templates.
Use the Edit the template_part_planner.dat file procedure to define the Teamcenter templates.
Note:
When template_part_planner.dat defines the available templates, you retrieve the design item from Teamcenter, so that it is in your NX session, and then you switch to the NX Manufacturing application. NX pulls a copy of the template_part_planner.dat file from Teamcenter and copies it to your temporary workspace.
The template_part_planner.dat file in your temporary workspace is what generates your list of templates, and you create your cam setup from that list of templates.
The template_part_planner.dat file is a named reference of the standard UGCAMTemplateData dataset in Teamcenter.
Edit the standard MEOPRevision_DefaultChildProperties TC preference to add the root_activity value.
Modify the UGCAMPTP definition to support all file types/extensions created by your post processors.
The standard UGCAMPTP definition delivered with NX only includes .ptp files. If your site has a post that creates some other file type, Teamcenter will not display this data in the activities.

You must be the Teamcenter administrator to do this procedure.
Confirm that you have the current version of NX installed.
Confirm that the following environment variables are defined:
UGII_TMP_DIR
UGII_BASE_DIR
Confirm that the following Teamcenter preference is set to true.
TC_Allow_Longer_ID_Name
This step is required because Teamcenter appends the units and NX version to the file names.
In a Teamcenter prompt window, run the tcin_cam_template_setup.bat script provided in the UGII_BASE_DIR\ugii\templates\sample\ folder.
%UGII_BASE_DIR%\ugii\templates\sample\tcin_cam_template_setup.bat —u=<username> —p=<password>
The script includes optional arguments to support multi-field keys.
This script imports the Manufacturing templates in MACH\resource\template_part\english and MACH\resource\template_part\metric into the Teamcenter folder [NX version] CAM Setup Templates. Each template file has the units and NX version appended to the file name.
For example, if you import the NX 7.5 Manufacturing template files into Teamcenter:
The location is NX75 CAM Setup Templates.
The metric version of the machining_knowledge.prt template file is now named machining_knowledge_metric_NX75.
NX75 CAM Setup Templates
machining_knowledge_metric_NX75
MillTurn_Express_metric_NX75
DieMold_Express_metric_NX75
turning_metric_NX75
MillTurn_Express_target_metric_NX75
mold_sequences_metric_NX75
Version specific CAM templates in Teamcenter

Document Title: Edit the template_part_planner.dat file to use the correct manufacturing templates
Document Body:
In Teamcenter, in the CAM Setup Templates folder, select the UGCAMTemplateData object and click Check Out .
In the Checking Out dialog box, click OK.
Right-click the UGCAMTemplateData object and choose Named References.
In the Named References dialog box, select template_part_planner.dat and click Download.
Note:
template_tc.dat is a legacy file.
In the Downloading File dialog box, select a location for the file and click Download.
Edit the template_part_planner.dat file with a text editor to correct the template file names.
The template names in the template_part_planner.dat file do not match the template names for the current version of NX.
Example:
Current version of NX = 1980
Existing template name = mill_planar_metric/A
Correct template name = mill_planar_metric_NX1980/A
Tip:
Use the find and replace function in your editor. For example, replace metric/A with metric_NX1980/A.
In the Named References dialog box, select template_part_planner.dat and click Delete .
In the Delete dialog box, click Yes.
In the Named References dialog box, click Upload.
In the Upload File dialog box, navigate to and select your modified template_part_planner.dat file.
Click Upload.
In the Named References dialog box, click Close.
In Teamcenter, click Check In .
In the Checking In dialog box, click OK.

Document Title: Edit the PAX file to use the correct manufacturing templates
Document Body:
In Teamcenter, create an item to contain the Manufacturing PAX file.
The ID you give this item is required in step 3. This example uses FileNewPaxCam.
Add a dataset to the item.
In the New Dataset dialog box, select Text or Text Editor from the Tools Used list.
Click Import. Navigate to the %UGII_BASE_DIR%\ugii\templates\sample\ folder, and select the nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates_sample.pax file.
Click OK.
To confirm the selection, right-click the dataset and choose Named References.
Add the preference to point to the PAX file.
Select the database and choose Edit→Options.
In the Preferences dialog box, click New.
In the Name box, enter TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_<version>, where <version> is the version of NX that you are running.
With this preference, NX uses the .pax file to define the available templates when you:
Enter the Manufacturing application.
Choose File→New.
For example, set TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_NX12 to use setup templates for NX12.
In the Current Values box, type the ID of the item that you created in step 1 to contain the Manufacturing PAX file. For example, FileNewPaxCam.
Note:
When the TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_<version> preference is set, the nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax file defines the manufacturing templates that are available to use in Teamcenter.
When the TC_NX_FileNewPAXFiles_<version> preference is not set, the template_part_planner.dat file defines the available templates. The following table shows how the key words in template_part_planner.dat map to the current pax files.
template_part_planner.dat
nxdm_ugs_manufacturing_templates.pax
LIBRF
<Libref>
TMPL_CLASS
<TemplateClass>
TYPE_TEMP
<TypeTemplates>
ATT1
<TemplateDescription>
<FileNew>
Indicates whether or not to use the template in a File→New workflow.
For more information on the pax file preference, see Define the preference for PAX files.

In the Business Modeler Integrated Development Environment (BMIDE) application, you must modify the UGCAMPTP definition to support all file types/extensions created by your post processors. This example adds the .lpt file extension.
In Windows, choose Start
Start→All Programs→Teamcenter x.x→Business Modeler IDE
In the Teamcenter x.x Launcher dialog box, click Launch to accept the default workspace.
If necessary, create a new project.
